book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Introduction 1 - Name of the Book: Its name, as it appeared on the first folio of the manuscript, is "The Book of Approximation of the Definition of Logic, the words of the unique leader Aristotle and others, which the unique and most learned Imam Abu Muhammad Ali bin Ahmed bin Saeed bin Hazm took care to explain?". Ibn Hazm referred to it multiple times in his book *Al-Fisal fi al-Milal wa al-Nihal*; he said in a chapter regarding the nature of proofs, "This is a chapter we have mastered in our book marked as *Al-Taqrib* (The Approximation) in the definitions of speech" (1). He said in another place, "This is a sophistry we have long warned against in our books which we compiled on the definitions of Logic" (2), so he applied the name "The Books" to this book because it is composed of eight books. He mentioned it a third time in *Al-Fisal*, saying: "We have explained in the book *Al-Taqrib* regarding the definitions of speech that the instrument called the Giraffe? etc." (3). He said a fourth time, "According to the premises we explained in our book marked as *Al-Taqrib* regarding the essence of proof" (4), so he referred in this naming to a specific part of the book. Mention of this book appeared in what Ibn Hazm al-Andalusi wrote according to both Al-Humaydi in *Al-Jadhwah* and Sa'id in *Tabaqat al-Umam*. Al-Humaydi said: "*The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and the Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples*; for in clarifying it, removing suspicion about it, and belying...

...the impostors using it, he followed a path that no one before him had followed, as far as we know" (1). This title is the most accurate of what is there, and it is exactly what is established fully on folio (55) of the book *Al-Taqrib*. As for Sa'id, he said: "He concerned himself with the science of Logic and composed a book on it which he named *The Approximation of the Definitions of Logic*, in which he elaborated on clarifying the paths of knowledge, used jurisprudential examples and legal maxims, and disagreed with Aristotle, the founder of this science, in some of his principles—the disagreement of one who did not understand his purpose nor had exercised himself in his book; thus, his book, because of this, contains many errors and clear omissions" (2). It seems that Ibn Hayyan, the historian of al-Andalus, saw this statement by Sa'id and repeated it without mentioning the name *Al-Taqrib*, as he said: "Abu Muhammad was a bearer of various arts of Hadith, Fiqh, dialectics, genealogy, and what relates to the fringes of literature, along with participation in many types of ancient teachings of Logic and Philosophy. He has many books in some of those arts in which he was not free from error and omission, due to his boldness in scaling the walls of the arts, especially Logic; for they claimed that he slipped there, and went astray in treading the paths, and disagreed with Aristotle, its founder—the disagreement of one who did not understand his purpose, nor had exercised himself in his books" (3). Sa'id and Ibn Hayyan agreed on the statement that Ibn Hazm erred in understanding some principles of Aristotle's words, and their opinion is one view because the latter relied on the former. This is a matter I will address in what follows. 2 - When was this book written: Ibn Hazm's references to the book *Al-Fisal* do not indicate to us that *Al-Taqrib* predates *Al-Fisal* in time, for we noted in the previous paragraph that he also referred to *Al-Taqrib* within the book *Al-Fisal* itself. This may indicate that he worked on both books without completing one before the other and that he was alternating work between them. In the book *Al-Taqrib*, he also refers to two other books: *The Book of Politics* and *The Book of Ethics of the Soul*. We do not know the date of his authorship of these two books either, but *Al-Taqrib* precedes them because when he mentions them, he says "as we will explain in?", so he attached his speech to the future, and indicated...

The Approximation of the Definition of Logic. In the name of God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. "O God, send blessings upon the Master of Messengers and upon the family of Muhammad and his companions and grant peace." The unique, most learned Imam, Abu Muhammad Ali bin Ahmed bin Saeed bin Hazm bin Ghalib bin Salih bin Khalaf bin Ma'dan bin Yazid al-Farisi said: Praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds, Originator of the heavens and the earth and what is between them, Possessor of the Glorious Throne, Doer of what He intends. And may God bless Muhammad, His servant and the seal of His prophets and His messengers to His servants from among the living souls capable of death, from mankind and jinn, with the religion by which He chose them, so that he who obeys him may dwell in Paradise, which is the abode of eternal bliss, and he who disobeys him may enter the Fire, which is the place of everlasting torment; and our success is only by God Almighty, and there is no power and no strength except by God, the Mighty, the Majestic. As for what follows: The First, the One, the Truth, the Creator of all existents other than Himself, says in His revelation which He gave to His Prophet and His sanctified friend: {God is the Creator of all things, and He is, over all things, Disposer of affairs} (39 Az-Zumar: 62). And the Almighty said: {And they give thought to the creation of the heavens and the earth} (3 Aal Imran: 191), praising them. And the Almighty said: {The Most Merciful. Taught the Qur'an. Created man. Taught him eloquence} (55 Ar-Rahman: 3). And the Almighty said: {Recite, and your Lord is the most Generous - Who taught by the pen - Taught man that which he knew not} (96 Al-Alaq: 3).

Ibn Hazm says in *Al-Taqrib*: "We did not compose this book of ours, and much of what we composed, except while we were exiled, banished from home, family, and child, fearing alongside that for our lives from injustice and aggression" (1). This statement, despite its utility, does not define anything precise; it merely informs us that *Al-Taqrib*, like his other works, was written after leaving Cordoba and starting to move around the cities of Al-Andalus. In *Al-Taqrib*, there are important indications that point to the timing, which are: 1 - Ibn Hazm narrates a story about his tutor Ahmed bin Muhammad bin Abdul Warith and asks for mercy upon him (2), but unfortunately, we cannot benefit from this fact because I did not find a date for this man's death. 2 - Ibn Hazm talks in the book about the incident of his arrest at the hands of Al-Mustakfi (3), because Ibn Hazm was loyal to Al-Mustazhir, and this happened in the year 414 or late 413 at the latest estimation. 3 - He mentions that his friend Ibn Shahid composed a book on the science of rhetoric while he himself was writing the book *Al-Taqrib* (4). Ibn Shahid died in the year 426 and stopped composing a year or more before that. This determines that the book *Al-Taqrib*, or some chapters of it, were written before that. We add to these indications the statement of Sa'id: "And his son, the jurist Abu Muhammad, was a minister for Abdul Rahman Al-Mustazhir... then he abandoned this path and turned to reading sciences and recording traditions and Sunan, so he concerned himself with the science of Logic... and after that, he delved deeply into increasing his knowledge of the sciences of Sharia" (5). Thus, he did not begin his studies, according to Sa'id, until after the year 414, and Logic was among the first sciences he turned to... "And after" that, he delved into Sharia sciences, accumulating them. All these evidences combined place the date of *Al-Taqrib* after the year 415 and before the year 425 AH. 3 - Reasons for its authorship: Ibn Hazm spent part of his youth seeking knowledge in Cordoba until the year 401. This is what distinguishes angels, humans, and jinn from all other living souls; it is the expression regarding all existing things, despite their different aspects, and the clarification of their meanings, which, due to their differences, necessitated that their names differ, and the knowledge of the categorization of named things under names. So whoever is ignorant of the magnitude of this blessing within himself and the rest of his species, and does not know its position with him, is not superior to beasts except in physical form; so praise be to God for what He taught and gave, there is no god but He. And whoever does not know the attributes of the named things, which necessitate the differentiation of their names, and defines all of that with their definitions, has been ignorant of the magnitude of this precious blessing, and has passed it by heedless of knowing it, turning away from it; and he has not failed a minor failure, but a very grave one. If an ignorant person says: Did any of the Pious Ancestors (Salaf) speak about this? It is said to him: This knowledge is settled in the soul of every person of [2v] intellect. The sharp mind reaches, with what understanding God Almighty has enabled in it, the benefits of this knowledge, while the ignorant person is withdrawn like the blind until he is alerted to it; and so are all sciences. None of the Pious Ancestors, may God be pleased with them, spoke on issues of Grammar, but when the ignorance of people spread regarding the variation of vowel markings—by the variation of which meanings in the Arabic language vary—scholars established books of Grammar. Thus, they removed great ambiguity, and that was an aid to understanding the speech of God Almighty and the speech of His Prophet, peace be upon him. Whoever was ignorant of that was deficient in understanding his Lord, the Exalted. So this action by the scholars was good and necessitated reward for them. The same is said regarding the compilation of books by scholars on Language and Jurisprudence; for the Pious Ancestors had no need for all of that due to the virtue God gave them and their witnessing of Prophethood. Those after them were in need of all that; this is seen through senses and the deficiency of one who does not study these sciences and does not read these books is known, and that he is close in relation to beasts. ...Philosophical sciences in general without verification. Those are the ones he meant by his saying: "And I have seen groups of losers whom I witnessed during the prime of our seeking [knowledge], and before our powers were firmly established in knowledge, and at our first involvement with various people of different opinions; they used to decide based on their corrupt conjectures without certainty produced by trustworthy research that Philosophy and the definitions of Logic are contrary to the Sharia" (1). Perhaps the environment of Cordoba and Andalusia in general—at that time, with its hostility towards the sciences of the Ancients—was what stimulated his curiosity, making him study Philosophy and Logic. Hence, the feeling grew strong in him that Philosophical sciences do not contradict the Sharia; rather, Logic specifically can be taken as a standard to evaluate Sharia opinions and correct them. His direction towards debating people of other sects and creeds imposed on him to arm himself with logical strength in debate and argumentation. These two goals were among the first factors that led him to write on Logic to prove the lack of contradiction between it and the Sharia, to reinforce his intellectual position against opponents, to establish correct rules for argumentation and debate, and to clarify the tricks of sophistry and rioting. Ibn Hazm remained of this opinion, believing in the benefit of Logic, Philosophy, and all sciences of the Ancients—except Astrology. In the epistle *Maratib al-Ulum* (The Hierarchy of Sciences), he advises the student, after learning reading, writing, the principles of Grammar, Language, Poetry, and Astronomy, to look into the definitions of Logic, the science of genera and species, singular names, propositions, premises, syllogisms, and conclusions, to know what proof is and what riot is, and to distinguish them from falsehoods a distinction that leaves no doubt (2). Someone asks him his opinion on the people of his time and how they divided into two groups: a group that followed the sciences of the Ancients and a group that followed the science of what Prophecy brought, asking him to explain which one is correct. He says in the answer: Know—may God grant us and you success to what pleases Him—that the sciences of the Ancients are Philosophy and the definitions of Logic which Plato, his student Aristotle, Alexander, and those who followed their footsteps spoke about. This is a fine, elevated science because in it is the knowledge of the whole world with all that is in it from its genera to its species, to the individuals of its substances and accidents, and standing upon the proof without which nothing is valid, and distinguishing it from what is thought to be proof out of ignorance but is not proof. The benefit of this science is great in distinguishing truths from others... (3)

...sophistry passes upon him as valid, and he does not differentiate between it and the truth. He does not know his religion except by imitation (Taqlid), and imitation is blameworthy; and it is likely, if he is safe from confusion—we seek refuge in God from it. For this reason, and what we will mention after this, God willing, it became necessary to hasten to compose this science, and to toil in explaining and expanding it, by the power and strength of God. We say, and we seek God's help: All things which the First—who has no first absolutely other than Him—brought into being, and which the One—who has no 'one' by way of correction, far be it from Him—divided, and which the Creator—who has no creator in reality except Him—invented; their ranks in the aspects of manifestation (Bayan) are four, having no fifth at all. If one of them decreases, the manifestation is disrupted by the amount of that decrease. The first of these is the existence of things as real in themselves (Ontology); for if they are real, their manifestation is possible. If they do not have a manifestor existing at that time, this is the first rank of manifestation; for what is not existing, there is no way to its manifestation. The Second Aspect: Their manifestation to the one who perceived them, and the transfer of their forms and attributes to his soul (mind), and its settlement therein via the material of the intellect by which the rational person is favored among souls, and his distinguishing of them as they are; for he to whom a thing is not clear, his knowledge of it and reporting about it is not valid. This is the second rank of the ranks of manifestation. The Third Aspect: Producing composed words from distinct letters, for which the Wise [3r] and Capable enabled exits from the chest, throat, tubes of the lung, palate, tongue, lips, and teeth; and He prepared for them the air propelled by the knocking of the tongue to the auditory meatus of the ears. Thereby, the soul of the speaker conveys the likeness of what it has perceived and what has settled in it to the soul of the listener, transferring it to it with an understood sound through the nature's acceptance of a language they agreed upon. Thus, what the speaker's soul has perceived becomes clear, and it settles in the listener's soul just as it has settled in the speaker's soul, and the likeness of what is with him goes out to it, as a kindness from the Subtle, the Aware. This is to produce, by what He granted us of this noble property, elevated power, and virtuous nature...

This belief in the benefit of the sciences of Philosophy and Logic is what made Ibn Hazm, after studying them, attempt to convey what he understood of them simply to others. This direction earned him the enmity of the group that hated Philosophy and Logic, which was the dominant group in Andalusia at that time. His enemies took this aspect of him as a target for their attacks. An example of this is that one of the resentful people wrote him an unsigned letter accusing him that corruption entered him from his reliance on the books of the Ancients, the Materialists (Dahriyya), the Logicians, the book of Euclid, the Almagest, and other atheists. So Ibn Hazm wrote in response: Tell us about these books of Logic, Euclid, and Almagest: Did you read them, O you who denied that for yourself? And tell us about the atheism you found in them if you have stood upon its places in them; and if you have not read them, how do you deny what you do not know? (1). Ibn Hazm came to believe that the benefit of Logic is a matter no fair person doubts because it is a benefit not stopping at the borders of knowledge and mental exercise, but intervenes in all sciences: Religion, Articles of Faith, Desires, Grammar, Language, History (News), Medicine, Geometry, and whatever is of this form; it is worthy that it be sought and books be written on it, and difficult truths be approximated in it. This belief in the value and benefit of Logic became—initially—a strong incentive to write on it. However, Ibn Hazm faced two difficulties in his study of this science, so why not attempt to overcome them for the reader who wishes to benefit from the study of Logic? The First: The complexity of translation and the presentation of this science in words that are not common (vernacular). By 'common', Ibn Hazm means widespread, familiar words that people understand due to frequent circulation. So let him write, then, a book close to understandings, "for the fortune belongs to him who prefers knowledge and knows its merit, that he simplifies it with his effort, brings it closer as much as he can, and lightens it as possible" (2). He thinks well of the translators and sees that their making words difficult was a miserliness with knowledge and hoarding of it when people were serious about seeking it, spending the precious and valuable for it. The Second Difficulty: Logicians have been accustomed to using symbols and letters in giving examples. Something like this is difficult for the general public to handle. So let Ibn Hazm convert the examples from symbols to others extracted from the familiar in daily and Sharia conditions. He senses the danger of what he is undertaking. And he believes that he is the first to attempt this endeavor.

So to Him belongs praise and thanks from us, and hearing and obedience are upon us. And from His completing that for us by His grace and bounty, God Almighty said: {And We sent not a messenger except in the language of his people to make clear to them} (14 Ibrahim: 4). This is the third rank of the ranks of manifestation. The Fourth Aspect: Signs that occur by agreement, the mainstay of which is outlining what has settled in the soul of the mentioned manifestation, with contrasting lines having a color different from the color of what is written upon, agreed upon by the sound mentioned previously. It is called a Book (Writing), represented by the hand which is an instrument for that. Thus, the soul of the writer conveys what it has perceived to the soul that wants to share with it in perceiving what it has perceived; so the eye, which is an instrument for that, delivers it to it. This applies in distant regions and across divergent distances where the air called sound disperses before reaching them, and it cannot be delivered to those therein to inform them of that without informing those neighboring in the place whom one does not wish to inform. Were it not for this mode, the wisdom of the dead would not have reached us over the eons of time, nor would we have known the knowledge of those gone in past ages, nor would the news of past nations and empty centuries have ended up to us. Included in this section are things that clarify but are not widespread [words]; among them are signs by the hand only, and among them are signs by the eye or some limbs. It may be possible to convey manifestation by tastes; from that is what the blind person perceives of manifestation regarding the present object alone according to what is agreed upon with the one signaling that to him. This is the fourth rank of the ranks of manifestation [3v], since there is no way to the Book (Writing) except after agreeing on distinguishing those lines by the sounds assigned to them—a rarity which minds were incapable of fully knowing. The One, First, True Creator stood alone in managing that and inventing it without a cause necessitating that upon Him, except that He does what He wills; there is no adjuster of His judgment, and He is not questioned about what He does, but they are questioned. The utmost virtue became what we mentioned, and its usage in its aspects, and the acknowledgment to the First, One, True Creator of power, ability, and knowledge...

Ibn Hazm did not write this book until he was motivated by many reasons in daily life, and only after he found the need for Logic pressing in practical aspects of people's relationships and thinking. He met someone who described him by asking about the difference between the Subject (Mahmul) and the Possibility (Mutmakkin), and he met many rioters adopting sophistry in argumentation. He faced someone asking him to show him the Accident sifted from the Substance. He read complex writings with no point beneath their complexity. He saw someone claiming wisdom while being innocent of it. So he wanted his book to be a rectification of the crookedness of these matters and a reform of their corruption, a refutation of opponents and rioters, and an establishment of the correct rules for debate, which was at that time a preoccupation of the scholars of Andalusia. - 4 Sources of the Book: Since the era of translation began in the history of Arab thought, translators and the commentators after them began to care for the logical books of Aristotle. It is attributed to Ibn al-Muqaffa that he transferred three of the Aristotelian logic books: Categories (Qatighuriyas), De Interpretatione (Peri Hermeneias), and Analytics (Analutiqa), and that he translated the Introduction known as Isagoge? And he expressed what he translated of that in an easy phrase close to grasp (1). Timothy the Catholicos, who contacted Al-Rashid and Al-Ma'mun, mentions that the Caliph "ordered us to translate the book Topics (Topica) by Aristotle the Philosopher from Syriac to Arabic. Sheikh Abu Nuh performed this with the help of God" (2). Timothy believes that the translations done before that were meager, not only in terms of words but in terms of meanings. The author of *Al-Fihrist* left us a picture of the efforts of translators and abbreviators of the eight logical books (3). It is a statement indicating what was exerted by Al-Kindi, Ahmed bin al-Tayyib, Thabit bin Qurra, Matta bin Yunus al-Qana'i, Al-Farabi, Yahya bin Adi, and others in this field: 1 - As for Al-Kindi, he has a treatise on the Introduction, summarized and brief, a treatise on the Ten Categories, a treatise on guarding against the tricks of the Sophists, and a treatise on the brevity and abridgment of Logical Demonstration.

After: The sages who passed before our time collected books in which they arranged the distinctions of the occurrence of named things under names upon which all nations agreed in their meanings, even if they differed in their names by which expression occurs about them; for nature is one, and choice is different and diverse. They arranged how the manifestation of known things stands from the compositions of these names, what is valid of that and what is not valid. They tracked these matters, defined definitions for that, and removed ambiguity. So God Almighty brought great benefit through them, brought the distant close, eased the difficult, and humbled the proud [in] seeking truths. Among them are the eight books of Aristotle collected in the definitions of Logic. And we say the saying of one who desires his One, First Creator to guide and protect him, and attributes to himself no power or strength except by Him, nor knowledge except what He taught him: From the righteousness by which we hope to be envied with our Lord Almighty is the explanation of those books due to their great benefit. For we saw people regarding them in four categories: Three of them are an ugly error and a heinous license, and the fourth is an abandoned truth, an obscured correctness, and an oppressed science; and aiding the oppressed is a duty and a reward. One of the four categories is a group who judged those books as containing disbelief (Kufr) and supporting atheism, without standing upon their meanings or reviewing them by reading. This, while they recite the saying of God Almighty—and they are the ones intended by it when He says: {And do not pursue that of which you have no knowledge. Indeed, the hearing, the sight and the heart - about all those [one] will be questioned.} (17 Al-Isra: 36). And His saying Almighty: {Here you are - those who have argued about that of which you have [some] knowledge, but why do you argue about that of which you have no knowledge?} (3 Aal Imran: 66). And His saying Almighty: {Say, "Produce your proof, if you should be truthful."} (27 An-Naml: 64). So we saw great, abundant reward regarding this sect in removing this falsehood from their unjust souls which judge before verification, accepting without knowledge, deciding without proof, [4r] and lifting the major sin from them by their casting this corrupt suspicion upon innocent people with a safe courtyard, pure skin, and smooth surface regarding what...

2 - As for his student Ahmed bin al-Tayyib, he summarized Categories, De Interpretatione, Analytics I and II, and Isagoge. He has a book on the Dialectic Art on the doctrine of Aristotle from the book Sophist specifically by Aristotle. 3 - Thabit has De Interpretatione, Compendiums of Analytics I, an Abridgment of Logic, anecdotes preserved from Topics, and a book on the fallacies of the Sophists. 4 - The leadership of the logicians ended up with Matta in his era, and most of his efforts were directed towards transmission (translation); he also interpreted the four books on Logic in their entirety, and people rely on them in reading. He has a commentary on Isagoge. 5 - The most far-reaching of them in impact on logical studies is Al-Farabi. He was not a translator but placed the logical books in an authoritative form and interpreted them in clear phrases that won the admiration of those who came after him, and his books became the preferred reference in this section. 6 - Another logician studied under him and under Matta, who attained leadership after them in Logic, namely Yahya bin Adi. From Yahya, Abu Sulayman al-Mantiqi derived—the teacher of al-Tawhidi and the sheikh of that band of students—who wrote an essay on the purposes of Aristotle's books, an essay on the meanings of Isagoge, and a book on the ambiguity in the four books of Logic. That is the situation in the East. As for Al-Andalus, the demand for Philosophy and Logic before the era of Al-Hakam Al-Mustansir was weak. The most famous person who cared for philosophical studies in general before the Berber Fitna (399) was Abu al-Qasim Maslama bin Ahmed al-Majriti. Some famous wise men of Al-Andalus studied under him, but he and most of his students leaned towards a mathematical direction with some interest in logical matters. This interest was shared by the first class of students of Logic in Al-Andalus, namely: Ibn Abdun al-Jabali, Omar bin Yunus bin Ahmed al-Harrani, Ahmed bin Hafsun, Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Ibrahim the Judge, Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Masoud al-Bajjani, Muhammad bin Maimun known as Marcus, and Saeed bin Fathun al-Saraqusti. Ibn al-Kattani, Ibn Hazm's sheikh, studied under these (1). We add to these Andalusians interested in Logic: Malhan bin Ubayd Allah bin Salim...

...they accused them of. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him—the intermediary between us and the First One—said: "Whoever says to his brother 'O Disbeliever', it has become true of one of them." So we hope from our Creator that we be among those for whom a plentiful share is struck in lifting this distress, strictly on the day of our poverty for good deeds and our need for saving ourselves from what sinners fall into. He eases us towards a good sunnah (tradition) so we share the reward of whoever acts upon it after it, because we were the cause of his knowing it, without his reward being diminished at all. Thus the First Creator promised us on the tongue of His Messenger, peace be upon him. So these are one category. The Second Category: People who consider these books delirium of Logic and nonsense of speech. In general, most people are quick to be hostile to what they are ignorant of and to criticize what they do not know. It is as the Truthful One [the Prophet], peace be upon him, said: "People are like a hundred camels; you can hardly find a riding mount among them." We also saw that among the aspects of righteousness is to make those who are ignorant understand this amount which we stipulated its virtue first; and by my life, that is not little, for by knowledge of this meaning we distance ourselves from beasts and understand the intent of the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, in His address to us. The Third Category: People who read these mentioned books with defective minds, afflicted desires, and unsound insights. Their hearts were imbued with the love of being taken lightly; they found the vehicle of incapacity soft, found the transmission of Sharia unwholesome, and accepted the saying of the ignorant. So they branded themselves with understanding them [the books], while they are the furthest of people from them and the most remote from knowing them. What we mentioned added to the confusion about these books and alienated people from them. So hope grew strong that in our explanation of what we explain of them, there will be a cause for the guidance of him for whom guidance was preordained in the knowledge of God Almighty; thus he wins the highest fortune and acquires the most sublime portion, if God Almighty wills. We did not find anyone before us who undertook this, so we hoped for the reward of God Almighty in that. The Fourth Category: People who looked with clear minds and thoughts pure from bias and sound intellects, so they were enlightened by them and stood upon their purposes. They were guided by their beacon, and Monotheism was established with them by necessary proofs from which there is no deviation. They witnessed the division of creatures and the effect of the Creator in them and His management of them. They found these virtuous books like the righteous companion and the sincere friend...

...who had insight into the definition of Logic and reading of philosophy books; and Al-Rabahi, who looked into Logics and mastered them (1); and two Jews, Munajjim bin al-Fawwal, a resident of Zaragoza who wrote a book on Logic in the manner of question and answer, and Marwan bin Janah, for whom no specific composition in Logic is mentioned (2). Based on this, Ibn Hazm would be from the men of the third class who devoted themselves to logical studies in Al-Andalus; indeed, he might be the most prominent of them in his era. I do not rule out that his sheikh Ibn al-Kattani had a far-reaching effect on his direction towards these studies, for he speaks of him in his books with admiration and appreciation (3). But to what extent were the Eastern translations, commentaries, and summaries known in Al-Andalus? Neither Judge Sa'id tells us anything of that, nor does Ibn Hazm in the book *Al-Taqrib* indicate anything clear and precise. All we can say in this regard does not exceed hypothesis and estimation. We can assume that Easterners traveling to Al-Andalus like Al-Harrani, and Andalusians traveling to the East like Ibn Abdun al-Jabali, transferred with them, among the books they transferred, some of the translations in Logic. It is not unlikely that Ibn Hazm benefited from some of them and relied on them as he relied on some works of the Andalusians themselves. Indeed, he says in some of his comments in *Al-Taqrib*: "The Sheikh said: These are the phrases of the translators, and they contain confusion because they decided that the Sketch (Rasm) is not taken from genera and differentia, but rather it is taken from accidents and properties" (4). His phrase stopped me because it speaks only of "the translators"? in the plural form—but because he prefaced it with his saying: 'The Sheikh said', and such a preface is not of what occurs in Ibn Hazm's books. Then research guided me to a phrase in *Kitab al-Radd ala al-Mantiqiyyin* (Refutation of the Logicians) by Ibn Taymiyya wherein it came: "And for his veneration? meaning Ibn Hazm—of Logic, he narrated it with his chain of transmission to Matta the Translator who translated it into Arabic" (5). This phrase solved some problems and created others; it informed us of the source utilized...

...and the loyal friend [4v] who is not surrendered during hardship nor missed by his companion in distress except that he finds him with him. They did not walk a path of the paths of sciences except they found the benefit of the books in front of them and with them, nor did they climb a mountain pass of the passes of knowledge except they sensed their benefit inseparable from them. Rather, they familiarized every locked matter for them, and hinted at every obscure matter in all sciences. They were to them like the moneychanger (standard), and the things in which are properties to clarify their specifics. When we looked into that, we found some of the impediments calling for the calamities we mentioned to be the complexity of the translation in them and their presentation in words that are neither common nor of widespread usage. Not every understanding is suitable for every expression. So we drew near to God Almighty by presenting the meanings of these in easy, simple words, in the understanding of which the commoner and the elite, the scholar and the ignorant, are equal, God willing, according to their perception and what our Creator, Blessed and Exalted, granted us of power and capability. The reason that led the predecessors among the translators to obscure the words, make them rugged, and roughen the path towards them, was stinginess on their part with knowledge and hoarding it. It occurs to us that seekers of knowledge in those days, and those desiring it, were many and possessed of strong zeal. But as for now, people have renounced it, to the point of harming its people, terrorizing them, pursuing them, and attacking them. One is not content to leave it and his ignorance of it, but has become a caller against it and a forbidder of knowledge by his action and speech. They became as Habib bin Aws al-Ta'i [Abu Tammam] said describing them: "They went forth as if ignorance gathers them... A father, and those of literature among them are extras (anomalies)." For the fortune belongs to him who prefers knowledge and knows its merit, that he simplifies it with his effort, brings it closer as much as he can, and lightens it as possible. Indeed, if it were possible to shout it on the crossroads of passersby, invite to it in the streets of the wayfarers, call out about it in the gatherings of travelers; indeed, if it were easy for him to give money to its students, pay wages to those who acquire it, increase the payments for it to those searching for it, and elevate the ranks of its people, being patient in that over hardship and harm, that would be a fortune...

...Ibn Hazm in this book of his, which made me believe that the word "Sheikh" might refer to Matta al-Mantiqi himself. However, Ibn Hazm mentioned nothing about this Matta in this copy. Is the copy in our hands lacking that chain of transmission? We have the right in this situation to ask: Did Ibn Taymiyyah view the book *Al-Taqrib*? And if he did, why did he not discuss Ibn Hazm as he discussed other supporters of Logic? The strongest conjecture is that he viewed it but did not have it on hand when he composed his book, or that he did not see a threat to Eastern thought in a Maghrebi book, so he sufficed with attacking the books of the Easterners and refuting them. Furthermore: Were there special Andalusian translations other than those we assumed arrived from the East? There is no decisive answer to this question. All we can estimate here is that Ibn Hazm perhaps knew some Latin translations, for he knew this language, and he mentioned it in places in the book *Al-Taqrib*. He said: "Whoever masters the Latin language knows the difference between the two meanings we intended in the interrogation" (1). He said another time: "This is clearly evident to us in the Latin language" (2). And he said in a third place: "For this meaning in Latin, there is a word of clear expression" (3). It is not strange for Ibn Hazm to know Latin, as it was common in Andalusia at that time. As for Greek, there was no one who mastered it, and thus we find in *Al-Taqrib* suggestions that he did not know it (4). However, what draws attention is his discussion of some opinions as being things Aristotle did not say. Did he derive this from Matta al-Mantiqi, or did he know precise sources while quoting from those he calls "The Ancients"? There is another Eastern source which I suspect Ibn Hazm reviewed, which is a book—or books—authored by Al-Nashi' al-Akbar Abu al-Abbas, known as Ibn Shuraysh (d. 293). This Abu al-Abbas, the poet, was a Mu'tazilite who wrote in refutation of the Logicians and is among the first thinkers who tried to challenge the logic of Aristotle. Abu Sa'id al-Sirafi cited him in his debate with Matta al-Mantiqi—the debate preserved by Abu Hayyan in the book *Al-Imta' wa al-Mu'anasah*. It appears from what Ibn Hazm cited that some of Al-Nashi's opinions were a type of sophistry, and for that reason, he attacked him and described him as having much prattle.

...abundant [reward], good work, a thankful and noble endeavor, and a revival of knowledge; otherwise, it would have been effaced, worn out, and hidden, except for a fulfilled oath, and nothing would remain of it but faint traces and effaced landmarks. And God is the One sought for help. We viewed these books like strong medicine; if a person of health and strong constitution, sound nature, firm composition, and good temperament takes it, he benefits from it, it clears his structure, removes his [bad] humors [5r], strengthens his senses, and balances his qualities. But if a sick person of disturbed temperament and frail composition takes it, it overcomes him, increases his affliction, and perhaps destroys and kills him. Likewise are these books: if a person of sharp intellect and strong understanding takes them, he will not lack—wherever he turns and however he proceeds in them—great benefit, illuminating guidance, clear expression, success in every science he undertakes, and good in his religion and worldly life. But if a person of silly intellect takes them, they invalidate him, and if a person of dull understanding takes them, they stupefy and confuse him. So let every man partake according to his capacity. And our success is only by God Almighty. Let no reader of this book of ours be terrified by this action, recoiling in retreat, fleeing in panic, turning back his reins from this mountain pass. For we speak a word supported by proof, and we judge a case backed by eyewitness: Indeed, there are people whose minds were too weak to understand the Quran, so they approached it with unjust desires, occupied thoughts, and tainted understandings. They did not delay in deviating from the path and swerving from the truth. Among them are those who deem the blood of the Ummah permissible, those who yearn for some paths of disbelief, and those who say about God Almighty what He did not say. God Almighty repeated His revelation and speech, saying: {He misleads many thereby and guides many thereby. And He misleads not thereby except the defiantly disobedient} (2 Al-Baqarah: 26). And so it is with everyone who approaches a thing improperly, or is incapable of it. And we seek help from God Almighty. Let him who reads this book of ours know that the benefit of these books is not in one science only, but in every science. Their benefit in the Book of God Almighty, the Hadith of His Prophet, peace be upon him, and in giving Fatwa (legal rulings) regarding the Halal (lawful) and Haram (unlawful), the obligatory and the permissible, is of the greatest benefit. The summary of that is in understanding the things which God Almighty and His Messenger, peace be upon him, stipulated, the meanings contained therein upon which rulings apply, the named things that fall outside of them, and their categorization under the rulings according to that...

Perhaps Al-Nashi' was among those who drew Ibn Hazm's attention to researching the issue of the Names of God Almighty, because Al-Nashi' used to say: The names are "literal regarding the Creator, metaphorical regarding the created" (1). 5 - Ibn Hazm's Methodology in Al-Taqrib: The Muslim logicians inherited from the Scholastics and Alexandrian commentators and others the arrangement of the Aristotelian logical books into eight. This is what Al-Farabi clarified sufficiently in a detailed text quoted by Ibn Abi Usaibia (2). He named the first book "Categories" (Qatighuriyas), the second "Interpretation" (Peri Hermeneias), the third "Syllogism" or First Analytics, the fourth "Demonstration" or Second Analytics, the fifth "Dialectical Topics" or Topica, the sixth "Sophistical Wisdom" or Sophistica, the seventh "Rhetoric", and the eighth "Poetry" or Poetics. Al-Farabi said: And the fourth part is the most advanced of them in honor and leadership; logic is sought primarily for the fourth part, and the rest of its parts are only borne for the sake of the fourth. Ibn Hazm followed this division, in an approximate manner. He presented before the eight books a discussion on the Introduction or Isagoge. Then he addressed the books of Aristotle; he named the first "Singular Names," and the second "The Book of Reports"—which is what Al-Farabi called "Interpretation." He incorporated the following four books (3, 4, 5, 6) into one chapter and collected them under the name "Demonstration" (Burhan), rejecting the name "Syllogism" (Qiyas). Despite his belief that "Demonstration" is the ultimate goal, he did not distinguish "Second Analytics" distinctly. He scattered the discussion on Sophistry across several places. Shortly before the end of this chapter, he discussed the rank of argumentation and the etiquette of debate (Paragraph: 18). Then he followed this paragraph with another (Number: 19) in which he discussed taking premises from sciences, dividing them into twelve sciences, stating that he does not adhere in this division to what the predecessors followed. After that, he wrote two small chapters in which he applied judgments of his own on Rhetoric and Poetry and did not stop at any of Aristotle's opinions. He divided the whole book into two volumes (Safers). He stopped at the end of the first volume at the end of Categorical Propositions. He began the second volume by mentioning Conditional Propositions without this division having any relation to the nature...

...and words whose phrasing differs but whose meanings agree. Let the knowledgeable know that whoever does not understand this amount has become distant from understanding his Lord, the Exalted, and the Prophet, peace be upon him. It is not permissible for him to issue a Fatwa between two people due to his ignorance of the definitions of speech, the construction of some of it upon others, the presentation of premises, and their production of conclusions by which proof stands and which are always true, or distinguishing them from premises that are true once and false another time and cannot be relied upon. As for the science of looking into opinions, religions, desires, and articles of faith, its practitioner cannot do without understanding the meanings of these books, due to what we will explain of its chapters, God Almighty willing. The summary of that is knowing what stands by itself and what does not stand by itself, the subject and the predicate, the modes of predication in rioting (sophistry) and adherence, and other than that. As for the science of Grammar, Language, History (News), distinguishing its truth from its falsehood, Poetry, Rhetoric, and Prosody [5v], it [logic] has in all of that intense usage, subtle entry, frequent recurrence, and apparent benefit. As for Medicine, Geometry, and Astronomy, their people also cannot do without it for verifying divisions and escaping the three shared things and other matters, for which this book of ours is not the place to mention. These are sentences that will be evident to anyone who reads these books, becomes skilled in them, exercises with them, and then looks into any of the sciences we mentioned; he will find what we said to be true, and their landmarks will appear to him in their mountain passes and obscurities, revealing to him all that was hidden. And success is by God Almighty. This book of ours falls under the types in which people of knowledge and correct discrimination do not compose except therein, under the fourth type, which is the explanation of the obscure; this is the fourth rank of the ranks of honor in compositions. We will not fail, God willing, to include in it the clarification of correcting a corrupt opinion in which many people are about to err, alerting to an obscure matter, summarizing what the seeker of truths has no necessity for, and collecting scattered things while being comprehensive of everything for which the seeker of proof has the slightest need, abandoning deletion from that entirely. The types we mentioned are seven, with no eighth: They are either something we were not preceded in extracting, so we extract it; or something incomplete, so we complete it; or something mistaken, so we correct it; or something obscure, so we explain it; or something long, so we summarize it, without deleting from it anything whose deletion would harm its purpose...

He mentioned in one place in his book (1) that he built it upon brevity, but in reality, he gave free rein to himself whenever he found the subject before him allowing for expansion, especially in behavioral aspects, etiquette of interaction, doctrinal matters, and the like. If we examine *Al-Taqrib* closely, we do not find an explanation of Aristotle's opinions as written on the first page, but rather it is mostly a simplification of the closest opinions. Furthermore, a fleeting comparison between what Ibn Hazm wrote about Demonstration (Burhan) and what Ibn Sina wrote in his book *Al-Burhan* indicates something regarding the distance or closeness of the emulation to the Aristotelian original. From other comparisons, we see Ibn Hazm standing alone with logical ambition in many places. The text that Al-Farabi mentioned regarding the names of the eight books themselves is itself proof of that. 6 - Value of the Book: Ibn Hazm did not claim for himself any innovation in Logic; rather, he stated that this book of his falls under the fourth type of compositions, which is the type that deals with explaining the obscure: "We will not fail, God willing, to include in it the clarification of correcting a corrupt opinion in which many people are about to err, alerting to an obscure matter, scorning what the seeker of truths has no necessity for, and collecting scattered things while being comprehensive of everything for which the seeker of proof has the slightest need" (2). Ibn Hazm was accused—as previously mentioned—of disagreeing with Aristotle in some of his principles, the disagreement of one who did not understand his purpose nor had exercised himself in his book. Proving this disagreement is something this introduction does not have room for, nor do circumstances allow, but it is a disagreement that is not unlikely for several reasons, including: 1 - Ibn Hazm moved beyond representing with letters and symbols to extracting examples from the familiarities of life and Sharia; hence, error easily enters, and disagreement arises. 2 - He proceeded in his concepts from religious premises that Aristotle did not have, and his passion for bringing Logic and Sharia closer might lead him into illusion or impossibility. 3 - He applied his Zahiri (literalist) view in many matters, so he denied Qiyas (analogy) and denied causality in Sharia matters, and elaborated on explaining rational knowledge, while weakening the value of induction, even though...

...or something scattered, so we collect it; or something disordered, so we arrange it. Then authors vary in merit regarding what they suffered in their compositions of what we mentioned, according to the extent of their comprehension of what they intended, or some fall short of others. For each is a share of excellence, virtue, thanks, and reward, even if he only spoke on a single issue, provided he does not go outside the types we mentioned in whatever science he authored. As for one who takes the composition of another and repeats it as it is, moving things forward and backward without improving its order, or changes its words without bringing simpler and clearer ones, or deletes what is needed, or brings what is [not] needed, or refutes a truth with an error, and brings what has no benefit—these are but the actions of the people of ignorance, heedlessness, impudence, and silliness; we seek refuge in God from that. [Introduction to Logic or Isagoge] This is when we begin, God Almighty willing, by His power and strength, in what we intended, so we proceed to explain the Introduction to the mentioned books, which is called in the Greek language *Isagoge*. The meaning of *Isagoge* in the Greek language is "The Introduction," and it is specifically authored by Porphyry of Tyre. The books following it are authored by Aristotle, the teacher of Alexander and the administrator of his kingdom. Success is by God Almighty, and to Him we hold fast and are supported; there is no god but He. 1 - Discourse on the Division of Heard Sounds [6r] All sounds apparent from those making sound are divided into two parts: Either they indicate a meaning, or they do not indicate a meaning. That which does not indicate a meaning, there is no reason to busy oneself with it because no benefit we can understand is obtained from it; and seeking what has this description is not of the actions of people of intellect. This is like every sound you heard and did not know what it was. Included in this also is the apparent speech of those with pleurisy (delirium) and madmen and whoever follows their course. If a sayer says: "But this speech you mentioned indicates that its speaker does not reason or that he is sick"; it is said to him, and success is by God Almighty: It indicates that to you [by] its implication. However, when it departed from the speech of people of discrimination, it was like a sign of an affliction in its owner. Also, such speech may appear from a narrator or a jester, so it does not indicate that its owner does not reason. Thus, what he objected with is not...

Aristotle says: "We must know the primaries by induction, for sense perception produces the universal therein by induction." 4 - He declared in places in his book that he is not bound in this or that opinion by the saying of the Ancients. 5 - He utilized judgments derived from the nature of the Arabic language itself, regarding what exists—or is not realized—in another language like Greek. Ibn Hazm was not alone in his attempt to approximate Logic by multiplying Sharia examples, but he was perhaps the first to open this door, just as Ibn Sina tried to derive examples from medicine, and later Al-Ghazali came and returned to deriving examples from Fiqh. Thus, the book *Al-Taqrib* proves that Al-Ghazali was preceded in this attempt. From the beginning, religious thinkers stood in two groups regarding the logic of the First Teacher. A group tried to be independent of it and created what can be called "The Logic of the Theologians" (Mantiq al-Mutakallimin), and another group supported Aristotelian Logic. With this book, Ibn Hazm stands in the second group with Fakhr al-Din al-Razi and Al-Ghazali, while on the opposite side of them stand Al-Nashi', Al-Nawbakhti, Al-Baqillani, and Ibn Taymiyyah. It is interesting for one to compare two who are extremely close in doctrinal school, like Ibn Hazm and Ibn Taymiyyah, while they stand on far opposite sides in their view of Logic. Whatever the case, the book *Al-Taqrib* is an important link in the history of Islamic philosophical thought in general and in the history of Andalusian thought in particular. In it, if we bypass the logical aspects, are important truths touching the nature of intellectual life in Andalusia, and some of it relates to the personality of Ibn Hazm himself and his view on life and people. There is no doubt that it opens new horizons for researchers in the study of logical terminology, in what Ibn Hazm disagreed with Aristotle on, and establishes comparisons between him and Al-Ghazali, Ibn Taymiyyah, and others within the scope of the attempt he undertook. It also points to the origin which Ibn Mada' was inspired by in *The Refutation of the Grammarians* and the denial of grammatical causes. - 7 Investigation of Al-Taqrib: I relied in it on a unique copy for which I know no second, which is a copy preserved in the Ahmadiyya Library at the Zaytuna Mosque in Tunis, number: 6814. It is among the manuscripts brought by the Institute of Manuscripts at the Arab League, film number: 8. My thanks go to those in charge of it for allowing me to photograph it.

...a valid objection. This science is only intended for what is truth, and distinguishing it from what might be truth and might not be. Then we return and say that the sound which indicates a meaning is divided into two parts: Either it indicates by nature, or it indicates by intent. That which indicates by nature is like the sound of the rooster which indicates, mostly, the dawn (magic hour); and like the sounds of birds indicating similar things; and like the sounds of storks, ducks, geese, and dogs at night indicating, mostly, that they saw a person; and like the sounds of cats in calling their young, their questioning, when seeking mating, and during fighting; and every sound that indicates by its nature its source, like crashing and the tapping of copper and similar sounds of animals other than humans. These only indicate all that we mentioned by the familiar habit of what accompanies those sounds, not that we understand from them what we communicate among ourselves in the languages agreed upon among nations, by which we conduct all our intentions. These sounds we mentioned, we did not intend them in this book of ours, as no instruction in knowledge, learning of a craft, or benefit of a news report is derived from them. As for the sound which indicates by intent, it is the speech with which people converse among themselves and correspond with scripts expressing it in their books to convey what has settled in their souls from one to another. These are what the Philosopher expressed by naming them "The Logical Indicative Sounds." If a rioter riots using what appears from some non-rational animals of understood speech, like what the starling, parrot, and magpie learn of mimicking speech in which an existing meaning is known, that is not correct [as logic], nor is the understanding of a meaning intended by it. It is not counted among what is known, nor does he [the animal] place it in its place, but repeats it just as he repeats the rest of his chirping as he was accustomed. It is in the nature of many animals to make sounds with certain letters in a certain order, and all of that is contrary to the speech of humans [6v] by which they express types of sciences, crafts, news, and all intentions. The manuscript consists of ninety-two folios, with 26 lines on each page and an average of 11 words per line. It is written in a precise Naskh script—or of medium precision—and many words lack diacritical points. Among its most prominent features is that the scribe places the letter "Ta" (ط) over a word to indicate its deletion or omission. He establishes the "Ya" (ي) in the nominative state [for indefinite defective nouns] in words such as: *Mutanāhī* (finite), *Tālī* (consequent), *Wāhī* (flimsy), and so on. I have deleted this "Ya" wherever it occurred and indicated some of that—not all—in the footnotes by way of example. Furthermore, the scribe does not adhere to the rule of reversing the gender of the single number with the counted noun; for example, he writes: "Six [feminine] legs [feminine]," and I have taken the liberty of changing this as well. There are no marginal notes on the copy except for some corrections and two or three comments. The copy is not dated, but its script may indicate that it was perhaps written in the seventh century [AH] or slightly before. I have exerted my effort in correcting it, but I was not able to solve every problem I encountered (1), despite prolonged consideration and repeated attempts. I hope that God will make this book beneficial through His grace and generosity. Beirut, July 10, 1959. Ihsan Abbas.

It either indicates a single person (individual) or it indicates more than one person. As for that which indicates a single person, it is like our saying: Zayd, Amr, the Commander of the Faithful, the Minister, this horse, Khalid's donkey, and the like. These only give us, when we hear the speaker pronounce them, the specific person the speaker intended alone; we do not benefit more than that from it. This is not what we intended to discuss, because the definition of these names is not governed by their name due to a difference we will mention after this, God willing. Know that every collective entity in the world has many parts like it in the world, except that some are distinct from others. We call it an "individual" (Shakhs) by agreement among us, such as the single man, the single dog, the single mountain, the whiteness of a single garment, the single movement, and everything else that stands alone from another. So if you hear us mention "the individual" and "the individuals," this is what we want. As for the second section: It is that which indicates more than one, such as our saying: People, horses, donkeys, garments, colors, and the like. For every word among what we mentioned, when we say it, indicates very many individuals. Standing in the place of these words in the Arabic language are also nouns that apply to the group, as we mentioned, but also apply to the single one, except that the condition of the speaker clarifies his intent. Like your saying: "The Human" (Al-Insan); this word indicates the whole species, as in the saying of God Almighty: {Indeed, mankind is in loss} (103 Al-Asr: 2). He meant the collective children of Adam, peace be upon him. This word also applies to a single one, so you say: "Are you coming to the human (al-insan) you know?" while you mean his servant, his wife, or a specific one among people. Likewise in all species, you say "The Horse" and mean every horse. Do you not see that you say: "The horse is neighing" [meaning the species], or you say "The horse" referring to a specific, familiar horse? So if you wanted to remove ambiguity, you would use the plural form assigned to it, saying: "The horses" or "The people" and the like. This section is what we intended to discuss. Because it applies to a group, we needed to clarify it, and we spoke about it—not the other sections we mentioned before—due to the extreme need to define every single individual under this word with attributes found in all of them...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...and not found in other individuals to which this word does not apply, distinguishing it from what is other than it. For you are able to bring attributes found in everything named "camel," from which it is never devoid, and which are not found at all [7r] in anyone named Zayd. This is the difference we promised to mention just now. Necessity also called for seeking these differences due to the variation of names in Arabic and foreign languages; so we needed to estimate the attributes by which the named things are distinguished, since meanings in all languages are one and do not differ, whereas only the names differ. Also, language might be too narrow to assign a unique name to every type, or perhaps that was not prepared for people by agreement, or God Almighty knows best about it. Most of this is in "Qualities" (Kayfiyyat); for you find the yellowness of the narcissus is yellow, the yellowness of the sun is yellow, the yellowness of the gillyflower is yellow, and the yellowness of gold is yellow. All of these are visibly distinct to the eye, yet not every one of them has a specific name clarifying our intent regarding it. Likewise, many types of animals, such as those generated in stagnant waters and rotting dampness, up to types of insects for which we know no specific names, yet the difference between their attributes is visible and known. Therefore, one must seek differentiating attributes by which the clarification of what we want occurs, God Almighty willing, there is no god but He. 2 - Discourse on Nouns that Apply to a Group or Individuals: We looked at the section we intended to discuss and found it to be two parts: One of them indicates the group of individuals with an indication that never separates from them, and is not removed from them except by their corruption. This section the philosopher named "Essential" (Dhati) and likened it to a part of the parts of what it is in, due to its adherence to it. We say it is more adherent to what it is in than the part is to the rest of its parts. For the part may go away while the rest of the parts remain as they are, like the hand of a human may fall off while he remains a human as he was. But this term [Essential], if the attributes for which the named thing deserved to be called by this name go away, the named thing is nullified entirely, as we will explain after this, God Almighty willing. The second part indicates a group of individuals with an indication that may separate from what it is in, or its separation is imagined without it being corrupted by its separation. This section the philosopher named "Accidental" (Ghayri) due to the evidence we mentioned regarding it. Then we looked at the first section which we said is called "Essential," and found it divided into three parts:

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Either it is a word by which many individuals, differing in their individuals and their species, are named, and it answers one who asks saying: "What is this thing?" So we agreed to name that word a "Genus" (Jins). Or it is a word by which many individuals, differing in their individuals not in their species, are named, and it answers one who asks saying: "What is this from the group that was named?" So we agreed to name this word [missing text: likely "Species" (Naw')]. Or it is named for many individuals whose species and individuals differ, except that it answers one who asks saying: "Which thing is this from the group that was named?" [7v] So we agreed to name this a "Difference" (Fasl). The interpretation of these meanings will come after this, God Almighty willing. These three sections are Essentials (Dhatiyyat) as we presented. The explanation of that is that you say: "What is this?" It is said to you: "A body." You say: "Which of the bodies is it?" It is said: "Growing." It is said: "Which of the growing things is it?" It is said to you: "Possessor of fronds, leaves, branches, tall, and the fruit named dates." So Body is a Genus; Growing is a Species; and your saying "Possessor of fronds, leaves, and branches" is a Difference. If you drop the attributes we mentioned, for which those individuals deserved to be named by the names we mentioned, and you imagined their meanings to be nonexistent, those names would fall from them entirely; for this reason, they were called Essential. Then we looked at the second section which we mentioned is named "Accidental," and we found it divided into two parts: Either a word indicating things different in their species in answer to "Which?", so it is a "General Accident" ('Arad 'Amm). Or a word indicating things different in their individuals in answer to "Which?", so it is a "Specific Accident" or "Property" ('Arad Khass). Know that the Arabic language did not enable expression in it with more than what you see. However, asking with "Ma" (What) and asking with "Ayy" (Which) may be equivalent in the Arabic language, and each of these two words substitutes for the other and occurs with one meaning. Whoever has mastered the Latin language knows the distinction between the two meanings we intended in the interrogation, for it has a word for interrogation about the general different from the word for interrogation about the parts of that general, with a clarity that is not confused for its speaker at all.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: 3 - Discourse on Interpreting Words Included in the Chapter Before This One Which We Begin With: We mentioned in the chapter before this things that differ in their species and individuals, and things that differ in their individuals only without their species. An example of that is that we say regarding the Essential: "Animal," so it indicates to us the human, the horse, and others. These are things that differ in species and individuals together; for the human differs from the horse in his person in that he is other than it, and differs also in the attributes of his person. We say: Zayd's horse and Amr's horse; these two differ only in person—meaning this one versus that one—otherwise, this is a horse and that is a horse, agreeing in the attributes by which each of them deserved to be named a horse. Likewise, the dinar and the dinar, the dirham and the dirham, and so on with other things. Similarly, we say regarding the Accidental: White and White; we mean the human is white and the wall is white. These are all different in their species in that each one is other than the other. They also differ in their attributes in that one is flesh and blood, the second is woven linen, and the third [8r] is dust, water, and plaster. And we say "Laughing" and "Laughing"; they differ only in person in that this is other than that. As for the rest of the attributes by which they deserved the name of Humanity, they are agreed therein. This summary is sufficient to dispel most of the cloudiness in ignorance of what is meant by this word presented before. Much interpretation remains which will come after this, God Almighty willing. 4 - Discourse on Definition (Hadd), Description/Sketch (Rasm), the Totality of Existents, and the Interpretation of Subject and Predicate: This is a chapter that should be mastered thoroughly, for it is like the key to what comes after this, God Almighty willing. Know that there is no existent at all, nor any reality whatsoever, except the Creator and His creation only; there is no way to a third at all. The Creator is One, First, Eternal. As for the creation, it is many. Then we say: As for creation, it is divided into two parts with no third at all: A thing that stands by itself and carries another, so we agreed to name it "Substance" (Jawhar); and a thing that does not stand by itself and must...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...be carried by another, so we agreed to name it "Accident" ('Arad). The Substance is the body of the stone, the wall, the wood, and every body in the world. The Accident is its length, its width, its color, its movement, its shape, and all its attributes carried in the body. For you see the unripened date (1) green, then it becomes red, then it becomes yellow; and the red is other than the green and other than the yellow. The essence (source) upon which (2) these colors alternate is one, then it transforms and becomes another body. Likewise, you see gold as dust (3), then it becomes an ingot, then it becomes a minted dinar, and the body in all of that is itself. Likewise, you see the human lying down, then bowing, standing, then sitting, and he is in all of that one, not exchanged, while his accidents are exchanged and changing; an attribute goes and [an attribute] occurs. It is necessary for everything we mentioned of the two parts of creation to have attributes carried in it, or a meaning existing for it, by which it is distinguished from others, and due to which the difference between names becomes necessary. As for the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, He is neither a carrier nor carried in any way whatsoever; we have mastered this meaning in a place other than this, and praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds, for guiding us. Then we return and say: The attributes or meanings which we mentioned are necessary for everything other than the Creator Almighty are divided into two parts: Either indicating the nature of what it is in, distinguishing it from others, so we agreed to name it "Definition" (Hadd); or distinguishing it from others while not indicating a nature, so we agreed to name it "Description" or "Sketch" (Rasm). We say: Disputing (4) over names is meaningless; only people of prattle, foolishness, and ignorance busy themselves with that. Our purpose from them is only the distinction between named things, and what achieves understanding between one another. God Almighty sent messengers with various languages, while the intended meaning is one [8v]. So it is established that the purpose is only mutual understanding. Everything other than the Creator Almighty must necessarily be described (marsum) and defined (mahdud) (5), because there must exist for it a meaning by which...
