book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...its nature is distinguished from others, whether it is an accident or a substance. The predecessors named the noun in this place "Subject" (Mawdu'). So if you hear them say "The Subject," they only mean the noun intended to be clarified by description or definition. Every defined thing is described, but not every described thing is defined, because every definition is a distinction of the defined from others, and every description is a distinction of the described from others. Thus, every definition is a description [in the sense of distinction], but not every description distinguishes the nature of the described or clarifies it; and every definition distinguishes the nature of the defined and separates it. So not every description is a definition; thus, the description is more general than the definition. The Sheikh said: This is the phrasing of the translators, and it contains confusion because they asserted that the Description (Rasm) is not taken from genera and differences (differentia), and that it is only taken from accidents and properties. Then they did not delay in contradicting themselves, saying: "Every definition is a description," thereby necessitating that the definition is taken from accidents, or that some description is taken from differences; this is the opposite of what they said before. Also, they said: Description is other than Definition, then they asserted that Definition is a part of Description; this is a contradiction as you see. But the correct view is to say: Every discriminator of one thing from another is either a discrimination found from genera and species, so it is a Definition indicating the nature of the thing, distinguishing it from others; or it is distinguished by a discrimination found from accidents or properties, so it is a discriminator of the thing from others only, not indicating its nature. Thus, the Discrimination is a comprehensive head, divided into two types: either Definition or Description. So Description is divided into two parts: a part that distinguishes the nature of the described, which is Description and Definition; and a part that does not distinguish it, so it is Description not Definition. The Ancients expressed the Definition as: "A brief statement indicating the nature of the Subject, distinguishing it from others," and the Description as: "A brief statement distinguishing the Subject from others." The Definition is predicated on the Defined, and the Description is predicated on the Described, because each of them is attributes of what it is in. So if the distinction is taken from the genus of the thing intended to be distinguished and from its differences, it is a Definition and a mark (Sīma); and if it is taken from its properties and accidents, it is a Description, not a Definition. This is merely a clarification of the meaning of the word 'Definition' and the word 'Description,' not that the Definition needs a definition; if that were so, it would necessitate the existence of infinite definitions, and this is impossible, absurd, and false. We are only troubled in this place by one of two men: Either a rioter who is not ashamed of...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...denying what is known [9r] to be true, striving to invalidate definitions for defined things; or an atheist striving to prove the eternity of the world. Both are of no concern, because they deny observation; and praise be to God. We have explained that the Definition is merely certain attributes certain to exist in some things and certain to be absent in other things, describing each by what is in it. Whoever denies this has denied sense and eyewitness and has exited the boundary of those we engage with. The Definition is like our saying regarding the Human: He is the body capable of color, possessor of the rational soul, living, dying. "Living" is a genus for the soul, whatever soul it is; and the rest of what we mentioned are differences (differentia) for it from other animal souls. This is the Definition as you see. The Description (Rasm) is like your saying (1) regarding the Human: He is the laugher or the weeper. It is, as you see, distinguishing the human from others, but not indicating his nature which is the acceptance of life and death. The Definition clarifies that. The rule of the Definition is that it must be equal to the Defined. The meaning of that is that its wording, when mentioned, necessitates all that is intended, so nothing of what you wanted to define deviates from it, nor does anything that is not of it enter into it. If you add a word to the Definition, and the word you added applies to more meanings than the meanings of the Defined or meanings equal to it, the Defined remains as it is. Like our saying in the definition of the human soul: It is living, rational, dying, a substance, sensing, laughing, weeping, shining in a body accepting color, upright in stature, and the like. The Defined up to now is correct in rank because every soul of every human has these attributes. But if the word you added necessitates fewer meanings than the meanings of the Defined, that is a decrease from the Defined. Like your saying regarding the human soul: It is living, rational, dying, weaving; or you say: practicing medicine or writing. For this is only a definition for some human souls, not all of them, since not every human is a writer, a doctor, or a weaver. However, if you decrease from the Definition that has no excess—meaning no increase in it over the amount of sufficiency in the definition—it is an increase in the Defined. Like your saying regarding the Human: It is living, rational. For the angel and the jinn enter under this definition. The Ancients agreed to name the one reported about "Subject" (Mawdu'), and agreed to name your mention...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...of what you want to report about him "Setting" (Wad' - Subject), and they agreed to name the report "Predicate" (Mahmul), and the existence of the attribute in the described "Predication" (Haml). Whatever is Essential among attributes—as we presented—it is said of it: This is an "Essential Predication" (Haml Jawhari); and whatever is Accidental, it is said: This is an "Accidental Predication" (Haml 'Aradi). All of this is convention regarding simple words under which many meanings are gathered, to approximate understanding. If you say: "Zayd is departing," Zayd is the Subject, and departing is the Predicate upon Zayd, meaning it is a description of him. The grammarians call this the Inchoative (Mubtada') and the Enunciative (Khabar) if it comes in this order. So if you hear "The Subject" and "The Predicate," you only intend the Reported About and the Report About It, so know this. Discourse on Genus: The Ancients mentioned a division in Genus that has no meaning, which is: Like Tamim for Banu Tamim, Basra for its people, Ministry for every minister [9v], and Craft for its people. This is unrestricted... so there is no reason to busy oneself with it. We only intend by our speech the Genus we mentioned first, which is: The comprehensive word for two types of creatures or more. It does not indicate a specific single person like Zayd and Amr, nor a group varying only in their individuals like saying: The people, or like saying The camels, or like your saying The tribe. Rather, [it indicates] a group varying in their individuals and their species, like your saying "The Living" (Al-Hayy), which indicates horses, humans, angels, and every living thing. The Genus being discussed applies not to some of what its definition necessitates, but to everything to which the definition applies. The Genus does not separate from what is named by it except by the corruption and impossibility of the named. That is like your saying "Substance"; for this word names everything standing by itself carrying another. It is not possible to find a thing standing by itself carrying another that is not named a substance, nor is it possible to find a substance that is not standing by itself carrying another. If you imagined this thing not standing by itself, it would cease to be named a substance. As for the town, a human may move from it to another and remain a human as he was. Likewise for the plan, the craft, and the trade. As for Banu Tamim, we may find many people who are not from Banu Tamim, so none of these aspects is a Genus.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: 6 - Discourse on Species: The Ancients named the Species in some places by another name, which is "Form" (Surah). I see this as following the Greek language, for perhaps this name among them—I mean that which is translated into Arabic as "Form"—applies to the Absolute Species. There is no meaning in busying ourselves with this as there is no benefit in it. We only intend to name by it every group agreeing in their definition or description (sketch) and differing only in their individuals, like your saying: Angels, humans, jinn, stars, palm trees, apples, locusts, blackness, whiteness, standing, sitting, and all that resembles this. The Species falls under the Genus because it is a part of it. A Genus may gather many Species, such that its name—we mean the name of the Genus—applies to every Species among them, and its definition is found in all of them, while they vary beneath it by attributes specific to each Species to the exclusion of the other. That is, you say: "Living/Animal" (Hayy), and under this naming fall humans, horses, mules, lions, and other animals. If you define "Living," saying: "It is the sensing, moving by will," this definition is also comprehensive of all that we mentioned and found in all of them. Yet, every Species we mentioned is distinguished by an attribute excluding the rest, such as speech (reason), neighing, braying, roaring, and so on. So "Living" is a Genus, and all that we mentioned are Species under it; meaning "Living" gathers them, and they are its parts, and they differ under it as we presented [10r]. Here is a wondrous rank: The starting point in the division of the world is a Genus that is never a Species, such as "Substance" (Jawhar); for stones, trees, plants, and animals are named by it; all of that, from first to last, is Substance. Substance is a principle (Mabda') above which there is no Genus such that its name applies to Substance and non-Substance. And the stopping point (Waqf) in the division of the world is a Species that is never a Genus, such as humans, horses, tigers, rubies, grapes, and what resembles that. For under each of these names, there are only its individuals, such as Zayd, Amr, and Hind; every horse individually; every ruby individually; and every grape individually. Do not consider descriptions that gather some humans and not others—such as blacks, whites, flat-nosed, tall, and short—to be species; likewise in every species, these are merely varieties (Asnaf) and divisions. The nature in every one of them is one, and the definition of every one of them is one, comprehensive of them all. The definition of Species is not like that; rather, every Species has a separate definition that no other Species shares with it...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...at all. Between the two extremes are things that are both Species and Genus, such as "Growing" (Nami). It is a Species of Substance, because Substance [can be] growing and non-growing. And "Growing" is also a Genus for that which has a living, dying soul, and for that which does not have a soul, because trees, plants, the human body, and other animals capable of death are all growing things, and the name "Growing" applies to all of them and encompasses them. The Ancients agreed to name the first Genus "Genus of Genera" (Summum Genus)—meaning that above which there is no Genus, and which is never a Species at all. They agreed to name the other Species "Species of Species" (Infima Species), which is the one regarding which we said there is a stop, and it is never a Genus at all, and there is no Species below it, and nothing is below it except its individuals only. This Species is the one expressed as being adjacent to the individuals. As for the rest of the Species we mentioned that are between the two extremes, being both Species and Genera, they are not adjacent to the individuals in rank, because between them and the individuals are other Species. Like your saying: "People" (Humans); this word is between your saying "Living" and: Zayd and Amr. Thus, it has become clear, and praise be to God, that the Genus is divided into two parts: A Genus that is not a Species, which is the Principle—I mean Substance; and a Genus that may be a Species. And it has become clear that the Species is divided into two parts: A Species that is not a Genus, which is the stopping point in division, like individuals of humans or horses; and a Species that may be a Genus. The latter falls into three sections: One section is Pure Genus, the second section is Pure Species, and the third section is Genus from one aspect and Species from another aspect. It is a Genus for what is below it because it is generalized by it. Some expressed this by saying it is only a Species for what is below it, meaning gathering it, and no one expressed it by saying it is a Genus [10v] for what is above it. I only mentioned this to you so you do not see it and become confused. The correct view is what we mentioned first: that it is a Species for the Genera above it, and a Genus for the Species below it. Because if you attribute it to what is above it, it is better to call it by a name other than what you call it when attributing it to what is below it, so that the difference between its two attributions becomes apparent. As for the Species of Species which we mentioned, it is not permissible to call it a Genus at all, because Genus is only applied to what gathers two Species or more, not that which is adjacent to individuals only.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: 7 - A Comprehensive Chapter on Genera and Species: Genera of Genera which are never Species at all, and are the primaries in the division of the world: The predecessors mentioned that they are ten, then they verified and said: The principles among them are four. The ten are: Substance (Jawhar), Quantity (Kam), Quality (Kayf), Relation (Idafah), Time (Mata), Place (Ayn), Posture (Nasbah), State/Possession (Milk), Action (Fa'il), and Affection (Munfa'il). The four which they verified as the heads of principles and primaries of division are: Substance, Quantity, Quality, and Relation. As for the remaining six, they are composites of the mentioned four, that is, from joining some of them to others as will occur in their chapters, God Almighty willing. Know that Substance alone—among the names we mentioned—stands by itself and carries the rest. The remaining nine are predicated in the Substance, are accidents to it, and do not stand by themselves. If a speaker says: "Why did you not make 'Thing' (Shay'), 'Existent' (Mawjud), 'Established' (Muthbat), or 'Truth' (Haqq) a comprehensive Genus for these ten names, because all of them are existent, established, true, and a thing?" It is said to him, and success is by God Almighty: We have already presented that the Genus provides the definition of everything under it. Nature is a power in the thing by which its qualities exist as they are. So whatever does not inform about the nature of what is under its name is not a Genus. Since the words 'thing', 'existent', 'established', and 'truth' do not inform about the nature of all they apply to, and contain nothing more than that it is not false or non-existent only, it became necessary that none of these words be a Genus for what is named by them. As for the word 'Known' (Ma'lum), it may apply to the existent and the non-existent, the truth and the falsehood, because falsehood is known to be falsehood, and the non-existent is known to be non-existent; so it is also not a Genus according to what we presented, and because it would necessitate that falsehood and truth be under one Genus, which is a heinous impossibility. Furthermore, our existence of some of these Heads is contrary to our existence of the rest [11r]. Some of them the soul finds through the four senses which convey the attributes of their sensible objects to the sensing soul, not standing by themselves. Some of them the soul finds by pure intellect, not standing by themselves, like the existence of Number, Time, and Relation. Some of them the soul finds through the mediation of both senses and intellect together, not standing by themselves, like Movements. And some of them the soul finds through the mediation of intellect and senses together...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...standing by itself, like Substance. And the soul may find by pure intellect—graduating from the existence of these ten—knowledge of What is truly existent, not described by any of the attributes of these ten, Who is the First, One Creator, Eternal, there is no god but He. For everything that falls under one Genus, its existence is only upon one attribute comprehensive of its collection—meaning a single definition exists gathering everything under the Genus—or by a single property gathering everything under the Genus, as we will explain in the chapter of each Head of the mentioned ten. The properties of the verified Heads among these ten are different, so it was necessary that they not all be under one Genus. Thus, it was necessary that 'Existent' never be a Genus for these ten. The statement regarding 'Established' is like the statement regarding 'Existent', with no difference. As for the words 'Truth' and 'Thing': Some of these ten are true by themselves, which is Substance; likewise, it is also a thing by itself. The rest of them are true by other than themselves and things by other than themselves, because they were realized through the Substance, and by it (1) they became things. Were it not for the Substance, they would not be truth nor things. Everything that falls under a Genus has one nature, not different ones. These things have different natures as you see, so it was necessary that 'Truth' and 'Thing' not be a Genus for them. For applying names of Genera to what is under them is only according to their agreement in their natures, agreement in their definitions, and agreement in their differences (differentia), which necessitates the agreement of their names. And according to their difference in natures, their differences and definitions differ, so their Genera differ for that reason. Know that 'Existent', 'Truth', 'Established', and 'Thing' apply to everything they apply to as Homonyms (Equivocal Names), as we will explain in the chapter on Names for Named Things. If a speaker says: "Why didn't you make your saying 'Accident' a Genus for the remaining nine excluding Substance?" It is said to him, and success is by God: These nine named 'Accident' have different modes of being. The Substance's carrying of them is a different carrying; for some are carried in its person and are an accident in it, like Qualities; some are carried in its nature and are an accident in it, like Number and Time; and some are an accident to it from the direction of another, and carried in its nature by the nature of another, like Relation. We have presented that the Genus informs about the nature of what is under it. These which we mentioned have different natures in their being 'Accidents', and their descriptions differ; so the existence of [11v] 'Accident' as a Genus for them is invalid. So whoever disputes with us among the people of...
foot_note: 1. (1) Realized through the Substance and by it: Realized through Substantiality.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...silliness and sophistry, saying: "I want to call 'Genus' every name expressed for many and a group, and I do not care about the agreement of their natures under that name or their difference," we say to him: We will not dispute with you nor spend hours with you on what has no benefit. However, we say to you two sufficient statements for one who reasons and does not desire rioting. We say: If you are determined on what you mentioned and you are a Monotheist, know that you have placed God Almighty under Genera, because He, the Exalted, is Existent, Truth, and Established. If you place Him under a Genus, you have made Him defined by necessity, since everything that falls under a Genus is defined (limited); God is exalted above that. The second statement is we say: We do not dispute with you regarding the [letters] Jim, Nun, and Sin. If it appears to you to name your hand, your foot, or your molar a "Genus," there is nothing preventing you from that, except that you need someone to agree with you on conversing in this language you invented. It suffices us that you stop at your obedience regarding a name you agree with us upon, agreeing to apply it to every group gathered by a single nature from which its differences arise, and from which its definitions are found, and under which many differing in their species are found, so that we may understand our intent by it. If you refuse that and place what is other than the Creator Almighty not under definitions, then you fall into open declaration of stubbornness against intellect and senses. For you necessarily see things agreeing in one attribute, and other things differing from them in that attribute while agreeing in another attribute. This is the meaning of Definition, because every attribute defines what it is in, excluding what it is not in. No one rejects this except a madman or one who is in a worse state than a madman by intending to invalidate truths, confuse knowledge, and establish ambiguity. Whoever desires [this] here, speaking with him is abandoned, since our goal with whom we speak is that he turns to the truth or for the sake of truth, not those (1) upon whom intellectual judgments do not apply—along with the fact that this is disbelief (Kufr) from its believer, if he is among those who label themselves with faith. And in God we seek refuge from error and what leads to it. With this, we also speak to the one who says to us: "Why didn't you call 'Species' what you called 'Genus', and call 'Genus' what you called 'Species'?" For indeed, a fool may ask this question. Know that Substance alone, excluding the other things we mentioned, exists by itself, while the others alternate upon it. All of them exist through it; there is no way for them to exist without it at all.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Substance, even if it does not exist without them either, may exist without some of them. But there is no way for any of them to exist without Substance at all. Substance is perceived by the intellect only; it is not visible, tasted, touched, or smelled. We only see colors, so if color is absent, we see nothing, like moving air—which is wind—for it is perceived by touch and butts [12r] against great bodies knocking them down, yet it is invisible because it has no color. The Jinn are likewise; the Truthful One [the Prophet], peace be upon him, informed us from God Almighty that they see us from where we do not see them; we possess colors and they are without colors. Similarly, we do not smell a stone because it has no scent; we only smell scents according to their differences. Also, a stone is not tasted because it has no taste; tastes are only tasted according to their differences. And the tangible is only touched regarding roughness, softness, smoothness, hardness, or friability. Some Substance might be allowed/heard (1) by an accident in it as will come after this, God Almighty willing. We only placed what falls under the senses under Quality to seek brevity and to gather the many (2) under one name, and because they are all described by one description, as will occur in its chapter, God willing. Each of the Heads we mentioned gathers the nature of many things, so we named each one "Genus of Genera." We also named much of what falls under each Head "Genera" as well, until we reach the Pure Species which are adjacent to Individuals. Know that every Higher Head—and we mean by that the Genus of Genera—and everything under it called Genus or Species: everything falling under it is named by the name of the Head which is higher than it, and we define it by its definition. For the human soul is called a substance and called living, and is described by the description of Substance and defined by the definition of Living. Likewise, the human body is called growing, a substance, and a body, and is defined and described by the description and definition of each of these names. Know that the Higher Head is not named by the name of what is below it, nor defined by its definition. The predecessors express this place by saying: "The Higher is said of the Lower, and the Lower is not said of the Higher." This is only because the Lower exists in the Higher Head and others which fall under the Higher Head. If you named the Higher Head by the name of what falls under it, you would have...
foot_note:
1. (1) Allowed (Yusmah): Heard (Yusma'). 
2. For the many: For multiplication/abundance.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...diminished it of some of its attributes. Do you not see that every Growing thing is a Body? If you named the Absolute Body "Growing," you would be mistaken and lying, because a stone is a Body but the stone is not Growing; this is impossible. But if you named the Growing thing a "Body," you would be correct. Zayd is a human and is defined by the definition of Human; he is named Living and defined by the definition of Living; he is named a Body and described by the description of Body. But the Absolute Body is not called Living nor defined by the definition of Living, nor called Human nor defined by the definition of Human, nor called Zayd nor defined by the definition of Zayd. We mean by Absolute Body everything to which applies [the description of] every long, wide, deep thing. So the stone is a Body but not Living, nor Human, nor Zayd. The Absolute is the universal name that encompasses everything named by it. We have [12v] presented before that things and creatures are divided into three divisions: Genera, Species, and Individuals. Everything called a Genus, whether it is only a Pure Genus or constitutes a Genus and a Species, is defined with us and in Nature. That is, we begin and say: Everything other than the Creator Almighty is divided into two parts: Substance and Non-Substance. The Substance is the Body according to our view, and the Body is the Substance; and there is nothing other than the Creator Almighty except a Body or carried in a Body. Others have affirmed a substance that is not a body, and this is false. This is not the place to solve the doubts raised against us in this statement, and we have mastered it in its place. Success is by God. The discussion on this falls into Metaphysics and the Science of Tawhid (Theology), and we have established it in the book *Al-Fisal fi al-Milal wa al-Nihal*. Likewise, others described the definition of Human as "Living, Rational, Dying." This definition must either mean the Composite Body alone, or the Soul alone, or the Composite Body and Soul together. If he meant the Composite Body, that is an error because he entered the Composite Body under "Living," while the Living is only the Soul alone—which is the sensing, moving [entity] that if it is nullified, the sensation and movement of the body are nullified entirely. If he meant the Soul alone, that is also an error because he entered it under "Growing," and the Soul is not growing; rather, the Growing is only its composite body. The proofs for this have another place we have mentioned in the book *Al-Fisal* in the Chapter on the Soul. Then we return and say: And Substance...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...is divided into two parts: Living and Non-Living. The Living is divided into two parts: Rational Soul and Non-Rational Soul. Nothing is alive with life except a soul alive with life. The definition of the Living possessor of life is: The sensing, moving by will. The Rational Souls are the Angels, the souls of the Immortal Individuals which the Truthful One [Prophet], peace be upon him, informed us are in the Abode of Bliss—consisting of Houris and Youths—and the souls of Humans, and the souls of Jinn. Others believe, in place of the Immortal Individuals we mentioned, that the celestial bodies of stars and spheres possess living rational souls; the discussion on all this doubt has a place other than this. The Non-Rational Soul refers to the souls of other animals. The Rational Soul is divided into two parts: Rational Mortal (capable of death) and Rational Non-Mortal. The Non-Mortal are the Angels and the souls of the Immortal Individuals we mentioned. The Mortal are the souls of Humans and Jinn. The meaning of our saying "Mortal" is that they separate from the boundary of their vessel—the bodies composed of the four elements to which they began clinging in the world of testing—not that they become non-existent, nor that their sensation, thought, distinction, and movement are nullified at all. The Mortal is divided into two parts: Possessor of sensation [13r] accepting colors, which is the soul of Human; and possessor of a body not accepting colors, which is the soul of Jinn. As for the Non-Rational, it is described by neighing, barking, braying, and other specific attributes distinguishing its species. They are many species adjacent to individuals. As for the Non-Living, it adds to the section of Living, being divided into two parts: Composite and Non-Composite. The Non-Composite are the four elements: Fire, Air, Water, and Earth; and the nine Spheres and what is in them of planets and stars. The nine Spheres are the seven Heavens which are seven paths for the planets; the Footstool (Kursi) which is the sphere of the Mansions; and the Throne ('Arsh) which is the Universal Encompassing Sphere that rotates one rotation every day and night, above which is neither vacuum nor plenum, and which is the end of the body of the world and its existence, and there is nothing after it. The meaning of our saying Composite and Non-Composite is: The Composite is what God Almighty created from various things, like the bodies of animals and trees composed of the four elements. The meaning of our saying Non-Composite is what God Almighty created as one, not from various things; otherwise, every composite and every non-composite is composed of many parts accepting division and partitioning always. The Composite is divided into two parts: Growing and Non-Growing. The Growing is divided into two parts: Possessor of Soul and...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Not Possessor of Soul. The definition of Growing is what is nourished by nutrition distributing from its center to its extremities, transforming it into its type. The Not Possessor of Soul (1) are trees and plants, and they are two parts: Possessor of a trunk (stem) and Not Possessor of a trunk. Then each of these two parts divides into many species adjacent to individuals. The Possessor of Soul is divided into two parts: Possessor of a Rational Soul like the bodies of Humans and Jinn, and Possessor of a Non-Rational Soul like the bodies of other animals. The Possessor of Rational Soul is divided into two parts: Colored body, which is the body of Human; and Non-Colored body, which is the body of Jinn. The Possessor of Non-Rational Soul refers to the bodies of other animals, and they are very many species adjacent to individuals. They are defined by their specific attributes and their differences (differentia) distinguishing their natures, and by attribution to their souls. So we say: Possessor of a predatory, roaring soul; possessor of a braying soul; and the like. Thus, every species of tree and plant is defined by its differences distinguishing its natures and by attributes specific to it. This is a matter that becomes very numerous and broad; we only intended here to discuss the generalities. The Non-Growing is divided into many parts: Among them are minerals [13v] like ruby, gold, and others; and among them are woody things. They are pure Species adjacent to individuals. Each species of them is defined by its differences distinguishing its nature from others and by attributes specific to it. These Genera are limited as you see according to us, counted; and limited in themselves, counted. This is what we meant by our saying that they are limited in Nature, because we are certain that these divisions have no increase at all and that they are finite in number as we mentioned. As for everything that is a Pure Species—which are the Species adjacent to Individuals, and which we said are called Species of Species—they are limited in Nature but not limited according to us. We mean by this that the number of these species of animals, trees, plants, and stones is finite in its essence with the Creator Almighty, by a number that never increases or decreases. We are certain that there will not arise afterwards, for example, a four-legged camel that flies, nor a three-headed one; nor will horses perish until no horse is found in the world; and likewise other species. The Messenger, peace be upon him, alerted to that by his saying: "Were it not that dogs are a nation among nations, I would have commanded killing them." In this is a report that every nation among...
foot_note: 1. (1) The Not Possessor of Soul: The Possessor of Soul.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the nations, there is no way to annihilate it. And the Almighty said regarding that there is no increase in species (1): {And the word of your Lord has been fulfilled in truth and in justice. None can alter His words} (6 Al-An'am: 115). Likewise His saying Almighty: {And He taught Adam the names - all of them} (2 Al-Baqarah: 31). A second proof: All species are of a counted number with no increase in them, because the Almighty introduced Totality (Al-Kulliyyah) into them, and Totality only enters into what is finite. However, we do not encompass their numbers; we do not count the species of birds, nor the species of aquatic and land animals and other insects. Only their Creator, Mighty and Majestic, knows their number, but it is finite and counted as we presented. The proof of that is that what is infinite cannot have anything more than it, and the individuals falling under the species are more than the species. Since that is so, it is necessary that the species are not infinite; and if that is so, it is necessary that they are finite by necessity. Since we do not encompass the particulars of the Species of Species, that necessitated us to reach them through the Species that are Genera, to arrive at the knowledge of their agreement and difference. For that reason, we did not descend from the First Genera to the Pure Species. As for Individuals, they are not counted according to us nor in Nature, because we find by necessary sense that individuals of people, if there is a plague or a swift killing on a day of battle, have become very few compared to what they were yesterday. Then if growth and reproduction continue and the lands settle, the inhabited (2) almost narrows for its people due to their multitude. So they are always increasing and decreasing. The Species are not like that. Rather, they [14r] never increase nor decrease, unless the Creator wills the annihilation of what He wills of them on the Day of Resurrection in the World of Recompense; [He is] the Capable of what He wills, there is no god but He. As for Individuals, they have no number at which they stop; so it is not possible that they increase or decrease [as a fixed set], but what emerged from them into existence is limited in number, counted since God created the world until every time it is said "Now." As for what has not emerged from them yet, but is among what God Almighty knew will emerge, it is limited and counted in God's knowledge, and in Nature it is countable when it emerges, not before it emerges. Increase in it is possible in His Power, Mighty and Majestic, without end in number or duration.
foot_note:
1. (1) In the margin of the page at his saying "no increase in species": What is in it is not hidden, due to His saying: "And He creates what you do not know." Then the commentator cited a story narrated by Abu Nu'aym in *Al-Hilya* about a woman of double creation (conjoined twin?). 
2. Al-Ma'mur (Inhabited): Al-'Umur.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: You see—by what we explained—that whenever we start from ourselves, meaning Individuals, ascending to the Genus of Genera, we start with multitude. Whenever we rise, the number decreases until we reach the Heads we mentioned. If we start from there, we only start with two parts: Substance and Non-Substance. Then the number increases in multitude until we reach the Species adjacent to Individuals. Know that Generality is not infinite, but has an end. The most general of things is your saying "Thing" and "Existent"; this is what the grammarians call the most indefinite of indefinites. Likewise, Specificity is also not infinite, but the most specific of all names below God, Blessed and Exalted, is "I" and "You"; this is the most definite of definites. Know that the Genus of Genera is a principle for what is below it, like Adam for people; the Species are like nations; and the Species of Species are like tribes—we mean they are like them only in branching off from them. Know that they said: The Genus which is the Genus of Genera is described (marsum) not defined (mahdud), because there is no Genus above it from which a definition can be taken. As for Species, they are defined. As for the divisions into which the Species of Species are divided, they are called Sections and Varieties (Asnaf). That is like the males and females of every species, or its blacks or whites, or what differs in colors among other species, or what differs in tastes among what is leveled under one species of fruits, plants, and other things that differ in an attribute while a single species gathers it all. For you find the black and white among people, and the male and female in every species of people and non-rational animals and many non-living growing things, and those of different colors among horses, chickens, and others. All of that is defined by one definition and gathered in one nature. Much of that encompasses parts of many species, like male and female, black and white. It is impossible that under one species fall different natures with opposite attributes, not all defined by a definition gathering them. Therefore, we did not make these [varieties] species gathering what is below them. We only alerted to this so an ignorant person does not say: "These sections are different, so why didn't you make them different species?" So we showed him that their definition is one, their nature is one, their properties are one, and their differences (differentia) are one. They only [14v] differed in accidents...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...only. For this reason, we did not deny dyeing copper until it returns to the likeness of the color of silver, but we denied and prevented that the nature of copper be transformed at all into the nature of silver, just as there is no way to transform the nature of a donkey into a human at all. 8 - Chapter on Difference (Differentia - Fasl): The Ancients mentioned two parts in Difference which they named: General and Specific. Their placement of them, according to us, in the chapter of discourse on Difference which we intend in Philosophy is not correct, because they fall into the chapter of discourse on the difference that does not separate species from one another under one genus. Like you saying: "Living" (Hayy), and the soul of the donkey is living; so which of the living do you mean? You say: "The Rational, Mortal Living." So Rational and Mortal are two Differences (Differentia) separating the species of Human from the species of Donkey under the genus of Living. This is the Difference we intend, not other than it. This is what the Ancients call "Specific of the Specific." We seek help from God and by Him is success: The Difference (Fasl) is what separates a nature from a nature, so it becomes clear to us by it that this is other than that entirely. If we imagined that Difference to be non-existent in what it is in, lifted from it, then what it is in would be corrupted and nullified entirely. For if you removed speech (reason) and death from the Human, he would not be a human at all, in any way. This is the difference between the Differentia (Fasl) and the Property (Khassah) as will occur after this, God Almighty willing. Therefore, this Difference was named "Essential" in what passed before this. By this Difference, Species stand under the Genus, separate from one another, and are distinguished from one another. Its benefit is great in every science, since some Growing things may require what others do not, and some Living things may require what the rest do not. Were it not for the Differences distinguishing every species individually, rulings, crafts, and all benefits of the world would be mixed up and would not be clear. Know that the Ancients name these "Substantial Differences" (Jawhariyyah) because of their adhering to what they are in, so they are like substances due to their stability. Know that Differences, Genera, and Species do not accept "Stronger" and "Weaker" (intensity), nor...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: It applies to what it applies to only in an equal manner. It is not permissible for a human to be 'more human' than another human. We do not mean regarding bravery or manhood (virility), but we mean only regarding being a human and a person. Nor is a horse 'weaker in horseness' than another horse, nor a donkey 'stronger in donkeyness' than another donkey. And so it is with all things that are equal in a genus, species, or differentia; they are all equal within it, and one part of them does not exceed another in being that thing at all, in any way. The definition (sketch) of the Differentia (Fasl) is that you say: It is that by which species are distinguished from one another under a single genus. The differences (differentiae) exist in the species in actuality (bil-fi'l), and in the genus in potentiality (bil-quwwah). By 'in potentiality', we mean: the possibility that it exists; and by 'in actuality': that it has necessarily [15r] appeared and existed. For if you say: 'The Living' (Animal), then 'Rationality' (speech/reason) is in it in potentiality—meaning that some living things are rational. If 'Rational' were in it in actuality, then every living thing would be rational, and this is impossible. But if you say: 'The Rational Animal', then 'Rationality' is in it in actuality, meaning it has appeared and existed. The 'Nutq' (speech/reason) mentioned in this science is not speech [words], but rather the discrimination of things, thinking in sciences, crafts, neighborhoods, and the management of affairs. We have expressed all these meanings by 'Nutq' (Speech/Reason) by agreement among us. Every human is rational with the rationality we have explained, unless an accidental affliction enters his mind; otherwise, his constitution—even if he throws stones—is capable (or if that affliction were removed) of all that we mentioned. This is not the case for other animals, except Angels and Jinn, for it is not imagined that any animal other than what we mentioned understands the matters we described. As for the Differentiae, if you verify them, they are Qualities, except that they do not separate from what they are in, nor is their separation imagined except by its annulment. That meaning by which individuals came to be named species and genera is also a Quality, as we mentioned. If you find an Essential Differentia that suffices to distinguish the species you want from others, then be content with it, and there is no meaning in bringing another differentia. But if you are compelled to use many differentiae, by the sum of which the species you want to separate is isolated from others—while other things share with it in each one of them individually—then you must bring...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...all of them, or whatever isolates it, so that the distinction and extraction you wish to clarify is completed for you. Know that the Genus and the Species are nothing other than the Individuals; they are merely names that encompass a group of individuals that gathered and shared some of their attributes, while other individuals separated from them therein. Do not think other than this, as many ignorant people who do not know think. 9 - Chapter on the Property (Khassah): Among Properties is that which is equal (co-extensive) to the specialized subject, meaning it is in all its individuals; this is what we intend to discuss in this book. And among them is that which is more specific than the subject specialized by it, meaning it is in some of its individuals not all of them. That is like grey hair in old age, for it is in what it is in during one time and not another. And like Grammar and Poetry, for they are in actuality in some of what they are in, and in potentiality in others; for not every human is a grammarian or a poet, except that it was possible and imaginable that he be a grammarian and a poet. As for the Equal Property, it may stand in place of the Definition, and what possesses it may be described (sketched) by it with a correct description (Rasm) [15v] that revolves (is convertible) upon the two ends of its described subject. For you say: 'Every human is a rational, mortal animal', and 'Every rational, mortal animal is a human'. This is the correct Reflection (conversion), and this is the revolving upon the two ends. Meaning that nothing of what you want to describe or define deviates from it. Every human is 'laughing', either in potentiality—meaning by possibility at all times—or in actuality at some times and not others—meaning by the appearance of laughter from him. If a speaker says: 'Why did you differentiate between the Property and the Differentia?' The answer is: The Differentia is that whose non-existence from the thing it is in cannot be imagined except by the annulment of that thing. For if Reason and Death are imagined to be non-existent in a thing, that thing would not be a human at all. As for the Property, it is contrary to that. If we imagined laughter to be non-existent entirely, all at once, such that it is not known what it is, the Human would not be annulled, nor would he be prevented, due to the lack of laughter, from speaking on Grammar, Jurisprudence, and Philosophy, or from making brocade, sewing, planting, plowing, and harvesting. This is what Reason—which is discrimination—produces for him. This is a clear difference.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: 10 - Chapter on the Accident ('Arad): This, even if it is a Quality like the Differentia and the Property, has a great difference between it and them. The difference is that the Differentia is not found in other than what it differentiates at all, and the Property is likewise, not found in other than its specialized subject at all. As for the General Accident which we intend to discuss in this place, it encompasses very many species. It is divided into sections: Some of it occurs in some species and not others, then in some of its states and not others. That is like the redness of shame, the pallor of anxiety, and the depression of grief; these are very quick to vanish. And like sitting, standing, sleeping, and the like; all of these change the states of the one they are in by the change of the causes generating them, and his states are separated by them from one another. Among them is that which is slower to vanish, like the youth of a boy and the middle age of a middle-aged man and the like. And among them is that which does not vanish at all, except that if it were possible for it to vanish, nothing of the meanings of what it is in would be annulled; like the blueness of the blue-eyed, the aquiline nose of the hook-nosed, the pug nose of the snub-nosed, the blackness of the crow, and the sweetness of honey and the like. For if the Zanj (Negro) were imagined white and the crow white-footed (or white), they would not exit thereby from 'Crow-ness' nor from Humanity. Likewise, honey might be bitter and not cease to be honey. By the attributes we mentioned, some types of Accidents are separated from others. Know that in Accidents there are species, genera, and individuals, just as in Substances, as we presented before. Know that if some [16r] of the Species were imagined non-existent, the Genus would not be non-existent. Do you not see that if whiteness were non-existent, Color would not be non-existent, because blackness, greenness, redness, and others remain? Likewise, if Human were non-existent, Animal (Living) would not be non-existent, because horses, chickens, and others remain. But if the Genus were non-existent, all Species would be non-existent. This is the end of the discussion on the Introduction to the Science of Logic and the Five Terms which are: Genus, Species, Differentia, Property, and Accident. This is what the Ancients call 'Isagoge'. The first to compile it was a man named Porphyry from the people of Tyre. Praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds, abundantly; there is no partner with Him. There is no power or strength except in God, the High, the Great. May God bless Muhammad, His servant and messenger, and grant him peace.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: - 1 - The Book of Single Names: It is the first book Aristotle began with among his books. It is called in the Greek language 'Qatighuriyas' (Categories), meaning: The Ten Discourses. We say, and by God is success: [First Introduction]: The Names (Nouns), each of which applies to many—that is, to a group of individuals—under which their named objects fall in all languages, from first to last, occur in five ways, with no sixth. 1. Either the named thing agrees with the second named thing in its name and its definition together. Like our saying: 'Horse' and 'Horse', or our saying: 'Living' (Animal) and 'Living'. For each of these two named things agrees with the other in its name, because it is one word, and it also agrees with it in its definition, because both are sensing, moving by will; and both are neighing, sharp-eared, used for riding, with an expectation of speed in running. This type is called 'Univocal Names' (Mutawati'ah), and if you wish, you can say: 'Agreeing'. 2. The second is that the named thing differs from the named thing in its name alone [meaning they are two distinct things with different names and definitions], like our saying: 'Man' and 'Donkey'. These two are different. This type is called 'Different Names' (Mukhtalifah). 3. The third: That the named thing agrees with the named thing in its name but differs from it in its definition. Like our saying: 'Nasr' (Vulture/Eagle) for the bird that exaggerates in rising in the atmosphere and eats carrion; and our saying 'Nasr' (Frog/Hoof-part) for part of the horse's hoof; and our saying 'Nasr' (Vega/Altair) for the star...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...which is in the sky, and similar cases which are many in the language. This type is called 'Homonymous Names' (Mushtarakah). From this, much tribulation occurs in debate; opponents dispute and increase commotion while one intends a meaning and the other intends another meaning. This only happens between two ignorant people, or an ignorant person [16v] and a scholar, or two sophists, or a sophist and a fair person. It never happens between two fair scholars in any way. No one is safe from this except one who is distinguished in this art, supervises it, and is strong in it, for nothing of the meanings of speech is hidden from him. 4. The fourth is that the named thing agrees with the named thing in its definition, but differs from it in its name. Like our saying: 'Sinnawr', 'Daywan' (1), and 'Hirr' (synonyms for Cat). These are different words, but they all apply with a single application to every individual of the species kept in houses for hunting mice, which persists in begging when eating, and resembles the lion in its creation. This type of names is called 'Synonymous' (Mutaradifah). 5. The fifth: That the named thing differs from the named thing in its definition (2) and in its name which its species is specialized by, except that they agree in an attribute of their attributes which necessitated for them sharing in a name derived from them—either physical or psychological, whether a state or a form. The physical is like our saying: A white garment, a white bird, and a white man. For each one of these named things has a definition other than the definition of its companion, and its name in its species is other than the name of its companion, yet they all shared in that each of them is named 'White'. The psychological is like our saying: A brave lion and a brave man. This type of names is called 'Derived/Paronymous' (Mushtaqqah). These five divisions apply to Genera, Species, and varieties of Species that are like species, such as our saying: Man and Woman, Male and Female. As for the Specialized Names, they are those that apply to the essence of the named thing alone, or to every individual of a certain group. They are such that the named things have names assigned to them specific to the named thing or to certain individuals to distinguish some from others. They either agree in them or differ. They may be changed and do not settle with a necessary stability; it is only by the choice of the namer...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...and if he wished, he would not name it so. He did not intend by it the clarification of attributes gathered in the named thing to the exclusion of others, as he intended in the first [types], nor are they derived for the one named by them from an attribute in him at all. The grammarians call these 'Proper Nouns' (Al-Asma' Al-A'lam). That is like your saying: Zayd and Amr; or Zayd and Zayd; or Asad (Lion) as a man's name, or Kafur (Camphor) as his name also, and the like. These are all the divisions of Named Things under Names, and the application of all Names to Named Things; there is no addition. The Names of God Almighty, which the Text brought, are Proper Names not derived from anything at all. As for the Attributes of Action for Him, the Exalted, they are derived from His actions, like 'The Giver of Life' (Al-Muhyi) and 'The Giver of Death' (Al-Mumit) and the like. Those actions are accidents originating in His creation, not in Him; God is exalted above that [17r]. B - [Second Introduction]: Chapter on the Divisions of Speech and Its Meanings: We have explained before that speech is divided into two parts: Single and Compound. The Single does not benefit you with a benefit more than itself, like your saying: 'Man' and 'Zayd' and the like. The Compound benefits you with a valid report, like your saying: 'Zayd is a prince', and 'Man is a living thing' and the like. The Compound is entirely divided into five parts with no sixth, which are: Either News (Declarative), Inquiry—which is Interrogation, Call (Vocative), Desire (Request), or Command (Imperative). These four [latter ones], truth and falsehood do not occur in them, nor does a primary demonstration stand upon them. As for those who deny the obligation of the Command, or [argue] regarding the obligation of accepting the Command due to a report necessitating it or by agreement of the two opponents, the Command is then demonstrated regarding the validity of its obligation, but it is not a demonstration [in itself]. A report may be enfolded in the Command; that is, the speaker saying: 'Do such,' enfolded in it is 'You are obliged to do such.' As for Prohibition, it is a type of Command types, because it is a command to abandon. Likewise, enfolded in the Request—which is Desire—is a report that the requester wants the requested thing. Do not think that your saying as a command: 'Stand' (Qum), is a single noun; that is a corrupt thought. Rather, it is compound because its meaning is 'Stand you' (Qum Anta). Likewise your saying reporting about an absent person: 'He stood' (Qama); if it were isolated in the reality of meaning without a pronoun, it would not be complete and would be deficient, so know it.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Likewise your saying interrogatively: 'Aqama?' (Did he stand?), meaning 'Did he stand?'. As for Desire, if it exits its proper mode, falsehood may enter into it, like one who says while healthy: 'O God, heal me'; whereas the truth is to say: 'O God, perpetuate my health.' Likewise Interrogation, if one asks about a falsehood, like a questioner asking: 'Why did the heat intensify in winter?' As for News (Declarative), truth and falsehood enter into it. In it occurs Necessity and Persuasion. In the corrupt structure of it occurs Sophistry/Rioting. From the correct part of it, Demonstration stands upon every proposition in the world. It is what the Ancients and Moderns intended by speech (logic). Under it enter all Sharias (Laws) and every accepted matter of physics and others upon which people agreed or differed. It becomes valid through several ways: One is that its validity is known by primary reason or by the senses. Among it is what is validated by a proof establishing its validity from premises that produce results, as will occur in this register, God Almighty willing. And among it is what is transmitted by a truthful person whose truthfulness is established by proof from what we presented, or transmitted by those believed by necessity, as has occurred in other than this discourse. Some people thought that Oath, Condition, Wonder, and Doubt are additional modes to what we mentioned. That is a corrupt thought [17v], because they all fall under the division of News and return to it. As for the Oath, it is a report of your will; if you said: 'By God' (Wallahi), your saying that is merely swearing while magnifying the command of God Almighty. As for the Condition, it is a clear report with no hiddenness. The Doubt is likewise. Wonder is reporting the state you wondered at. Some people thought that among News is that which neither truth nor falsehood enters, which is the reporting of a delirious person about a matter whose validity is certain, which he did not intend [to report], like his saying: 'There is no god but God', or 'So-and-so died'. These are two correct reports. Abu Muhammad [Ibn Hazm] said: This thought is incorrect because no one is a reporter (Mukhbir) unless he intends the report. The Report (Khabar) is with the Reporter (Mukhbir) by way of relation (Idafah); so there is no Report without a Reporter. The delirious person is not a reporter by his speech, so his speech is not a Report.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Since the mention of Command has come to us, let us speak briefly on its divisions. Command is divided into sections, among them: The Obligatory Binding, which is the essence of Command; the word of Command is not removed from it except by a demonstrative evidence. Among them is the Encouraged but not binding. Among them is the Permissible, where leaving it is better. Among them is Disavowal, like the speaker saying: 'Do what you wish', while the commander is not pleased with the commanded. Among them is Threat, like His saying Almighty: {Do whatever you will} (41 Fussilat: 40). Among them is Sarcasm (1), like His saying Almighty: {Taste! Indeed, you are the honored, the noble} (44 Ad-Dukhan: 49). Among them is Confirmation, like saying to the disobedient: 'I forbade you, so be patient and bear what has come to you.' Among them is Incapacitation, like His saying Almighty: {Say, "Be stones or iron"} (17 Al-Isra: 50). Among them is what is in the meaning of Supplication, like the speaker saying: 'Go away, be chased away.' Among them is Scolding, like the speaker saying: 'Be chased away therein.' Among them is Formation (Creation), and this section belongs only to the Creator Almighty alone in His commanding what He wants to exist by existence (Kun), and what He wants to nullify by destruction. Among them is a command with the meaning of Prohibition, like saying to one whom you previously forbade from something: 'Do it, and you will see what happens', or 'Do it if you are a man', and the like. Among them is a command with the meaning of Wonder, like his saying: 'How good is Zayd!' (Ahsin bi-Zayd), meaning 'How good he is'. Then Nouns (Names) are also divided into four sections: Either Carrier-Describing (Universal Subject), Carrier-Described (Particular Subject), Carried-Described (Particular Predicate), or Carried-Describing (Universal Predicate). The meaning of your saying 'Describing' (Na'itah) is that it is said of a group of individuals under it, so all those individuals are named by that name. The meaning of our saying 'Described' (Man'utah) is that it is named by a single name while it is a group (or individual entity). The meaning of our saying 'Carrier' (Hamilah - Subject) is that they stand by themselves and carry others. The meaning of our saying 'Carried' (Mahmulah - Predicate) is that they do not stand by themselves. The mentioned Predication (Haml) is of two types: Essential Predication and Accidental Predication. The Essential is more general or equal, and is never more specific at all. The Accidental [18r] can be more general, equal, or more specific. The More General Essential Predication is like your saying: 'Man is Living'. For Life is predicated in Man as an essential predication, since without it he would not be a man, and Life also exists in other than Man. Therefore, we said this predication is more general. The Equal Essential Predication is like the existence of Life in the Living (Animal); it is equal to the Living; there is no life in a non-living thing, nor is there a living thing in the world without life. Our naming the Creator Almighty 'Living' is not upon...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...this mode. We only named Him that following the Text. Otherwise, it would not be permissible for us to name Him 'Living', since Life is only a power by which voluntary movement and sensation exist, and both matters are negated from the Creator, Mighty and Majestic. His Names, Almighty, are not derived at all, nor do they fall under any of the five divisions we mentioned. Rather, they are only Proper Names; no proof necessitated naming Him by them—except that we were commanded, Almighty, to name Him by them, call upon Him by them, and address Him by them; there is no god but He. The Demonstration only indicated that He, Almighty, is First, Truth, One, Creator only. Then we report about Him by His actions, Mighty and Majestic, only: such as giving life, giving death, shaping, arranging, and the like; or what we were commanded to name Him with, without there being anything there that necessitated naming Him that. It is not permissible for an Essential Predication to be more specific at all; in that case, it would be non-essential, since the Essential is that by which the entire species is named, not what is in some of it and not others. As for the More General Accidental Predication, it is like our saying of the Zanj (Negro): 'Black'. For Black is more general than Zanj, because blackness is in the crow, the jet (bead), and the *Marah* (1). As for the Equal Accidental Predication, it is like our saying of Man: 'Laughing'. Laughter is not in other than Man, and there is no Man except he is laughing. As for the More Specific Accidental Predication, it is like our saying of some people: 'Jurists' and 'Weavers' and the like. For these attributes are not found in every human, but in some of them, and they are not found in other than humans. From this predication may be what is the Most Specific of the Specific, like your saying: 'This person is Zayd'. As for the Possible Predication, it can be more general, like whiteness is in some people and others; and it can be more specific like medicine, which is only in some people, not all of them, nor in others; and it is not equal, like laughing is to Man. As for the Necessary Predication, it is divided into two parts: General like Life for the Living, and Equal like Laughing for Man. It can be more general like Life for him and others, but cannot be more specific. The Negation in the Impossible is more general only, like negating Inanimateness from Man; and perhaps it is found equal...
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Marah: Thus in the text. Perhaps it is: Al-Harrah (Volcanic stones). As for Al-Sabaj, it is the black bead.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...and it is not found more specific in what Nature necessitated for the Species [18v]. As for the Carrier-Describing Things (Universal Subjects), it is like your saying: 'The Universal Man', meaning that which applies to all individuals of people. This is what God Almighty intended by His saying: {Indeed, mankind was created anxious} (70 Al-Ma'arij: 19). For He, Almighty, did not intend a specific human, but He, Mighty and Majestic, meant the whole Species. As for the Universal Man—and it may also be said: 'The Absolute Man'—he is a Carrier (Subject) for his attributes of Reason, Life, Color, Length, Width, and others; and a Describer (Predicate/Universal) for Zayd, Khalid, Hind, Zaynab, and every individual among people. This is called the 'Particular Man'. For Zayd is named a human, and Amr is named a human, and every one of the people likewise. So the Universal Man is a Describer for everyone we mentioned, meaning every one of the people is named by it. This section is never carried (a predicate/accident in the philosophical sense of relying on another) at all, meaning it is never an Accident, because the Accident is carried (mahmul) not a carrier (hamil), and the Substance is a carrier not carried. As for the Carrier-Described (Particular Subject): These are the Substantial Individuals, like your saying: Zayd, Amr, Khalid's dog, Ubayd's camel, and others. For all these are Described; they are all named by one name that gathers them as we explained. They are Carriers (Subjects) for their attributes of Knowledge, Bravery, Length, Width, Reason, and other attributes. These also are never Carried (Predicates) at all. As for the Carried-Describing (Universal Predicate): It is like our saying 'Knowledge' for any type of the soul's qualities. Under Knowledge are many types for which it is a gathering Genus, like Jurisprudence, Medicine, Philosophy, Grammar, Poetry, and others. Each one of these is named 'Knowledge'. So Knowledge describes them. Each one of these sciences is a Species under which fall varieties, individuals of chapters, and issues, like the falling of tribes and individuals of people under your saying: 'Man'. Thus is every Species under every Genus. So glory be to the Disposer of the World as He wills; there is no god but Him. Then we return to the interpretation of the Describing-Carried. We say: Universal Knowledge is carried in the souls of grammarians, and likewise every science in the souls of its people. We say: Every science among the sciences describes what is below it of chapters and issues; meaning all of them are named by the name of that science. So every issue of Grammar issues is named Grammar or Knowledge; every issue of Jurisprudence issues is named Jurisprudence and Knowledge; every proposition of Medicine propositions is named Medicine and Knowledge; every...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...word of the Language is named Language and Knowledge; every hadith of News is named News and Knowledge; and so on in every science. These issues are called by (1) the Ancients 'Partial Knowledge'. The knowledge of every single person is also called 'Partial Knowledge', and all people's knowledge is called: 'Universal Knowledge'. As for the Carried-Described (Particular Predicate), it is the knowledge of every man individually [19r], and they are also the issues of every science. For they are carried in the soul of the one knowing them, and they are described by the name of the Science gathering them—meaning they are all named 'Knowledge'—as we said. Know that the Describer may be Described, except that there must be at the first of its ends a Describer that nothing describes, which is the Genus of Genera we presented first; and there must be at the last of its ends a Described that describes nothing, which are the Individuals of Substances—as we presented. Know that the Carrier is never Carried at all, and the Carried is never a Carrier at all. For we have explained that the Carrier is that which stands by itself, and the Carried is that which does not stand by itself. So it is impossible, not formable in the mind, that a thing be standing by itself and not standing by itself [simultaneously]. Some of our friends annoyed me with a tribulation brought upon him by his good opinion of speech he read by the heavy-prattler nicknamed Abu al-Abbas, known as Al-Nashi'. He was always asking me the difference between the 'Carried' (Mahmul - Predicate/Accident) and the 'Situated' (Mutamakkin - Place-occupier). The Creator Almighty did not help him, up to our time in which we wrote this book of ours, to understand the difference between them. It is that 'The Carried' (Mahmul) you say only regarding attributes that become nullified by the nullification of what they are in, like Zayd's whiteness and life. For if Zayd is nullified, his life and whiteness are nullified, without doubt. His whiteness may also be nullified while Zayd is not nullified but remains correct and sound, either due to paleness or some accidents. 'The Situated' (Mutamakkin) we say only regarding Substances that do not become nullified by the nullification of what they are in, like the being of Zayd in the house; then the house is demolished and becomes a hill or a pit (2), while Zayd is standing, sound, looking into his affairs. Zayd leaves the house and neither of them is nullified. Thus, the parts of the body in the body are Situated, not Carried. This is a difference not confused to one of sound sense or fairness. In sum, the being of a body in a body...

1. (1) Tusammiha: Read *Yusammiha* (The Ancients call it). 
2. Rabiyah aw Huwwah: Read *Ramah aw Haddah* (Rubble/Demolition).

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...is 'Situation' (Tamakkun), which is other than 'Predication' (Haml) which is the existence of the Accident in the Body. Everything that describes a Species describes the individuals of that Species; meaning every name by which a Species is named, every individual of that Species is named by it, whether it is a Substance or non-Substance. Since the Genus is nothing other than its Species, and the Genus and its Species are nothing other than the Individuals falling under them. Know that the Differentiae (Fasl) of every Genus of the Genera describe everything under it of its Species, and every individual of the individuals falling under its Species. Like 'Sensing' (Hassas); it is said of every Living thing, and of every Human, Horse, and Donkey, and of Zayd, Amr, Hind, and all individuals of animals. And so on in all Genera and Species. We also said: Genera give everything under them—species or individual—their names and definitions. Meaning that the name of that Genus alone names and defines every species under it and every individual falling under [19v] every species of the species of that Genus. Know that the Differentiae of every Species are not found in another Species at all, in any way—neither its name nor its definition. Because the Horse is not named by the name of the Human nor defined by his definition; and likewise every Species always. [The Ten Categories] 1 - Discourse on Substance (Jawhar): It is the first of the Ten Heads which we presented as the Genera of Genera, because it is a Carrier for them, and the rest of them are Carried in it. It stands by itself, and they do not stand by themselves. The Ancients named (1) the individuals of Substances: 'Primary Substances', meaning by that Zayd, Amr, Abdullah's camel, Khalid's dog, Amr's garment, and the like. They named [Genera/Species] 'Secondary Substances', because the primary ones in reality are the existing Individuals. They named what is in the Individuals of Accidents: 'Primary Accidents', and named their species and genera which are in the species and genera of Substances: 'Secondary Accidents'.
foot_note: 1. (1) Thus in text. Perhaps there is missing text after 'named'.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Know that Substances have no Contrary (Opposite) at all. If they are posited with contrariety one day, it is only intended that their Qualities are contrary. By this meaning, the First [God] would be a contrary to His creation, because He, Mighty and Majestic, has no Quality at all, and Contrariety only occurs in a Quality upon a qualified subject. So the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, is not a contrary, nor opposed, nor incompatible; there is no god but He. Substance is not said to be 'stronger' or 'weaker'; meaning a donkey is not 'stronger in donkeyness' than another donkey, nor a goat 'stronger in goatness' than another goat, nor a human 'weaker in humanness' than another human. Likewise Quantity also, as will occur in its chapter, God Mighty and Majestic willing. Contrariety and 'stronger/weaker' only occur in some Qualities as will occur in their chapter, God willing. The definition (sketch) of Substance is that you say: It is the Self-Subsisting, Receptive to Contraries. For the Soul stands by itself and accepts knowledge and ignorance, bravery and cowardice, integrity and greed, and other contraries of its character which are its qualities. Likewise, many bodies accept whiteness and blackness—one of which is a color dispersing vision, which is white, and the second gathering vision, which is black. Many of them accept heat and cold; and tactile qualities which are roughness or smoothness; and scent which is perfume or stench; and other attributes upon which senses fall. So every self-subsisting thing is receptive to contraries because it is a carrier for them in its essence. By this, the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, is excluded from being a substance or named a substance, because He, Almighty, is not a carrier for anything of qualities at all [20r], so He is not a substance. As for what (1) some people think—that Quality accepts contraries because Color accepts whiteness and redness—that is a corrupt thought. Because the species of Quality, some of them are the Contraries themselves. They are contrary by their essence, not carriers of contrariety in their essence; rather, they are the Carried Contraries themselves. The Substance is the carrier for them, like Zayd: at one time he is a boy, another time an old man; at one time yellow from fear or sickness, another time brown from the sun; at one time hot due to proximity to fire, and another cold due to proximity to snow; at one time sitting and another standing. And he is Zayd himself. All these are qualities and accidents succeeding upon him, going and coming; some are contrary and some are different. Similarly, Speech and Thought—which is imagination—do not accept contraries...
foot_note: 1. (1) Ama ma: Read *Mimma* (From what/As for what).

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: the acceptance of contraries by Substances. Because speech and imagination are either truth or falsehood, based on the validity of the meaning of the imagined thing or the speech, or its invalidity. Truth and falsehood do not alternate upon a single speech; rather, they are two [different] speeches: one is truth and the other is falsehood. The same applies to imagination. 2 - Discourse on Quantity (Which is Number): The Ancients mentioned that Quantity falls into seven types: First is Number, then Body, then Surface, then Line, then Place, then Time, then Speech. Then these seven are divided into two parts: One is Discrete and the other is Continuous. That which has a common boundary (Fasl Mushtarak) includes five of these seven: Body, Surface, Line, Place, and Time. The common boundary for the Body is the Surface; the common boundary for the Surface is the Line; the common boundary for the Line is the Point; the common boundary for Time is the 'Now'; and Place also has a common boundary. The Discrete is that which has an order but no common boundary, which are: Number and Speech. Abu Muhammad Ali bin Ahmed—may God be pleased with him—said: We will, God Almighty willing, explain what we mentioned in this, according to what we stipulated at the beginning of the book.
