There is no power or strength except in God, the High, the Great. We say: The section that is 'Number' among these seven is the true Quantity, and there is no Quantity other than it. However, it applies to the other types we mentioned. Its application to the Body is by its measurement (area/volume): for every body in the world has a measurement, whether small or large. Measurement is a number found by an agreed-upon amount: either a span, a cubit, a mile [20v], a parasang, the thickness of a fingernail or a hair, or less or more. For this reason, they included Body in the category of Quantity. Number also applies to Bodies in another way, which is the number of its parts after they are divided, or the number of individuals if you wish to count a group of them. 'Bodies' (Ajaram) are 'Physical Bodies' (Ajsam). You count whatever you want of them by one, two, three, four, until you reach what you wish to count of them. I have seen some who claim this science criticize the Ancients for including Body under Quantity. This indicates this objector's absence from this science and from the intended truth...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Had this class of people been fair or abandoned learning, it would have been more protective of knowledge, less harmful to its people, and of greater benefit. But God Almighty spoke the truth when He said: {And they will not cease to differ, except whom your Lord has given mercy, and for that He created them} (11 Hud: 118-119). The mentioned Body is everything long, wide, and deep. As for the application of Number to the Surface, it is a limit (end) from all its six directions. This is also one of the ways Number applies to the Body, for every Body must have six directions: Up, Down, Front, Back, Right, and Left. Every Body must have these six directions, and there is no way to a seventh direction. Six is a number, so this is a necessary number applying to every Body. The application of Number by measurement to the Body is exactly its application to the Surface. We also say, adding explanation regarding the Surface: The Surface is the termination of every body that meets another body, [whether] air, earth, or other than that—whatever body it is. Measurement applies to the Surface, as we presented, since every Surface has a certain amount, measured in cubits or counted, as we described just now. As for the application of Number to the Line, it is the finite limit of every Surface and its termination. I will exemplify that with an example to increase clarity, so I say: The knife is a body; the limit of its two sides is a surface; the limit of each of its sides is a line. From the beginning of its sharp edge to its end is a line. Likewise, what is taken from the limit of its surface with the edge of its spine is a line. Its end (limit) is the Point. Number, area, and measurement do not apply to the Point because it is not a 'thing' at all; it is merely a name expressing the cut-off, the limit, and the lack of continuation of that body only. The mentioned Line also has a measurement which is measured in cubits or counted; this is also one of the ways Number applies to the Body. As for the application of Number to Place, Place is also a body among [21r] bodies, because it is either earth, air, water, a carpet, or other than that—whatever body contains another body. Every thing among what we mentioned has an area and a counted measurement.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: As for the application of Number to Time, times are three: Present, Past (1), and Future. This is one way Number applies to Time. Also, Time is the duration of a body remaining stationary or moving. Motions are counted as first, second, and so on as they increase; thus, Number is necessary and applies to it from this aspect. Otherwise, Time is not a pure, abstract number, but is composed of a body, its quality in rest or motion, and the number of that quality. As for Speech: The Ancients only intended by that the number of melody tones and the number of meanings of speech, for all of that has a number limited in itself—some of which we know and some of which is obscure to us. They also intended by that the letters heard via the sound propelled from the exits of speech, which the common people call "Letters of the Alphabet" (Huruf al-Hija), starting with Abjad and Alif, Ba, Ta, Tha. They are limited and counted, with no increase in Nature at all, even if their numbers vary in languages. In Arabic, they are twenty-eight letters; that is where our counting ended. The informant, Abu al-Futuh al-Jurjani, informed me that in the Persian language they reach forty letters. I did not ask him about the quality of that, unless they count among them the sounds resulting from the saturation of the three vowels—which are Raf' (u), Nasb (a), and Khafd (i)—then they reach forty-one letters. Discussion of this meaning has another place. As for Number itself, it is: Two, Three, Four, and whatever exceeds that. One is a principle (origin) and is not a number, as we will explain at the end of this chapter, God Almighty willing. As for what we mentioned just now that some Quantity is Continuous and some is Discrete, and what we mentioned regarding the Common Boundary: The meaning of the Common Boundary is that for the types to which Number applies, there is a limit (end) such that if it meets the limit of another thing of its type, the two things unite together—meaning they become one thing. Like two bodies; if they meet after being separated and mix, they become one body, like water you gathered to water so it became one water, and earth...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...to one earth, and a wall to a wall, and the like. This only [happens] by the meeting of their two surfaces. Likewise, if a surface meets a surface, they become one line [Note: text says line, likely implies surface continuity], after the two surfaces were [21v] separated—like the surface of dough you joined to the surface of another dough, becoming one dough, and the like. The same is said regarding the meeting of two lines. All of that is only by joining a body to a body. Likewise, a place where Zayd was, and a place where Amr was beside him; if they stood up from it, the two places became one place. This is the Common Boundary between two bodies, which is the end of the first and the beginning of the second. It is not a part of them nor of either of them, but is a limit raised by the occurring meeting. Likewise is the Common Boundary of Time; it is your saying "Now." For the "Now" is the end of the past and the beginning of the future. When the future comes, that which was "Now" becomes past, along with the past before it, so they unite—meaning they become one past time. And your saying "Now" is a state, neither past nor future. This is what we said regarding it being continuous; two things from it become one thing. As for our saying regarding Number and Speech that they are Discrete and have an order but no common boundary: It is because the letters we mentioned just now—the letters of the alphabet—it is not permissible for the Ba to join with the Ta and become together one Ba and one Ta or one letter. Likewise the Ba and Ta with the Ta, and every letter with its like or its opposite; there is no difference. This is contrary to what we mentioned before about two places becoming one place, two bodies becoming one body, two surfaces becoming one surface, and two lines becoming one line. However, these letters have an order in joining one to another; from that order, the understanding of meanings in speech arises. Likewise musical tones; it is not permissible for two tones to become one tone, nor two meanings one meaning. But for all of that, there is a known order. For this reason, Speech was called Discrete, and it was said regarding it that it has [no] common boundary [Note: Text says 'it has', context implies 'has no' or distinct separation]. Likewise Number; it is not permissible to join a Three that has ended, starting another, so the two Threes become one Three. And so is every number, unless some numbers are joined to others in a known order and arrangement by which the ratio of some to others is known, and the occurrence of numbers from adding some to others. This is the utmost clarity in this chapter, and we left no ambiguity in it by the power of God Almighty and His strength arriving to us...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...gifted from Him, Mighty and Majestic; to Him belongs praise and thanks, there is no god but He. The Ancients also mentioned another division for the types of Quantity we mentioned, which is also divided into two parts: One is that which has [22r] a Position (Positional), and the other is Non-Positional. The interpretation of that is that his saying "Positional" is an expression for what has fixed parts. And his saying "Non-Positional" is an expression for what does not have fixed parts. That which has fixed parts includes Body, Surface, Line, and Place, because the parts of each of these are stable as counting passes over them. For whenever you measure a Place or Body, what you measured of it remains along with what you will measure of the remainder. The Line and Surface have counted measurement along with the number of the measurement of the Body carrying them. As for that which is Non-Positional, it includes Time, Number, and Speech. For if you say "Yesterday" or count the hours of your day, you find everything you count of that vanishing, passing, not fixed nor remaining. Thus passes the first and then the first [next] of Time; everything that passes of it is vanishing and non-existent, contrary to what we mentioned before regarding the permanence of the parts of the Body. We find the parts of Time that have not come yet to be non-existent, contrary to all parts of the Body and what Number folds within it of its surfaces and lines. The Time you are in does not stabilize with a stability you can establish or hold onto at all, in any way. Rather, it stabilizes then expires without delay, and so on always. Likewise, the parts of Speech; if you speak its letters, organization, and meanings, everything you spoke of that has perished and ceased to exist. What you have not spoken of it is non-existent, not having happened yet. The part you are in of all that, you have no power to establish, hold, or fix at all, in any way. Rather, it expires first by first without delay. So glory be to the Inventor of the World and its Disposer. As for one who thinks that Qualities may also fall under Quantity because he heard people say "Much whiteness" and "Little whiteness," that is a corrupt thought. Because he only means by that the surface of the Body carrying the color, or its narrowness and lack of measurement. Quantity here belongs to the area of the Body carrying it as we presented before. Likewise, one who says "Much or long work"...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...that is only due to the abundance of Time and its length. Quantity has no contrary (opposite) at all; there is no contrary to a Cubit, nor a contrary to a Span, and likewise other amounts of Quantity. Similarly, one who thinks that Many is the contrary of Few, and Big is the contrary of Small—his thought is corrupt. That belongs to the category of Relation (Idafah), since there is nothing in the world Big by its essence, nor Small by its essence. Rather, the Big is big in relation to what is smaller than it, and the Small is small in relation to what is bigger than it. Do you not see the mustard seed? Likewise, the Earth is small in relation to the Heaven (Firmament). There is no part, however minute, except that a more minute one is imagined [22v]. Likewise the Highest Sphere, which has nothing in actuality bigger than it; yet in the power of the Creator Almighty, increase in it and the creation of what is greater than it is imaginable. We may say: A small mountain, and a big mustard seed, in relation to a bigger mountain, and in relation to another smaller mustard seed. If Small were a contrary to Big, it would be a contrary to itself, because it is big from one perspective and small from another; this is impossible. The same applies to Few and Many, with no difference. For a hundred is few in relation to a thousand, and many in relation to ten. Thus is every number; increase upon it is always imaginable. Except that whatever emerges from it into actuality is finite (1) always. If there were ten people in a city, that would be a very small number; but if they were with a man and a woman in a house, they would be a very large number; likewise if they were his sons. Know that Many, Few, Long, Short, Small, Great, Despicable, Grand, Minute, Huge, Tiny, Thick, Thin, Massive, Slight, Trivial, and Scant—all these belong to the category of Quantity (via Relation). Nothing is described by them in the world absolutely, but in relation to what is above it or below it—as we presented. Before and After also fall under Number, because two is before three; and they occur in Time; and they occur in Relation as will be mentioned in its chapter, God Almighty willing. Quantity is every meaning where the question "How much?" (Kam) is appropriate. Quantity does not accept "Stronger" nor "Weaker" (Intensity). You do not say five is "more five" than [another] five, nor weaker than it in that either. Thus you do not say: A time is "more time-like" than...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...another time, nor weaker. The Property (Khassah) of Quantity is not found in other than Quantity, nor is any type of Quantity devoid of it: It is Equal and Unequal, Many and Few, Excess and Deficiency. For you say: This ten is equal to eight and two, and unequal to eight alone. And so on in all types of Quantity. This is an expression for which the Arabic language gave no other [specific term], and Quality may share in it. This is evident in the Latin language, according to us, with a clear evidence that is not confused; it has a word specific to Quantity excluding the rest of the Ten Categories. Quality also has in Latin a word specific to it with a clear indication having no ambiguity, excluding other Categories, for which no matching translation exists in Arabic. In such cases, one resorts to what is furthest from ambiguity according to what exists in the language. Success is by God Almighty [23r]. By what we mentioned, it becomes clear that One is not a Number, because Number is what finds another number equal to it; and One has no number equal to it, because if you divide it, it is not one but becomes a fraction then. By this, it is necessary that the True One is only the Creator, the Originator of all creation, and He is not a counted number, while all creation is counted. 3 - Chapter on Quality (Kayfiyyah): Quality almost encompasses all nine Categories, excluding Substance. But since it is an answer to what is asked with "How?" (Kayfa), it does not encompass them with an absolute, universal generality. For whoever asks: "How is this?" is not answered: "It is seven cubits," nor "It is yesterday," nor "It is in the mosque." Quality is everything that alternates upon all bodies—those with souls and those without souls—such as a state of health, sickness, wealth, poverty, obscurity, and color. Whether the matters we mentioned are fleeting, like the yellowing of fear, the redness of shame, and the gloom of grief; or non-fleeting, like the yellowness of gold, the greenness of vegetables, the redness of blood, the blackness of tar, and the whiteness of crystal. Among Qualities also are all accidents of the soul: reason, foolishness, determination, silliness...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...bravery, cowardice, discrimination, stupidity, knowledge, ignorance, satisfaction, anger, debauchery, acknowledgment, denial, hatred, and love. Among them are Tastes, Scents, Tactile qualities, compositions of Speech, Heat, Cold, Forms in all shapes, and other Accidents. All of that is Quality. Contrariety (Taddad) exists only in Qualities specifically. It is not in every Quality, but in some and not others. Qualities are very many species; in some species of Quality, contrariety occurs, so one species is a contrary to another species by their essence. Among the properties of Qualities also is that some are stronger (more intense) than others, and some weaker, just as some Quantities are more than others and some less. You say: The sound of thunder is stronger (louder) than the sound of a duck, the scent of musk is more fragrant than the scent of sandalwood, the taste of honey is sweeter than the taste of colocynth. Likewise in roughness, softness, colors, and many Qualities. That only occurs in those that have intermediates between two contraries and accept mixture and the interpenetration of one another—not in every Quality, as we will explain in the Chapter of Discourse on Opposition, God Almighty willing. As for the equality of its individuals under the Species gathering them under the Genus, it is not permissible for "Stronger" or "Weaker" to occur in any of that. Nor [23v] is it permissible to say: A color is "more color-like" than another color, regarding each of them being a color. We do not mean by that brightness or dullness. Likewise, a truth is not "more true" than another truth, nor a lie "more lying" than another lie. This only varies in sin and ugliness. Otherwise, the lie of a joke is a pure lie, and the lie against the Creator Almighty is a pure lie; likewise, the impossible is a pure lie. All are equal in being lies, a correct equality with no differentiation, no stronger and no weaker. But some are greater in sin and uglier in abomination than others. Likewise, the knowledge of one thing is not "more correct" than the knowledge of another thing, nor ignorance of one thing "more ignorance" than ignorance of another thing; no stronger and no weaker. If the mediation of doubt enters any of that, that Quality exits from being Knowledge entirely, and that Conjecture does not fall under the species of Knowledge. Likewise, a blackness is not counting "blacker" than another blackness unless whiteness, redness, greenness, or yellowness has entered (mixed with) one of the blacknesses. Likewise, a speed is not "faster" than...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...a speed unless a pause intervened in one of them during the motion. And so is everything in which "Stronger" and "Weaker" is said. Contemplate this with your intellect and you will find it certainly correct, with no deviation for you from it at all. As for the Property (Khassah) that characterizes all Qualities and from which no Quality is devoid at all, it is: Similar and Dissimilar. For you say: This truth is similar to this truth, and this lie is dissimilar to this lie; and so on in every Quality. We mentioned before that this is an expression for which we could not find a clearer one in the Arabic language. For this meaning in Latin, there is a word of clear expression, unequivocal, for which no matching translation was found in Arabic, so recourse was made to the closest found to remove ambiguity. Qualities are Genera, intermediate Species, and Species of Species. For Color is a species under Quality and a Genus for what is below it; then Whiteness, Redness, Greenness, and Yellowness are species under Color having various individuals. Thus are the qualities of the Soul: Virtue is under Quality; Patience is a species under Virtue; Forbearance is a species under Patience. This is very numerous. We say: Qualities are divided into two parts: Physical and Psychological. Physical is what is general to bodies or specific to some, like Color, Taste, Tactile quality, and others. Psychological is what is general to souls or specific to some, like Reason, Foolishness, Knowledge, Ignorance, Thought, Memory, Imagination, and other character traits of the Soul. We also say: The two parts we mentioned are each divided into two parts: One is what is In Potentiality (Bil-quwwah), which is what is possible to appear but has not appeared yet. Like the sitting of the standing person, the disbelief of the believer, the belief of the disbeliever, the anger of the forbearing, the forbearance of the angry [24r], and the blackness of what accepts dye which has not been dyed yet, and the like. The second is what is In Actuality (Bil-fi'l), which has appeared and is known by sense, or by mediation of sense, or by intellect. Like the redness of the red, the tallness of the tall, the sweetness of the sweet, the belief of the believer, the forbearance of the forbearing, and the like. This is the meaning of what we understand from the narration about the Ancients that they say: "This matter is In Potentiality" and "This matter is In Actuality." They only mean by "In Potentiality": Possibility, and what the structure or rank bears to exist in it or by it. And they mean by "In Actuality": That which has appeared, existed, and become necessary. Then we say: Qualities are also divided; one is called "State" (Hal)...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...which is what is quick to vanish, like sudden anger, sudden delight, the redness of shame, the pallor of fear, standing, sitting, and the like. The second is called "Disposition/Form" (Hay'ah), which is what is not known to vanish from what it is in, unless its vanishing is imagined while the thing it is in remains as it is: like the nature of greed, the nature of impetuosity, the nature of silliness, the blueness of the blue-eyed, the pug-nose of the snub-nosed, and the like. As for the Physical Quality, it falls under the Senses. It is divided: One part transforms its contrary, if it meets it, into its own nature; this is called "Active" (Fa'il). This is like Heat and Cold; for Heat, if it meets Cold that does not resist it, gives its carrier heat; and Cold, if it meets Heat that does not resist it, gives its carrier cold (Note: text says heat, likely error for cold). The second part is weaker in this command and the action of the first part is frequent in it; this second part is called "Passive" (Munfa'il). That is like Moisture and Dryness; for Heat, if it meets a moist thing, dries it, and may also moisten it by causing moisture to ascend to it. The occurrence of Physical Quality under the Senses divides into five parts: One is what is perceived by the sense of Sight; the second is what is perceived by the sense of Hearing; the third is what is perceived by the sense of Smell; the fourth is what is perceived by the sense of Taste; and the fifth is what is perceived by the sense of Touch by the hand or the whole body. All these senses are conveyors to the Soul, and the Soul is the sensor and perceiver via these senses delivering to it. These senses are to the Soul like doors, alleys, outlets, and roads. The proof of that is that if the Soul is distracted or occupied by a distraction, all senses are nullified, despite the senses being sound. So glory be to the Disposer, there is no god but He. That which Sight perceives is divided into two parts: One is what is perceived by looking with the eye purely only, and that is nothing other than Colors. The second is what the Soul perceives by intellect and knowledge, and by the mediation of Color and Touch or both together; such as the limit of length and width, the shape of every shaped thing (round, square, etc.), motion or rest, or [24v] the hugeness of a body and its slenderness, and the like. For when you see the Color has ended by its termination from every direction, you know the quality of the shape of that Body. Likewise, when you see the Color transferring from place to place, you know that its carrier is moving, transporting it. Likewise...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...when you see the Color stationary, you know that its carrier is stationary. All of this the Sighted perceives; and the Blind perceives by Touch, just as we said regarding Color, exactly the same. If you touch the tactile surface of a thing moving, you know that the carrier of that tactile surface is moving; and if you touch it stationary, you know its carrier is stationary regarding the essence (what-ness) of vision and its perception. Among this is what is perceived by the mediation of Color alone and the Intellect; they deliver to the Soul what they perceived and what the Intellect understood by the mediation of its perception and the perception of the Sighted [text unclear: Mu'all/Mughfal?], such as meanings understood from writing in a book. For by the termination of the colors of the lines (letters), you know the letters from whose composition you understand the meaning. And like your knowledge of the condition of a human, that he is ashamed, afraid, broken, angry, a king, or a scholar, and the like. From your knowledge by seeing the color and knowing the attributes, you knew who the seen person is and what he is. Discussion of the essence of Vision and its perception of colors has another place. However, we mention a part of it here according to the entitlement of this register: Vision, if it meets a colored object and stops, you know that its carrier has ended and its length has ended. Likewise, you know that two lines/rays exit from the two pupils falling upon the seen object without time, and by the formation of that seen object in them; and in the power of the observer is the acceptance of all colors. We only said "without time" because you see the stars in the distant spheres if you close your eyes and then open them, without time (instantly). Likewise, if you close your eyes and then open them, you see the closest things to you in the same state in which you saw the stars, not faster. So it is correct that it falls upon the seen object without time. Also, on the path to the seen object are many things the vision does not fall upon, either due to darkness around them or the resemblance of colors. If it crossed places by a temporal movement, it would see the nearer before the farther. We only asserted the exit of the two lines (rays) from the two pupils—excluding the other opinion of some Ancients—because we are able to direct those two lines however we wish, with another mirror, returning the power of sight to the back of the viewer. Those two lines may also be returned by rising vapors, water, and other things, and by a mirror in them, so those two lines reflect and you see your face. Likewise, the sound exiting from the shouter reflects opposite the mountain after it strikes the mountain, returning to the ear of that shouter, so he hears his own voice as if another speaker replied [25r] to him with the likeness of his speech. In this is sufficiency.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: As for the Perceived by Hearing, it is divided into two parts: One is the perception the Ear hears itself by its essence without an intermediary, but by the ladder of air propelled from what is between the sound—whatever thing it is—and what strikes or what is struck, by the nature the Creator Almighty installed in it, to the ear of the listener. It crosses places in a varying duration according to distance and proximity, and the strength of the strike and its weakness. For that reason, there is a duration between the first strike—which is the element of sound—and the listener's hearing of it. We clarify that: If the sound-maker is very far from you, it is valid that there is a duration, like what is witnessed of the fuller beating the ground with the cloth; we see him when he lifts it without time (instantly), then he holds it for a while, and only then the sound reaches us. The same is said regarding thunder occurring with lightning; the lightning is seen first when it occurs in the atmosphere without delay, then it stays for a while, and then the thunder is heard. That is the decree of the Exalted, the All-Knowing. The second part is what the Soul perceives by intellect and knowledge and by the mediation of sound, such as the composition of melodies, the structure of tones, the meanings of heard speech, and the like, since that was delivered to us by the sense of Hearing and its mediation. By this part, it is valid for us to say we heard the speech of God Almighty, and we heard the speech of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and we heard the speech of So-and-so and So-and-so whom we did not witness and whose time preceded among the past eloquent ones and poets, and everyone whose speech was narrated to us. From that is your distinguishing by speech who the speaker is and what his state is: a beggar, a king, or sick, and the like; and like your knowledge of what the sound-maker is and which thing it is. As for the Perceived by Smell, they are Scents (Spirits) of perfume and stench, and what follows them of intermediates like the smells of some minerals and the like. Smell is the Soul's perception, by the mediation of the nose's smelling, of a change occurring in the air between them and the smelled object, and an affection from the nature of the smelled object and the dissolution of some of its parts from its moistures. The Soul may also perceive, by the mediation of Intellect and Smell, the knowledge of the essence (what-ness) of the smelled object of the scent, like our knowing the intoxicant by distinguishing its smell; and stench likewise, and other smelled things. As for the Perceived by Taste, they are Flavors, such as Sweetness, Bitterness, Insipidity, Acridity/Bitterness (1), Salinity, Sourness, Pungency, and Astringency. It is the Soul's perception by the contact of the organs of...
foot_note: 1. (1) And Insipidity and Acridity: And the Insipid and the Acrid.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...understanding (mouth/taste) with the body of the tasted object, with no mediation between them except by the dissolution of what dissolves from the tasted object's moistures, mixing with the moisture of the palate, tongue, lips, and uvulas. The mentioned organs [25v] may also perceive some flavors by the mediation of air and the dissolution of some parts of the tasted object in it, like crushed colocynth. The Soul may also perceive, by the mediation of Taste and Intellect, the knowledge of the essence of the tasted object, like our knowledge by tasting honey in the dark that it is honey, and likewise other tasted things. Our knowledge that it is honey is other than our knowledge that it is sweet. Knowing it is sweet is by taste purely; knowing it is honey is by the mediation of Intellect and Taste together. The same is said regarding the previous divisions in other senses. As for what nothing dissolves from, it has no taste and no smell, like some stones, glass, and the like. The Soul perceives the taste according to the strength of what dissolves from the tasted object. As for the Perceived by Touch, it is divided into two parts: One is what the Soul perceives by the contact of the skin of the healthy body with the surface of the touched object without the mediation of anything between them. Either from the evenness of the parts of its surface, called Smoothness; or from its stability, called Hardness; or from their separation, called Friability (pouring/looseness); or from the difference of the parts of its surface, called Roughness. The second is what the Soul perceived by Intellect and Knowledge or by the mediation of the mentioned Touch or Vision, like what we presented before of knowing the limits of the body, the quality of shapes, motion, and the essence of the touched object—what thing it is. For it is known what it is by the mediation of Intellect and Touch together, or by the Soul's sense purely, or by the mediation of Touch alone, like Heat, Cold, Moisture, and Dryness. It is correct as you see that the Intellect shares in all senses regarding what they perceive, and stands alone from them in indicating many things and perceiving numerous things. 4 - Chapter on Relation (Idafah): Relation in reality: is joining a thing to a thing. Here is another expression more specific to the meaning intended by Relation in the path of Philosophy, which is to say: Relation is the ratio of a thing from a thing and its calculation from it, like the Few which is not few except by its relation to what is...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...more than it, its ratio to it, and calculating its amount from its amount. As for the purpose intended by Relation in this place, it is the ratio of two homogeneous things, the stability of each one depends on the stability of the other, revolving upon it and not negating it. The meaning of our saying 'homogeneous' is that they are under one Genus of the Ten Categories which we presented as the Genera of Genera. The Two Related Things are two things where one is not established except by the establishment of the other. In general, when the Ancients saw two things where one is not established except by the establishment of the other, and that joining each to its companion [produced] a third meaning other than them, they appointed that [26r] meaning as a Head of the Heads of Categories, which is Relation. They spoke about it abstractly, even if it cannot be abstract, just as they spoke about Quality abstractly, Quantity abstractly, and Substance abstractly. Although Substance is never devoid of Quality, Quantity, Time, and Place; nor is Quality devoid of a Substance carrying it; nor is Quantity devoid of a numbered thing; nor Time from a stationary or moving thing; nor Place from a situated thing. But [they did so] to distinguish varying things, so the judgment of each thing individually becomes clear to every seeker of knowledge. For the tribulation in opinions and religions only came from the mixing of speech and the weakness in extracting the judgment of every thing regarding what is specific to it excluding others. The Related is divided into Symmetrical (Nazir) and Non-Symmetrical. The Symmetrical is that in which the two related parties agree in name and relation together, like your saying: Friend, Neighbor, Brother, or Enemy. For no one is a friend to anyone unless that other is a friend to him; likewise the Enemy, the Brother, and the Neighbor. As for what belongs to [the reality of] this relation, like Friend and Enemy, a person may be a friend to one who is not a friend to him—meaning loving—and likewise the Enemy; a person may be hostile to one who loves him, like many sons to their fathers and some spouses to each other. As for the Non-Symmetrical, it is divided into two parts: One is where the essence of each of the related parties existed before the relation, like Master and Slave, Husband and Wife; for the slave may exist before being a slave (owned), and likewise his master. The second part is where the essence of one of the related parties existed before the relation and before the other related party. That is like Father and Son; for the essence of...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: The essence of the father existed before he was a father, and before the essence of the son existed, even if they are simultaneous in the relation; meaning he existed but was not a father until the son existed. In general, the entitlement of one of the two related parties to the name of the relation between them is equal; neither precedes the other in it. This is because if one of the related parties is mentioned by the name that necessitates the relation, it indicates the existence of the other by necessity. And so it is with every related thing. Likewise, it is not permissible to say 'Double' unless 'Doubled' (Half) is necessary. The Doubled is a half of a number called the 'Second Half' when added to this half, becoming a double of it. The same is said regarding Small and Big, Few and Many, Light and Heavy, Loose and Compact [26v], Equal and Like, and other things that necessitate a related counterpart. Relation occurs in all Categories if you are correct in managing it and applying its judgment. For you say regarding Quality: The form is a form for the one formed by it, and the one formed by the form is a possessor of form; the curly is curly by curliness, and curliness is the curliness of the curly. Likewise, Knowledge necessitates a Knower, and the Knower among us necessitates Knowledge; and so on with other Qualities. Likewise all Quantities: Number necessitates a Numbered, and the Numbered necessitates a Number. Likewise, Place necessitates a Situated (occupant), and the Situated necessitates a Place. Likewise, the Possessor of Time necessitates Time, and Time necessitates a Possessor of Time. And likewise Standing, Sitting, Possession, Action, and Affection. Relation is only correct if you are accurate in the wording of its application and management. Similarly, the Ancients said that Relation exists in all Categories by Accident, not by Nature; meaning it is not present in the requirement of the word in every case. Because if you said: 'The bird is a bird by the wing,' it would be incorrect, because you find a possessor of wings that does not fly, like the ostrich, and you find what has lost its wing due to an affliction still called a bird. But if you said: 'The winged is winged by the wing, and the wing is a wing for the winged,' it would be a correct and valid statement. So guard against the likes of this in your debate and your seeking of truths. For you might be compelled regarding a thing that it necessitates another thing, and you concede to it, while it is not obligatory upon you, otherwise it would bind you—based on what we presented. This is among the fallacies of the deceitful riffraff, such as the saying of some liars: 'The Doer (Agent), because of his action, is a body.' This is very corrupt as we have explained to you, because it is not that because the Doer is a doer, it is necessary that...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...he be a body. But the correct view in the proposition is to say: 'The Doer is a doer by the action' or 'possessor of action.' This is a correct proposition known by the soul through primary reason. Some have used sophistry: 'The Hearer is a hearer by hearing, and the Living is living by life,' wanting to necessitate for the Creator Almighty life and hearing [as accidents]; He is exalted above that with great highness. We did not name the Creator Almighty 'Living' due to the existence of 'life' for Him [as an accident] such that relating life to Him would bind us; nor is the naming of Him Almighty as 'Seeing' likewise. We only named Him Living, Hearing, and Seeing following the Text (Revelation), not because a meaning necessitated it. None of that is derived from an accident in Him—God is exalted above the sayings of the atheist ignoramuses—nor does it fall under Genera and Species, nor [27r] via the carrying of Accidents. All of this implies composition which exists only in a created being. Rather, these are Proper Names for the Creator Almighty only. Likewise, the statement that 'The oar is an oar for the ship, and the ship is a ship by the oar' is an error. The correct statement is: 'The oar is an oar for the rowed object, and the rowed object is rowed by the oar.' Similarly, if a human said: 'The head is a head by the human, and the human is a human by the head,' it would be an error, since there may be a possessor of a head that is not a human. But the correct statement is: 'The possessor of the head is a head-possessor by the head, and the head is a head for the head-possessor.' This rank is the utmost correctness and Relation. These are the four Heads, and the remaining six are composed of them as will occur in their chapters, God Almighty willing. 5 - Discourse on Time (Zaman): We presented in the chapter on Quantity what Time is and what we mean by this word, and that it is the duration of the existence of a body, static or moving. If there were no duration, there would be no body. We mentioned in the chapter on Relation the aspect of Time being related (relative). God, Glorious and Exalted, is not a body nor carried in a body, so He has no time and no duration; God is exalted above that. If He Almighty had a duration, He would have a 'first' and a 'last' other than Himself. If that were so, Number would apply to them, and they would enter via their number under a type of Quantity. If that were so, He Almighty would be limited and created; God is exalted above that. He Almighty is not gathered with His creation by a number, since two things are not counted by one number unless they are gathered in one meaning, and there is no meaning to gather the Creator and the creation at all.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Time is divided into three parts: One is Static (Residing), which the grammarians call the Present verb; then Past; then Coming, which the grammarians call the Future verb. They have engaged much in discussing which of them is first. This is only due to ignorance of the natures of things and their realities. This matter is clear: The State (Hal), which is the Static Time, is the first of all of them, because Action is movement or rest occurring in a duration. If the time of the Action is first relative to other times, then the Action within it is first relative to other actions by necessity. The Static Time is the first of all times because before it existed as static, it was not existing at all, nor was it a thing whatsoever. What is not a thing is merely non-existence ('Adam), so there is no way to speak of it as anything other than non-existence and nothingness. Then when it existed, that was the first of its ranks in reality. Then it expired and became Past, and speaking about it became valid because it had been a true [27v] existent. Those who erred in this chapter erred for two reasons: One is that he looked at the state of himself; when he found himself anticipating matters before their being, and time before its arrival and before the passing of all that, he estimated that Future Time is before the Static and before the Past. This is a gross error and severe ignorance, because he agrees with us from where he does not understand. Do you not see that he only made it first in rank being 'future' because it had not come yet? This is the Static Time in reality, and his doing that is the action of the 'State' (Present) because it is other than it. It is what we said before is the first of times and the precedence of actions. Then that anticipated time and the expected action came together after that. The Past is more verified than the Future because the Past has been existent and a valid meaning about which reporting is good, and upon which Quantity and Quality apply. The Future is contrary to all of that. Know that the Existent among these times is the Static alone. And the Existent among Actions is that named 'State' (Present) which is in the Static Time. Because the Past was only existent, fixed, valid, real, and a 'thing' when it was Static; then when it transferred from the rank of being Static, it became non-existent, nullified, and vanished. The Future only exists, becomes valid, fixed, and becomes a reality and a 'thing' when it is Static; as for before that, it is not a 'thing', but rather non-existence and void. Ponder this with your intellect, and you will find it necessary and certain, with no deviation from it and no way to other than it, except for one who stubbornly denies his senses and rejects his intellect; we seek refuge in God from that. The second reason is that he who did not verify the investigation, when he could not hold Time...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...for two moments, the grasp of Time escaped him and he could hardly verify that with his senses. You must know that Time does not stay fixed; it is merely passing always, thing after thing. The Static Time is the 'Now'. For your saying 'Now' is a boundary existing always between the Past time and the Coming time. The 'Now' is the truly existent part of Time always; what is before 'Now' is Past, and what is after 'Now' is Future. However, the expression in the Arabic language for the Static Time and the Future Time uses a single word, whereas in foreign language[s] it is in two different forms, which is clearer in explanation and understanding. However, in the Arabic language, if you want to extract the Future purely and remove ambiguity from it, you introduce 'Sin' or 'Sawfa' to it, so you say: 'Sa-yakun' (It will be) or 'Sawfa yakun', so the Future comes extracted and abstract. If you wish, you add a word other than this [28r], which is like your saying: 'Tomorrow' or 'After an hour' or 'In what resumes' and similar words that define the meaning of Future purely without ambiguity. Time is composed of a Body, a Quality in its rest or its movement, and the Number of the parts of its rest or the parts of its movements. Therefore, it was not a Head (Category) alongside the four preceding Categories. 'Before' and 'After' occur in Time by the relation of some of it to others. 6 - Discourse on Place (Makan): It is what answers the question 'Where?' (Ayna). You say: 'Where is Muhammad?' The answerer says: 'In the mosque' or 'In the palace' or 'In his house' and the like. Place can never be anything but a Body; nothing else is permissible. Place is composed of a body related to a body in the sense that one of the surfaces of the Place met one of the surfaces of the Situated (object), or some of them, or all of them, according to the situation of the Situated in the Place. The Situated with the Place is divided into two parts: One is that the Situated is shaped by the shape of the Place it is in. That is like every thing with fluid parts or scattered parts, inside every thing with solid parts or gathered parts. Like water in a jar; it takes the shape of the jar, such that if you represented it standing [without the jar], you would see it in the attribute of the jar itself. You see that visually if the water freezes in it after being fluid and the jar breaks. And like wheat and flour in a vessel...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...square or triangular, and other shapes. You see all of that also shaped by the shape of its container or the house it is in, as we presented. This is one section. The second section is that the Place is shaped by the shape of the Situated in it. This is the reverse of the section we mentioned; it is the existence of every thing with solid or gathered parts inside every thing with fluid or scattered parts. Like the existence of a body in water or in air; its place in them is formed by its form. This is exemplified by the body of an egg or a stick you inserted into water, and the water froze around them after having been fluid; you find it shaped by the shape of what is in it, meaning formed by its form and configuration. Likewise, the existence of a stone in flour or wheat; its place is shaped by its shape. Air is a body among bodies, having six directions, accepting contraries of heat, cold, humidity, and dryness, except that since it was not colored, the sense of sight did not fall upon it, so it was not seen. You know it is a body by the movement of your hand or a fan, or if a fast horse runs with you; you find a body meeting you, which you sense with a strong sensation that no one denies except a silly ignoramus or a stubborn person. The existence of bodies situated in it—while it is a place for them—is like the existence of an aquatic animal in water. When a body [28v] moves from the place it was in within the air or water to another place, what was in its place moves to where it went—of air and water—to the place it exited from. The Void (Vacuum) is false. Its interpretation is a place in which there is no situated object. Since Place is of the category of Relation, there is no Situated except in a Place, and no Place except for a Situated. The proof of the invalidity of the Void belongs to a place other than this—except that we will indicate a sufficient part of it, God Almighty willing, to complete the discussion on the nature of Place. It is what is seen of the action of the vessel used for children's amusement called the 'Water-Thief' (Clepsydra/Pipette), and the action of the syringe (Zarraqah) and the cupping glass (Mahjamah). For by these things, heavy objects whose nature is to sink downwards are transformed from their natures to rise and ascend, to allow air or water to enter these things. If another body did not succeed the place of all that, that place would be empty. If that were so, the Void would be valid. Since that did not happen at all in any way, we knew that the Void is non-existent, there is no way to it. In this is sufficiency. If a speaker says: 'If a body necessitates...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...a place, and every place is a body, then every place necessitates a place forever.' He intended by this to prove that the body of the world has no end (infinite). This is corrupt sophistry. We have clarified the finiteness of the body of the Sphere and the World in the 'Book of Al-Fisal', which suffices against repeating it. However, we mention here a part of it so the purpose is completed, God willing. We only present in this book what suits its intended meaning. By the power of God and His strength, we say, and by God Almighty we are supported: The Body falls under Quantity—we measure it as we presented. The sphere of the World is a body that has appeared in actuality, so Number applies to its measurement by necessity. Number only applies to what is limited by it, meaning counted by it. We have presented that there is no Number except that it has other numbers which, if gathered, are equal to it. Equality only occurs in a finite thing by necessity. Everything upon which calculation by Number and Quantity falls is finite without doubt. Also, every number that has come out into actuality possesses parts, like half, third, and the like; and all of this necessitates finiteness with certainty. This is from the category of Relation. So the Sphere (Falak) which encompasses the whole world is finite by necessity. If a speaker says: 'Then the Sphere has a place,' it is said to him, and by God Almighty is success: Every part of it, the part adjacent to it is a place for it; other than that, it has no place at all. Its movement is circular; it does not transfer from its place, but every part becomes where the one following it was only. However, its upper surface has nothing touching it from above it in any way—neither void nor plenum. There is nothing above it: no place, no situated object, no area [29r], and imagination does not fall upon it in any way. We presented that every body has six surfaces: Up, Down, Right, Left, Front, and Back. Up and Down may occur in Relation, because there are things that are above other things. They may also not occur in the category of Relation from this perspective; for the upper surface of the Sphere is 'Up' and it has no 'Up' (above) at all, so it is not 'Down' (under) anything at all. The center of the Earth is 'Down' (Below) originally, so it is not 'Up' (Above) anything at all. The mentioned Center is a beginning from our perspective, and the upper surface of the Sphere is the end of that beginning, meaning a stopping point with no continuation beyond it. We do not mean by this proving that it has a 'beyond'; rather, we mean it is finite in measurement, having no 'beyond', no 'above', and no 'after' at all. This is our intent in saying that a preceding time did not have a time before it; we only mean it has a first beginning, so a time would have preceded. The upper surface of the Sphere is a beginning from the perspective of Universal Nature, meaning the existence of things...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...and their generality and encompassing. The mentioned Center is an end to that beginning, meaning a stopping point with no continuation after it. The First Creation was made [by] 'There is no god but He'. Place is composed of a Quality and a Substance with a Substance. 7 - Chapter on Position (Posture/Nasbah): Position is a valid Quality with no doubt in it. It is a type of the Species, except that they specialized the name for it. The meaning of Position is the configuration (Hay'ah) of the Situated in the Place, like his standing in it, or his sitting, kneeling, reclining, and the like. 8 - Chapter on Possession (State/Milk): Possession is a valid Relation, except that they specialized this name—meaning Milk—for what is of the Relation regarding possessing the Substance, like wealth and the like. This is the reality of Possession. It is composed of a Substance with a Substance and a Relation. However, some Ancients included in Possession your saying: 'So-and-so has a hand and a foot, and has heat,' and the like. This, according to us, is a corrupt judgment, so there is no reason to busy oneself with it, since our goal is truths and what is established by proof or part of a proof leading to knowing them. By God Almighty is success, there is no god but He. 9 - Chapter on Action (Fa'il): Action is an influence occurring from a choosing or natural body upon another body. Either it transforms it to its nature, stripping it of its type and clothing it with the type of itself; or it transforms it from some [29v] of its qualities to other qualities; or it performs an abstract action like the mover, the stander, the thinker, and the like. As for the first two parts: The first of them is like the action of fire on water and air; it strips them of the attributes of their substantial types—meaning it transforms them into fire. And like eating; it transforms the nature of what is eaten into its [the eater's] type. As for the second, it is like the action of the knife, the stone, and the cutter with them; they transform from gathering...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...to separation. Examples of that are many. And like the nature of the Elements of which the human is composed, in that every strong one among them transforms what it meets of the others to its type. This is found in everything composed of them. Every man wants to multiply himself through others in his accidents. Blessed be the Disposer, there is no god but He. Action is divided into two parts: Either an action whose trace remains after its expiration, like the action of the plowman, the carpenter, and the painter (decorator). Or an action whose trace does not remain after its expiration, like the swimmer, the walker, the speaker, and the like. The Agent (Actor) and the Patient (Affected) are composed of Substance, Substance, and Quality. 10 - Chapter on Affection (Passivity/Munfa'il): The Patient is that which is prepared to accept the action we mentioned, like the burnt and transformed by fire, the cut by the knife, the sewn by the needle, and the like. These things, even if they only exist with the assistance of others, were it not for the acceptance of influence in their natures, it would not be possible for the actor in them to do anything in them at all. If that were not so, let him sew with a spear or a banana, or burn with his breath, or cut with his foot. These objections are rioting and sophistry from the objectors who say: 'Fire did not burn, but the human burned with it; and the knife did not cut, but the human cut with it.' We wanted to clarify that the knife has a power, and in the fire likewise; were it not for them, it would not be possible for the human to perform with them an action resulting from them. Know also that the Patient influences the Action—it must be so—except that it is less influencing. For if you prolonged the will with a sharp, polished iron grip on smooth, moist parchment, that would influence the grip with length [of time] an influence appearing to anyone with the slightest sense, a clear, evident appearance. And so is every influencer in the world—do not exclude anything at all—even if it is far from your sense. With length, continuation, and the passing of successive ages, it appears clearly, even if it were the dragging of a finger on iron. So glory be to the True Influencer whom nothing influences; there is no god but He. This is a rank necessitating the existence of the Creator, the Influencer in whom [nothing] is influencing [30r] by necessity, as we explained in the Book of Al-Fisal. The Ancients mentioned that two elements of the four elements are Active, namely: Heat and Cold; and that two elements of them are Passive (1), namely...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Moisture and Dryness. This is a correct judgment. Their intent by this is that Heat and Cold, if they meet something, return it to their nature; whereas Moisture and Dryness do not do that. If a speaker says: 'Moisture may moisten what it encounters, and Dryness dry what it meets,' the answer, and by God Almighty is success, is: Reliable propositions are those that are always true, not those that are true once and false another time. Not everything moistens by meeting the moist, nor does everything dry by meeting the dry. If you threw iron into water and kept it there as long as God wills it to stay, it would not become moist (liquid), nor does the water become dry due to meeting the iron. As for Heat, if it meets something, it must heat it by necessity. Likewise, the Cold does not meet anything except it cools it. By God Almighty is success. The discussion on the Ten Categories has ended, and praise be to God abundantly. D - Discourse on Other, Same (Like), Difference, Opposite, Incompatible, Opposition, Possession, and Privation, and the Interpretation of the Meanings of these Names: We presented our intent by saying 'Individual' and 'Individuals', and informed that we do not mean by that the Body alone, but every gathered, singular part of a body or an accident carried in a body. So we say: The individual of the blackness of this garment is intense or polished; the individual of the movement of this mover is from here to there; the individual of this issue is precise; and the like. This is an agreement from us so that understanding of our intent occurs thereby, God Almighty willing. People of every science and every craft must have words specific to them to express their intentions and to abbreviate many meanings. [We say] and by God Almighty we are supported: Every two individuals and every two things brought together by one name or two different names not specific to one thing excluding the other—they are 'Others' (Mutaghayiran) by necessity, in every case. Meaning that each one of them is 'Other' than the other. So Zayd is other than Amr; Zayd's knowledge is other than Amr's knowledge; Zayd's garment is other than Khalid's garment; Zayd's height is other than Amr's height; Khalid's whiteness is other than Muhammad's whiteness. And so are every two things also, definitively, and every two existents. The Creator Almighty is 'Other' than His creation. If this thing were not 'Other' than this thing, it would be it, and it would be itself; there is no way to a third division. Likewise...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...every two words: Either their meanings are different (1)—meaning the named of every [30v] word of those two words is other than the named by the other word; there is no way to a third division in any way. It is not formable in imagination nor intelligible nor ever existent that two words whose meanings are neither different nor not-different. For it is among the most heinous impossibilities that the meaning of this name is not the meaning of this name, not the meaning of this second name, nor is it another meaning other than it. It is also among the impossible, prohibited falsehoods that the meaning of this name is the meaning of this second name while being also other than it. This leads to 'this is this' [and 'this is not this'], and this is a manifest corruption. For it is not permissible that anything be intended by the two names except one meaning or more than one. Whatever exceeds this is whispering (delusion). We praise God Almighty for what He bestowed of intellect. If a group objects with what the Ancients mentioned, that 'A thing is only other than the thing if its substance is different from its substance'—for they also said: 'The Human is the Donkey by Genus-hood', meaning they are under one genus, and they did not intend what we are discussing. What we intend is only that the thing is not other than this thing at all by its essence, or it is other than it. If a speaker says: 'Is the Part the Whole or is it other than it?' The reality is that it is other than it, because the Part may be nullified while the Whole is not nullified. If it were not other than it, it would not exist without it. 'The Whole' is merely a word by which all these parts are named in the state of their gathering. The Parts are the portions; otherwise, every part is other than the other part. The Whole is divided into two parts: One is a Whole where every part of its parts is named by the name of its Whole. That only occurs in the individuals of a Species, or in what is not composed of different things, like parts of water; all of them are named water. And parts of fire likewise. Likewise, every individual of the Universal Human is named a human. The second part is a Whole where none of its parts is named by the name of its Whole. That is in what is composed of different elements, like the organs of a human; none of them is named a human. Likewise the door; it is composed of wood and nails; the wood and nails are not named a door. Whoever debates you here, task him to find for you the meaning of 'Differentiation' (Taghayur) and the meaning of 'Identity' (Huwwiyyah), then speak to him. If a speaker says: 'If part of the thing is other than the thing, and every part of its parts is other than its Whole, and the Whole thing is only all its parts, it is not...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...a thing other than them at all, so the thing is other than itself, and the part is other than itself.' This is a deception. Because the Whole is only a name applying to all parts if they gather, and does not apply to any of them individually. Do you not see that [31r] the Part, if it perishes, the Whole does not perish by its perishing? Nor is it defined by the definition of its Whole. The name 'Whole' is like the name 'Human'; the hand is not a human, the head is not a human, the leg is not a human, and the stomach is not a human. But if all that gathers, the name 'Human' occurs for it then, not before that. Thus is the Whole with its parts. However, in the question, we clarify and do not leave for the confused a meaning to be confused about. So we say: Every two names do not escape one of two ways by necessity, with no third: Either they both apply to one thing, or to more than one thing. The questioned must then proceed to one of these two meanings, otherwise his interruption (silence) becomes evident. It becomes valid then that the meaning of the two words is one meaning—each of the two words expresses a single named thing—or that each of the two words expresses a meaning other than the meaning of the other word. If their meanings are different, then each one of them is other than the other. Then we return, and by God Almighty is success, and say: Then things, after Differentiation, are divided into sections: Among them are 'Similar Others' (Aghyar Amthal), like the blackness of this crow and the blackness of this garment; and like the dinar and the dinar; and everything that falls under one type of the species adjacent to individuals, whether a body or other. Among them are 'Different Others' (Aghyar Khilaf), like the dinar and the dirham; whiteness and redness; standing and reclining; and like the dinar and redness; and everything that falls under two different species or two different genera. Except that everything we mentioned, even if they are 'Different' as we said, they are also 'Similar' (Likes) from another perspective: due to their agreement in the Highest Head which is the Genus of Genera, or their agreement in Division even if a Genus of Genera does not gather them, and in Origination and Composition. As for the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, He is 'Different' (Khilaf) to His entire creation from every perspective. There is no similarity between Him Almighty and all His creation, nor between Him Almighty and anything of His creation in any way at all. The first term, which is Differentiation (Taghayur), occurs in every two named things. These two sections occur in Substances and Accidents. This second section, I mean Difference (Mukhalafah), occurs between every two existents, whether they are (1) under two different species or two different genera, or one of them is among what falls under Genera and the other among what does not fall under Genera. It is necessary in every two existents by necessity that they be Different or...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Similar. Then two remaining sections occur only in Qualities. One is: 'Opposite Others' (Aghyar Ad-dad), like blackness and whiteness. The second is 'Incompatible Others' (Aghyar Mutanafiyah), like Life and Death, Rest and Motion, and the like. Opposites (Ad-dad) are every two words whose meanings share the two ends of distance (extremes), falling under one Category [31v], and having intermediates between them. Either under two different species under one genus, like Blackness and Whiteness which fall under the genus of Color. Or like Generosity and Miserliness which are two species falling under two different genera, Virtue and Vice. Or like Virtue and Vice which are two genera gathering what we mentioned, and Quality gathers them. Every two Opposites are perceived by a single sense; it is not permissible otherwise. Either they are perceived together by the Intellect, or together by Vision, and likewise Touch, Taste, and Smell. Contemplate this with your intellect and you will find it certain. Every two Opposites: if one of them is in the Soul, the second is in it also; and if one is in the Body, the second is in it also. Only this is permissible. Because Opposites also alternate upon their carrier, like Whiteness and Blackness in the body, and Forbearance and Rashness in the soul. Likewise other character traits of the soul: Knowledge and Ignorance, Justice and Injustice, Piety and Debauchery, Anger (1) and Satisfaction, and all its traits. Likewise other Opposites alternating upon the Composite Body: Heat, Cold, Dryness, and Moisture. Opposites are such that if one occurs, the other is lifted, and there are intermediates between them. The Incompatibles (Contradictories - Mutanafiyah) are what also share the two ends of distance but have no intermediates between them; and when one is lifted, the other occurs. That is like Life and Death, Gathering and Separation, Health of an organ and its Sickness, and the like. Our saying in this place "Life and Death" is merely looseness (lexical dispute), not verification. We only intended by that the meeting of the Soul with the Body composed of elements; in this, we expressed it as Life. And we intended by our saying Death the separation of the Soul from the mentioned Body. This Gathering and Separation are the Incompatibles. As for Life, which is Sensation and Voluntary Movement, it is essential in the Soul, never separating from the Soul. Since that is so, there is no Opposite to Life in reality, because an Opposite and its Opposite are always situated alternating upon a single thing. Likewise the Incompatibles. 'Deadness' (Inanimateness) in reality is the absence of Sensation and Voluntary Movement; this is in inanimate objects. So Death is essential to them also, not separating from them in any way. So there is no Opposite to Deadness also in...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...reality in this mode, nor is there an Incompatible to it, nor to Life. The Body composed of the four natures is inanimate always; it has no life in any way at all [32r]. Life belongs only to the Soul permeating it. But we were compelled to express their meeting with the mentioned Body and their separation from it as Life and Death, due to people's habit of these two expressions for these two meanings. We wanted approximation and understanding as you see. So when you see in this book of ours that Death is the opposite of Life, this is what we intended; do not think it an error from us in this meaning. Some people of Sharia said: 'Knowledge is the opposite of Death.' This is corrupt speech, because the Soul, after separating from the Body, is more firmly knowledgeable than it ever was; whereas the Composite Body knows nothing. The difference between the Incompatible (Munafi) and the Opposite (Didd) is that between two Opposites there are intermediates belonging to neither of the Opposites, like Redness, Yellowness, and Greenness between Blackness and Whiteness; and like the state of Moderation between Generosity and Miserliness, as we explain in our book on *The Ethics of the Soul* (1), God Almighty willing. The Incompatibles are those between which there are no intermediates. For Life and Death, in what they are in, have no intermediate that is neither life nor death. Likewise, the Health of an organ and its Sickness; it is not permissible for an organ to be 'healthy-sick', nor 'neither healthy nor sick'. Health is the disposal of the organ in its natural action, and Sickness is its weakness from that. Likewise Injustice with Justice and Judgment: it is not permissible for a judgment to be 'neither justice nor injustice', nor 'justice-injustice'. Since these two matters—I mean Opposition (Tadadd) and Incompatibility (Munafah)—are two different meanings, we needed two different names to express them so ambiguity does not occur. A group defined the Opposite as 'That which if it occurs, the other is lifted.' This is an error, because this statement necessitates that Reclining is the opposite of Sitting, and Greenness the opposite of Redness. This is an error; rather, this is of Difference and Differentiation, not Opposition. The definition of the Opposite in reality is what we expressed just now. As for the state of the body which negates both Opposites together, regarding some Opposites and some Incompatibles, no name is known [for it] in most places. Like the state of the soul of an infant; it is not called righteous nor wicked, nor learned nor ignorant. Rather, all these states are negated from it by the particle 'No' (La). We say: The infant does not know anything; and the name of Ignorance is not applied to him except with the possibility of Knowledge. It is said the infant is 'not righteous nor wicked'; when he grows strong and bears both matters, one of them applies to him according to what appears from him. Like the stone; it is not said to be alive nor dead, but we negate both matters from it...
foot_note: 1. (1) Ethics of the Soul: See it in the Collection of Epistles of Ibn Hazm.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...by the particle 'No' or 'Not' (Laysa). We say: The stone is not alive nor dead. The dead is [not] alive, the black is [not] white, and the white is [not] black. That is not necessary [by nature], but according to what exists, but it is possible mostly and imaginable—if it were—[32v] how it would be in general. It may enter into impossibility in actuality due to types of Position preventing it by habit. As for Opposition (Taqabul), it is divided into two parts: Opposition in Nature and Opposition in Speech. That which is in Speech is Affirmation and Negation. We mean by Affirmation the establishing of a thing for a thing, like your saying: 'Zayd is speaking', 'Wine is forbidden', 'Zakat is obligatory on one who owns such and such amount among Muslims', 'The world is originated', 'Muhammad is the Messenger of God', and the like. Negation is the denial of a thing from a thing, like your saying: 'Zayd is not a prince', 'Musaylimah is not a prophet', 'Usury is not lawful', 'The world is not eternal', and the like. The wording of Affirmation and Negation may come as a lie if you affirm falsehood or deny truth. The difference between Affirmation and Negation is the introduction of particles of negation, which are 'La' (No), 'Laysa' (Is not), 'Ma' (Not), or particles that make verbs jussive in Arabic—without the meaning of condition—or make them accusative, which are 'Lam' (Did not) and its sisters, 'Lan' (Will not), and the like. It becomes Negation; or removing them, so it becomes Affirmation. As for that which is in Nature, it is divided into three parts: One is the opposition of Opposites and Incompatibles. The second is the opposition of the Related (Relation). The third is the opposition of Possession and Privation (Nullity). We have spoken before on Opposites, Incompatibles, and Relation sufficiently. Know that regarding two Opposites, the stability of each is by itself; likewise the Incompatibles. As for the Related pair, the stability of each is by the stability of the other, as we explained there. Therefore, each of the Opposites does not revolve upon the other, nor do the Incompatibles. As for the Related pair, each of them revolves upon its companion; we say: 'Double of the Half' and 'Half of the Double'. But we do not say 'Injustice of Justice', nor 'Justice of Injustice', nor 'Whiteness of Blackness', nor 'Blackness of Whiteness', nor 'Evil of Good', nor 'Good of Evil'. The meaning of Opposition is the existence of two things in specific ends necessitating that one implies the existence [or negation] of the other upon the ranks we mentioned; so it is as if one opposes the other. As for the opposition of Possession and Privation, that is like Sight (1) and its lack which is Blindness. For one of these revolves upon...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the other, and the other does not revolve upon it. The meaning of revolving is Relation; so we say 'Blindness of Sight' (blindness regarding sight), but we do not say 'Sight of Blindness'. Know that Possession is what does not revolve upon Privation—meaning it is not related to it—while Privation revolves upon Possession—meaning it is related to it (1). Privation (Nullity) is not a 'meaning', but the departure of a thing and its annulment. Nothing is counted as 'lacking' (privative) except what bears the possibility of the existence of what it lacks. Do you not see that the stone is not called 'blind' (lacking sight)? This was a meaning with us [33r] in which the Greek language was followed. As for the Arabic language, every state in which something is not present, the name of 'privation' of that thing is applied to it, whether it existed before that or not. Likewise, everything that 'is not' is called Privation (Non-existence) in it, whether its existence is imagined or not. However, the difference between Opposites and between Privation and Existence is that both Opposites have 'Iyyah' (Is-ness/Being)—meaning they are existent—and Existence has 'Iyyah'—meaning it is existent—while Privation has no 'Iyyah', meaning it has no existence. Know that Affirmation and Negation occur only in Propositions (Reports), and thereby Truth and Falsehood exist. The Philosophers mentioned here a thing (2) they called 'Being of a thing in a thing'. It is hardly limitable according to us, even if it is limited in Nature. We saw no reason to busy ourselves with it, as it is merely splitting hairs; such as their saying: The Species is in the Genus, and the Genus is in the Species, and the like, which has no power in perceiving truths, establishing proofs, and the quality of inference which is our goal in this book. They also mentioned a thing they described as 'Being of a thing with a thing' (Simultaneity). They arranged it into three parts: One is the being of a thing with a thing in Time; this is the familiar usage in language, since every two things in one time are 'together', meaning each is with the other. They also arranged in that the being of two Related things with one another, meaning with the half is the double, and with the double is the half. They also arranged in that the being of two Species together under one Genus, meaning equal in it, like the horse and donkey under the genus of Animal. All these parts return to Time and do not exit from it. They mentioned a thing they called 'Anteriority' (Qidam). This is a word used by the people of the Arabic language for what precedes the time of another...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...like their saying: 'The Sheikh (old man) is older (Aqdam) than the boy', and 'The state of Banu Umayya is older (Aqdam) than the state of Banu Abbas', and the like. As for the Theologians (Mutakallimun), they used it in reporting about creatures and the Creator Almighty, so they named the First One, Mighty and Majestic, 'Old' (Qadim).
