We prevent that and refuse it, and we do not remove 'Old' (Qadim) and 'Oldness' (Qidam) from their places in the Arabic language, nor do we describe the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, with it at all. He, Mighty and Majestic, said: 'Like the old date-stalk' (36 Ya-Sin: 39), meaning the worn-out one over which different times have passed by their prolongation. We place in the stead of this expression the word 'The First' (Al-Awwal), and the report that He, Almighty, never ceased to be, and that all other than Him—which are all creatures—were not, then were; and that everything other than Him Almighty is originated, created; and He is a Creator, First, One, Truth; there is no god but He. The Ancients mentioned things in 'Anteriority' that are not correct. Among them: 'The Genus is anterior to the Species by Nature' [33v], because it is mentioned in rank before it. This has no meaning because the Genus is the sum of its Species themselves; so a thing cannot be anterior to itself, nor is it permissible for the Whole to be anterior to its Parts. They also mentioned that 'The Introduction to Sciences is anterior to Sciences'. This is an error because Science exists in Nature—meaning in potentiality therein—before the entrant enters to seek it. They also mentioned 'Anteriority of Honor'. This is completely corrupt, unless it was in the Greek language. Some were deceived regarding this by the Arabic language in their saying: 'Faras 'Atiq' (Noble Horse), meaning old (Qadim). It is not so, because 'Atq' in Arabic is among Homonymous names; it applies to the Old, as in 'Old Wine'; and applies to the Good/Beautiful, as in 'Atiq al-Wajh' (Noble/Beautiful of face), and 'So-and-so has apparent nobility ('itq)', meaning apparent beauty. Upon this meaning they said 'Noble Horse'. It also applies to Freedom from ownership, so they say: 'So-and-so freed ('ataqa) his slave', and 'The slave is freed ('atiq)', meaning absolved from ownership. As for Cause and Effect (Ma'lul), it belongs to the category of Relation. It is not permissible for the Cause to precede the Effect at all. If it preceded it, there would be a time when it was not necessitating it; if that were so, it would not be a Cause...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...since the Cause is not a thing at all except the power necessitating the existence of what must exist by its existence. And by God Almighty is success. E - Chapter of Discourse on Motion (Harakah): Motion is divided into six parts: The first two parts are the motions of Generation (Kon) and Corruption (Fasad), which are in Substance. The meaning of Generation: "Its exit from Possibility and Non-existence to Necessity and Existence." This is a motion for the emerging Substance, not for its Originator who brought it forth, Mighty and Majestic. The meaning of Corruption: "Its exit from Existence and Necessity to Nullity and Non-existence." That is necessary in Accidents, and imaginable regarding Bodies if their Creator Almighty wills what He wills of them. Corruption, according to us in reality, is the separation of the body into many things, the departure of its accidents, and the occurrence of other accidents upon it. As for all Bodies (Matter), their essences are never non-existent in any way, but they transfer from attribute to attribute as He Almighty said: {Creation after creation} (39 Az-Zumar: 6), and from place to place, and from world to world, until the worshipped among them settle in the Abode of Bliss or Torment in the World of Recompense without end. These two motions occur in all Accidents because they are generating and corrupting. Then two other parts are the motion of Growth (Rabw) and Diminution (Idmihlal) [34r], and they belong to Quantity. Growth is: "The distancing (1) of the limits of the body from its center." Diminution is: "The approaching of the limits of the body to its center." These two only exist in Growing things. Growth is by food transforming into their type and spreading from their center to their extremities. Diminution is by the taking of a part of its moistures, more than what the body accepts of food. You see the tree, the animal, and the composite plant feed, so the food transforms into parts of the fed. In the animal, it transforms into blood, flesh, fat, bone, veins, arteries, nerves, hair, bristles, feathers, and skin; so that body extends, lengthens, widens, and bulges. Food for the tree transforms—from water and moistures of the earth and manure—into wood, bark, leaves, flowers, taste, gum, fronds, and twigs; and it extends and grows big as we mentioned. Likewise...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...in plants. Then when all that begins to diminish due to the end of its matter which its Creator arranged for it—from the moistures of the bodies we mentioned being [consumed] more than what it accepts of food—until the tree and plant dry up, the animal dies, its parts separate, and its soul returns to its world. This is the world in which we witnessed the Truthful One sent from the Creator Almighty, the Prophet, peace be upon him, during his journey and disposal in the world of the Spheres by the Divine Power specialized for him. It is what is between the beginning of the Spheres, which is the Sphere of the Moon, and the limit of the farthest of the four elements. May God grant us therein success, salvation, and rest, and save us from what the sinful rebels fall into. The rest of the bodily elements separate to their resting place which He Almighty arranged them in, until He gathers them all on the Day of Resurrection and returns them as He began them; there is no god but He. The parts of trees and plants also separate to their resting place of the four elements which are Fire, Air, Water, and Earth. So glory be to the Originator, the Composer, the Perfecter, the Disposer; there is no god but He. {Indeed in that is a sign for a people who know} (27 An-Naml: 52). {And how many a sign within the heavens and earth do they pass over while they, therefrom, are turning away} (12 Yusuf: 105). Then two remaining parts are Alteration (Istihala) and Locomotion (Naqla). Alteration is like the transformation of wine into vinegar; for the wine did not grow nor diminish, nor did its essence nor the essence of the vinegar originate [from nothing], nor did either of them cease to exist, nor did it move from place to place. Likewise the transformation of fire to air, air to fire, and some elements to others. We may find a square increase by a square, so it grows and increases but does not alter from squareness. As for Locomotion, it is [34v] the general, apparent motion, which is the change of places. These two parts are Quality. The incompatible of every motion is the Rest of the mover by it; so Rest in general is incompatible with Motion in general. Spatial Locomotion is divided into two parts: Voluntary and Natural. Voluntary is divided into two parts: One is the Creator Almighty moving what He wills of the bodies of the atmosphere where He wills Almighty—of wind, rain, and the like. It is a motion residing in the mentioned things and an influence in them. The second is the Soul moving what it possesses of bodies up and down, forward and backward, right and left; and the moving of every choosing body by its nature. Natural is divided into three parts: Motion from the center, meaning Up, like Fire and Air...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...always taking to rise, not taking down except by force and coercion. And Motion to the center, like the motion of Water and Earth; they never take except down seeking the center, and do not take up except by force and coercion. And Motion around the center, which is the motion of the Spheres and everything in them of bodies running on a customary, natural order, which is circular motion. This motion is divided into two parts: Either from East to West like the Highest Sphere in its essence; or from West to East like the Sun, Moon, Planets, and their spheres. Then they also differ in the state of their speed and slowness. Blessed be the Creator, the Disposer; there is no god but He. The Book of Qatighuriyas (Categories), which is the Book of Single Names, is completed by His power and strength. May God bless Muhammad and the family of Muhammad and grant peace.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: The Book of Reports (Propositions): It is the Nouns gathered with others, called "Composite." It is named in the Greek language "Peri Hermeneias" (On Interpretation). 1 - Sketch (Definition) of the Noun: The Noun is a sound established by agreement that does not indicate a specific time, and if its parts are separated, it does not indicate any of its meaning. By our saying "established by agreement," we mean a convention by the people of language regarding what they abbreviate of many meanings with a brief word indicating them. Like the agreement of the Arabs to name the grazer, long-necked, hump-backed, high-legged, short-tailed, taken for carrying and riding, a "Camel" (Ba'ir). And the agreement of non-Arabs to name it by another name. All those names indicate the animal we mentioned [35r] with a single indication. And so is every named thing for which a name was placed. Your saying "Camel" does not indicate a specific time—neither present, nor past, nor future. If you divided it and said "Ba'i," it would not indicate the meaning of Camel. Some ignorant people thought that there are names where a part of its parts indicates a part of its meaning, like your saying: "Abdullah" (Servant of God). For "Abd" indicates a meaning; know that the meaning "Abd" indicates is other than the meaning "Abdullah" indicates—meaning it does not indicate the meaning intended [by] naming a man Abdullah. Do you not see that you say regarding one whose name is Abdul Rahman: "This is not Abdul Rahman," or "This is Khalid" regarding one whose name is...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Khalid, and you would be truthful and correct; while the one naming him Abdullah [if asserting the meaning of servitude to God as a fact, not a name] would be lying and mistaken? If the intent in naming were to report that he is a servant of God, it would be [true] for Abdullah too, and you would be lying in your negation that he is 'Abdullah' [if denying servitude], and the one naming him Abdullah in testifying about him and reporting about him would be truthful, and there is no doubt in his lying [if the name is just a proper noun but the attribute is false]. What we mentioned is correct, and by God Almighty is success. It has appeared by the truth we explained that Descriptions and Reports all fall upon the Named Things (Meanings), not upon the Names, and that the Named Things are the Meanings, and Names are expressions for them. It is established by this that the Name is other than the Named. The error of those who thought otherwise among our companions who speak on Theology (Kalam) without verifying it—that the Name is the Named—has become clear. Some of them argued for their error with the saying of God Almighty: {Glorify the name of your Lord, the Most High} (87 Al-A'la: 1). This is a severe lapse from them. The explanation of that is that since there was no way to report about Named Things at all except by the mediation of expressions agreed upon for them, the Named Things were made the essence of those expressions, while the intent is [the entity] expressed by them. Since there was no way to praise God Almighty except by mentioning the Name expressing Him, one could not effectuate Praise, Commendation, and Glorification for Him Almighty except by the mediation of the Name. So He commanded us Almighty with what we are capable of, not what we are not capable of at all. The intent of Glorification is He Almighty, not the perishable, interrupted sound, non-existent after its existence, falling under the limit of Quantity in the type of Speech, as we presented. So know this. Among Names are Definite ones, which are Particulars, like your saying: Zayd, Amr, the man you know, Zayd's servant, the man's servant, my servant. And among them are Indefinite ones, which are Generals, like your saying: A man, a donkey. The Names that substitute for them are known in languages; some for the specific speaker (1), some for the present addressee, some for the one reported about (absent), and some for the one pointed [35v] to, like your saying: I, You, He, This. These are the ones named by Grammarians: Pronouns, Vagues (Demonstratives), and Metonymies. We have presented that they are the utmost Specificity and the most definite of Definites. 2 - Discourse on the Verb (Kalima): Philosophers mean by this word the thing Grammarians call "Attributes" (Verbs/Adjectives acting as verbs) and which...
foot_note: 1. (1) Lil-khas lil-mutakallim: Thus in original (For the specific speaker).

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Theologians call "Descriptions" (Sifat). When Grammarians define it, they say: It is a noun derived from a verb, like 'Sahha' (became healthy), 'Yasihhu' (becomes healthy), so he is 'Sahih' (healthy), and the like. The Ancients said: It indicates a specific time, because you say 'Sahha' (Past), 'Yasihhu' (Future/Present), so he is 'Sahih'. This is a report about his state Now, and that is a past and future action. This Verb (Kalima) is a sound established by agreement also, as we presented regarding the Noun; some of its parts do not indicate its meaning, except that it indicates a resident (static) time as we mentioned. They mentioned regarding your saying "Health" (Sihhah) that it is a Noun, not a Verb (Kalima). This is what Grammarians call the Infinitive/Source (Masdar). In reality, it is a name for safety from illnesses, except that it is divided into two parts: One is an action of an actor and a movement of a mover, like 'Beating' (Darb) from the Beater. The other is a description of a described, like 'Health' for the Healthy; it is carried in him and is one of his attributes. As for 'Healthy' and 'Beater', they are names of the one free from illness and the one moving by beating; they deserved them by their predicate and influence. We only mentioned these two words because they are the Subject of the Report and its Predicate, so they are two parts of the Report. Likewise, your saying 'Fa'ala' (Did) and 'Qa'ada' (Sat) are things established to express the influence appearing from bodies or in them. They are also part of the parts of the Report, like your saying: 'Zayd stood' (Qama Zayd), or your saying: 'Zayd is healthy' and 'Abdullah is departing'. The Report stands on two names: one is a name distinguishing the Reported About from others, which is the Subject (Mawdu'); and the second is a description distinguishing the Report About Him from others, which is the Predicate (Mahmul). 3 - Discourse on Speech (Statement/Qawl): The Ancients intended by the word 'Qawl' here every Report standing by itself. The least of that is a Noun and a Description (Verb/Adjective) as we presented. The mentioned Report: every part of it indicates a part of its meaning, contrary to single words. If you said 'Muhammad is a Prophet', 'Muhammad' indicated to you part of your intent by your saying: 'Muhammad is a Prophet'. The Report has followers which the Ancients named "Adjuncts" (Lawahiq) and "Connectives" (Rubut). Adjuncts are things added for clarification and emphasis, like your saying: 'The good mind belongs to Zayd', and 'The long, good hair [36r] belongs to So-and-so', and 'The people, all of them, came to me'. For your saying 'The good mind' are two names by which completion is not achieved, like your saying 'Zayd is standing'. The gathering of these two incomplete words was not like the judgment of gathering the two by which the meaning is completed. The Alif and Lam entering the Arabic language for definition, or what stands in their place in other languages, are among the Adjuncts...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...also, because all that is an explanation attached to the explained; therefore, these were named 'Adjunct Additions'. As for Connectives (Rubut), they are what Grammarians call 'Particles' (1) in meaning. They are words established for meanings connecting Noun and Noun, Noun and Description, and Reported About and Report. Like your saying: 'Zayd is in the house', and 'Zayd did not stand'. They are like prepositions such as: In (Fi), About ('An), From (Min), and others; and like particles of interrogation such as: Is (Hal), How (Kayfa), and the like. For you say: 'Did Zayd stand?' And likewise other particles connecting meanings. The benefit of these particles in expression is great, so their meanings in the language should be cultivated, as expression is not complete except with them, and they substitute for much lengthiness. Do you not see that you say 'Your brothers and your uncles came to me'? Were it not for the 'Waw' (And), you would need to isolate each of the two sentences and report about it that they came to you. A Statement (Qawl) may be composed of two words and not be complete, like your saying: 'If you come to me', or 'When Zayd dies'. If you said 'If you come to me, I will honor you', it would be [complete] speech. Or 'If Zayd dies, his movement ceases', it would be complete speech. The Report, as we presented, is either Affirmation or Negation. The Affirmation is either false or true, and the Negation is likewise. If the Report is complete as we mentioned, it is called a Proposition (Qadiyya). It is either true or false. Memorize this and remember it, for it will pass by you often, God Almighty willing. The Negative and Affirmative Proposition each is divided (2) into two parts: Either Suspended by a condition (Conditional) or Categorical (Cutting). The Conditional is like your saying: 'Whoever changes his religion to other than Islam, killing becomes necessary for him'; and your saying: 'If it is moving by will, it is alive'; and your saying: 'When the sun sets, it is night'. Know that 'Mata' (When), 'Ma' (What/Whatever), 'Idha ma' (Whenever), and all these particles—their ruling is one in conditioning and suspending the Predicate on the Subject therein. If you want to make these propositions with a wording of negation, you say: 'Whoever changes his religion, it is not permissible to spare him unless he accepts Islam'; 'If it is moving by will, it is not dead' [36v]; and 'If the sun sets, it is not day'. As for the Categorical, it is that you say: 'Every human is a substance', or that you say: 'The five prayers are obligatory on whoever is addressed by them'. Negation is by inserting 'La' (No), 'Laysa' (Is not), 'Ma' (Not), or...
foot_note:
1. (1) Hurufan: Read *Harfan*. 
2. Tanqasim kull wahidah: Read *Yanqasim kull wahid*.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the particles we mentioned that make verbs jussive without condition or make them accusative. If you insert one of these particles on a false proposition, the negation becomes true. 'A god other than God' [exists] is a false proposition; 'There is no god but God' is true. If you insert these particles on a true proposition, you would be lying. This is what the Ancients named 'Privation and Affirmation' (Salb wa Ijab), because these particles strip (negate) what you affirmed in your wording upon which you inserted them. For every Affirmative there is one Negative, and that is only by inserting a particle of negation particles we mentioned or removing it only. By God Almighty is success. Know that every proposition where an exception occurs in the first of its knot (structure) is Conditional. The Conditional is of two types: Either Conjunctive (Muttasil) or Separating Disjunctive (Muqassim Fasil). The Conjunctive is what necessitates the connection of a thing to another thing that only exists by its existence. It is of two types: Either Affirmative like your saying: 'If the sun sets, it is night', or Negative (1) like your saying: 'If the sun does not rise, it is not day'. Do you not see that you connected the existence of day [to the existence] of sunrise and linked it to it, and connected the existence of night [to the existence] of sunset and linked it to it? As for the Separating Disjunctive, it is what comes with a wording of doubt—even if it is not doubt—but is a judgment for the Subject with one of the divisions of Predicates. That is like your saying: 'The world is either originated or eternal'. If you wish, you bring the word 'Aw' (Or); except that the word 'Imma' (Either), if you cut and divide, is clearer than the word 'Aw'. If you are deciding interrogatively, if you wish you bring the word 'Am' (Or/Is it), and if you wish the word 'Aw'. You say: 'Is the world originated or (Aw) eternal?' If you wish you say: 'Or (Am) eternal?'. The divisions of this type—I mean the Disjunctive—may be more than two parts. That depends on the division fulfilling all that it bears in the mind. This is a place where error becomes great if a flaw or lack occurs in the division. So guard against it with extreme caution. If you are questioned, contemplate: Did your questioner leave out a part of the parts of his question? Alert to it, for you must err by necessity if you answer [an incomplete division]. If you are a questioner, do not satisfy yourself with this, for it is of the ignorant or those of base character who mislead their opponents, satisfied with overcoming the moment without perceiving truths. Know [37r] that if the Predicate is one and the Subjects are many, they are many propositions, like your saying: 'The Angel, Man, and Jinn are living'. These are three propositions. And if...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the Subject is one and the Predicates are many, it is one proposition [containing many], like your saying: 'The soul of man is living, rational, mortal, shining upon a body accepting color, upright in stature.' If you separated all that, they would be different propositions. Know that speech is not called a Proposition until it is complete, whether long or short. Like your saying: 'The human composed of a body accepting color and a living rational mortal soul moves his hand with a body having a sharp tip, and in its tip is a fluid body differing from the color of the surface of the body in his hand, writing on that surface lines whose meanings are understood.' All this is equal to your saying: 'A writing human.' Know that propositions are either Binary—which is composed of a Subject and Predicate as we presented—or more than Binary, which is adding an attribute or a time. You say: 'Muhammad was yesterday a minister', and 'Amr is a rational man'. You may also add to this by adding another benefit, which is adding to the proposition: either its Necessity inevitably, or its Possibility, or that it is Impossible to be. If you add to the proposition—which is Reported About and Report—another attribute as we mentioned, that is permissible. The addition you added becomes your goal in the Report; meaning it becomes the Predicate and the Report together, and the Predicate and Subject—which were the Reported About and the Report together—become Subject and Reported About only. Like your saying: 'Zayd is departing'. If you added and said: 'The departing Zayd is generous', or 'Zayd is a generous departer', then your saying 'Zayd is departing' becomes a Subject—meaning Reported About—and your saying 'Generous' becomes the Predicate, meaning it is the Report. The same applies to Negation with no difference. Know that propositions are either Indefinite (Neglected/Muhmala), Singular (Makhsusa), or Quantified (Dhawatu Aswar). The Singular is what is a report about a single person or specific individuals, not about their entire species by negation or affirmation. Like your saying: 'Zayd is not departing', 'Your brothers are not generous', 'So-and-so is a Caliph', and 'Amr is alive'. Know that this section which we named Singular, no general demonstration rises from it; so guard against that. The explanation of this saying will come in the book following this book, God Almighty willing. As for the Quantified, they are divided into two parts in Affirmation and two parts in Negation. The two parts of Affirmation are either Universal or Particular. The Universal is what occurred with a word of [37v] generality, like your saying: 'All' (Kull), or 'Entire' (Jami'), or 'Not one [is not]', and the like. The Particular is what occurred with a word of...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...partition (partiality), like your saying: 'Some' (Ba'd), or 'A part' (Juz'), or 'A faction' (Ta'ifah), or 'A piece', and the like. The two parts of Negation are inserting negation particles upon these two parts. These names [which] give certain Generality or certain Partiality are named 'Walls' (Quantifiers/Aswar) because they are like the wall surrounding it in its circle or other shape. From this—I mean the Quantified—the correct Demonstration rises, as will come after this, God Almighty willing. By them occurs the compulsion by which truths become clear. Like your saying: '[Every] human is living', and 'All people are living', or 'Not one of humans is braying', and 'Not one of humans is neighing'. Or your saying: 'Some people are writers', or 'A faction of Muslims are doctors', and the like. And like your saying in negation: 'Not some people are stones' (Some people are not stones), and the like. As for the Indefinite (Neglected/Muhmala), it is that which has none of the Quantifiers we mentioned. In the Arabic language, the Indefinite may substitute for the Quantified. That is because it is a word applying to the Genus or Species, like your saying: 'The Living (Animal) is sensing', or 'Man is living'. This word, if you do not mean a specific one by it, there is no difference between your saying 'Man is living' and your saying 'Every man is living'. The truth in that, upon strong examination, is that you contemplate the Indefinite proposition and look at its predicate. If it cannot be but general, the Subject is Universal. If it cannot be general, the proposition is Particular. What clarifies this is that if you uttered the Indefinite and said: 'Man is a rational mortal animal', 'Man is laughing', no one would deny that. But if you said: 'Man is a doctor in actuality', 'Man is a weaver in actuality', every listener would deny that upon you and call you a liar, because the attribute is particular. Likewise, if you said: 'Doctors are do-gooders', every listener would call you a liar because 'Doctors' is general, and 'Do-gooders' are [only] some doctors without doubt. When you carried a particular attribute upon the Indefinite, souls denied it. Know that the Quantifier is only permissible to be placed before the Subject—meaning before the Reported About—not before the Predicate, which is the Report. Because if you said: 'Every human is living', you spoke truth. If you said: 'Human is every living', you lied. It is only permissible to join the Universal Quantifier with the Predicate if it is a Definition or Description, like your saying: 'The soul of man is every living rational [thing] thereof possessing a colored body'. Or if you said: 'Man is every laughing [thing]'. Or if the Quantifier is Particular, like your saying: 'Man is some living [thing]'.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: 4 - Chapter on Elements (Modes/Maddah): [38r] Know that the elements of all things—meaning their divisions regarding reporting about them—are three parts with no fourth: Either Necessary (Wajib), which is what has become necessary and appeared, or what is such that its being is inevitable, like the rising of the sun every morning and the like. This is called in Laws (Shari'ah): 'The Obligatory and Binding'. Or Possible (Mumkin), which is what may differ and may not differ (may be or may not be), like our expectation that it rains tomorrow and the like. This is called in Law: 'The Lawful and Permissible'. Or Impossible (Mumtani'), which is what there is no way to, like a human remaining under water for a full day, or living a month without eating, or walking in the air without a trick, and the like. These are what, if they appear from a human, we know he is a Prophet. This section is called in Laws: 'The Forbidden and Prohibited'. Then the Possible is divided into three parts with no fourth: Close Possible, like the possibility of rain falling when clouds thicken in the months of Kanun (December/January), and the victory of a large number of brave men over a small number of cowards. Far Possible, like the defeat of a large number of brave men by a small number of cowards, and like a cupper becoming Caliph, and the like. Pure Possible (Equal), where its two ends are equal, like a standing man: either he walks or [sits], and the like. Likewise, we find this middle section in Laws divided into three parts: Permissible Recommended (Mustahabb), Permissible Disliked (Makruh), and Level Permissible (Mustawin) having no inclination to either direction. As for the Permissible Recommended, it is that which if you do it you are rewarded, and if you leave it you do not sin nor are rewarded, like praying two Rak'ahs as voluntary worship. As for the Permissible Disliked, it is that which if you do it you do not sin nor are rewarded, and if you leave it you are rewarded; that is like eating while reclining and the like. As for the Level Permissible, it is that which [if] you do it or leave it, you do not sin nor are rewarded; that is like dyeing your clothes whatever color you wish, and riding whatever mount you wish, and the like. The wording expressing the Possible may come in ways: Some of it comes with the wording of Affirmation, like your saying: 'It is possible that this sick person dies'. It may come with the wording of Doubt, so you say: 'This sick person either dies or lives', and 'This pomegranate is either sweet or sour'. It may come...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...with a wording of Negation, so you say: 'This sick person is not impossible to recover'. Know that every Possible, you describe it with two contraries together: one in Potentiality and the other in Actuality. Like your saying: 'The sitter is a stander'—meaning he is sitting in Actuality, standing in Possibility. Know that the Necessary is before the Possible, because the Necessary is the Existent, while the Possible has not come yet. As for the Impossible, it is false because it does not exist nor appear. Know that the Necessary is divided into two parts: One [38v] is what was known before its being that it must be, like the rising of the sun tomorrow, or everything that has always been inherent and necessary since it existed, like the inherence of composition to bodies. The second is what was, before necessity, not decided that it would be, like the recovery of the sick or his death. Know that the Impossible is divided into four parts: One is Relative Impossibility. It is either in a time and not a time, or in a place and not a place, or from a substance and not a substance, or in a state and not a state. Like the necessity of elephants being widespread in India and their being, until now, impossible to be widespread in the land of the Slavs. And like the necessity of beardlessness during a person's fulfilling fourteen years, or the impossibility of a beard in that period, and its necessity after its existence. And like the necessity of a man—who is not breathing his last nor fainting—lifting light pounds, and the impossibility of his carrying a thousand pounds. And like the impossibility of the weak carrying five hundred pounds, and the necessity of the strong carrying them. And like the possibility of the intelligent diving into obscurities and creating good poetry, and the impossibility of that from the stupid, dull (1), idiotic nature. This is one aspect. The second is Habitually Impossible definitively. It is formable in the soul's sense and its place—if it were, how it would be—like the transformation of inanimate objects into animals, the invention of bodies without generation, and the speech of inanimate objects. This section is by which the Prophethood of the Prophet, peace be upon him, is validated if it appears from him, while there is no way to it for others. The third is Rationally Impossible, like a man being standing and sitting in one state, and like a body being in two places, and like the transformation of the Eternal into originated or the Originated into eternal, or the existence of many eternal things. This generally includes everything that contradicts the Primaries known by Primary Reason. This is what there is no way to its existence at all, nor does the Creator ever do it, nor does it happen at all. In it is the corruption of the structure of the world and the breaching of the ranks of intellects which are the causes of knowing truths. And the words of...
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Balid: The text says *Al-Ba'id* (Far/Remote), but implies Stupid/Dull.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...your Lord have been fulfilled in truth and justice; none can alter His words. The fourth is Absolute (Unrestricted) [Impossibility], like every question necessitating a change in the Essence of the Creator. This is the Impossible that contradicts itself and its beginning invalidates its end. This is like the question of one who asks: Can God Almighty create His like? And similar to this. Know it, for it does not happen primarily at all. Know that there is no division for the propositions of the world other than what we mentioned at all. The word expressing the Necessary may come with the wording of Negation and with the wording of Affirmation. The word expressing the Impossible may come with the wording of Negation and may also come with the wording of Affirmation. There is no way for them to come with a wording of doubt. You say: 'It is necessary that the sun rises tomorrow', and 'It is impossible that it does not rise tomorrow'. And you say: 'It is necessary that cold is not found in fire', and 'It is impossible [39r] that cold is found in fire'. A group said the Elements are two: Necessary and Impossible only. They said: There is no Possible at all, because the thing you call Possible is Impossible before its existence, and after its existence it is Necessary; so there is no third. They said: What is absent from us is either in God's knowledge that it will be, or that it will not be. If God Almighty knew it will be, it is now Necessary to be. If He Almighty knew it will not be, it is now Impossible to be. We say: This is a corrupt judgment. As for their argument now that a thing before its being is Impossible, it is an error; rather, in Potentiality and in Conjecture, perhaps it has been and perhaps it has not been. As for their argument by God's knowledge, God Almighty has commanded and forbidden. If the thing God commanded were not yet imagined to be in the commanded person, there would be no meaning to the Command. The imagined-to-be is the Possible. Actions of choosing agents before their being fall into the section of Possible, contrary to actions of Nature. Then we say: Sense and Reason have established that there is a difference between the walking of the sitter who is healthy in limbs and body, not prevented, and the walking of the paralyzed whose legs are invalidated. This is a difference between the Possible and the Impossible. Likewise, there is a clear difference between the sitting of the healthy person we mentioned—who if he wills leaves it, he leaves it—and the sitting of the paralyzed who if he sought his utmost to leave it, he could not. This is a difference between the Possible and the Impossible. It is obligatory that we compel those who say...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...contrary to our saying, that he should not prepare for hunger if it afflicts him by eating food, because if his term has ended, it is Necessary that he dies, and if his term has not ended, it is Impossible that he dies. He should throw himself into fires if it is in the Unseen that he will not burn, so it is Impossible that he burns. It implies for our opponent that his preparation, thought, and striving in defending himself against cold, thirst, and harm is like his preparation to stop the movement of the Sphere or to prevent the sun from rising. We only debate people to return them to the mandate of Reason or Sense, or to compel them to exit the ranks of Reason and [enter] the stubborn denial of Sense. If they exit to what we mentioned, they have spared us the trouble with them. It becomes obligatory on us to turn away from them and leave them wishing for delusions and rejoicing in falsehoods like drunkards and children deceived by their states, happy with their actions. We busy ourselves with what is obligatory on us of clarifying truths to those seeking them. We only speak with rational, distinguishing souls, not with tongues only, nor with silly souls. 5 - Discourse on Affirmation and Privation (which is Negation), its Ranks and Aspects: The Negation that provides a meaning, and by which you negate what your opponent affirmed, its rule is to be for the Predicate, not [39v] for the Subject. Because you establish the Name then affirm an attribute for it or negate it from it. If you negated the Subject—which is the Name reported about—you would not obtain a meaning to report about. Like your saying: 'Not Zayd is departing' (La Zayd Munṭaliq); because the appearance of this wording is the negation of Zayd and the negation of departing with him. The Ancients call such a thing 'An Infinite (Indefinite) Proposition' (Ghayr Muhassala). The correct way is to say: 'Zayd is other than departing' (Ghayr Muntaliq) or 'is not departing' (Laysa Munṭaliqan). Thus, you would have established Zayd and negated departing from him. The Ancients call this a 'Metathetic Proposition' (Ma'dulah) and 'Changed in the Predicate' because you changed it from Affirmation. So be guarded in this place. The least in that is that you answer one of the two aspects of speech—which are either negating the Reported About entirely or negating the Attribute from it—so you become an answerer before verifying the question and correcting it, thus deficiency of understanding and injustice in judgment stick to you. If you want to negate what your opponent affirmed with a complete, correct negation, you must [know] that you only want to refute some of it or refute all of it. If you want to refute some of it, clarify that. And if...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...if you want to refute all of it, your speech must combine eight conditions; otherwise, it is not a complete refutation. The first is: The Subject in what he affirmed and in what you negated must be one. If it is two, chaos (sophistry) occurs. That is like a speaker saying: 'The Existent is originated (Muhdath)', and the other says: 'The Existent is not originated'. This is a corruption in the structure of speech, and neither speech is a refutation of the other, because the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, is Existent and is not originated, while the World is existent and is originated. Something like this happened to our companions among the Sunnis and the Mu'tazila; they engaged in much dispute and discussion until they accused each other of disbelief. The Mu'tazila said: 'The Quran is created', meaning the knowledge of the Creator, Mighty and Majestic. The second: The Predicate which one of you affirmed must be the [same] Predicate the other negated, not another at all. That is like a speaker saying: 'Zayd is knowledgeable ('Alim)', and the opponent says: 'Zayd is not knowledgeable'. If one meant knowledgeable in Grammar and the other meant knowledgeable in Jurisprudence, their propositions do not contradict. The third: The part of the Subject upon which the judgment settled must be one in both propositions, not another. Like a speaker saying: 'Zayd is black', meaning black of hair, and the other says: 'Zayd is not black', meaning the [skin] color or the eye. The fourth: The part of the Predicate in the two propositions must be one, not different. Like a speaker saying: 'Zayd is weak', and the other says: 'Zayd is not weak'. One means weakness of the body by general constitution, and the other negates weakness of the body by disease which is a part of the parts of [40r] weakness. The fifth: The Time in which one of them affirmed what he affirmed must be the Time in which the other negated what he affirmed, this and no other. Like a speaker saying: 'Zayd is a writer'—meaning has written [in the past or potentially]—and [the other] says: 'Zayd is not writing now'. The sixth: The State (Condition) in which he affirmed what he affirmed must be the State in which the other negated what he affirmed, this and no other. Like a speaker saying: 'The infant is a knight (rider)', meaning in potentiality and capability in constitution, and the other says: 'The infant is not a knight', meaning in actuality in the state of infancy. The seventh: The relation of the thing he affirmed and the relation of the thing his opponent negated must be to one thing, not to two things. Like a speaker saying: 'Zayd is a servant ('Abd)', and the other says: 'Zayd is not a servant'. One means to God Almighty, and the other means negating that he is owned by a human. Similar to that: 'The sword cuts', and your opponent: 'The sword does not cut', one meaning this meat, and the other meaning this stone. The eighth: The two propositions must be...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...equal in Substance or in Accident, not different. Like a speaker saying: 'Zayd is moving', and his opponent says: 'Zayd is not moving'. They are both reporting about a sitter in a sailing ship; he is moving by accident—meaning by the ship's moving him—while he is not moving by his essence, rather he is static. In general, inspect your opponent's speech. If in your speech which you want to affirm or negate there is a meaning contradicting what he judged with affirmation or negation, clarify it. Do not contradict anything of his meanings except with the particle of negation only; otherwise, you would be a riotous obstructor or an ignoramus. These are the conditions of the Contradictory (Naqid). Universal Negation—which is your negating the attribute from the entire species, or your negating the entire attribute from some of the species—you utter [it] with a wording whose appearance resembles the Particular. Because if you wanted Universal Negation, which is General, you said: 'Not one of humans is neighing', 'Not any of humans is neighing', 'Not one of horses is speaking', and 'No speech is in this horse'. Particular Negation, which is your negating the attribute from some of the species not all of it, you utter with a particular wording and with a universal wording. Because you say: '[Not] some people are writers [?]' (1). The meaning of these two wordings is one with no difference; the appearance of one is Generality and the appearance of the second is Particularity. Universal Affirmation, which is your affirming the attribute for the entire species, is only with a universal wording: either with a Quantifier as we presented, or Indefinite intended for Generality. Like your saying: 'Every human is living', or 'All people are living', or you say 'Human is living' and you do not mean a specific single person, or you say 'People are living' and you do not mean some of them. Particular Affirmation, which is your affirming the attribute for some of the species, is never except with a particular wording, like your saying: 'Some people are writers'. Understand this rank and be firm in it. Some [40v] of the predecessors said that if a speaker brings an Indefinite proposition saying: 'Human is a writer', the first thing coming to the soul is that his intent by that is some of the species, not all of it. As for us, we say: This saying is incorrect. These Indefinites—meaning words that come in the language sometimes for the whole species, sometimes for the single person, and sometimes for a group of the species—if the speaker using them does not clarify that he intended a single person of the species, or some of the species excluding some, or if a necessary or accepted or agreed-upon demonstration between opponents is not established for that, it is not permissible to carry it upon the generality of the entire species because words...
foot_note: 1. (1) [?] Here is a deficiency; Particular Negation with a Universal wording is estimated.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...were only established for understanding, not for confusion. Every word expresses its meanings and necessitates all that is understood from it. It is not permissible to task the addressee with understanding some of what the word necessitates without the rest, since [that] is not in the power of nature at all. Rather, this is of the Impossible to which there is no way, and of the category of divination, unless by agreement between them or additional clarification. Otherwise, it is sophistry, rioting, and prolongation with what does not benefit nor verify a meaning. Some predecessors named the speaker's saying: 'Every human is living', and the opponent's saying: 'Not every human is living', as 'Contrary' (Didd). And they named the speaker's saying: 'Every human is living', and the other's saying: 'Not some people are living' (No human is living/Some people are not living - context suggests contradictories), as 'Contradictory' (Naqid). He mentioned that the Contradictory is stronger in disparity than the Contrary. He argued saying that the first two propositions which we named Contrary are both Universal; one is Affirmative and the other is Negative. The other two propositions which we named Contradictory, one is Universal and the second is Particular; one is Affirmative and the second is Negative. The first two only differed in one direction which is Quality only—meaning Affirmation and Negation—while they agree in Quantity—meaning both are Universal. The other two differed in two directions: One is Quality, meaning Affirmation and Negation like the difference of the Contrary proposition; and the second is Quantity, meaning one is Universal and the second is Particular. He said: What differed in two directions is more disparate than what differed in one direction. We say: This is an error. The speaker only observed the appearance of the wording without the reality of the meaning. This speaker's judgment, even if truthful in the number of aspects of difference, is a false judgment regarding the intensity of difference. Had he said: 'It was stronger [or] more', it would have been true. Rather, we say: That which is called Contrary, we call 'General Negation' or if you wish 'General Contradictory'; [it is] more disparate than [41r] the other which we call 'Specific Contradictory' or if you wish 'Specific Negation'. Because the speaker of the first negated all that the other affirmed and belied him in all he narrated, leaving no meaning of the meanings of his proposition except he opposed him in it and disparated him in all of it. As for the second, its speaker only negated some of what the other affirmed and withheld from the rest of the proposition; he did not negate it nor affirm it, nor did he oppose him in it nor agree with him. He only disparated him in part of his proposition, not in all of it. The disparater in all is stronger in opposition than the disparater in part. If your opponent brings you an Indefinite premise, decide with him its meaning: Did he intend Generality or Specificity? Meaning, does he carry it on the Whole or some of what the word he spoke necessitates?

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Guard against neglecting this chapter. If you judge a proposition and your opponent negates it, contemplate: If what you affirmed and he negated is of those having intermediates, verify with him to clarify what he intended. Like your saying: 'Zayd is white', and he says: 'Zayd is not white'. It does not bind him by this saying that Zayd is black; perhaps he intended that he is red or yellow. An example of this in Laws (Sharia) is that you say: 'Such matter is forbidden (Haram)', and your opponent says: 'It is not forbidden'; or you say: 'Such matter is obligatory (Wajib)', and your opponent says: 'It is not obligatory'. In his saying 'It is not forbidden', it does not bind him that it is obligatory; nor in his saying 'It is not obligatory' that it is forbidden. Rather, perhaps he intended that it is merely permissible (Mubah). As for those without intermediates, do not care (1) about this. Because if you said: 'Zayd is living', and your opponent said: 'He is non-living', he has necessitated that he is dead by necessity, and there is no intermediate here. Death is bound to him by his saying. Look, the meaning of Negation may be in the wording of Affirmation, except that this is not a general condition the soul trusts, but is in one place and not another. Because you say: 'So-and-so is dead', and your opponent says: 'So-and-so is writing' or 'So-and-so is alive'; this is a correct meaning in negating death, but do not trust this. For if you said: 'So-and-so is reclining', and your opponent says: 'So-and-so is sitting', you might both be lying if the reported about is standing. The reality of Negation is where one is true and the other is false. If you want the reality of Negation and the removal of ambiguity, there is no escape from one of the particles of negation we mentioned before, so you are safe from error. For this reason, the predecessors said: Every Affirmative has one Negative, and every Negative has one Affirmative; meaning that is only by inserting the particle of negation only. [41v] 6 - Chapter on the Divisions of Propositions regarding Truth and Falsehood: Since we mentioned that the elements of Reports are three—meaning their division is three: Necessary, Possible, or Impossible—let us mention, God Almighty willing by His success to us, the modes of division of Affirmative and Negative propositions regarding Truth and Falsehood in these sections. We say, and by God Almighty we seek help: General Negation and General Affirmation are divided into Truth and Falsehood by necessity in...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the element of Necessity. The Affirmative is true (Haqq), and the Negative is always false (Batil). Like your saying: 'Every human is living'; this is true, and its negation is false if you said: 'Not one of humans is living'. This is a matter that never betrays you, so grasp it. Likewise in the element of Possibility. For your saying: 'Every human is a writer', if you meant in potentiality [it is true]. But if you meant in actuality, the two General propositions, Affirmative and Negative, are always false in it. Like your saying: 'Every human is a writer'—meaning proficient in writing—or your saying: 'Not one of humans is a writer'; both are false. As for the element of Impossibility, the Negative is always true, and the Affirmative is always false. Like your saying: 'Every human is braying'; this is false. If you said: 'Not one of humans is braying', this is true. Then let us speak on Specific Negation and Specific Affirmation, God Almighty willing. We say, and by God we are supported, that the propositions of Specific Negation and Specific Affirmation in the element of Necessity share Truth and Falsehood by necessity. Because you say: 'Some people are living', that is true; and its negation 'Not some people are living' is false. As for the element of Impossibility, they also share Truth and Falsehood, in that your saying 'Some people are stones' is false, and its negation 'Some people are not stones' is true. So the Negative is always true in this section, and the Affirmative is false in it. As for the element of Possibility, both are true by necessity. That is your saying: 'Some people are writers'—you mean in actuality—is true; and its negation 'Some people are not writers'—you mean in actuality—is true. Then let us speak on General Affirmation and Specific Negation. We say, and by God Almighty we are supported: The propositions of General Affirmation and Specific Negation in the element of Affirmation [Necessity?] share Truth and Falsehood by necessity. For your saying: 'All people are living' is true; and its negation: 'Not all people are living' (or 'Some people are not living') is false. So the Affirmative is always true and the Negative is false. As for the element of Possibility, they also share Truth and Falsehood. For your saying 'All people are writers', you mean in actuality, is false; and its negation 'Not all people [42r] are writers' or 'Some people are not writers', you mean in actuality, is true. So the Affirmative is false and the Negative is true. As for the element of Impossibility, they also share Truth and Falsehood by necessity. Like your saying: 'Every human is braying' is false; and its negation 'Not all people are braying' or 'Some people are not braying' is true. So the Affirmative is false and the Negative is true. Then let us speak on Specific Affirmation and General Negation. By God Almighty we are supported:

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: The propositions of Specific Affirmation and General Negation in the element of Necessity share Truth and Falsehood by necessity. For your saying 'Some people are living' is true, and its negation 'Not one of humans is living' is false. So the Affirmative is true and the Negative is false. As for the element of Possibility, it is likewise also, because your saying: 'Some people are writers' is true, and its negation 'Not one of humans is a writer' is false. So the Affirmative is true and the Negative is false. As for the element of Impossibility, it is likewise also, because your saying: 'Some people are stones' is false, and its negation 'Not one of humans is a stone' is true. So the Negative is true and the Affirmative is false. Ponder this division, for you will see a fine rank that will never betray you. Grasp: That we meant by our saying—in what preceded for us—"General" what the Ancients call "Universal," and what we said regarding it "Specific" is what the Ancients call "Particular." Know that Generality in Negation and Affirmation in the element of Possibility are always true [Note: Text might mean Particularity or the combination]. Know that the General Affirmative in the element of Necessity is always true. Know that the General Negative in the element of Necessity is always false. Know that the Specific Affirmative in the element of Necessity is always true. Know that the Specific Negative in the element of Necessity is always false. Know that the General Affirmative in the element of Possibility is always false. Know that the General Negative in the element of Possibility is always false. Know that the Specific Affirmative in the element of Possibility is always true. Know that the General Affirmative in the element of Impossibility is always false. Know that the General Negative in the element of Impossibility is always true. Know that the Specific Affirmative in the element of Impossibility is always false. Know that the Specific Negative in the element of Impossibility is always true. Included in what we mentioned just now is a matter in which a group of people erred, so their error became great and very obscene. That is, they estimated that the speaker saying: 'Some people are not braying', has necessitated braying for the rest of them [42v]. They thought it a false proposition. This is a lie from them and a corrupt, bad, false thought producing for them results of great obscenity. Because he did not report about the rest of them with a report at all—neither that they bray nor that they do not bray. We do not know if he reported, whether he would report...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...falsehood or truth until he reports; then we would know the attribute of his report. But now he has been truthful in his negating braying from some of them, a correct, certain truthfulness, and he remained silent about the rest. It does not bind the one who reported about some of the Species with a report general to it and general to the rest of its species that he must report about the rest of the Species unless he wishes to report. Silence is not speech; whoever is silent has not spoken. Do not judge anyone by his silence as a judgment that is only known by speech, except where the Sharia has passed judgment regarding what became—by command—outside the known customary practice only. That is only in two places with no third: One is the Prophet's approval, peace be upon him, of what he saw. The second is the silence of the virgin [in marriage consent]. Whoever spoke has not remained silent. Do you not see that whoever said 'Zayd's soul is living, rational, mortal' is truthful? If the opinion of this thinker whose error we invalidated were true, the speaker saying 'Zayd's soul is living, rational, mortal' would be a liar, because according to the judgment of these ignorant people, he would be affirming for the rest of people's souls the contrary of what he reported about Zayd's soul. This is what no rational person thinks. If this were so, all Singular Propositions would be false—meaning every report about an individual would be false, since it implies for them that the rest of his species is contrary to that. Since this is stubborn denial of sense, what we said first is correct: that the reporter stating that 'Some people are not donkeys' is truthful. The negation of what is negated is more worthy of truth in it than the affirmation of what is affirmed. It does not bind him that he be thought to have necessitated donkey-ness for the rest of the remaining species he was silent about. Rather, the rest of the species is suspended on what it is upon—meaning it has the judgment that became necessary for it by other than this proposition which judged some of it. This is what many of those who spoke in the science of Sharia erred in regarding "Dalenat al-Khitab" (Implication of Address/Inverse Implication), judging corrupt propositions by it. Likewise, whoever reported a Possible thing saying: 'Some people are writers' or 'Zayd is not a writer', there is not in it that the rest of people are not writers, nor that whoever is other than Zayd is a writer. His saying does not necessitate what we mentioned regarding what he was silent about at all. Rather, the judgment of the rest is taken from other proofs and propositions other than this. If what these heedless people thought were true, it would be necessary by necessity that the saying [43r] of the speaker: 'Zayd is a writer' is a lie, since that necessitates according to their judgment that all people except him are [not] writers. Since both matters are false, the judgment for all they mentioned is invalid. Since...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the speaker saying: 'Zayd is not a writer', and the speaker saying: 'Amr is a writer', and the speaker saying: 'Khalid is alive', and the speaker saying: 'Abdullah is not a stone' are truthful, and all that did not necessitate a judgment on other than those mentioned—neither by agreement nor by difference—what we said became correct: that the Proposition only gives you its specific concept, and what is beyond it is suspended on its proof. The saying of one who said: 'What is beyond it is outside its judgment' is false, and the saying of one who said: 'What is beyond it is inside its judgment' is also false. By God Almighty is success. Let no thinker think that this is a refutation of what we said in our books on Religious Rulings: that the ruling by which the First One Almighty judged on the tongue of the one He sent as a Messenger to us regarding an individual of a species is binding on the entire species, unless it is clarified that He specialized that individual with it. We also said that it is not binding on other than that species at all, except by a statement indicating that it is in other species. Whoever thinks this thought about our speech has missed understanding our saying. The explanation of that is that the number of individuals is infinite according to us, as we presented at the beginning of this register. There is no way to encompass every individual among them with an address specific to him, since they are originating generation after generation. The Messenger, peace be upon him, is sent to judge in every individual and upon every individual that originates forever until the end of the World of Testing. So if he, peace be upon him, judged regarding an individual with a ruling and did not inform us that he specialized him with it nor that individual was singled out by a speech specializing him, it was like his ruling on the part (some) which was in his era, and that was applicable by accepted premises to every originating individual forever. It suffices for the invalidity of this objection that nothing of his speech, peace be upon him, came isolated except that a clear, general explanation came with it for whoever is other than that individual and what is other than it forever. This is not the place to discuss that; we only alerted to it so that one who encounters it among those who hold our view does not become confused. By God Almighty is success. Know that your saying: 'All people are living' and the saying of the one debating you: 'Some people are living' is not a contradiction to your saying. Likewise if he said: 'Zayd is alive'. Rather, this is 'Following' (Tatali/Subalternation) in Affirmation, because he followed you and verified some of your saying, and did not contradict you in the rest nor agreed with you, but withheld from it. Likewise if you said: 'All people are not stones', and he said: 'Some people are not stones', he did not contradict you, but followed in Negation—meaning pursued. It is only a contradiction if you said: 'All people are living', and he said 'Not one of humans is living', or said: 'Some people are not...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...living'. This is a difference (Opposition) [43v]; one is General Negation and the second is Specific Negation. As for Singular Propositions—which report about a single person—they always share Truth and Falsehood in the Necessary, Possible, and Impossible. As for the Necessary, the Affirmative is always true and the Negative is false, like your saying: 'Zayd is alive' / 'not alive'. As for the Impossible, the Affirmative is always false and the Negative is true, like your saying: 'Zayd is a stone' / 'not a stone'. As for the Possible, however the reality of the report agrees with the attribute of the reported person—like your saying: 'Zayd is a doctor' / 'Zayd is not a doctor'—the one that agrees with his attribute is true, either the Affirmative or the Negative, and the one that contradicts his attribute is false, either the Affirmative or the Negative. 7 - Chapter on Mentioning the Position of Negation: Know that it is obligatory to observe, if you want to negate a certain attribute, where you place the particle of negation. The principle of judgment in it, if you want clarification and removal of ambiguity, is to place the particle of negation before the Report (Predicate), not before the Reported About (Subject). Your opponent says: 'Zayd is living', so you say: 'Zayd is not living'. Know that the Ancients, if they placed the particle of negation before the Subject—which is the Reported About—whether a report was with it or not, they called it then 'Non-Obtained' (Indefinite/Infinite). [And] if they placed it before the Subject, and placed it a second time also before the Predicate which is the Report, they called it 'Non-Obtained and Changed'. If they placed it before the Predicate [only], it was named 'Changed' (Metathetic) only. They mentioned that it may occur in the Indefinite (Neglected) which has no quantifier, in the Singular which is reporting about a single person, and in the Quantified. If they placed it before the Predicate in the Quantified proposition, they called it: 'Privative' (Maslub). If they placed it before the Quantifier, they called it 'Contradictory' (Naqid). If they placed it in every place of these places, they gathered for it the three mentioned names. Every proposition where the particle of negation is not before its subject—which is the Reported [About]—is called 'Simple', whether negative or affirmative, quantified or unquantified. If you say: 'No human is a stone', you have not obtained a thing to report about. Contemplate the great...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...error occurring (1) in your equating the placement of the negation particle before the Quantifier and its placement before the Predicate. For if you said: 'Not every human is a writer' (2), you spoke truth, and you only negated (3) by that writing from some people in reality, not from all of them—as we presented that Partial Negation appears by a universal statement and by a particular one also. Contemplate that in your saying: 'Laysa kullu insanin katiban' (Not every human is a writer); this is clearer in the Arabic language and more evident in that it is a negation by a particular [44r]. Likewise if you implied the noun of 'Laysa', saying: 'Laysa kullu insanin katib' (Not every human is a writer), meaning 'The judgment is not: every human is a writer'. These are all Particular Negations, so grasp that firmly. But if you said: 'Every human is not a writer' (Kullu insanin la katib), you negated writing from all as one. So guard against the likes of this. The least in that is that your report is a lie, even if you did not intend it, so you mislead by that one who thinks well of you. This is a plan of degradation a virtuous person is not pleased with. Know that you only negate what you attach the negation particle to. If you attached it to the Predicate—which is the Report about the Reported About—you negated the entire Predicate. If you attached it to the Quantifier, you only negate part of the proposition or all of it according to the form of your wording in the language. Do you not see that you say: 'It is possible that Zayd be a prince'; this is a 'Contradictory' because you negated the Mode (Naw'/Type) which is the Element, meaning you negated the possibility of the entire proposition. If you placed the negation particle after 'possible' and before the mention of 'be' (yakun) which is the Time, saying 'It is possible that Zayd not be a prince', this is 'Change' because you did not negate Possibility but affirmed it, but inserted into it the negation of what your opponent inserted Possibility into. The premise changed from its state, which is: Zayd being a prince. If you placed the negation particle after the Element and the Time—meaning after the word of admissibility which is Possibility and after the word of Being—and before the Subject which is the Reported About, saying: 'It is possible that be not-Zayd (other than Zayd) a prince', you did not negate anything from Zayd. This is what is called 'Non-Obtained' (Indefinite), and also called 'Changed', since [Ghayr/Other] is in the meaning of 'Laysa' (Not). You did not negate anything from a specific person nor did you negate also what...
foot_note:
1. (1) Al-Waqi': The footnote says *Al-Rafi'*. 
2. Katib: Read *Katiban*. 
3. Nafayta: Read *Anfayta*.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...your opponent affirmed, nor did you affirm anything for a specific person either. Rather, you reported about 'other than Zayd', and 'other than Zayd' is not obtained—who he is nor what he is. You kept Possibility and Being as they are, affirmed not negated. Likewise, the premise your opponent affirmed, you did not negate it nor affirm it either, but kept silent about it entirely, so you did not contradict him nor oppose him. If you placed the negation particle after the Mode, after the Time, after the Subject, and after the Predicate (1), saying: 'It is possible that Zayd be not-a-prince', this is Privation, and also called 'Transfer' (Intiqal), because you affirmed the Mode which is Possibility, the Time which is Being, and the Subject which is the Reported About, and negated from them the Predication which your opponent affirmed only. This is a negative proposition. The same is said in Indefinite propositions and in Predicative propositions with no difference in negating what you negate and affirming what you affirm. Understand the difference of these ranks; their benefit in presenting truths, cultivating, and removing ambiguity is of very [great] benefit. By God Almighty [44v] is success. Know that if you affirmed for the Reported About—using the word "Dhu" (Possessor of)—a certain thing, like your saying: 'Possessor of wealth' or 'Possessor of such attribute', then if you want to negate that from him for whom you affirmed it, you must keep the word "Dhu" in your negation of that, saying: 'He is not a possessor of wealth'. 8 - Remaining Discourse on the Divisions of Propositions regarding Truth and Falsehood: Know that among propositions are those that are true individually and true collectively; those that are true individually and false collectively; those that are false individually and true collectively; and those that are false individually and false collectively. That which (2) is true individually and collectively is like your saying: Human is living, Human is rational, Human is mortal, Human is laughing. All that is right and true. If you said: Human is living, rational, mortal, laughing; all that is right and true. As for that which (3) is true individually and false collectively, it is like a slave who is striving (Mujtahid) for himself not for his master. Your saying about him: 'He is a slave' is true, and your saying about him: 'Striving' is true (4). But if you said: 'This is a striving slave', you lied, until...

1. (1) Text says 'after the Predicate' but example shows negation *on* the predicate ('not-a-prince'). Context implies placing negation *on* the predicate. 
2. Allati: Text has *Alladhi*. 
3. Allati: Text has *Alladhi*. 
4. 'Fihi mujtahid haqq' is repeated in the original.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...you clarify the aspect of his striving. This is only in the two predicated attributes if they are related to two different things, so you confused by dropping what it is related to, giving the illusion that both attributes are related to one thing. As for that which is true collectively and false separately, it is like a man strong of soul, weak of body. If you said: 'So-and-so is weak', you lied. If you said 'So-and-so is strong', you lied. Until you combine and say: 'So-and-so is strong of soul, weak of body'. This is only in what (1) the attribute is not said absolutely but by relation. As for that which is false collectively and individually, it is like your saying: 'Man is neighing', 'Man is braying', 'Man is brave' [if false]. This is a lie. If you combined it saying 'Man is neighing braying brave', it is also a lie. Grasp all of this if you want to verify knowledge and correct propositions. By God Almighty is success. 9 - Chapter on Discourse on Equivalents (Mula'imat): This is a term by which the Ancients expressed propositions of different wordings but agreeing meanings, even if the appearance of the wording of some is Negation and the appearance of some is Affirmation—yet they are agreeing in meanings a correct agreement with no difference between them. Know that reports [45r] and propositions may come with various wordings while their meaning is one. The ignorant thinks they have different meanings because of what he sees of the difference of their wordings, so he errs greatly. This is something seekers of truths should grasp and stand upon its ranks, not passing by it turning away. An example of that from Sharia examples is your saying: 'A man's intercourse with anything other than his permissible wife or his permissible maidservant is forbidden (Haram)', and your saying: 'Nothing of what is other than a man's permissible wife or his permissible maidservant is lawful (Halal)'. Two meanings agreeing, corresponding. The wordings are different; the appearance of one proposition is permission [if read loosely, but here structure implies prohibition definition] and the appearance of the other is prohibition. Likewise if you said: 'Everything that is not pork is lawful', and your saying: 'Some of what is not pork is not lawful' [Note: Text seems to contrast lawful/not lawful]. These are two different wordings and two agreeing meanings. Thus you should contemplate the incoming words and contemplate their meanings so that you and your opponent do not pull at arts of difference and dispute while you are agreed, not disagreeing.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Know that your saying if you said 'It is possible to be' (Mumkin an yakun), and said 'It is possible not to be', and said 'It is not impossible to be', and 'It is not impossible not to be', and said 'It is not necessary not to be'—all are Equivalent (Mutala'imat), meaning agreeing in meanings. Know that your saying 'It is necessary not to be', 'It is impossible to be', 'It is not possible to be' are agreeing in meanings. Know your saying 'It is not necessary to be', 'It is not necessary not to be' are agreeing. Know that your saying 'It is not impossible to be' and your saying 'It is not impossible not to be' are agreeing. Know that your saying 'It is possible not to be' and 'It is possible not to be' [repetition/typo? possibly 'possible to be'] are agreeing. Know that these six are all agreeing. Know that your saying 'It is possible to be', its negation is not 'It is possible not to be', but its negation is to say: 'It is not possible to be' (La mumkin an yakun). The contradictory of your saying 'Necessary to be' is your saying 'Not necessary to be'; its contrary is 'Necessary not to be'. The contradictory of 'Impossible to be' is 'Not impossible to be'; its contrary is 'Impossible not to be'. This is what we named previously General Negation and Specific Negation. Know that your saying 'Every composite is not eternal' and your saying 'Not one of composites is eternal' are agreeing. Your saying 'Not every wet-nurse is forbidden' and your saying 'Some wet-nurses are lawful' are agreeing. Your saying 'Some composites are not compound [simple]' and your saying 'Not every composite is compound' are agreeing. Know that your saying 'Not one of composites is non-originated' and your saying 'Every composite is originated' are agreeing. Included [45v] in this type is every number from which a number is excepted; like your saying 'One hundred other than one' is equivalent to your saying 'Ninety-nine'; and your saying 'One hundred other than ninety-nine' is equivalent to your saying 'One'. Likewise every number to which you added another number is equivalent to the equal number, like your saying 'Three and Seven', that is equivalent to your saying 'Ten'. Know it. The collector for this chapter is that if you affirmed a meaning with a wording of Affirmation for a certain thing, then you negated from that thing the negation of the attribute you affirmed for it, you have affirmed that attribute for it. Every speech given a meaning like the giving of another speech, the two speeches are different and the meaning is one. Memorize this and grasp it.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: If you privated (negated) a meaning from a certain thing—meaning negated it from it with a wording of Negation—then you affirmed for that thing the negation of that meaning which you negated from it in the other proposition, the wordings are different and the meaning is one. An example of that is that we say: 'Zayd is righteous'. If you privated righteousness saying 'Zayd is other than righteous', then if you negated the negation saying 'Zayd is not other than righteous', you have affirmed righteousness for him. Preserve this, you will rest from much rioting and much confusion. Do not transgress this rank, God willing. Know that the Universal among Reports which are called Propositions and Premises necessitates the Particular among them; meaning that the Particular is part of the Universal if both are Affirmative or both are Negative. This is a meaning of the meanings of 'Following' (Subalternation/Tatali) which we mentioned before. Do you not see that you say: 'Every sensing thing is living'; this is a Universal proposition. Then your opponent or you say: 'Every human is living'. This Particular is not opposing that Universal at all nor incompatible with it; rather, it is part of it and entering under it. An example of this in Sharia is the saying of God Almighty: {The thief, male and female, cut their hands} (5 Al-Ma'idah: 38). Then the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "Cutting is in a quarter of a dinar." This Particular is part of that Universal and an explanation of a part of its parts.
