It is not refuting it nor anything of it at all, nor preventing cutting in less than a quarter dinar unless by inserting a particle of negation, so what the particular wording negated is negated then. That would be like a speaker saying: 'The sensing is rational', then saying after that: 'There is no rational except human, angel, and jinn'. This Particular would be explaining the intent of the speaker: 'The sensing is rational', meaning he intended some sensing things not all of them. That is not a lie, because 'Sensing' applies to 'Human'—meaning he is described by it—just as it applies to every animal. This statement is for Universals among Negatives [46r] and Particulars among them, with no difference. By God Almighty is success. We have come upon everything the seeker of truths and supervisor of correct meanings of speech has need and necessity for regarding the rulings of Reports which are Composite Nouns. Things remain which will occur, God Almighty willing, in the book following this, which is the Book of the Art of Demonstration. I only left out individuals of divisions of Affirmatives and Negatives, of Intermediates and Changed, of Quantified and Indefinite, of Singular, and of Binary, Ternary, and Quaternary [propositions] that are not needed. They are merely exercise and skill for one who has verified this science with a verification desiring to grasp...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...all its aspects. These issues we left out are like the calamities (hypothetical cases) posited in Jurisprudence, like the speaker saying: 'A man died and left twenty grandmothers adjacent, and twenty paternal aunts of sons, and sons of sons some lower than others in different degrees.' Such things we do not need because they do not occur in time, but they are a skill and sharpening of the mind. And like the long issues Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad introduced at the beginning of his book 'Al-Muqtadab' in Grammar; they never occur to anyone in a book nor in speech. And like much of the wild language such as 'Al-'Afunjaj', 'Al-'Ajalit', and 'Al-Qid'amil'. We do not dispraise one who seeks all this; rather, we validate his opinion. But we say: The seeker of every science should begin with its principles which are collections for it and premises, then with what is indispensable of interpreting those sentences. If he becomes skilled in that and wants to go deep and excessive, let him do so. For whoever trains with the rugged, it increases the lightness of his handling the easy. We have been informed about some heroes that if he wanted war, he would persist in wearing two coats of mail for a period before that; then if he fought, he took off one of them so the single one would be light on him. The soul is like that. By God is success, and to Him belongs the command before and after. The Book of Peri Hermeneias is completed. Praise be to God for that abundantly as He is worthy, and may God bless our Master Muhammad and the family of Muhammad and grant eternal, supported peace.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: 3 - 4 - 5 - 6 The Book of Demonstration (Burhan) 1 - [General View on Propositions and Their Reflection]: Abu Muhammad Ali bin Ahmed bin Saeed bin Hazm, may God be pleased with him, said: This part of this register of ours, we gathered in it what is in the third book of Aristotle's books on Logic, named in Greek "Analytica" [Prior Analytics] [46v], and in the fourth book of his books on Logic, named in Greek "Apodeictica" (1) [Posterior Analytics], to suit the meaning of the two books since the purpose in them is the clarification of the forms of Demonstration and its conditions, on the same [pattern] as what comes after this, God willing. We also added to it what he mentioned in his fifth book of his books on Logic, named "Topica", which is the subject on Dialectic. We increased in this things from the ranks of argumentation and its conditions which disputants seeking truths cannot do without, since what is mentioned in this book is among the condition of establishing Demonstration and its consequences attached to it. We also added to it what he mentioned in his sixth book on Logic, named in Greek "Sophistica", which is the description of the people of rioting who deviate from truths to supporting ignorance and jugglery, since the seeker of truths cannot do without knowing the people of this description and preparing for them. Since all we mentioned is clinging to Demonstration, we gathered it to it and reached the limit in investigation, expansion, explanation, and brevity as we promised. Praise be to God. We say, and by the First Creator we seek help: Matters have passed for us in the preceding books of this register which must be grasped, remembered, and present in understanding and memorization, and brought forth when needed for clarification to yourself from others and clarification from you to others, by the power of the First One and His strength gifted from Him to us, Mighty and Majestic. We are now taking up the fruit of this register and its purpose, which we intended by all that preceded...
foot_note: 1. (1) Apodeictica: Known as Second Analytics (Posterior Analytics).

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...for us in the parts preceding this part. Our purpose is the clarification of establishing Demonstration and the quality of correcting Inference in the sentences of difference occurring between differers in whatever they differed in. We say, and by the First One we are supported: We have said that the Proposition does not give you more than itself. If two opponents agree on it, validate it, and commit to its judgment, and differ in a branch of the branches of that meaning, they must bring another proposition they agree on its validity also. If the two mentioned propositions are correct in their nature and composition, then submission to them is necessary for each one. Know that the two mentioned propositions, if they gather, the Ancients named them "The Conjunction" (Premise Pair/Qarinah). Know that by their gathering—as we mentioned—a third proposition always occurs from them, always true, necessary by necessity, from which there is no deviation. This proposition occurring from the gathering [47r] of the two propositions is named "Conclusion" (Natijah). The Ancients call the two propositions and the conclusion together in the Greek language "Syllogismos" (1). All three are called in the Arabic language: "The Collector" (Al-Jami'ah). An example of that is you say: 'Every human is living'; this is a proposition called individually: "Premise". Then you say: 'And every living thing is a substance'; also a proposition called individually "Premise". If you gather them together, its name is "Conjunction" (Qarinah) due to their pairing. That is if you said: 'Every human is living, and every living thing is a substance', a third proposition occurs from this gathering, which is 'Every human is a substance'. This proposition is called individually "Conclusion". If you gather all three, they are called "The Collector" (Al-Jami'ah); and the Collector is the Syllogism. We presented in the part before this the mention of Propositions, that they are Simple and Changed. We said that the Changed in the Subject are the Non-Obtained, which are those where negation particles fall before the Described Thing which is the Reported About, which the Ancients call the Subject. Know that these which (2) are called Changed do not produce [a conclusion]. Meaning it is not trusted that they produce in every case a correct production always never betraying. Even if they may produce in some conditions, they may also produce falsehood. What is of this description, which is true once and false another, should not be trusted regarding its premises nor the results occurring from them, nor...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...is it obligatory to commit to taking Demonstration [from them]. Rather, one should trust what is certain that it never betrays. Then we have said that Simple [Propositions]—which are verified with the Reported About then affirmed an attribute for it or negated an attribute from it—among them are Quantified and Indefinite. We explained that the Quantified is what is preceded by a word clarifying that the intent is Generality, called Universal; or a word clarifying that the intent is Specificity, called Particular. That is like your saying: 'All people are speaking', 'Some people are speaking' or 'writing' if you wish, 'Not one of people is neighing', 'Not some [people] are neighing' or 'writing' if you wish, and the like. The Ancients mentioned that Indefinite [propositions] do not produce, just as we mentioned regarding Changed ones, exactly the same. This is not correct in the Arabic language; the people only narrated about their language. But we say that the Indefinite, as long as its speaker does not clarify that he intends by it some of what its name gives, or a necessary preventer does not prevent Generality in it, is like the Quantified Universal with no difference. The explanation of this will come in what we resume, God Almighty willing. Upon this judgment, it follows that the Indefinite produces like the production of the Quantified Universal. Then we return and say that Particulars among [47v] the Quantified, and the Indefinite which is certain to be particular, do not produce; meaning they do not produce a correct, necessary production always. We only said this if the two premises are both Particular, whether Negative or Affirmative. But if one is Universal and the other Particular, that produces, as we will explain after this, God Almighty willing. Know that the Singular Proposition, which specializes a specific single person, its rule in all we said is the rule of the Particular with no difference in that, like your saying: 'Zayd is departing' and the like. Then we said that the Quantified is divided into two parts: Affirmative and Negative. Know that Negative Propositions also do not produce, whether Universal or Particular—meaning they do not produce a trusted production in every case. That is only if they are both Negative. But if one is Negative and the other Affirmative, that produces, as we will explain after this, God Almighty willing. It is correct now that the Premises which should be trusted are the Quantified and the Indefinite which...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...is in the meaning of the Quantified. It is every Conjunction (Pair) accepted by a Universal Premise and an Affirmative Premise. Either one of the premises combines both matters: Generality and Affirmation; or the premises share the matters so one is Universal and the second is Affirmative. Know that we presented that the least of propositions is a proposition of two words: Subject and Predicate, meaning Reported About and Report. If you want to gather two propositions from which a Demonstration rises, there must be in both propositions a word existing in each of them—meaning that word is repeated in each of the premises. And there must be in each of them a word unique to it and not repeated in the other. Since if they agreed in the Reported About and the Report, the two propositions would be one proposition by necessity. Like your saying: 'Every human is living', and 'Every living thing is a substance'. These are two propositions; the mention of 'Living' is repeated in each of them. This repeated word as we mentioned is called by the Ancients "The Middle Term" (Al-Hadd Al-Mushtarak) due to the sharing of the two propositions in it. Each of them is unique with a word; the first is unique with 'Human' because it is mentioned in it and not in the second—if it were mentioned, the second would be the first itself. The second is unique with 'Substance' and it is not mentioned in the first—if it were mentioned, they would be one. Understand this and grasp it, God Almighty willing. Know that Simple Quantified Propositions [48r] are divided into two parts: A part that Reflects (Converts) and a part that does not Reflect. Reflection (Conversion) is to make the Report a Reported About (Subject) described, and make the Reported About a Report (Predicate) described by it, without the meaning changing in that at all. Rather, if the proposition was Affirmative before Conversion, it is Affirmative after Conversion. If it was Negative before Conversion, it is Negative after Conversion. If it was True before Conversion, it is True after Conversion. If it was False before Conversion, it is False after Conversion. Except that in some places, the proposition is Universal before Conversion, and Particular after Conversion; it does not differ in Conversion other than this at all. We only mean by this Conversion what does not transform (become impossible/false) ever in what we mentioned before. As for what may convert as we mentioned in some places, but perhaps also changes when converted—either from truth to falsehood, or falsehood to truth, or negation to...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...affirmation, or affirmation to negation—this is the section we said does not Reflect. This section is not what we care about in establishing Demonstration because it may betray and is not continuously true always. The Conversion we mentioned is only the exchange of the positions of words in the proposition only. We presented the modes of divisions of attributes in the described before, and that they are six: Describing a thing by what is Necessary for it is divided into two parts: Either more General than it, like Life for Man, for it encompasses him and encompasses with him many species (1) other than him. Or Equal, like Laughter for Man, for it is for every human and not for non-humans at all; and it is not permissible to be more Specific at all. Describing a thing by what is Possible for it is divided into two parts: Either more General like Blackness, for it is in some people and in things other than people. Or more Specific like Medicine, for it is in some people not others, and not in non-people; and it is not permissible to be Equal at all, because if it were Equal it would be Necessary, and the Necessary is other than the Possible. Describing a thing by its Impossibility, by what is Impossible in it, so it is more General like describing Man that he is not a stone; for this description encompasses him and encompasses every animal. It may be possible to find it Equal like negating Inanimateness from Animal. Then we return to the clarification of Conversion. We say, and by the One Creator we are supported: The Universal Negative Converts to Universal Negative. We say: 'Not one of humans is a stone'. If you convert it, you say: 'Not one of stones is a human'. Know that whatever converts universally converts particularly, since whatever you affirmed for the Whole is affirmed for every part of its parts named by its name, and whatever you negated from the Whole is negated from every part of its parts which [48v] is named by its name. We mean by Parts here the individuals of the Species, where every individual is named by the name of the Species—for every human is named in his essence 'a human', and the Species also is all named 'Human'. We did not mean parts of the body where the name of the Whole does not apply to the part, like the hand of a human and his leg. Do you not see that if you said also 'Not some stones are human' or said 'Not some humans are stones', you would be truthful? This which we mentioned is a correct Conversion true always. The Universal Affirmative Converts to Particular Affirmative. You say: 'Every human is living'. If you convert, you say: 'And some living things are human'. This is true always. Know that what is of this chapter and the one following it, regarding what we said converts particularly...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: It does not convert universally at all because everything necessary for the Part is necessary for the Whole. Do you not see that if you said: 'And every living thing is a human', you would be lying, because the angel is living and not human, and the elephant is living and not human. Do not be deceived by what you find of this chapter converting universally truly, like your saying: 'Every living thing is sensing', and 'Every sensing thing is living'. If you also said: 'And some sensing things are living', you would be truthful. This is only true in the Equal (Co-extensive). For this conversion, if it is true in one place, it is false in another, as we presented. It is only false if the Description is more general than the Described or more specific than it, as we presented. As for the more General, it is like your saying: 'Every human is living'. As for the more Specific, it is like our saying: 'Every doctor is human'. If you converted and said: 'And some humans are doctors', you would be truthful. If you said: 'And all humans are doctors', you would be lying. Therefore, we intended its conversion to Particular because it is true in all that always, in every case of General, Specific, or Equal (1). Guard against this chapter and do not err in it. If you follow the path we paved for you, you are safe from error entirely, and there is no way against your speech. The Particular Affirmative converts to Affirmative. You say: 'If some humans are grammarians, then some grammarians are humans'. It does not convert to Universal, because even if you are truthful in some places, you would be lying in other places also. It is true in the Specific and Equal Predication, and false in the General Predication. If you converted it to Particular, it would be true always in every case. Do you not see that you say: 'If some grammarians are humans, then all humans are grammarians', you lied. Know that all these propositions which we mentioned convert—meaning they are true if converted always—are true in your affirming the Necessary, in all your reporting about the Possible with what is true of its attributes, and in your negating the Impossible. [49r]. Know that the Particular Negative does not convert; meaning it has no rank in which it is true always. Because even if it is true in negating the Impossible—if you said: 'Some humans are not stones', and converted saying: 'And some stones [are not humans]', you spoke truth—if you negated the Possible with a true negation saying: 'Not every human is a doctor', you are truthful. If you converted saying: 'And not every doctor is a human', or said: 'And not some doctors are humans', you would be lying. Therefore, we did not busy ourselves with converting...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Negatives in Particulars, because in some places they are false in conversion. Understand all that, for every seeker of true knowledge has a need for it. We exemplify that with a Sharia example. We say: You say in the Universal Negative: 'If it is correct that no intoxicant is lawful, then no lawful thing is an intoxicant'. Or if you converted it to Particular, it would also be true. But the Universal is more complete and more general of requirements, so we sufficed with it if we found it, and dispensed with mentioning what is folded within it of particulars, except that reporting about the Whole is reporting about every part of its parts. We say in the Universal Affirmative: 'If every parent is obligatory to be treated kindly, then some of those obligatory to be treated kindly are parents'. If you converted it to Universal, you would be lying, because kindness is obligatory to the mother, the Caliph, the scholar, the virtuous, and the neighbor, and not one of these is a parent (father). You say in the conversion of the Particular Affirmative: 'If some disbelievers are of permissible blood, then some of those of permissible blood are disbelievers'. If you converted it to Universal saying: 'And everyone of permissible blood is a disbeliever', you would be lying, because the married adulterer is of permissible blood and is not a disbeliever. Understand all this and trust it, for it never betrays you. The proof of the validity of what we mentioned first—if we said 'No human is a stone' and that it converts universally so we say 'And no stone is a human'—is that if an opponent opposes us in the validity of this conversion, we say: If our conversion is not true, then its contradictory is true according to what we presented of the divisions of the two propositions of Negation and Affirmation regarding Truth and Falsehood. The contradictory of our saying 'No stone is a human' is 'Some stones are human'. We join our saying 'Some stones are human' to our premise which we validated, saying: 'No human is a stone, and some stones are human'. If some stones are human, then some humans are stones. Yet we presented that 'No human is a stone'. This is a contradiction and impossible. This is what we mentioned in the element of Necessity, which is the inherence of the Attribute to the Described. As for the element of Possibility, there is no difference between [49v] propositions in Particular Affirmatives and what we mentioned of propositions of the element of Necessity. We say in the General Predication: 'If some humans are black, then some blacks are humans'. We say in the Specific Predication: 'If some humans are doctors, then some doctors are humans'. There is no Equal Predication in Possibility because the Equal is necessary for the entire Species in actuality. As for Universal propositions of Possibility, they are false in Affirmatives. We say: 'It is possible that every human is black or a doctor'; this is false. The conversion of the Specific Predication...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...is true. We say: '[Possible] that every doctor be a human'. As for Negative propositions of Possibility, the Universal is always false, and its conversion. We say: 'If it is possible that not one of humans be black or a doctor, then it is possible that not one of blacks or doctors be a human'. As for the Particular Negative in the element of Possibility, it converts to Particular Negative. We say: 'It is possible that some humans are not black', and its conversion: 'It is possible that some blacks are not humans'. This is in the General Predication. It is false in the Specific Predication, because if you said: 'It is possible that some humans are not doctors', you are truthful. If you converted and said: 'It is possible that some doctors are not humans', you lied. As for the element of Impossibility, the Particular Affirmative converts to Particular Affirmative. We say: 'It is impossible that some humans are not stones' [Double Negative? Context implies Affirmation: Impossible some humans are stones -> Impossible some stones are humans], and 'It is impossible that some stones are not humans'. It also converts to a true Universal Affirmative, so we say: 'It is impossible that every stone be a human'. As for the Universal Affirmative, it also converts to true Universal and Particular always. We say: 'It is impossible that every human be a stone', and 'It is impossible that every stone be a human', and 'It is impossible that some stones be human'. As for the Universal Negative in the element of Impossibility, it converts to Particular. You say: 'If it is impossible that not every human be living' [Impossible that no human is living], then 'It is impossible that not some living things be human'. This is true in preventing the negation of Laughter which is equal to the Species. In the Specific Predication like Medicine and the like, we say: 'If it is impossible that no doctor is a human, then it is impossible that some humans are not doctors' [Logic unclear in text, likely means 'Impossible no human is a doctor']. As for the Particular Negative in the element of Impossibility, it converts to Particular Negative, like your saying 'It is impossible that some living things are not humans'. This converts in the Equal and Specific Predication always. Our benefit in knowing the conversion of propositions is from two aspects. One is what we resume of reducing some Demonstrations that contain difficulty to the clear explanation among them, which is what will come, God Almighty willing [50r], in reducing the modes of the Second and Third Figures to the First Figure, explained...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...in its place. The second aspect is in correcting the premises which seekers of invalidating truths want to present to make them principles to produce from them what witnesses to the correct sayings. Since we presented that the Proposition consists of Subject and Predicate—meaning Reported About and Report—and that the Conjunction (Syllogism pair) consists of two premises in each of which is a word shared by the two premises together, know that every word of the words of the two premises is called by the Ancients a "Term" (Hadd), and they call the shared word: "The Middle Term" (Al-Hadd Al-Mushtarak). Know that the Figures of Demonstration are only three—we mean by its Figures the forms of Conjunctions from which Demonstration arises—because the Middle Term must be Predicate in one premise and Subject in the second; or be Predicate in both of them; or be Subject in both of them. There is no way for the rank of Reason to a fourth division in any way at all. Know also that there is no difference between your saying: 'Life is in every human' and your saying: 'Every human is living'—you mean in meaning. The Ancients call this "Predicate Precedence" (Taqdim al-Haml), meaning you make the Attribute reported about, and the Described returned to the Attribute as if it is a report about it. Do not mind the difference of these expressions. Know that the Ancients call the premise containing the more General word "Major Premise" (Muqaddimah Kubra). Like your saying: 'Every human is living', and 'Every living thing is a substance'. The one mentioning Substance contains a word more general than the word in the other premise, because Substance is more general than Living and Human. The other they call the Minor (Sughra). Know that two Particular Negatives do not produce [a conclusion], nor two Singulars—which is reporting about a specific single person. Know that the Middle Term is not mentioned in the Conclusion at all; if it were mentioned in it, the Conclusion would be one of the premises. Only the word unique to the one premise and the word unique to the second premise are mentioned in the Conclusion. Know that nothing comes out in the Conclusion except the least of what is in the two premises and the farthest from certainty and decisiveness, because the Conclusion by its nature follows the truth in them. Therefore, nothing comes out in it except the least regarding which there is no doubt. If one of the premises is Indefinite and the other is Quantified...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the Conclusion is Indefinite. If one of the premises is Particular, the Conclusion comes out Particular. If one of the premises is Singular, the Conclusion comes out Singular. If one of the premises is Negative, the Conclusion comes out Negative. If [50v] one of the premises is Particular or Singular and the other is Negative, the Conclusion comes out Particular Negative or Singular Negative. We say: 'No human is a stone, and Zayd is a human', so 'Zayd is not a stone'. This rank is only in what is always true and trusted in its production. Likewise, if one of the premises is Necessary and the second is Possible, only the Possible comes out in the Conclusion. But if the two premises are equal, the Conclusion is like them. If they are both Affirmative, the Conclusion is Affirmative. If both are Necessary, the Conclusion is Necessary. If both are Possible, the Conclusion is Possible. If both are Indefinite, the Conclusion is Indefinite. Except that if they are both Universal (1), the Conclusion is Universal, and perhaps it is Particular; do not mind this, for the Particular is enfolded in the Universal, while the Universal is not enfolded in the Particular. We mention based on what we told you that the Figures of Demonstration are three: The First Figure has four Moods (Anha'); the Second has [four Moods]; and the Third Figure has six Moods. We only mean by that the Moods true in production always in every case. The Figure for Demonstration is like the Genus, the Mood for it is like the Species, then the taken Premises are like Individuals—and they are uncounted by number because they are used in every science in every issue. Know that it was named the First Figure because the other two Figures return in reality to it, as we will explain after this, God willing. Know that two Negative premises [may] be presented to you and produce for you a true, correct production; do not trust that, for it is a treacherous path not trusted in its truth always. Indeed, we may present them correct and they produce for you a false conclusion. The deceptive of this chapter is like what I say to you: 'Not every human is a stone, and not every stone is a donkey'. Conclusion: 'So not every human is a donkey'. This is true. The exposer of all we mentioned is like what I say to you: You say 'Not every human is black, and not every black thing is living'. These two are true. Conclusion: 'So not every human is living'. Likewise if you said: 'Not some people are living'. Both are lies. So beware of being deceived...
foot_note: 1. (1) Kanata kulliyyatayn: Text has *Kana*. The brackets indicate text insertion *[four Moods]* based on context.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...by two negative premises at all. The first conjunction was true due to the good arrangement of the premises, because you arranged them such that what you negated from the stone is what is negated from the human entirely. I show you now increased clarity in the truth of this judgment. I will make for you two premises, one of which is a pure lie, producing for you a true production. That is to say: 'Every human is a stone, and every stone is a substance'. Conclusion: 'So every human is a substance'. You say: 'Not every human is a dog, and not [51r] every dog is a horse'. Conclusion: 'Not every human is a horse'. That is true. The first is a lying premise that produced truth by its good arrangement, which is that you described the stone with an attribute encompassing it and encompassing the human. The other in negation is likewise—we mean in good arrangement only. Know now that there must be truth in each of the premises, and with truth in them, there must be good arrangement on the path I described to you. Otherwise, matters will confuse and confound you, and truth will mix in your mind with falsehood. Likewise in two Particular premises. We presented that the ruling of the Singular is the ruling of the Particular with no difference. We say: 'Zayd is rational, and some rational beings are dead'. So 'Zayd is dead'. This is a true conclusion. But do not trust two Particular premises at all, nor two Singulars, nor a Singular and a Particular. Know that these were only true due to the truth of the report about the natures of the reported-about and the generality of the attribute for the reported-about. I show you the treachery of this path. That is to say: 'Zayd is white, and some white things are stones'. True. Conclusion: 'So Zayd is a stone'. This is a lie. If you wish, you say: 'Zayd is rational, and some rational beings are writers'. These are two true premises. Conclusion: 'So Zayd is a writer'. This is a conclusion possible to be true and possible to be false. Ponder the likes of this and do not forget it; you will be safe from great rioting and know that two Particulars, two Singulars, and a Particular [mixed] do not produce a true, consistent, consistent production that does not betray. Here we are, by the power of God our One Creator Almighty and His aid to us, commencing the specification of the three Figures mentioned just now with a Sharia example to be easier for the seeker and clearer for doubt. I have seen groups of losers whom I witnessed in the prime of our seeking [knowledge] and before the establishment of our powers in knowledge and our first involvement with types of people of different opinions; they used to decide by their corrupt conjectures without certainty produced by trusted research that...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Philosophy and the definitions of Logic are contrary to Sharia. The mainstay of our purpose and our knowledge is illuminating this darkness by the power of our One Creator, Mighty and Majestic; we have no power [except] by Him alone, He has no partner. Know that the speech we prepare to present diligently and alert you to listen to is the intended purpose of this register. It is by which we measure all that is disputed in whatever science it is. Taste it a taste that never betrays you, ponder it deeply, and guard it strictly. It is what the Ancients made rugged and expressed [51v] with letters of the alphabet, being stingy with it. We sought reward in revealing it, facilitating it, and bringing it closer to everyone who looks into it for the reasons we mentioned at the beginning of this register of ours. We were not content until we made all Moods from one word in Affirmation and one word in Negation, so that the return of some to others and the suitability of some to others and the existence of work in taking Demonstration by them appears. We brought close the distant of that, clarified the problematic, explained the difficult, eased the rugged, and humbled the hard. We do not know anyone who permitted that nor tired his mind in it before us; praise be to God first and last. By your standing on this chapter, you push away from yourself the cloud of ignorance and aversion generated by panic from bad opinion of this science and the intensity of distress from the jugglery of many who claim it while not being of its people. May God grant us and you and all people of our species generally and people of our creed specifically success to what pleases Him, Amen. Know that the First Figure: its Major Premise is always Universal—either Affirmative or Negative—and its Minor Premise is always Affirmative—either Particular or Universal. Know that the Second and Third Figures return to the First Figure always, either as a Conjunction of its conjunctions, or a Conclusion of its conclusions, either in wording or in rank, as we will explain in every Mood of them, God Almighty willing. Know that the Minor of the two premises is always advanced so that the word unique to it comes out as Subject in the Conclusion—meaning Reported About. The Major is always delayed so that the word unique to it comes out as Predicate in the Conclusion—meaning Report. Know that if an attribute falls under the Species in Time in one of the premises, it is necessary by necessity that the other be Universal. We mentioned before that some Ancients described that the Major Premise contains a word more General than the two final words—the Shared one and the one the other premise is unique with. This is a matter not correct absolutely. Rather, he upon whom is the reliance in this, Aristotle the arranger of this Art, permitted Equality...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...in the premises, and it is the correct view. We found five Moods, four of which have Equal Premises: The Second Mood of the First Figure, the First and Second Moods of the [Second] Figure, and the Second Mood of the Third Figure. And the Fifth Mood of the Third Figure; its Minor is Universal and its Major is Particular, so the General (1) word in that Mood is specifically in the Minor Premise [52r], not in the Major. We have alerted to every Mood of them in its place, God Almighty willing. Our success is only by God Almighty. This is when we begin specifying the mentioned Moods: The First Figure: The Middle Term (Shared Limit) in it is Subject in one premise, Predicate in the other. Meaning the word mentioned in both premises is in one of them Reported About and Described, and in the other Report and Attribute. Example of the First Figure: The Middle Term in it is Reported About in one premise and Report in the other. The First Mood of the First Figure: Every human is living, and every living thing is a substance. Conclusion: Every human is a substance. The Second Mood in the First Figure: Every human is living, and not one living thing is a stone. Conclusion: Not one human is a stone. Or if you wish: No one of humans is a stone. This Mood has Equal Premises; one is not more General than the other. The Third Mood of the First Figure: Some people are living, and every living thing is a substance. Conclusion: Some people are substances. The Fourth Mood of the First Figure: Some people are living, and not one of the living is a stone. Conclusion: Some people are not stones. The Second Figure: The Middle Term in it is Predicate in both premises—meaning it is in both of them together. The First Mood of the Second Figure: Every human is living, and not one of stones...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...is living. Conclusion: So not one of humans is a stone. There is no [difference] between this First Mood of the Second Figure and the Second Mood of the First [Figure] except that the Predicate is the Report which is in the Major Premise of this First Mood of the Second Figure, according to what we brought there and here only. Proof of the validity of this Conclusion: We convert the Negative Premise saying: If not one of stones is living, then not one of humans is a stone [Error in text logic? Should be: then not one of living is a stone]. And we said 'Every human is living'. We add the word obtained for us in conversion to this one not converted, saying: 'Every human is living, and not one of the living is a stone'. This is the Second Mood of the First Figure exactly. The Reported About came out in the conversion as Report, and the Report as Reported About, as we presented when we described the ranks of Conversion, so remember it. We only did not convert the Affirmative because if we converted it, the Third Mood of the Figure would come to us, and it will come after this, God Almighty willing. The Second Mood of the Second Figure: And not one of stones is living, and every human is living. Conclusion: Not one of stones [52v] is a human. There is no [difference] between this Mood and the one before it at all, except that the Major of that is the Minor of this—delayed there and advanced here—and the Minor of that is the Major of this—advanced there and delayed here. That was only because we extract the Subject of the Conclusion of the one before this Mood by two conversions: a conversion for the second premise and another conversion for the Conclusion we mentioned. We say: If not one of stones is living, then not one of the living is a stone. And we said that every human is living. So: Not one of the living is a stone, and every human is living; so not one of stones is a human [Error in deduction steps in text? Should lead to: No human is a stone]. Then we convert this Conclusion saying: If not one of stones is a human, then not one of humans is a stone. This is the Conclusion of the Second Figure from the First Mood exactly. Know that the two premises of this Mood and the one before it are equal; there is no word in one more general than the word in the other. Know that there is no difference in any of the Moods between your saying: 'Not one of humans is a stone', and your saying 'Nothing of humans is a stone', and your saying 'Not one human is a stone'. All that is equal; say how you wish. It is better to say what is clearer in the language you express with. Thus is the ruling of all you negated.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: The Third Mood of the Second Figure: Some people are living, and [not] one of stones is living. Conclusion: Some people are not stones. There is no difference between this Mood and the Fourth Mood of the First Figure except that the Predicate of the Major Premise of that Mood is the Subject of the Major Premise of that Mood is the Predicate of the Major Premise of this Mood [Text confusion]. Its proof is by converting the Negative Premise. You say: If [not] one of stones is living, then not one of the living is a stone. We add to that the Premise not converted, saying: 'Some people are living, and not one of the living is a stone'. This is the Fourth Mood of the First Figure exactly. The Fourth Mood of the Second Figure: Some stones are not living, and every human is living. Conclusion: So some stones are not human. If you wish, you say: 'So not every stone is a human', because we said before that the Particular Negative appears with a Universal wording and a Particular wording if you wish. Then you convert this Conclusion saying: 'If some stones are not human, then some humans are not stones' [Invalid conversion]. This is the Conclusion of the Fourth Mood of the First Figure exactly. This Mood, its premise is not converted because if you converted the Universal Affirmative, it would convert to Particular, and with it [53r] is a Negative Particular; and two Particulars do not produce. And the Negative Particular does not convert as we presented. But its proof removes absurdity [from] speech. That is we say: If a denier denies that this Conclusion is true—which is our saying 'So some stones are not human'—then its contradictory is true, which is 'Every stone is a human'. Then you say: 'Every stone is a human, and every human is living'—according to what we established in the Major Premise. That produces for us: 'Every stone is living'. Yet we validated in the Minor Premise: 'Some stones are not living'. This is contrary to what the last produced for us. This is impossible. The Third Figure: The Middle Term in it is Subject of both (1) premises—meaning Reported About—and its Conclusions are all Particulars. The First Mood of the Third Figure: Every human is living, and every human is a substance...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Conclusion: So some living things are substances. Its proof is by converting the Minor Premise. We say: If every human is living, then some living things are human. And every human is a substance, so some living things are substances. This is the rank of the Third Mood of the First Figure. The Second Mood of the Third Figure: Every human is living, and not one of humans is a stone. Its proof is by converting the Minor Premise. We say: If every human is living, then some living things are human. And no human is a stone, so some living things are not stones. This is the rank of the Fourth Mood of the First Figure exactly. This Mood has Equal Premises; neither has a word more general than in the other. The Third Mood of the Third Figure: Some living things are people, and all living things are substances. Conclusion: Some people are substances. Its proof is by converting the Particular Premise. We say: If some living things are people, then some people are living. Then we add that to the Universal Premise saying: Some people are living, and every living thing is a substance. This is the Third Mood of the First Figure exactly. The Fourth Mood of the Third Figure: Every human is living, and some people are substances. Conclusion: Some living things are substances. This Mood is different in rank from the one before it regarding presenting the Particular and delaying it. The Major of that is the Minor of this, and the Minor of that is the Major of this. Except that the Subject of the Conclusion of the one before this comes out as Predicate in the Conclusion of this one in rank, and the Predicate of the Conclusion of that as Subject in the Conclusion of this one, since the Term in the Major Premise is [53v] the one that comes out as Predicate in the Conclusion. Its proof is by converting the Particular Premise. We say: If some people are substances, then some substances are people. Then we add to the Universal Premise saying: Some substances are people, and all people are living. Conclusion: Some substances are living. This is the rank of the Third Mood of the First Figure exactly. The Fifth Mood of the Third Figure: Every human is living, and some people are not stones. Conclusion: So some living things are not stones. There is no conversion in this, because if you converted the Universal, it would convert to Particular, and we add to it another Particular; and two Particulars do not produce. And the Negative Particular does not convert. But its proof raises speech to absurdity. We say: If...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the mentioned Conclusion were false, then its contradictory is true, which is 'Every living thing is a stone'. Then we say: 'Every human is living, and every living thing is a stone'. Conclusion: 'So every human is a stone'. Yet we agreed in the Premise that 'Some people are not stones'. This is impossible. The Conclusion of this Mood is the Conclusion of the Second Mood of the Third Figure. This Mood returns to the Fourth Mood of the First Figure by taking the Conclusion and adding it to the Minor Premise. You say: 'Every human is living, and some living things are not stones'. Conclusion: 'So some people are not stones'. This is the Conclusion of the Fourth Mood of the First Figure. This Mood does not have in its Major a word more general than in its Minor. The Sixth Mood of the Third Figure: Some living things are human, and not one of living things is a stone. Conclusion: Some living things are not stones. Its proof is by one conversion. We say: If some living things are human, then some people are living. Then we add that to the Universal Negative saying: Some people are living, and not one of living things is a stone. This is the Fourth Mood of the First Figure. We only did not convert what did not convert of the premises in the Second and Third Figures because they would only result in two Particulars, or result in what had resulted before or after them of Moods, or because it would be longer in operation. We intended the briefest and most beneficial. These are the Moods other than which do not produce a consistent production. We will explain, God Almighty willing, the objections of the rioters in these Figures, and the solution to that by God's power and strength. Here we are taking to exemplifying these Moods with a Divine Example and a Sharia Example by the power of God, the Giver of virtues to whom He wills of His servants, to show the merit of this [54r] Art in every science. The First Figure. The First Mood of the First Figure: Every thing emerging into actuality from the world is counted, and every counted thing is finite (1). So every thing emerging into actuality from the world is finite. Sharia Example: Every intoxicant is wine (Khamr), and every wine is forbidden. So every intoxicant is forbidden. The Second Mood of it: Every thing emerging into actuality from the world is counted, and not one of counted things is eternal. So nothing of what emerged into actuality from the world is eternal. Sharia Example: Every intoxicant is wine, [and no wine] is lawful. So every intoxicant is not lawful.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: The Third Mood of it: Some of the world is composite, and every composite is composed of something. So some of the world is composed of something. Sharia Example: Some owned things are forbidden to have intercourse with, and every forbidden thing that avoidance of is not mandated [? Context suggests: every forbidden thing is mandated to avoid]. So some owned things are mandated to be avoided. The Fourth Mood of it: Some of the world is composite, and not everything of composites is eternal. So some of the world is not eternal. Sharia Example: Some sales are usury, and nothing of usury is lawful. So some sales are not lawful. The Second Figure. The First Mood: All groups of the world are composed of their parts, and nothing of composed things (1) is eternal. So nothing of the world is eternal. Sharia Example: Every slaughter of what you do not own you have been forbidden from, and nothing is lawful of what you have been forbidden from. So your slaughter of a thing you do not own is not lawful. The Second Mood of it: Nothing eternal is composed, and all groups of the world are composed of parts in them. So nothing in the groups of the world is eternal. Sharia Example: Nothing is lawful of what you have been forbidden from, and every slaughter of what you do not own you have been forbidden from. So your slaughter of what you do not own is not lawful. The Third Mood of it: Some of the world is composite, and nothing eternal is composite. So some of the world is not eternal. Sharia Example: Some fathers are disbelievers, and not everyone whose obedience is obligatory is a disbeliever. So some fathers, their obedience is not obligatory. The Fourth Mood of it: Some of the world is not a creator, and the Eternal is a creator. So some of the world is not eternal. Sharia Example: Some private parts of possessions are not lawful to have intercourse with, and every private part of a wife or permissible maidservant is lawful to have intercourse with. So some private parts of possessions—not a wife or maidservant's private part—are not permissible. The Third Figure. The First Mood of it: Every composite is finite (2), and every composite is composed. So some finite things [54v] are composed. Sharia Example: Every slanderer of a chaste woman is a debauchee (Fasiq), and every slanderer of a chaste woman is punished (Hadd). So some debauchees are punished. The Second Mood of it: Every body is composed of its parts, and not one of bodies...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...is eternal. So some of what is composed of its parts is not eternal. Sharia Example: Every pilgrim (Muhrim) is forbidden from hunting, and not one of pilgrims is women permissible for him. So not some of those forbidden from hunting are women permissible for them. The Third Mood of it: Some accidents are number, and all accidents are carried (predicates). So some number is carried. Sharia Example: Some worshipers are of accepted prayer, and every worshiper is commanded to face the Kaaba if able. So some of those of accepted prayer are commanded to face the Kaaba if able. The Fourth Mood of it: Every body is counted, and some body is composite. So some composite is counted. Sharia Example: Every woman breastfeeding five sucklings is forbidden (Mahram), and some women breastfeeding five sucklings are mothers. So some mothers are forbidden. The Fifth Mood of it: Some bodies are not accidents, and every body occupies a place. So some accidents do not occupy a place. [Logic check: Some Body is not Accident + All Body is Place-Occupying -> Some Place-Occupying is not Accident. Text says: Some Accidents not Place-Occupying. Likely error in text/example mapping]. Sharia Example: Not some killers without right are retaliated against (Qisas), and every killer without right is a debauchee. So some of those not retaliated against are debauchees. The Sixth Mood of it: Some bodies [possess] six directions, and nothing of bodies is an accident. So some of what possesses directions is not an accident. Sharia Example: Some conditions are corrupters of the contract, and nothing of conditions precedes the contract. So some corrupters of the contract [do not precede it]. Since we have completed, by God Almighty's power and His aid to us, what we promised of mentioning the Moods of the Figures of Demonstration, let us say that every Conclusion appearing in what we presented of Conjunctions: If it is Universal Affirmative, its conversion—which is Particular Affirmative—may be valid by its validity. If it is Particular Affirmative, its conversion—which is Particular Affirmative—may be valid. If it is Universal Negative, its conversion—which is Universal Negative—may be valid by its validity. If the Universal is valid, its particulars are valid; but it is not that if the Particular is valid, its Universal is valid. Contemplate this, you will find it. We have presented clear examples of that for you, dispensing with repetition. Ponder in this place the great benefit of Conversion, because what is folded within it of what we mentioned now becomes valid for you by the validity of the Conclusion. [55r] As for the Particular Negative, we have presented that it does not convert. Since what we said is so, that is a production from the Conclusion true always. The Conclusions as we mentioned are fourteen; eight of them convert...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...three in the First Figure, two in the Second are negative, and three in the Third are affirmative. That makes twenty-two true conclusions. Remember what we said before: that Propositions, which are Reports, are divided into two parts: Categorical and Conditional. These Categorical ones, we have mentioned their divisions. Praise be to God, the Giver of discrimination, knowledge, clarification, and power. He is the One from whom we seek increase in all that and of good, only from Him; there is no god but He. Since we have completed that, let us commence mentioning the second section, which is the Conditional, God Almighty willing. There is no power or strength except in God, Exalted be His mention. The First Volume (Safar) of the book *The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples* by Abu Muhammad Ali bin Ahmed bin Saeed bin Hazm bin Ghalib al-Andalusi, God's mercy be upon him, is completed. Praise be to God for that abundantly as He is worthy, and may God bless the Prophet Muhammad and grant peace.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: This is the beginning of the Second Volume. In the name of God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. O God, bless our Master Muhammad and the family of Muhammad. 2 - Chapter on Mentioning Conditional Propositions: We say, and by God we seek help, that the Conditional is that wherein a necessary thing is not decided in the description of the described [absolutely]. This Conditional is divided into two parts: Either Suspended (Mu'allaqah) on another thing, or Separating (Disjunctive/Muqassimah). The Suspended is divided into two parts: The Suspended by a sentence, called Conjunctive (Muttasilah), which is where the judgment is suspended on another judgment; it becomes valid by its validity or void by its invalidity. Example of that: 'If the one who committed adultery is chaste (Muhsan), mature, sane, but previously married (Thayyib), then he is flogged and stoned (1).' This is a Conditional proposition composed of two judgments: One is the description of the adulterer, and the second is the description of what is done to him if he commits adultery, which is flogging and stoning. The first judgment is called the Antecedent (Muqaddam), which is your saying [55v] 'If he committed adultery while being chaste, mature, sane, previously married'. The second judgment is called the Consequent (Tali), which is your saying 'Then he is flogged and stoned'. Stick to this naming also so it repeats for you, God Almighty willing. One of the two parts of the Suspended which we mentioned just now it divides into is that you except (affirm) the Antecedent. The meaning of our saying 'except' is that you stipulate that the existence of the matter mentioned first is a cause for the existence of the matter mentioned last. If the first is not, the last is not [necessarily]. The second part is what you except (affirm) the Consequent in, meaning you stipulate that the existence of the thing mentioned last is a cause for the existence of the matter mentioned first. If the mentioned last is not, the mentioned first is not. The first part is a premise composed of a Subject and Predicate except that...
foot_note: 1. (1) Fa-innahu yujladu wa yurjam: Then he is flogged and stoned, but he is Thayyib, so he is flogged and stoned.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...a condition particle is associated with one of them. If you want its production, you add another to it, saying: 'If the chaste, mature, sane adulterer is flogged and stoned'—this is a premise of Reported About and Report with a condition particle associated with one. Then you say: 'And this is a mature, sane adulterer'—this is a second premise to it. So a Conjunction is completed. The Result: 'Then this one is flogged and stoned.' The saying regarding everything accompanied by a condition particle is one; they are: In (If), Idh ma (Whenever), Mata ma (When), Mahma (Whatever), and the like. If you wish to advance in wording the Suspended over the Suspended Upon, you may do so. The Suspended is the Effect (Musabbab), and the Suspended Upon is the Cause (Sabab). Like Adultery with Chastity is the cause of Stoning; Sunrise is the cause of Day; and the interposition of Earth between Sun and Moon is the cause of the Moon's Eclipse. These causes are the Suspended Upon, and the Eclipse, Sun [Day?], and Day are the Effects, which are the Suspended. We say in advancing the Suspended: 'If it is Day, then the Sun has risen'; 'If he is chaste, sane, the name of Thayyib applies to the adulterer if he is mature, then he is flogged and stoned'. This is like your advancing the Predicate over the Subject in Categorical Propositions that have no condition. We say: 'Life is in every human (1) and Substantiality in every living thing, so Substantiality is in every human'. The two premises in the Conditional may be Negative, may be Affirmative, and may be Affirmative and Negative. Like your saying: 'If the sun does not set, the night does not come'; 'If there is no lightning in the atmosphere, there is no thunderbolt'; 'If he does not acknowledge what the Messenger, peace be upon him, brought, he is not a Muslim' [56r]. The first premise is your saying: 'If the sun does not set', 'If there is no lightning in the atmosphere', 'If he does not acknowledge what Muhammad, peace be upon him, brought'. The second is your saying: 'Night was not', 'Thunderbolt was not', 'He was not a Muslim'. As for two Affirmatives, it is like what we presented before. As for Affirmative and Negative, it is your saying: 'Water settles by nature unless it corrupts or alters', 'Fire rises by nature unless it corrupts or alters', 'The two sellers are by choice unless they separate'. It is as if you said: 'If you left water to its nature, it is settling'; 'If you left fire to its nature, it is rising'; 'If the two sellers are together, the choice is theirs'.
foot_note: 1. (1) Life is in every human: Life is in every human and Substantiality is in every human.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: The premises may be many in this chapter, like your saying: 'If the world is originated, and the originated necessitates an originator, and nothing is other than the Originated and the Originator, and there is no originator other than the Originator of the world, and the origination of unnatural things appearing from a human is originated by his choice, and he brings them as witnesses to his claim, and their Originator is the Originator of the world for him, and if their Originator requested them from the Originator of the world, then the Originator of the world is a witness to the validity of what he claims. And if the Originator of the world is a witness to him, and the Originator of the world does not bear witness for a false claimant, then this is not a false claimant. And if he is not a false claimant, he is a true claimant. And if he is a true claimant, believing him is obligatory.' The Antecedent of this Conditional inference, as you see, is many premises, and the Consequent is one: 'Then if he is a true claimant, believing him is obligatory'. This is the first section we mentioned wherein the Antecedent is excepted (affirmed). Meaning the first premise is what we decide is true after stipulating that: If the first is valid, the one whose validity is suspended on its validity is valid. And if it is void, the one whose validity is suspended on its validity is void. This is necessary by primary reason, since everything that cannot be valid until another thing is valid, then if that other thing is not valid, it is necessary by necessity that the one having no validity except by the existence of a validity is not valid. From this necessary demonstrative principle, we invalidated in Laws every contract linked to a corrupt condition; it is not valid in Marriage, Divorce, Sales, Manumission, and all contracts. Likewise, if the Consequent does not exist necessarily except by the existence of the First (Antecedent), and the Consequent is not existing necessarily except by the existence of the First, then [if the First is not existing] the Consequent is not existing. If you found the first premise Particular, and said: 'If Zayd is a doctor, he is rational (speaking); but Zayd is a doctor, so he is rational'. If you excepted the contradictory of the First, whose negation you validated [56v], saying: 'But Zayd is not a doctor', it would not be valid for you that 'he is not rational'. And so is everything where the description in the premise is Particular to that in the Consequent. But if it is Equal to it or More General, then if you negated the First, the Second is negated. Like your saying: 'If the human is sensing' or you said 'laughing', 'then he is living (animal)'; 'but he is not sensing' or 'not laughing', 'so he is not living'. It is not permissible for the Consequent to be Particular to the Antecedent at all, because it is linked to it, existing by its existence; so it is always either Equal or More General. Memorize all this and grasp it. If you excepted the negation of the Consequent [meaning] you validated it, it produces for you...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the negation of the First by necessity in every case, whether the First was Particular or Equal. Do you not see that if you said: 'If Zayd is a doctor, he is knowledgeable; but he is not knowledgeable at all, so he is not a doctor'. Likewise the Equal; do you not see that if you said: 'If the body is a human, it is laughing; but it is not laughing, so it is not a human'. Regarding the Particular, it is also licensed to say: 'If the body is a human, it is rational; but it is not rational, so it is not a human'. If you excepted the Consequent—meaning validated it—the First is not valid for you except in the Equal alone. As for the More General, no; because if you said: 'If the body is a human, it is living', [and said 'It is living'], it is not valid for you by that that 'it is a human'. So the way is: You either validate the First, so it produces for you the validity of the Consequent; or you validate the negation of the Consequent, so the negation of the First is valid for you. But if you validated the Consequent or validated the negation of the First, validating the Consequent does not validate the First for you. Nor does validating the negation of the First validate the negation of the Consequent for you, except in the Equal only. However, if you want to negate the Consequent by negating the First in the Equal, you need an operation extending in producing that, since that is not quickly evident like the evidence of the negation of the Consequent by the negation of the First. Do you not see that if you said: 'If life is long, old age exists; but life is not long', Conclusion: 'So old age does not exist'—[this is] evident. If you said—while the Conjunction remains—'for the existence of old age is non-existent', you need, in producing from that 'that long life is non-existent', an operation. Which is to say: 'If old age exists, long life exists; so it is not possible that old age is non-existent and long life exists. Since if life were existing then by existence, then old age would not be existing [due to] long life; yet we presented that old age exists by the existence of long life. This is a contradiction'. It would only be evident if you advanced and said: 'If [57r] the weakness of old age is non-existent, then long life is non-existent'. This is evident. We have said that the section from which the opposite of the Consequent premise is excepted—meaning you validate it—produces for you the negation of the First by necessity. Like you saying: 'If the world were not originated, it would be non-composite and not finite in body; but the world is composite, finite in body; so the world is originated'. The Consequent premises in this type may be incompatible, like your saying: 'If a time exists for a non-body possessing time—while Time is only a duration by which rest or motion is counted—then a time does not exist for a non-body possessing time'. These are the divisions of the Conjunctive Conditional. They are: Either you validate...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the Antecedent, or validate its negation; or validate the Consequent, or validate its negation. So know. As for the Disjunctive (Separating) Conditional, it is that you divide the thing whose ruling validity you want to know into all its parts that Reason gives it as a division originally. Those parts are only different or disparate, varying; each one is contrary to the rest. It is permissible for the parts to be two or more, but the mentioned difference is necessary. That which divides [into two] is like your saying: 'The world is either originated or eternal'; 'This thing is either forbidden or not forbidden'; 'This thing is necessary or not necessary'. And like your saying: 'These two names either apply to one meaning or to more than one meaning'. As for that which divides into more than two parts, it is to say: 'The world, if it is originated, is not devoid of: either it originated itself, or another originated it, or it originated for an originated matter'. And like saying: 'This thing is either obligatory, or level permissible, or recommended permissible, or disliked permissible, or forbidden'. These parts, as you see, are complete in meanings—meaning each part is contrary to the rest—and its division is complete, exhaustive. But if the division is incomplete—which is that you omitted some of its parts either out of ignorance, forgetfulness, or intent—its parts then are not completely differentiated. That is like your saying: 'The Originator of the world is not devoid of: either He originated it for His generosity, or His nobility, or to draw a benefit, or to repel a harm, or for a cause other than what we mentioned'. This is an incomplete division because you dropped from it the correct part, which is that He originated it for no cause at all. It may occur in this chapter [57v] that the division is only into two parts, so the divider deletes one of the two parts and mentions the other, making it universal in judgment while it is in reality particular. Like the speaker saying: 'Time is a motion of dimension', outputting that as a universal attribute of Time. Whereas Time is a meaning adhering to us—meaning not that Time is a meaning adhering to us—meaning not that Time is a motion of dimension or rest of dimension. From that also is to say: 'The Mudabbar (slave promised freedom at death) freed by death is bequeathed, so he is from the third [of the estate]'. The correct way is to say: 'The Mudabbar freed by death is either bequeathed his freedom or freed by an attribute', fulfilling the right of division. So guard against the likes of this with all caution. For the entry of fallacies often enters this chapter. The least in this chapter is that truths are blinded to you...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...if you are a researcher, so you believe falsehood and mislead (1) others who think well of you; or you become confused if what is corrupt of the parts appears to you; or you answer a corrupt answer if you are questioned; or you mislead your opponent if you are questioning. All these are unpraiseworthy states; rather, they are very blameworthy among people of intellect. If you are ignorant of Division, learn and search. If you are forgetful, inspect and ponder. If you are intentional, that is uglier, so turn away from it. From that also is to say: 'Either Zayd is sitting or reclining'. This is not a correct division, since perhaps he is walking or standing. Know now that Division, if it falls into two parts only and fulfills the reality of nature in the Complete Division from which nothing deviates: if you validate one of the two parts, affirm it, and remove it from doubt, it produces for you that the other part is valid [invalid?] by necessity—it must be so [Context: Validating one invalidates the other in disjunctive, or validates the negation]. Like your saying: 'The world is either eternal or originated; but the world is originated, so it is correct that it is not eternal'. If you validate the negation of one of the two parts and affirm it, it produces by necessity the validity of the other division. Like your saying: 'The world is either eternal or originated; but it is not eternal, so it is correct that it is originated'. Likewise if the parts are more than two; if you validate one of them, it is correct that it is contrary to the rest—it must be so. Also, if you validate the negation of all those parts except one, it is correct that its judgment is that one which remained by necessity. If you validate that its judgment is contrary to some of those parts and more than one remains, the parts which became correct that it is contrary to drop, and it is not correct that the judgment of the thing whose [58r] validity of judgment is sought is in one of what remains excluding the rest of what remains. Do not mind which parts you advanced in wording nor which you delayed in all these aspects. We exemplify the three aspects we mentioned. We say, and by God Almighty we are supported: If you said 'This taste is either insipid, or acrid, or sweet, or bitter, or sour, or salty, or pungent, or astringent; but it is bitter', you have negated from it all remaining tastes with certainty, without doubt. Likewise if you said: 'This number is either equal to this number, or less than it, or more than it', [and you negate equal and less], you have negated the two remaining parts without doubt [error in text logic or translation of example intent], and it is then neither equal nor less with certainty. If...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: If you invalidate all parts except one, saying in the first question: 'But it is not insipid, nor acrid, nor sweet, nor bitter, nor sour, nor salty, nor pungent', then it is doubtlessly correct that it is astringent. Likewise, if you said in the second: 'But it is not more than it nor equal to it', then it is correct that it is less than it with certainty. If you invalidate some parts and remain silent about more than one of them, only the parts you validated as contrary to it drop, and you have not affirmed one specifically among what you did not negate. Inference and examination remain obligatory regarding them. Like your saying in the first question: 'But it is not bitter nor sweet', so bitterness and sweetness drop from it, and the taste remains doubtful regarding the remaining parts. Whenever you drop a part, it remains suspended on the rest until only one remains; then it is correct that that one is its judgment. This is in all issues. I only extracted all aspects for you from one issue so you see the ratio of aspects to one another more enablingly and easily than if they were from various issues. If you mention two or more of the many parts with a particle of doubt, saying: 'But it is either sweet or sour or bitter', you have invalidated the rest, and the judgment remains suspended on what you restricted it to. Know that this chapter is not correct unless you mention all parts that Nature necessitates. If you begin by mentioning some parts, restricting to them in the division, you have performed poorly. The correct way is that it is prevented except from one direction which you should not shrink from: that the validity of one of the parts you mentioned happens to agree with the thing whose judgment validity you seek. For if you validate that specific matching part [58v], you encounter the truth not by doing well in hitting it, but like a person whom searching led to a treasure. That is like your saying: 'This thing is either hot or cold; but it is hot'. If you were correct in describing it with heat as the reality of its nature, that produced for you the invalidity of every part you mentioned or did not mention. But if you negated in this operation one of the two parts you mentioned, nothing is valid for you yet. That is like your saying: 'This thing is either hot or cold; but it is not hot'. Know that you have not yet hit upon the reality of its nature, nor affirmed cold for it, because you dropped the third part which is the Moderate (Temperate). Perhaps it is moderate since it is not hot, so it would not enter the second part you mentioned, which is the Cold. Had your division been exhaustive, the ambiguity would have been lifted—as we presented before. If you decide in the incomplete division that it must be one of the parts...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...you mentioned, then lying is your share of this report, and scandal is your attribute in it. These are two bad traits. The command is yours before and after. Memorize these meanings and distinguish them if they pass by you in all your pursuits. Inspect them in everything that comes to you; you will be illuminated in knowledge with a complete light and overlook wonders that relieve you of great worries if you are among those concerned with truths. Know that your bringing in the division the word 'Imma' (Either), or the word 'Aw' (Or), or 'It is not devoid of such and such', or 'It must be such and such', or 'This divides into such and such, a part of it is such and a part is such', or 'There is no way to other than such and such', or whatever gives the meaning—all that is equal. Nothing of that disrupts the meaning at all. 3 - Chapter on Types of Demonstration in which Attributes are Doubled: Know that premises may occur with a ratio of numbers in multitude or paucity or equality, or a disparity of qualities in intensity or weakness or their similarity. Some of them are a correct presentation producing a correct production returning to the First Figure. Like your saying: 'The Narcissus is more yellow [59r] than the Apple, and the Apple is more yellow than the Citron. Conclusion: So the Narcissus is more yellow than the Citron.' The Middle Term—which is the word shared in both premises, which I have long explained to you describing the moods of the three Figures—is our saying: 'The Apple'. Our saying 'more yellow' is the intended purpose and the link between the two terms; so it must come out in the Conclusion like the exit of the word 'All' or 'Some' in the previous Figures. The Divided Terms are the two words each premise was unique with, which are the Narcissus and the Citron. It may come with a correct symmetrical wording, so you say: 'The ratio of Five to Ten is like the ratio of Two to Four. Conclusion: So Five is half of Ten.' Thus if you likened a quality to a certain quality, then likened that second quality to another quality, that produces for you the likeness of...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the first quality to the second quality by necessity. That is like your saying: 'Zayd's whiteness is like Amr's whiteness, and Amr's whiteness is like Khalid's whiteness. Conclusion: So Zayd's whiteness is like Khalid's whiteness.' This Conjunction gave the Five that it is half of the Ten, and also gave it that it has a ratio of a number resembling the ratio of another number. Likewise, the other gave that Zayd's whiteness resembles Amr's whiteness and resembles Khalid's whiteness. This is a place where one should be cautious, for some fools might use sophistry in it, as Al-Nashi' nicknamed Abu al-Abbas did when he said: 'If ten times ten is a hundred, then five times five is fifty.' That is because fifty is half of a hundred and five is half of ten, and the ratio of ten to a hundred is like the ratio of fifty to fifty [sic, text error?], and the ratio of five to ten is like the ratio of fifty to a hundred. This fallacious illusion only occurred because the speaker used an unclear wording in the premise. The correct way was to say: 'If ten repeated ten times is a hundred, then five repeated five times is twenty-five.' But people of the art of calculation abbreviated the lengthiness with a word they agreed to establish for understanding among themselves. They are not obliged more than clarifying to the ignorant only. Guard also against bringing different sentences. The meaning of that is that the attribute you describe the Reported About with in this type of Demonstration is different, so an error is generated upon you from that.
