Like your saying: 'The Rose is better in scent than the Lavender, and the Lavender is weaker in scent than the Musk.' This is a corrupt composition [59v] because the right of these Conjunctions is that the attribute be of one type except in degree only, because it is the Middle Term. It is not permissible except to be with one word in one meaning. The Middle Term in these two propositions is different: one is 'better in scent' and the second is 'weaker in scent'. This is not shared; both are different; the limit of Conjunction is not complete in them. Therefore, the result came out corrupt in some places. Perhaps it is true, but it is not trusted as we presented. It may be true once and false another. Do you not see that if you said: 'The Rose is better in scent than the Lavender, and the Lavender is weaker in scent than the Violet', Conclusion: 'So the Rose is better than the Violet' is true. If you said 'The Rose is better in scent than the Lavender, and the Lavender is weaker in scent than the Violet', Conclusion: 'So the Rose is better...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...in scent than the Violet', is true [Example repetition or slight variation]. If you said: 'The Rose is better in scent than the Lavender, and the Lavender is weaker in scent than the Musk', Conclusion: 'So the Rose is better in scent than the Musk' is false. If you commit to what I defined for you, you will always be truthful without doubt. That is to say: 'The Rose is better in scent than the Lavender, and the Lavender is better in scent than the Basil (Daymaran), so the Rose is better in scent than the Basil'. This arrangement never betrays you. We exemplify that with a Sharia example. We say: If a deceiver deceived and said 'Ali is more in virtues than Al-Abbas, and Al-Abbas is less in virtues than Abu Bakr', wanting to conclude from that: 'So Ali is more in virtues than Abu Bakr', and said: 'My premises are both true', that is not permitted for him. It is said to him: Put in the place of Abu Bakr the Messenger of God, peace be upon him. For two true premises also come to you, then look what is produced. You say: 'Ali is more in virtues than Al-Abbas, and Al-Abbas is less in virtues than the Messenger of God, peace be upon him'. These are two true premises. 'So Ali is more in virtues than the Messenger of God, peace be upon him'. This is a lie and disbelief. He is not left to take in the conclusion of one conjunction what the Reported About was described with in the first premise, and in the conclusion of another conjunction what the Reported About was described with in the second premise—like taking the mention of 'More' in one and 'Less' in the second. But what he wants from that is reversed upon him, so his deception appears shortly. Until if you make the judgment of the Middle Term one in wording, you are correct. That is like your saying: 'Ali is more in virtues than Abu Hurayrah, and Abu Hurayrah is more [60r] in virtues than Mu'awiyah. Conclusion: So Ali is better than Mu'awiyah'. This arrangement never betrays you. Two attributes became valid for you for the Reported About in this type of Demonstration: One is his superiority over the one you related him from, and the second is his superiority over the one you related to, who you related from first. Therefore, we titled it first that attributes are doubled in it. By God Almighty is success. 4 - Chapter on Types of Demonstration whose Premises Differ in Appearance but the Purpose in their Negation and Affirmation is One: This is a type of establishing Demonstration that is always true if arranged well. Like your saying: Some...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...existents are a thing that never ceased to be (Eternal). No existent is except the Creator, Substance, and Accident. That which never ceased to be is not Substance nor Accident. Conclusion: So He is the Creator, Mighty and Majestic. The first premise of these three premises is of the type we mentioned before this, connecting its end to the beginning of this chapter, which gives the Reported About more than one attribute. Do you not see that you affirmed for the Reported About that He never ceased to be, and that He is existent, and that He is a Creator, there is no god but He. The third premise is of the Disjunctive propositions; you validated in it the negation of Him being Substance or Accident, so it became necessary that the third part by necessity is the Creator, Mighty and Majestic. The second middle premise is of the two mentioned types; you took from the type giving the Reported About more than one attribute—like your saying in it that He never ceased to be and is not Substance nor Accident—and took from the Disjunctive your saying 'Not Substance and Not Accident', and also described the Existent therein as being more than one. These three premises produced one result. This type is frequently repeated in the folds of debate, frequently passing (1) during the search for requested truths. Because you are certain of the necessity of a certain thing, so you want to verify its attributes. You take every possible part the described could be described with, then negate from it what is valid to negate by correct evidences, until all are negated except one of them. That remaining one is the attribute of the thing whose true judgment you want to know. From that is that we say: One of [the people] killed Zayd (2). There was no one in the house except Yazid, Khalid, and Muhammad. Muhammad was sleeping, and Yazid was unconscious from an illness in him. Conclusion: [60v] So Khalid killed him. Premises here may be very many, and may be from all types of Demonstration, producing a correct production according to what we mentioned of the rank of every type of Demonstration in its chapter. From this chapter, it is understood that the father has two-thirds from the saying of God Almighty: {And his parents inherit from him, so for his mother is one-third} (4 An-Nisa: 11). That is because the money is a third and two-thirds. The money belongs to the parents, and for the mother from it is the third. Conclusion: So the two-thirds are for the father. By God Almighty is success.
foot_note:
1. (1) Kathir al-murur: Wa harr al-murur. 
2. Wahid min al-nas qatala Zaydan: Wahid man fi qibal Zayd.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: 5 - Chapter on Types of Demonstration whose Premises are Many, and each Premise necessitates the Premise following it: An example of that is you say: If eating is excessive, indigestion is necessary. If indigestion is necessary, the stomach weakens. If the stomach weakens, bad digestion is necessary. If bad digestion is necessary, sickness is necessary. Conclusion: So the existence of excessive eating necessitates excessive sickness. This is a correct demonstration because corruption of digestion does not exist except with sickness of the stomach; sickness of the stomach does not exist except with bad digestion; indigestion does not exist except with corruption of the stomach; and increase above the amount agreeing with the power of nature does not exist except with indigestion. What does not exist except another thing exists with its existence, and the second also if it exists necessitates a third, then the third does not exist except by the existence of the first. This also is something one should be cautious in placing its premises so that a false premise does not enter them. For if a speaker said: 'If lack of money is found, poverty is found; and if poverty is found, need is existing', and wanted to conclude from that: 'If lack of money is found, need is existing', this is false. Because lack of money is not poverty; a man may be a craftsman and possessor of (1) sufficiency, needing no one and having no excess. But if you said: 'If the state of falling short of sufficiency is found, poverty is found; and if poverty is found, need is found', that would produce a correct production, which is: 'If the state of falling short of sufficiency is found, need is found'. One should be cautious of such things from Homonymous Names general to meanings, so verifying their meanings with words specific to them. And be cautious of Universal Attributes, so do not apply them by their generality to some of what is under them excluding others. Some opponents deceived, saying to invalidate this Demonstration: 'If [61r] fire is non-existent, heat is non-existent; and if heat is non-existent, we do not need cooling'. He wanted to conclude: 'If fire is non-existent, we do not need cooling'. This is a lie because the feverish and the one in summer need cooling, and no fire is apparent with them. This is because the first premise is a lie. The correct way is to say: 'If fire is non-existent, the heat generated from it is non-existent'.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: This is a Sharia example: Every intercourse where the intercourser's knowledge of its interior, exterior, and ruling is valid is either a marriage-bed (Firash) or adultery ('Ahr). Every eye (person) permissible for the intercourser is a marriage-bed. Everything not a marriage-bed is adultery. The shared maidservant is adultery. Every possessor of adultery is an adulterer. So every intercourser with a shared maidservant is an adulterer. Every adulterer has the stone (punishment/deprivation). So every intercourser with a shared maidservant has the stone. These premises all produced that every intercourser with a shared maidservant has the stone. 6 - Chapter on Demonstration Conditional in Wording, Categorical in Meaning: Its example: If describing a thing with Intoxication is a description with Prohibition, and fig wine (Nabidh) if it ferments is described with Intoxication, then Prohibition is necessary for fig wine if it ferments. This, as you see, its appearance is that the description with Prohibition is only suspended on Intoxication. If you want to make it Categorical in its wording, you say: Prohibition is the ruling of every intoxicant; some intoxicants are fig wine if it ferments; so Prohibition is the ruling of fig wine if it ferments. A group of rioters used sophistry in this chapter saying: You have decided that two negatives do not produce a trusted production, yet in some of these chapters you established, you produce a consistent production from two negatives. And in this chapter also, like your saying: 'Whoever is not laughing is not human; the horse is not laughing; so the horse is not human'. And you say: 'Everyone who does not believe is not accepted by God Almighty; the idolater is not a believer; so he is not accepted by God Almighty'. The answer, and by God Almighty is success: The Negation from which we excluded establishing consistent Demonstration is every pure negation, which is every negation [not] affirming an attribute for the Reported About at all. Whether the negation is of this description—meaning with a wording of negation or a wording of affirmation—it never produces anything. We will mention something of this in a separate chapter in this register regarding the confusions [61v] some sophists attempted in Figures, God Almighty willing. As for what was Negation in wording while affirming a meaning and an attribute for the Reported About, it is not Negation but a correct Affirmation. One only observes the meaning the word gives, not the form of the word alone. Hence, it does not bind us to liken the Creator Almighty [to creation] in our negating from Him things that are also negated from many in...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...His creation. That does not necessitate likening Him Almighty, like our saying: 'The Creator Almighty is not a body', and 'The Accident is not a body'; 'The Creator Almighty is not an Accident', and 'The Body is not an Accident'. Because in this judgment we did not affirm for the Creator a state in which He shares with the Accident since we negated Bodily-ness from Him, nor with the Body since we negated Accident-ness from Him. This is the pure, abstract Negation. As for the propositions we mentioned just now, we affirmed Laughter for whoever is human, and affirmed for the Horse the negation of Humanity, and affirmed for it with every resemblance with everyone who is not laughing that they are not humans. Likewise, we affirmed for whoever does not believe the opposite of Acceptance, which is Disavowal (Tabarru'). We affirmed for whoever does not believe the opposite of Acceptance, which is Disavowal [Repetition in text]. And we affirmed the opposite of Faith, which is Disbelief, for the Idolater. We presented that if the meaning is restricted to two things, and you negate one of them, you have affirmed the other by necessity—so memorize this. If you negated both, you affirmed nothing at all. If you negated, you have affirmed by necessity; and if you affirmed the Negation, you have negated without doubt. Cultivate all this; it produces your certainty in the validity of your knowledge. 7 - Chapter on Demonstration Taken from a False Conclusion by Validating its Negation: Know that if one of the premises is a lie and the other is truth, and they produced a false conclusion of apparent falsehood, and the lying premise was what your opponent accepted, you indulge him in that to show him the obscenity of his production. Because if a thing is false, its negation is true without doubt. So if a conclusion is false, its negation is true. Taking Demonstration in this manner may be valid with a consistent validity trusted always. Example of that: A person opposed you saying: 'The world is eternal'. You said to him: I indulge you in the criticism of this premise, so I say: 'The world is eternal'. I add to it another correct one which is: 'The Eternal is not composed'. The Result: 'The world is not composed'. This is an apparent lie. If this is a lie, its contradictory is true, which is 'The world is composed'. If this is true, and we have presented that 'The Eternal is not composed', it is correct that 'The world is not eternal' since it is composed. The falsehood of his premise appeared when he said: 'The world is eternal'. This is a correct inference that [62r] never betrays, since it takes the opposite of the conclusion and returns the conclusion to absurdity. Remember here what I wrote for you regarding Moods of the three Figures in which Demonstration is valid...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...by returning it to absurdity. From that also is the Christians saying: 'The First Agent is Three'. We say: 'So our Lord the Agent is Three'. Then we add to this premise a correct, certain premise which is: 'And Three is a number, and Number is composed of its parts equal to its whole'. So Three is composed of its parts equal to its totality. You said 'The First is Three', so 'The First is composed of its parts equal to its totality and whole'. Yet you and we are certain that 'The First is non-composed and non-possessor of parts'. So 'The First is composed possessor of parts, non-composed and non-possessor of parts'. This is impossible. Since this is impossible, and it is correct that He is [not?] composed [Text says 'correct that he is composed', context implies logical reductio leading to negation], it is correct that He is not a number. Since it is correct that He is not Three, the falsehood of your corrupt premise appeared. By God Almighty is success. 8 - Chapter on Demonstration Composed of Many Conclusions Taken from Various Premises: Example of that is to say: Every counted thing possesses two ends (limits), and every possessor of two ends is finite; so every counted thing is finite. Then we take the conclusion of this first demonstration and say: Every counted thing is finite, and every finite thing possesses parts; the Conclusion: Every counted thing possesses parts. Then we take the conclusion of this second demonstration and say: Every counted thing possesses parts, and every possessor of parts is composed; Conclusion: So every counted thing is composed. And every composed thing is accompanied by composition; Conclusion: Every counted thing is accompanied by composition. Then we take this fourth demonstration and say: Every counted thing is accompanied by composition, and every accompanied by composition [is preceded by composition? or did not precede composition]; Conclusion: So every counted thing did not precede composition. Then we take the conclusion of this fifth demonstration saying: Every counted thing did not precede composition. Then we take this sixth demonstration saying: The world did not precede the Originated, and what did not precede the Originated is originated like it. Conclusion: So the world is originated. In this chapter, premises may come to you as Categorical, Conditional, Conjunctive, Disjunctive, and Inference by the contrary of what comes out in the conclusion. In general, it disposes for you in all types of Demonstration. All of that, if you take it according to the conditions we presented, its production is trusted. Praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: 9 - Chapter [62v] on Rulings of Propositions: Know that among propositions, there are other propositions enfolded in your mentioning them, even if you did not utter them. This meaning is taken from Equivalents and from Conversion of Propositions, and we have mentioned them. This is like your saying: 'It is not permissible for the Eternal to be composed'. Enfolded for us in this speech is that 'It is not permissible for the Composed to be Eternal' by necessity, inevitably. Enfolded in it also is that 'The Composed is Originated'. Likewise if you said: 'Every intoxicant is forbidden', enfolded in it is that 'The intoxicant is not lawful', and 'What is not forbidden is not intoxicant' [Logic check: Contrapositive]. Enfolded in it also is that 'Date wine if it intoxicates is forbidden', 'Henbane if it intoxicates is forbidden', 'Apple wine if it intoxicates is forbidden', and so on. Just as if you said: 'Zayd is walking', enfolded for you in it is that he is moving, possesses a healthy leg, and is alive, and many things. Therefore, a group possessing rioting and ignorance thought that we are mistaken in our saying that 'The single proposition produces', and they refused what we mentioned. Their thought is not correct because all we mentioned is not 'Production' (Inference/Syllogism), since the condition of the meaning of Production is that we benefit from the gathering of both propositions a meaning not enfolded in one of them at all. For if you said: 'Every intoxicant is forbidden', there is no affirmation in it that 'Date wine intoxicates' inevitably at all, but until you utter it and validate for it that it may intoxicate. If you made this attribute for it, then you decide for it Prohibition without condition. Otherwise, in your saying 'Every intoxicant is forbidden' is only the possibility that it intoxicates, not the necessity; since in the world are many things that do not intoxicate, so perhaps it is one of them. Ponder this, leave indulgence, and verify. This which we mentioned in this chapter regarding propositions understood from propositions not uttered is only 'Enfoldment' (Intiwa') in them. The meaning of Enfoldment is that we [pointed] to many meanings and expressed them with one word seeking brevity. In general, reporting about their particulars enters into reporting about their totality. Like their saying: 'Human is living'; you have reported that Zayd and Amr are living, and Hind is living, and in general every man and woman, because they are parts of Human. Understand this. Likewise, enfolded in every proposition is the invalidation of its opposite. Like the saying of God Almighty: {Indeed, Abraham was forbearing, grieving} (9 At-Tawbah: 114). Enfolded in it is the negation of the opposite of Forbearance, which is Foolishness. So enfolded...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...in it is that Abraham is not foolish. As for Production (Inference), it is contrary to that, which is what we have explained. Praise be to God. Know also that not every time [63r] the speech you want to make a premise comes to you in the arrangement we presented to you in taking Demonstration. Rather, sayings contradicting those ranks come to you in three ways. One way is contrary to all we mentioned in rank and meaning; do not pay attention to it, and verify the rank and truth upon the conditions we presented to you, for no Demonstration stands for you from other than what we said at all. Another way contains extra words that neither fix the meaning nor corrupt it; if you remained silent about them, you would not need them nor mind them. You undertake taking Demonstration from the rest of the correct speech. Those extra words only give a meaning that is not in anything. From this place, establishing the Hadd (punishment) is affirmed for us by the testimony of two witnesses who agreed on what necessitates the Hadd, then differed in attributes having no meaning in the testimony, while the testimony is complete without them. Like two witnesses testifying against Zayd that he stole a cow; one said 'Yellow' and the other said 'Black'. Its being yellow or black is not what contradicts his stealing it nor negates it—we mean his stealing it—and the speech is complete without mentioning any of that. From this same chapter and its opposite, we invalidated the confession of one who confessed an impossibility, like one who said: 'So-and-so, I killed him with my magic', because of our knowledge that magic does not kill. The addition he added is corrupting the meaning, so it is a corrupt premise. If he confessed once saying: 'I killed him with a sword', and said another time: 'I killed him with a spear', it would be a valid confession because none of these additions contradicts the killing; his silence about them and his mentioning them is equal since there is nothing in mentioning them that corrupts the premise. Similar to this is what people of sects opposing us mention, that the world since it originated has [existed] seven thousand years. Others said five thousand years. Others said six thousand years. Others said four hundred thousand years. We said: We have no limit regarding that. It is possible it is multiples of multiples of all these numbers, and possible it is less than that. All these sayings do not impugn (1) our agreement that the world has a First and a Beginning. These...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...are all words regarding which we do not say they merely do not corrupt the Beginning and Origination, but we do not restrict to all that so we say: Rather, all of them, despite their difference, necessitate Origination and Beginning. So we are not harmed by the difference of such words, nor their increase, nor their decrease, if they give the correctness of the sought meaning and do not corrupt it. The third way is that a wording comes for which Demonstration has established the obligation of submission to it, so it needs to be taken in the premises between us and those who oppose us [63v] in some opinions among those who acknowledge with us that wording and submit to it. In that wording is a clear omission (deletion) and a word whose mention was left out. Our opponent cannot deny that, and that omission harms nothing; it is as if it were mentioned with no difference, if its being established in the meaning is certain. That is like a premise we take from the saying of God Almighty: {And if you are ill or on a journey or one of you comes from the place of relieving himself or you have contacted women and find no water, then seek clean earth} [4 An-Nisa: 43]. There is no doubt for the hearer of this verse, if he has the slightest understanding of the Arabic tongue and the least knowledge of the Islamic creed, that here is a meaning we pointed to by necessity which was omitted from the wording, sufficing with the fact that it is not hidden at all. It is "Fa-ahdathtum" (and you became ritually impure). The place of the meaning of this word is between "Journey" and "Or comes". Likewise, if we needed another premise from His saying Almighty: {That is the expiation for your oaths when you have sworn} [5 Al-Ma'idah: 89]. There is no doubt for one who has a tongue among the people of the Islamic creed and Arabic language that the meaning is "Fa-hanithtum" (and you broke the oath). Omission may be on another rank, which is that the wording in the structure of the language necessitates a link to a meaning not mentioned, which must be corrected. Like the speaker saying: 'So-and-so repented'; it is not confused to a hearer that he sinned. 'So-and-so apostatized'; it is not confused to a hearer that he had been a Muslim. 'This money is weighed'; it is not confused to a hearer that it is by a scale. Like this is much. Such omission does not harm the speech at all; the speech is correct. Taking premises from it for Demonstration is obligatory, and affirming the meaning for the omitted part is necessary. No one makes excuses in such omission except a dull ignoramus, a silly stubborn person, or an interrupted sneaker-away (1). Likewise if you said: 'Zayd struck Amr with the sword and separated his head', you produced that 'Zayd killed Amr'. This is a true, correct production and correct presentation. It does not harm you if you omitted from the premise: 'And everyone whose head is separated is killed', and 'Everyone who separated...
foot_note: 1. (1) Mutasallil: Thus wherever it appears; in Al-Fisal 2: 180 it is *Mutasallil 'anhu* (sneaking away from it).

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the head of another has killed him, killed So-and-so'. Likewise His saying Almighty: {So a fast of three days during Hajj and of seven when you have returned. Those are ten} (2 Al-Baqarah: 196). This is a correct production sufficing instead of saying: 'Seven and three is equal to ten, so those are ten', due to the correctness of knowledge of that. Understand now from this chapter that contradicting the ranks presented is only in three ways: Corruption of rank and meaning, so discard it. Increase of wording; if it corrupts the meaning, discard it; if it does not corrupt, do not mind (1) it, for it will not harm you. Omission from wording; if it corrupts the meaning, discard it; if it does not corrupt the meaning, do not mind it [64r], for it will not harm you. Cultivate all this, for the benefit in it is very great. Know that if the opponent acknowledges to you the two premises which are upon the conditions of correctness we presented, but denies the Conclusion, he has contradicted himself, fallen, and his saying is void. Likewise, if the Conclusion is false as we presented, it is obligatory on him to believe its opposite, as we presented regarding the Demonstration taken from the false Conclusion where you indulge the opponent in one of the premises. If he believes that opposite, he has returned to the truth, and it binds him to declare his corrupt premise a lie. If he believes the Conclusion and does not retract declaring his corrupt premise a lie, he has believed the thing and its opposite, or denied them both. Speech with him has become silly and fallen, and the invalidity of his saying has appeared. By God Almighty is success, and to Him belongs the command before and after, there is no god but He. Do not err and estimate that whoever agreed with you in your saying, what bound you binds him. This is ignorance from the one who wants to bind his opponent with that, or rioting. Know that the agreement of opponent to opponent is divided into two parts: One is agreement in the Conclusion only without agreement with him in the Premises producing the Conclusion. This is what we told you not to regard, since he only agreed with you on that due to his presenting other premises that produced that result—either they are corrupt or your premises are corrupt. For this, even if his premises entered him into agreeing with you now, they will exit him shortly to disagreeing with you. The second way is that he agrees with you on your premises. This is the necessary agreement by which the proof is established if they are correct in general, or...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...proof is established against the two opponents together only in every case—whether correct or incorrect—by their committing to them. If a speaker says: 'How do premises differ and produce one [result], especially when one operation in some premises is truth and the second operation is falsehood, so truth and falsehood produce a single production?' Let him remember what we mentioned before beginning to mention the Moods of Figures: that corrupt premises may produce a correct production. We explained it there. What we mention after this chapter is mentioned there: presenting two negative premises. So we say to you: 'Not every human is a stone (1), and not every stone is inanimate'. Result: 'Not every human is inanimate'. We said there that this is a deceptive, treacherous presentation, because if you trusted it and submitted to it, he would present to you like it saying: 'Not every human is black, and not every black thing is living'. Result: 'Not every black thing is living' [Text error: Result should be 'Not every human is living', which is false]. This is a corrupt presentation. It may produce a production agreeing [64v] with the correct production in some places, except that if you follow it, just as it entered you into truth in a place, it exits you from it in another. We explained this there and in the chapter following this chapter, and we left no way for ambiguity against you. The Jews often argue against us that we have agreed with them that their religion was true and their prophet true, and they want from here to bind us to acknowledging it even now. Grasp this place and know that we only agreed with them on their premises, which are premises that produced for us agreeing with them in what they mentioned. So strike away from those premises and following them in what they produced, and cling to the agreement in the Conclusion only. Do not be deceived in the Conclusion at all until the Premises are correct. We and they only corrected that 'Whoever is established to have come with miracles is a Prophet; Moses, peace be upon him, came with miracles, so Moses is a Prophet'. This premise itself produces the Prophethood of Muhammad, peace be upon him. We say: 'Everyone who came with a miracle is a Prophet, and Muhammad, peace be upon him, came with miracles, so he is a Prophet'. Grasp this very well. We have agreed with the Proponents of Analogy (Qiyas) in many results, except that their premises are other than our premises. It is not obligatory that our binding them or their binding us—lifting the riot with those results—is binding, but until we agree on the premises necessitating them. If a rioter riots saying: 'We have shown you premises whose production differs', and mentions the inference of the Kharijite and the Murji'ite by the saying of God Almighty: {None will burn therein except...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the most wretched, who denied and turned away} (92 Al-Layl: 15-16). The Kharijite said: 'Traditions and verses have been authenticated that the Killer burns therein except the most wretched who denied and turned away. So the Killer is the most wretched who denied and turned away.' The Murji'ite said: 'Traditions and verses have been authenticated that the Acknowledger of Tawhid and Faith enters Paradise, and the Fire is burned therein by none except the most wretched who denied and turned away. The Adulterer did not deny nor turn away, so the Adulterer does not burn therein.' Know that this is of the Demonstration I alerted you to—so remember it (1)—when I informed you that among accepted premises is speech containing omission. The omission in these premises which the ignorant estimated produced a different production is something Demonstration has indicated. It is the intent: 'He does not burn therein', and that it is specifically among the fires of Hell; no one burns in *that* fire except people of this description. It is not in this that *every* fire in Hell is burned therein only by people of this description. This is also something one should be cautious of by exhausting all that is connected to the premises; otherwise, it is an incomplete premise. It is not accepted by us in this verse alone, but [65r] many verses and many reports. We join them all to one another and do not take some speech without some, corrupting meanings. I warn you against the rioting of a group who, if they debate, seize upon it being a single verse or a single hadith. This is a severe fall and excessive ignorance, since what they seized upon is not more worthy to be taken as a premise to whose production one returns than other verses and other hadiths. This is arbitrariness and sophistry, so beware of it also greatly. 10 - Chapter on Fallacies We Cited Fearing a Rioter May Riot with Them in Demonstration: One should be cautious of fallacies and rioting used by rioters (2) in converting premises and in Figures. We have mentioned a part in some past chapters. From that is that we said: The Universal Negative converts to Universal Negative. If a speaker says to you: 'No Persian except a Non-Arab ('Ajam)'; this is true. Its conversion 'No Non-Arab except a Persian' is a lie. So be alert to the place of fallacy. Know that this proposition is Affirmative not Negative, even if its appearance is Negation. Remember what we said to you in this translated chapter; it is a chapter of Demonstration conditional in wording, categorical in meaning in producing from...
foot_note:
1. (1) Fatadhakkar 'alayhi: Thus, repeated in Ibn Hazm. 
2. After 'Mushaghibun' is 'Wa nahan fi sad' (and trending in P).

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...two premises whose appearance is that they are Negative. That clarifies this place for you. We increase clarification here, so we say: Do you not see that you have affirmed Non-Arabness for every Persian? This is Universal Affirmative and not Negative at all. Since it is so, its conversion is Particular Affirmative, which is your saying: 'And some Non-Arabs are Persian'. Likewise your saying: 'Not a thing of Substances is carried in an Accident'; this is true. If you converted and said: 'And not a thing of Accidents is carried in a Substance', this is a lie. Understand the place of fallacy in this chapter. It is that the Conversion whose ruling we mentioned in Negatives and validated is only the negation of the resemblance of the two Essences or the negation of the resemblance of their parts. We did not intend the negation of the resemblance of other than them. Here, you only negated the resemblance of the *place* of the Substance to the *place* of the Accident. Their place is other than them, and the place of every thing is other than the thing in the place without doubt. Be cautious also of the fallacy occurring in converting the Universal Affirmative. It may be said to you: 'Is not every past of time having been future?' You must say Yes. It is said to you: 'So some future has been past?' This is a lie. Be cautious of the place of fallacy here. It is that the erroneous speech entered only from equating two times which are other than the two attributes which are Past-ness and Future-ness. For Past-ness is a report about a thing that was existing; [it is] a state. As for Future, because the Future is non-existence, and there is no state for non-existence. The wording of [65v] the two Reported About necessitates their difference, not equating (1) them. The correction of that is to say: 'Some future becomes past'; this is correct. Be cautious also of an error occurring in converting the Particular Affirmative. Example: 'Some wine has been juice'. If you said: 'Some juice has been wine', you lied. The error here is from equating the two times of the two Reported About, while their time is other than them. Conversion is only valid in attributes adhering to the two Reported About, not in attributes adhering to others. The correction of that is to say: 'And some juice became wine or becomes wine'. Memorize now that Conversion is only in Essences or Attributes adhering to Essences. A group also used fallacy [from] some fools whose doctrine is spoiling truths and running to no goal, seeking what he does not know—so how about others? He said: The First Figure may lie. He says: 'The horse alone is neighing, and the neighing is living (animal); so the horse alone is living'. The error here came only from an addition added spoiling the meaning, which is 'Alone'. Remember what I told you in...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the chapter before this chapter regarding the ruling of the added word in premises corrupt in wording and rank. Contemplate the extra words as I defined for you. Know that the Described in the Conclusion does not necessitate that that attribute is only for it inevitably; rather, it may encompass it and encompass others. We increase clarification for you to strengthen your caution against the confusion of everyone who does not fear God Almighty in striving to spoil truths among the deceivers who are more deserving of punishment than deceivers in cash and sales. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever cheats us is not of us." No cheat is greater than cheating in invalidating truths. We say, and by God Almighty is success: Contemplate the weakness of this deceiver. If he decides that 'The horse alone is neighing', it becomes correct without doubt that 'The neighing alone is a horse', because neighing is an attribute equal to the horse, not more general than it—we alerted you to this in the chapter of Converting Propositions. When this deceiver brought a proposition necessitating that 'The neighing alone is a horse', he said: 'And the neighing is living', after stipulating the uniqueness of the neighing to horseness. He inserted in his saying 'The neighing is living' that it is the neighing intended by mention in the first premise. He necessitated by the rank of his wording that the description of the neighing with life is an equal description, because it is a more general description. So he became a sayer of 'The neighing alone is living'. This second premise is camouflaged as you see; it is false because it was placed in a position of falsehood and made to resemble truths. Due to the falsehood of the premise, the conclusion was false. I have explained [66r] to you that the falsehood of the second premise was only because he built it universal in wording upon a particular described object. Understand this and be very cautious of the people of stupidity. The correct way was to say in the Conclusion: 'So the horse is living', and not mention 'Alone'. Because 'Alone' in reality with 'Neighing' is a report about the horse. The word 'Alone' is not a follower of the Horse to be mentioned in the Conclusion, but it is a follower of the Neighing—which is the Middle Term. Had he mentioned it in the second premise with the Neighing saying: 'The horse alone is neighing, and it alone is neighing living, so the horse is living', he would have been correct. From that also, if a speaker said while pointing to a specific man: 'The human is a doctor', this wording would be general while its interior is Specificity. If he carried upon it a description that must only apply to a general meaning, he would be lying. Some sophists asked a doctor saying to him: 'Does heat dissolve cold?' He said Yes. He said: 'And does cold dissolve heat?' He said Yes. He said: 'So heat is cold and cold is heat.' The doctor said to him: 'The two modes of their dissolving are different. It is not because of their agreement...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...in a certain attribute that one of them must be the other.' The rioter persisted and refused. When the doctor saw his madness and stupidity, he said to him: 'Are you alive?' He said Yes. He said: 'And is the dog alive?' He said Yes. He said: 'So you are the dog and the dog is you.' Know that these two riots are from the Second Figure. He performed poorly in their arrangement because the condition in the Second Figure is that one of its premises must be Negative inevitably. Understand this and grasp it; it will never betray you. Do not pay attention to the people of rioting, for such people only run the course of jesters for silly kings and entertainers for weak obeyed ones; they are not of the people of truths at all, so do not care about them a bit. They also said: We have found two Affirmatives that do not produce [truth]: 'It is impossible that the human be a stone' and 'It is impossible that the stone be living'. These are two true [premises]. Result: 'It is impossible that the human be living'. This is a lie. Understand also the place of fallacy here is: These two premises are Negative with a pure negation having nothing of Affirmation at all. We said that two Negatives do not produce. We mentioned to you before that what is observed is only the reality of the meaning understood from the word, not the form of the word alone. These two premises, even if they are with the wording of Affirmation, their meaning is Pure Negation because they negated from [66v] the Human Stoniness and from the Stone Life, and did not affirm for a stone nor for a human a meaning at all other than what their names affirmed for them only. They also used fallacy saying: 'Every braying thing is living, and not one of humans is braying living'. These are two true [premises]. Result: 'So not one of humans is living'. This is a lie. The fallacy only came from the Attribute with which the Braying was described, which also encompasses with it the thing from which Braying was negated. This is the worst arrangement. He should have shared it with what is not shared by the one from whom he negated sharing it entirely in the second premise. From this chapter is that we say: 'Not every taker of money without its right is a thief; and every taker of money without its right while knowing is a debauchee'. These are two true [premises]. Result: 'So not every taker of money without its right while knowing it is a debauchee'. This is a lie. The fallacy only came because you described taking money without right in the Affirmative premise with an attribute encompassing it and encompassing every thief with it. You should have described it with what is not shared by the one from whom you negated sharing it in the other. They also used fallacy by dropping something from the Described. They said: 'Hair is other than a thing...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...existing in any of the bones; and bones exist in every human'. These are two true [premises]. Result: 'So hair is other than a thing existing in any of the human'. This is a lie. This is an ugly fallacy, because the Subject—which is the Reported About intended by description in the first premise—is only the Bones, because he negated Hair from them. Then he affirmed the mention of Bones in the second premise in that he described their place only. We presented that the Relation by Affirmation is only in the Essences of the Reported About and in the Attributes adhering to them, not in their places. However, if you corrected, you would say: 'So hair is not in any of the bones of the human'. Also, the power of these two premises is a Particular power because bones are some of the parts of the human, not in all of him. Remember what we told you before: that the Middle Term must be Reported About in one premise and Report in the other, or Reported About in both, or Report in both. If it is Reported About in one and Report in the second, look: If both are Affirmative, the description by it of what was described must be essential general to all of it; and the Reported About must also be generalized in the other premise by what became a description for it therein. If one of them is Negative, let the Negation you described the Negated-from in one of the premises be negated in reality from it and from the other by that Described in this [67r], because the Described thing in one of the premises is an Attribute in the other. If it is Described in both premises, one of the premises must be Negative. Then what you negated in the one will be general to what you negated it from, and negated from the Described in the second, according to what is stipulated in it. If it is Described in both, the action in the two Affirmatives is what we said in the First Figure. And do in the ones where one is Negative what we told you in the Second Figure. 11 - Chapter on Rulings of Demonstration in Laws (Sharias) according to the Ranks we Presented: The words appearing in Sharias, to which submission is obligatory after their establishment, and to which return is made regarding what is disputed of them, are: Either a General Universal Saying with a Quantifier. Or what runs the course of the Quantified from the Indefinite whose power in language is the power of the Quantified. And from the Report from which is understood what is understood from the Command. The Command also is upon the generality of meaning, except where it is clarified after this, God Almighty...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...willing. That is like his saying, peace be upon him: "Every intoxicant is forbidden"; this is Universal with a Quantifier. Or like His saying Almighty: {Indeed, intoxicants, gambling, [sacrificing on] stone alters, and divining arrows are defilement from the work of Satan, so avoid it} (5 Al-Ma'idah: 90). This is a general command. Like it is His saying Almighty: {Indeed, God commands you to render trusts to whom they are due} (4 An-Nisa: 58). Then these three modes, each divides into four parts: One is Universal in Wording, Universal in Meaning. The second is Particular in Wording, Particular in Meaning, which is what is judged regarding some of the species not all. This type also—be alert to what I say to you—is also general regarding what its wording necessitated. This type and the one before it are known by themselves, running according to their establishment in the language. They do not need an evidence that they necessitate what is understood from them. If they needed an evidence, that evidence would only be a word expressing its meaning; so the indicated would not be more in need of an evidence than that which is an evidence for it. This necessitates that nothing is ever established. In this is the invalidation of all truths, and the existence of evidences of existents having no primaries. This is impossible, corrupt. It is known by primary reason that from the Word, its meaning is [understood], not part of its meaning nor none of its meaning. Therefore, languages were established so that meanings are understood from words. The third part is Particular in Wording, Universal in Meaning. It is what the Wording came with regarding some of the species not all, but that judgment includes the rest of that species. This is not known [67v] from that Particular Wording, but from another incoming word to transfer the judgment of this Particular to the rest of the Species. The fourth part is Universal in Wording, Particular in Meaning. It is what came with a general wording while the intent is some of what that wording necessitated. However, this section and the [previous] one, their meanings are not understood from their wordings at all, but by a demonstration from another word, or intuition of reason, or sense. All that clarifies that only some of what that word necessitates was intended by it. Were it not for the Demonstration we mentioned, it would not be permissible at all to transfer it from its place in the language, nor to specialize some of what is named by it excluding the rest of all that is named by that word. As for the type which is Universal in Wording, Particular in Meaning, it is like people's saying in customary...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...address: "People are corrupted"; the meaning is only some of them. This is by intuition of reason, because people do not become corrupted all of them except by the departure of virtues entirely. Virtues are genera and species arranged in the structure of the world, and there is no way for an entire species to be non-existent completely such that it is not found in the world at all. And like the speaker saying: "Water is life for the thirsty"; he only means some waters. This is known by sense because seawater and bitter waters are not life for the thirsty. Of this type is the saying of God Almighty: {Those to whom the people said, 'Indeed, the people have gathered against you'} (3 Aal Imran: 173). This is known by reason that He Almighty only meant some people, because the meeting of all people informing them is impossible. From that is the saying of God Almighty: {When you stand up for prayer, wash your faces} (5 Al-Ma'idah: 6). The intent of that is only some states of standing for prayer, not others, which is the state of a person being in ritual impurity; this is only known by another clarification. Know that the meaning of this word is what we mentioned. This is used greatly in speech, except that there must be a proof diverting it from what was established as an expression for it in the language; otherwise, it is arbitrariness from its claimer and corruption of the clarity by which understanding occurs. I wish I knew: If the word is not an expression for the meaning, and every meaning does not have a known expression... (text unclear: 'ah'?), then what does he want to do with these words which... (text unclear: 'r'?) carries them on the basis that their universality... (text unclear)? Or he says by suspension (Tawaqquf) until the intent appears to him? And by what does he want to distinguish between meanings according to his claim? Does he find anything other than another word? And is that other word, in the possibility of doubt regarding the intent by it and its meaning, except like this first word with no difference? And so on forever. If this were correct, our superiority over beasts would be void, since understanding did not occur for us by names applying to named things. The rational person should not be pleased for himself [68r] with any speech that leads him to invalidating understanding, for that is an exit from the culture of reason and mockery of the blessings of the First One who favored us with these great powers by which we deserved that He addresses us. Among what exited by correct evidences from some of what its apparent wording necessitates is His saying Almighty in the verse of prohibition: {And your mothers who suckled you and your sisters through nursing} (4 An-Nisa: 23). And His saying Almighty: {The [unmarried] woman or [unmarried] man found guilty of sexual intercourse - lash each one of them with a hundred lashes} (24 An-Nur: 2). {And the thief, male and female, cut their hands} (5 Al-Ma'idah: 38).

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...and much of the like. Were it not for accepted proofs from other words clarifying to us that the intent by prohibition is some wet-nurses and sucklings, and some adulteresses and adulterers not others, and some thieves not others, it would have been obligatory to carry these words upon everything named by them, even if the Part also of these meanings is applied to by what applies to the Whole. As for the Particular Wording into which a Universal Meaning enters, it is His saying Almighty: {O you who have believed} (4 An-Nisa: 19) at the beginning of Surah An-Nisa, then the address continued to His saying Almighty: {Prohibited to you are your mothers} (4 An-Nisa: 23) the verse. Everything mentioned therein is prohibited for other than those who believed, but not by this wording, rather by other proofs from other words which also applied this judgment to those not named in this place. Were it not for those other words, those not named by the name of who was addressed would not have entered into this judgment at all. We only mentioned this section so an ignorant person does not think that this judgment transferred from this wording to other than whom it necessitates. If you want to present premises from the types we mentioned at the beginning of this chapter—and we have said that return is made to them regarding what is disputed—you say: 'Every intoxicant is wine (Khamr), and every wine is forbidden. Result: So every intoxicant is forbidden'. This is a Conjunction from the First Mood of the First Figure. If you wish, you say: 'Every thief of property equal to or more than a quarter of a dinar, cutting his hand is [obligatory] upon him; and Zayd stole something not less than a quarter of a dinar; so cutting his hand is [obligatory] upon Zayd'. Thus is done in all Commands, which is that the Command comes out with a Universal Report wording encompassing what the word necessitates, to which obedience is obligatory. Know that the Word, if it is of Homonymous words, runs upon all the types necessitated by that word—if capable of that—wherever they are found gathered or separate. No one has the right to say: 'I do not apply the judgment except upon the gathering of all meanings necessitated by the Name', because he becomes then contradictory to the judgment of the Name from where he estimated he is agreeing with it. Because every part of it, that Name applies [68v] to it. So if he does not apply it to that part if he finds it separate, he has prevented applying the Name to its generality and what it necessitates. This is invalidating the subject of the Name. If that is impossible in Nature, or it is a general word but no...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...understandable clarification stands from it; or it is a word applying to one type or one attribute, but its generality is impossible in Nature, with no way to it nor to excluding a limited thing from it; or affirmation by all aspects necessitated by that Name is not obligatory by the ruling of Sharia with certainty—then nothing follows from it except the least of what that wording necessitates. Because what exceeds this amount, one is not capable of fulfilling it. Incapacity is a preventing cause, and an utmost limit in clarifying that that wording was not intended for a generality that cannot be borne at all. That is like a speaker saying: 'Call the people for me to feed them'; there is no way to generalizing all people. This is only for a group to whom the name 'people' applies. Likewise where God Almighty mentioned 'The Needy' (Masakin) or 'The Poor' (Fuqara), since other than this is not bearable at all. Whoever tasks another with the Impossible has exited the boundary of one being spoken to. From the section which we said is a word encompassing possessors of various attributes is His saying Almighty where He mentioned 'Muhsanat' (Chaste/Protected women). It is not permissible to specialize some to whom this name applies excluding others, nor is it permissible to refrain from applying the judgment until all attributes gather, where every attribute of them is not Ihsan (protection/chastity) [alone]. But if one attribute or more is found, the name expressed by it becomes obligatory for it. It is a name applying to chaste women, free women, married women, and Muslim women—unless a wording comes preventing the generality of all we mentioned, so one stops at it as we presented. Likewise His saying Almighty: {And do not marry those [women] whom your fathers married} (4 An-Nisa: 22). Marriage (Nikah) applies to the valid contract and to intercourse, whether valid or invalid. So everyone the father had intercourse with by adultery or otherwise is forbidden to the son. You say in a premise of this chapter: 'Everything the father married of women is forbidden to the son; and Hind, Zayd's father married her; so Hind is forbidden to Zayd'. The Middle Term here is Marriage and Father. The Divided Terms: In the Major Premise are Women, Son, and Forbidden; and in the Minor are Zayd and Hind, which come out in the Result. Know that what I told you—that the Word applying to various types is upon its generality for all types under it, because they have no genus—is like the Word applying to the single Type in its generality of individuals, with no difference. Unless a proof is established [69r] as we presented that the intent...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...is some of those types not all, and some of those individuals not all. Then it is taken in that place specifically, not where that word is found in another place; for it is carried upon its generality for everything under it always. Because that proof which transferred it from its generality in the first place did not enter on the basis that it transferred it from its place in the language definitively, but it indicated that the intent by it in this place specifically is some of what its place in the language necessitates only. As for the speaker saying: 'So-and-so does not wrong [anyone] a grain of mustard', nothing is understood from that upon verification and abandoning looseness except what the wording necessitated specifically—that he does not wrong [regarding] mustard specifically. This is what the wording was established for in the language. It is not understood from that that he does not wrong in fortresses, estates, and houses, because estates and houses are not called 'mustard' at all. But if a speaker said: 'He does not wrong people a thing', or said 'He does not wrong in a thing', then he generalizes with negation everything upon which the name 'wrong' falls. If this is not so, it is because I attached a meaning in Names to Named things, and it was established in intellects that there is no clarification except by words expressing meanings assigned to them in the language. This is what no one knows other than it except one misleading himself, stubborn against his sense, indulgent where indulgence is not appropriate. Likewise His saying Almighty: {Say not to them [so much as], "Uff"} (17 Al-Isra: 23). Nothing is understood from the wording except the prevention of "Uff" only. As for killing, beating, and others, there is no prevention from them in this wording at all, because all that is not named "Uff" nor expressed by "Uff". If a human killed another, and a reporter reported about him and a witness testified that he said "Uff" to him, he would be a liar, a false witness, and a committer of a major sin—by the judgment of the Chosen One for mediation between us and the First One, peace be upon him, mighty is his Sender and majestic—since he judged that false testimony is among the major sins. Whoever is not deterred by the ugliness of exiting intellects, let him be deterred by the fear of severe punishment on the Day of Recompense; we seek refuge in God from that. If a swearer swore against the killer that he said "Uff" to the killed, his oath would be a false oath (Ghamus). So how did one describing himself with understanding permit judging a judgment by which he admits against himself that he is a liar if he verifies the judgment? By my life, many of them are virtuous, understanding, righteous, honored by their merit, but deficiency has not spared any human except those protected by Divine powers among the Prophets, peace be upon them [69v] specifically. The slip of the scholar is very harmful; if it did not infect others, its harm would be less. But when God Almighty said {And to parents, good treatment (Ihsan)}, this wording necessitated...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...performing everything called Ihsan (Goodness), and repelling everything called Isa'ah (Badness/Harm), because Badness is the opposite of Goodness. Goodness is obligatory, so Badness is forbidden. Because your saying 'Do good to So-and-so' stands in place of your saying 'Do not do bad to him'; that is a meaning necessitated by it only. But your saying 'Do not do bad to him' does not contain 'Do good to him'. Likewise if you said 'Do not do good to him', there is not in it that you do bad to him at all, because this is of the Opposites having intermediates. The intermediate here is what is between Badness and Goodness: Leaving alone (Mutarakah). But if you said 'Do bad to So-and-so', in it is the removal of Goodness from him, because the Opposite repels the Opposite; if one occurs, the other is invalid. Ponder these meanings; you will be illuminated in all your requests by the light your Creator Almighty granted you, by which He brought your resemblance close to Angels and separated you from Beasts. Otherwise, you would be like one stumbling in the dark, confused, not knowing what you undertake in reality, nor leaving by certainty but by sensing and rushing—which perhaps lead you to destruction and cast you into perils. May God guide us and you by His grace. If you reach this chapter, stop at it and cast your thought to what we spoke to you about just now regarding Equivalents (Mutala'imat) which we expressed with expressions. Perhaps [some] of the heedless—whose righteousness is desired more than they desire righteousness for themselves—will say upon looking into it: 'This author has troubled himself with something everyone equals him in knowing'. Let him know that we only view meanings with agreed-upon words to be decisive over what is obscure to understand of what is not of their type. Here the merit of our speech just now on Equivalents appears to you, and you find great relief in understanding it. Since we presented at the beginning of our book that there is no way to know the realities of things except by the mediation of the Word, there is no way to transfer the mandate of Reason from its place regarding the existence of things on their ranks which their Originator, Glorious and Mighty, arranged them upon. Nor is there a way to transfer the requirement of the Word from its place arranged for expression. Otherwise, you have committed Falsehood and left Truth. All evidences invalidate transferring the Word from its place in the language, and no proof validates it at all. If a speaker says: 'We have found a transferred word', it is said to him: That which you found, it has become clear to us that it is its placement in that place, and we did not find that in what we want to attach to it without proof. Not every named thing you found transferred from its rank by a proof necessitates that you transfer [another] to other than it by your opinion without proof. If your judgment in necessitating what you found no proof to transfer is because you have...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...found another word [70r] transferred as a correct judgment, then you have also found in Commands many abrogated ones by correct proof. So judge every command as abrogated because you found many abrogated matters! And you found also in people's speech many lies; this is invalidating truths, so turn away from it as is appropriate. By God Almighty is success. 12 - Chapter on Divisions of Knowledge (Ma'arif), which are Sciences: Know that the knowledge of every knower among us regarding what he knows—which is his knowing of what he knows—is divided into two parts: One is Primary and the second is Secondary (Consequent). The Primary is divided into two parts: One is what the human knows by his instinct (Fitrah) and the mandate of his creation favored with Speech (Reason), which is discrimination, disposal, and distinguishing between witnessed things. He knew this chapter by his primary reason, like knowing that the Whole is more than the Part; that whoever was not born before you is not older than you; that whoever did not precede is not before; that the two halves of a number are equal to its whole; that the existence of a single body in two different places at one time is impossible; that everything truthful in its negation, its affirmation is lie—[and everything false] in its negation, its affirmation is truth; that Truth is not in a thing and its opposite; and that all parts extracted by Reason in their totality completely, a correct extraction, where one of them is inevitable—if all are false except one, that one is true by necessity. The second part of this First Division is what the human knew by his Sense leading to certainty by the mediation of Reason. Like knowing that fire is hot, snow is cold, aloe is bitter, dates are sweet, new snow is white, tar is black, hedgehog (1) skin is rough, silk is soft, the sound of thunder is stronger than the sound of a chicken, and the like. This—no one knows how the validity of knowledge of it occurred to him, nor was there any time at all between the first times of his understanding and discrimination and his self's habituation to mentioning it, and his knowing the validity of what we mentioned. Neither long nor short, neither little nor much, nor delay. Rather, it is the action of God Almighty in the soul. It is compelled to do that by necessity and finds no deviation from it at all. This is not in some...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...souls excluding others, but in the soul of every discerning person not afflicted by a defect. Every soul knows that other souls know by necessity. If a human tried to make a human imagine contrary to what we mentioned, he would not be able. If he is able to do that one day, it is known that there is a severe [defect] in his mind; it is not permissible otherwise. Into the second part of these two divisions enters the validity of knowledge of what Transmission (Naql/Tradition) validated for the informed person, a necessary realization. Like our knowing that the elephant exists though we have not seen it [70v]; that Egypt and Mecca are in the world; that Moses, Jesus, and Muhammad, peace be upon them, existed; that Aristotle and Galen existed; and like the Battle of Siffin and the Camel; and the people of Constantinople being kings of the Romans and Christians, and Christianity being their dominant religion among them; and like news appearing to us every day regarding which a person finds no way to doubt at all. Likewise [that] in the human head is a brain, in his belly are intestines, in his chest a heart, and in his veins blood. Reference in that is made to the saying of anatomists and the saying of those who saw the heads of the killed cracked open and their insides brought out. That became valid also with a necessary validity. These two divisions, it is not permissible to seek proof for their validity, nor does anyone task another with that except one lacking reason and abundant in ignorance, or resembling them—they are few in number. Rather, from these two divisions all evidences stand. All demonstrations return—even if their end is far—as we presented to you, from conclusions taken from premises, and so on forever, even if conjunctions and conclusions multiply and their types differ, until you stop returning at these two knowledges gifted from the First One, and by His bounty and the overflowing of His favor upon us without merit from us for that. Since no action preceded from us necessitating He gives us this great gift by which He created for us the way to relation with Angels who are the best creation He created, and whom He overflowed with a complete overflowing, purifying them from every deficiency or defect (1). By these ways we mentioned, we knew that we have a One, First, True Creator who never ceased to be, and that what is other than Him is originated, many, created, was not then was. By them we knew the truthfulness of the Messengers calling to Him Almighty, the Mission of Muhammad, peace be upon him, and upon all Prophets, Messengers, and Angels. Were it not for Reason and the mentioned Demonstrations, we would not have known the validity of anything of all we mentioned, just as the...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...madman does not know it. Whoever denies the testimony of Reason and Discrimination has denied all they necessitated. That produces for him the denial of Lordship, Tawhid, Prophethood, and Laws. Either he enters into that, or contradicts himself the contradiction of a madman with his tongue; we seek refuge in God from abandonment. According to the closeness of these conclusions to these Primary Knowledges, their clarification is easy; and according to their distance, their stability is distant. Except that whatever is valid from these ways, closely or distantly, is equal in being Truth, an equality; even if some is more obscure. It is not permissible that a Truth be 'more true' than another Truth, nor a Falsehood 'more false' than another Falsehood. Since if it existed, it is established and existed. What is invalid, and what exited from the certainty of existence and stability and did not enter [71r] into the certainty of invalidity, is doubted by the doubter. In its essence, it is still either Truth or Falsehood; it is not permissible otherwise. Ignorance of the one ignorant of it or doubt of the doubter in it does not invalidate it if it is Truth; nor does the error of one imagining it or doubting it make the Falsehood true. This is the summary of speech on the First Division. As for the Second, it is what I mentioned to you just now that is known by premises producing [conclusions] upon the attributes we defined, that they return to Reason and Sense either closely or distantly. Into this division enters the description of knowledge of Tawhid, Lordship, Eternality, Invention, Prophethood, and what Laws, Rulings, and Worships brought, as we presented in our other books. Because if Tawhid is valid, Prophethood is valid, the obligation of obeying it is valid, and commands and prohibitions from the Prophet, peace be upon him, are valid, then believing their validity and obeying them becomes obligatory. Into this division also enters speech on Physics, Canons of Medicine, modes of treatment and temperament, and most ranks of Number and Geometry. Know that nothing is known at all in any way without these two paths. Whoever does not arrive from them is claiming knowledge and is not a scholar, even if his belief agrees with the Truth. But he is lucky here. We have found people of determination do not praise safety by risk. Waiting for finding a lost item and abandoning seeking is a blameworthy, rejected, very base character. In this, the Imitator (Muqallid) has a strong resemblance and correct relation to one whose craft is this. Rather, the Imitator is in a worse state because his waste is uglier and more dire in consequence, unless the Sharia necessitates that he be called a scholar and that be known by demonstration, so one stops at what the...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Sharia necessitated in that. However, there is a way here you should use in debate specifically by way of restraining the rioting of the ignorant opponent—not by which a saying becomes valid nor binds anyone in reality nor establishes a demonstration. It is that a group has become accustomed to a bad habit, so the virtue of discrimination is corrupted in them entirely. That is, they do not pay attention to Demonstration even if they acknowledge it is Demonstration. They have become accustomed to Persuasion and corrupt Rioting such that they are restrained if opposed by it. These, if you oppose them [with proof], it does not affect them, and perhaps they harm you with their tongues. But if you oppose them with Persuasion, they become humiliated with the humiliation of an orphan, spare you their evil, and their disgrace and rage intensify; perhaps that affects some of them. The matter of this sect, despite their multitude among people, reminded me of what some ancient physicians said: 'The one of severe nature whom strong medicines do not anesthetize [71v], a tablet of violet anesthetizes him.' Example of that are groups you see: if you support the correct opinion with correct premises stated in the Quran and Hadith which they acknowledge as authentic, that does not affect them at all. Likewise if you stood them upon it by sense and reason. Until if you said to them 'So-and-so says this saying' and mentioned a man of the common people marked with good, they submit to him, pause greatly, and their side becomes easy. Especially if you mentioned to them a group saying that, you are spared the trouble with them. These should be deterred by what affects them. The skilled physician does not give medicine except according to the endurance of the patient's constitution. Treating souls is more worthy of gentleness for their reformation than treating bodies. As for seeking the presentation of premises: either it is sought in its proper way which he placed, so the seeker is on certainty and confidence; or he and his opponent agree on premises not established by the work we presented but by mutual consent. This is divided into two parts: One is that the premises happen to be [on] truth, so they enter into the section we presented by their luck not their search, by their fortune not their effort, and by their lot not their inspection. The second is that they agree on a corrupt premise or two premises. This is divided into two parts: One is that they mutually consent to that, being unjust to themselves. What those calamities they smeared themselves with produced is binding on them in the laws of debate, not in reality. The reality remains as it is; the mutual consent of the ignorant to falsehood does not harm it. That is very frequent in sects, natural opinions, and creeds; like the agreement of Manichaeans on the eternality of the two principles, Christians on the Trinity, and a group of...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Mu'tazila that things in the world are originated not created. We call this "Reversing Error upon Error." Among what is present to us of that, despite its frequency, is our brothers' refutation of the judgment on the slave-woman's fetus based on their error in valuing the Ghurrah (blood money for fetus) of the free woman's fetus. The second part is that the verifying scholar opponent agrees with his opponent on a corrupt premise, presenting it not satisfied with it, but to show him the corruption of its production and that it leads him to an impossible, inherent corruption. Know that this judgment should bind the one satisfied with it to commit to it. It does not bind the one tolerant in it on the condition of clarifying its corruption. What bound Adurbadh bin Mara was like what refuted the Mobadh Mani bin Hammani in his own saying before it, which is contrary to what Mani verified first. Often in Sharia we bind the arbitrary proponents of Analogy (Qiyas) with things from their premises that return to contradiction or to what binds them, so the corruption of [72r] their doctrine appears. Like what a great one [of] our predecessors (1)—we love him for his virtue but the Truth is more beloved to us than him and better—presented. He said: 'Whoever reaches puberty, male or female, and does not know God at the beginning of his puberty with all His attributes by knowledge of inference, speculation, and research, is a disbeliever whose blood is lawful.' We swear by God our Creator an oath in which we make no exception that the Chief produced this judgment against himself to be a disbeliever whose blood and wealth are lawful. We repeat the oath by God Almighty a second time that he did not enter his grave except ignorant of the complete validity of what he narrowed after his knowledge this narrowing, even though he exceeded eighty-five (2) years of age. May God have mercy on us and him and forgive us and him. Were it not that this premise of his is corrupt, what is obligatory on one defined by his definition and described by his description would be obligatory on him. But it is, praise be to God, a false proposition, so what it produced is not obligatory on him nor on others. We mentioned this chapter in the Fifth Type of Demonstration. Know that whoever agreed with us in these Primaries then denied their requirements, or opposed us in the Primaries and did not affirm them, we left him. If we spoke to him, we would be like one speaking to a drunkard, except in two cases: One is that fear compels [us] to speak with him if we leave speaking with him. The second is hope for his return, or the return of another present or absent whom our speech reaches or our speech establishes [proof against?]. Whichever it is, it is obligatory on us to speak then with what we hope is beneficial...
foot_note:
1. (1) A great one of our predecessors: Meaning Muhammad bin Jarir al-Tabari: Al-Fisal 4: 35. 
2. Wa thamanin: Wa thamanun.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...either for ourselves or for the one of our species whom we are obliged to enlighten. For the First, One, Creator, Creator of Truth and Commander of it in His covenants to us said: {Be maintainers of justice, witnesses for God} (4 An-Nisa: 135). And Almighty said: {Invite to the way of your Lord with wisdom and good instruction, and argue with them in a way that is best} (16 An-Nahl: 125).
