His Messenger, the intermediary between us and Him Almighty, peace be upon him, said to us in his commandments to us: "That God guides by your guidance one man is better for you than red camels." Until if our fear or hope rises, it becomes obligatory on us then to do what the One, First, Mighty and Majestic commanded us in His covenants to us: {Upon you is [responsibility for] yourselves. Those who have gone astray will not harm you when you have been guided} (5 Al-Ma'idah: 105). So we say to the one of this sect whom we are obliged to speak to—and by my life they are many as the One First Almighty described when informing us about those who wandered in falsehoods: {Say, "Shall we [not] inform you of the greatest losers as to [their] deeds? [They are] those whose effort is lost in worldly life, while they think that they are doing well in work."} (18 Al-Kahf: 103-104). And Almighty said: {Do they have eyes by which they see? Or do they have ears by which they hear?} (7 Al-A'raf: 195). We say to one whose description is this: If you deny truths [72v] and what Sense and Reason witnessed and delivered to the Soul, do not be ashamed of the ugliness of this description. Leave the fatigue in eating food and striving for it, and wait as you are. Go out individually to the enemy's camps from the edges of the frontiers and the desolate wildernesses, trailing your robes. Remain there reassured, visible, until you see the truth of what we tell you becoming clear to the Soul that it befalls you. Throw yourselves on the crowns of your heads from the top of the minaret. Throw knives and stones at your flesh, then cut with them. If they refrain from all this, they have verified the Primaries indicating the consequences of matters. If they persist, we turn away from them to what is more useful for us and worthier for us, by which we hope to draw near to our Creator on the Day of our gathering for Judgment in the World of Recompense. We ask Him humbly to favor us and establish us in the number of the righteous rational ones in this abode, and to enter us into the number of the winners there. We seek refuge in Him from the opposite of what we asked, Amen. More complete in stupidity and more impudent in face than those we mentioned are the claimants of Inspiration (Ilham). The thick-faced is not incapable of claiming that he was inspired with the invalidity of their saying without proof. Such people are pitied for their departure from the Truth. By God Almighty we seek help. A group rioted saying: By what thing were these matters which became valid by Reason established for you?

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: And by what did you know the validity of Reason? This is corruption in Reason. We have said that the validity of that is established by necessity in the Soul without proof for the validity of that at all. What we opposed them with suffices us if they are fair to themselves; otherwise, we have no speech with one who admitted that he is not correct and has no reason. 13 - Mention of Things that are Confused for a Group in the Way of Demonstration: Know that a group estimated that Demonstration stands from what we mentioned in the Chapter of Relation regarding one of the two things necessitating the other. They did not differentiate between the Necessary of that and other than it. We differentiate, God Almighty willing, between the correct of that and the corrupt. We say, and by God Almighty is success and we are supported: This thing is called by the predecessors "Circular Argument" (Burhan al-Dawr). Example of that: A speaker says: 'The proof that the existence of moderation in matters exists is that excess exists.' It is said to him: 'And what is the proof that excess exists?' He says: 'Since moderation exists, it is necessary that excess exists.' From this speech arose: 'When excess existed, excess existed.' This is invalid, corrupt in rank, which is to cite the thing as witness for itself. The correct way [73r] is to cite the Certain as witness for the Unknown. If the thing is Unknown, it is not Certain for the one to whom it is unknown. You desire that it be clarified here by itself, which is that Unknown itself. If the thing is Certain, the Certain does not need a demonstration. This is a corrupt inference as you see. Every thing is either Known or Unknown. The Known validates others among Unknowns, and the Unknown is validated by others among Knowns. The existence of each of the two Related things necessitating the existence of its companion is a matter known by primary reason, so seeking inference for it is an error. As for the error in explaining the Unknown, it is like a human saying to a human: 'What is the description of the Elephant?' He says to him: 'The description of the Buffalo (Khanzir - Pig/Buffalo context dependent but likely logic example).' The questioner does not know the description of the Buffalo. He says to him: 'And what is the description of the Buffalo?' He says to him: 'The description of the Elephant.' This is severe corruption, returning to 'The description of the Elephant is the description of the Elephant.' Into this enters the confusion of one who desires to establish Analogy by Analogy or Report by Report and the like. As for a thing being used as evidence for its own invalidity, that is not permissible either except from one aspect: that it leads to corruption or contradiction, so it invalidates it then. So it is not...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...it invalidated itself. If its invalidation of itself were validated, it would be valid; and if it were valid, it would not be invalid (false). We presented that the validity of the mandate of Reason has no known cause other than its stability in the Soul by necessity, with no deviation from it. Reason is not established by Reason, but by the Necessity that met the Discrimination which nothing precedes (1) at all. Into Inference may also enter a thing called "Inference by the Effect (Ma'lum) to the Cause ('Illah)," like one who wants to establish Demonstration for the existence of Fire by Smoke which is generated from Fire and its action. The Cause is more apparent in minds than the Effect. However, if the questioner is ignorant of the Cause being a cause, and is knowledgeable that the Effect is generated from the Cause, it is obligatory then to verify for him that this thing is a cause for this other by deducing the Effect by it and its being existing by its existence. If a man saw smoke from a distance and said: 'In that place is fire inevitably because I see smoke has risen there', he would be inferring by the reality of Inference. This one did not infer that the totality of Fire exists because of the Smoke, but knew that the Effect does not exist unless its Cause exists. When he saw the Smoke, which is the Effect, he knew that the Cause is there, which is the Fire. By God Almighty is success [73v]. 14 - Mention of Things a Group Counted as Demonstrations while they are Corrupt, and Clarifying the Error of One who Counted them Demonstration: From that is a thing the Ancients called "Induction" (Istiqra'), and the people of our creed called "Analogy" (Qiyas). We say, and by God Almighty is success: The meaning of this word is that you follow with your thought existing things gathered by one species and one genus, and judged by one judgment. You find in every thing of the individuals of that species, or in every species of the types of that genus, an attribute adhering to every individual under the species, or in every species under the genus, or in everyone judged. Except that the existence of that attribute is not what Reason necessitates its existence in everything it is found in, nor does a nature necessitate that that attribute be in it inevitably. Rather, the existence of something of that...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...species being devoid of that attribute is imaginable. Likewise, a word did not come in the Judgment stating that it is adhering to everything in which that attribute is found. So a group decides, because of what we mentioned, that all individuals of that species—even if absent from them—contain that attribute; and that everything in which that attribute exists among things is judged by that judgment. By my life, if we were able to exhaust those individuals from first to last until we encompass with knowledge that not one of them deviated from us, and we found this attribute general to all of them, it would be obligatory that we require by its generality for them. Likewise, if we found the rulings stipulated for everything containing that attribute, we would decide that it is adhering to everything containing that attribute. But since we are not able to exhaust that, nor do we find it in the Judgment stipulated for everything containing that attribute, this is divination from the one judging arbitrarily by it, fabrication, looseness in lying, judging without knowledge, and deception of people and of himself first—whose advice (1) is more obligatory upon him. We exemplify that with a visual example. We say, and by God is success: The description of the Described by the Attribute is divided into two parts: One is an attribute inevitable for the Described by necessity, like our certain knowledge that every possessor of spirit is breathing, and every breather possesses an instrument by which he breathes—either by taking air or expelling it, or grasping by it and expelling it if he is among water dwellers. This is a division established in Reason, known by necessity, with no deviation from it. If the Soul lacked the Instrument, it would separate from the Body. The second part may be found adhering to the Described by it, but if it were absent it would not harm it, like the Gall Bladder. If you opened most types of animals, you would find it in them, except the Camel, for it has no Gall Bladder. A group mentioned that the Horse has no [74r] Spleen. And like the common knowledge among people that we have not witnessed a female mule nor a male mule (2) being born. And like our never finding a ram of sheep with a beard. An informant informed me in the gathering of some chiefs that he witnessed a female mule giving birth in a land, and a group who were in that region testified to the validity of that for him. One whom I trust informed me that he saw rams with beards and he-goats without beards. I saw a small cat give birth to two distinct, separate, complete bodies, no organ missing from them at all; in each body a tail, two hands, and two legs, gathered by one head having no eyes, two ears, and one mouth. I also saw a chick and a gosling; the two eggs hatched them, and each of them had four legs; a group who were with me were shown the chick. Deciding that this does not happen is the blameworthy arbitrariness that may betray.
foot_note:
1. (1) Nasihatuha: Text has *Fadihatuha* (Scandal/Exposing). 
2. Baghlun: Text has *Baghl*.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: A group of people of our religions and sects of our creed erred in this chapter. As for those opposing us in creed while agreeing with us in religion, they tracked Doers (Agents) and did not find a choosing Doer at all except a Body. So they decided that the First Doer, Mighty and Majestic, is a Body because they did not witness a Doer except a Body. Guard against such rioting; many people's error was great in it. I have shown you the path by which they were deceived, so avoid it. It is the saying [asserted] despite the establishment of Demonstration on its invalidity and despite it being a mere claim. In all that, they were contradicted in it. That is because if they [do not] mislead themselves and deceive them, and track what they found a correct tracking, they would not find a choosing doer other than originated and other than composed—either from birth or from transforming moistures. God is exalted above what the wrongdoers say with great highness. They have contradicted and invalidated their proof. Let them know that they are in a heinous trial. They acknowledge without disagreement among them that whoever believes this is separating from the religion, his blood is lawful, disavowing his Creator. It binds them—if their judgment is correct since they never witnessed a choosing doer except composed from birth or transforming moistures—to decide regarding the First One Almighty that He is originated, composed; otherwise they have contradicted. Is not one with the slightest understanding and reason ashamed to testify against himself that he is firm on a false thing? As for what those agreeing with us in creed among our companions the Traditionists (Akhbaris) erred in, they tracked every Described thing in the world and saw it only deserved that name by an attribute in it from which [74v] that name was derived for it. So they decided because of that that the First One, Mighty and Majestic, is Possessor of Hearing, Sight, Life, and Will, and that He is speaking not silent; that He Almighty is described as Hearing, Seeing, Living, Willing, having Speech. Had they been fair to themselves and not rushed into what they reproach their opponents with, they would have—if they inspected this inspection—found with certainty that they never see nor witness a Described with a thing except that attribute is an Accident carried in the Described, and that the Attribute is only carried by a Substance. Although what we mention, no thinker in the world imagines a rank other than it. It binds them—since they never witnessed a Described with an attribute except it is a Substance carrying an Accident in its essence—to say: The First, like Whom there is nothing, is a Substance carrying Accidents and never separating from them. God is exalted above that with great highness. But they recoiled from this error and fled from it. They did not differ that the sayer of that, believing it, is a denier of the Creator Almighty, his blood is lawful, due to his exit from the religion. Wonder falls upon these just as it falls upon the mentioned...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...before, with no difference. It is obligatory for every seeker of truth to acknowledge what Reason necessitated, and acknowledge what he witnessed and sensed, and what a Demonstration returning to the mentioned bases established. And not to rest on Induction (Istiqra') at all unless he encompasses with knowledge all Particulars under the Whole in which he judges. If he cannot, he should not decide in judgment on what he did not witness, and should not judge except on what he perceived, not what was not perceived. This, if you ponder it in Sharia rulings, benefits you greatly and prevents you from Analogy (Qiyas) which deceived many people and virtuous Imams by whose error thousands of thousands of people erred. If you do that, you are on certainty of correctness because you did not decide with Analysis (Halal) nor Prohibition (Haram) nor Obligation except on what the ruling from God Almighty came to you about. As for what you did not find a text in, withhold from it and do not decide on it, for it is [not] included in the ruling of what you found a text in; so withhold from it. Know that a group erred in this type an error by which they did not exit from this affiliation, except that by poor insight they thought themselves out of it, so they named their action in this chapter by another name: they called it "Inference by the Witnessed (Present) upon the Absent." In reality, had they achieved the search, they would have known that the Absent from the senses among known things is not absent from the Intellect; rather, it is witnessed in it like the witnessing of what is perceived by senses, with no difference. If a man is certain that senses are conveyors to the Soul, and that the Soul only [75r] validates its judgment by sensed things if its reason is healthy from defects, and by emptying itself of all that occupies its reason, and isolating itself to clarify by it and think in what guided it to it—the man would not find then for what is witnessed by his senses a superiority over what he witnessed by his intellect without his senses. There is no Absent among known things at all such that if it is absent from the Intellect, it is not permissible to be known at all. We find the blind man born blind certain that colors exist, like the certainty of the sighted, with no difference. Likewise, our certainty of the existence of the elephant even if we never saw it is like the certainty of one who saw it, with no difference. The blind and sighted only differed in the Quality (How-ness) of colors only. As for Color being correct existing, there is no difference between them in the certainty of knowledge of that. Likewise, one who saw the elephant only exceeds us in the Quality. As for the validity of its existence, he has no superiority over us in knowing that it is true. Even if we did not witness—nor did one who witnessed inform us, nor did it reach us—that there is among people today a human lifting six hundred pounds from the ground, we do not deny its existence, if found, like our denial of the existence of a human lifting six thousand...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...pounds. We witnessed neither, nor the like of either. It is not that our finding many things sharing some of their attributes a correct sharing, then our finding some of those things isolated by a ruling we are certain of from them, necessitates that we judge on the rest of those things with equality in this second ruling because of their equality (1) in the first ruling. This claim is ugly and foul arbitrariness. This is only binding if a nature necessitates that a thing exists in what it is in, and we know the necessity of that by our intellects. If that is so, we judge by necessity on what we did not witness of the parts of that thing by our judgment on what we witnessed of them. Like the nature of the measurement of every moving body necessitating it to be finite in diameters; this is known by the priority of Reason and the requirement of the judgment of Quantity. And like the nature of human beings necessitating that a mule is not born from him nor does he become pregnant, but [is born] a body (2) of a certain shape, having a rational soul accepting education, disposal, and craft. Our knowledge that our bodies are finite because the nature of Reason necessitates that is not stronger than our knowledge that the body of the Sphere is finite. It did not become valid for us because our bodies are finite; but the mode by which it was correct that our bodies are finite, by it it was correct that the body of the Sphere is finite. Likewise also our knowledge that every soft thing meeting a solid thing with a strong meeting clashes, the solid influences the soft by necessity—either by separating its parts or transforming it from its shape—not because we witnessed that in counted bodies, but the nature of Reason necessitates that [75v]. Like this is much. As for what the nature of Reason does not necessitate nor negate, if we find it we believe it, and if we do not find it we do not prevent it. We have witnessed among people one who does not eat milk at all, and if he ate it he would vomit severely; and another who does not eat fat at all. It is not from the principle of our finding that that we must decide definitively that among people also is one who does not eat dates at all, nor must we prevent the existence of that at all. Likewise, if we found a stone attracting iron, it is not necessary that we decide that there exists, inevitably, a stone attracting people, nor decide also that it does not exist. Like that is much. More severe than all this is the arbitrariness against the First Creator that He has forbidden this and permitted this...
