1. (1) Istiwa'iha: Istiwa'ihima. 
2. Wa lakin jism: But a body is born/generated.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...without a ruling coming from Him Almighty about that, but by the desires of souls, because He forbade another thing resembling this which you forbid in some of its attributes. Nay! God Almighty cursed disobedient, transgressing people; do you think He curses every human because they are like those cursed ones in being humans and disobedient transgressors? He burned a people because they cheated the measure, and burned with them their children and women; do you think every cheater of measure and balance is burned, he and his child and wife? Indeed, this is the far error. Among the wondrous things occurring to those deceived by this corrupt type is that if they like to change their mind in this judgment they judged, leaving it is not difficult for them. They extract things from the similar ones from a judgment found in some of them and say: 'This exited its principle and became anomalous (Shadhdh), and the Anomalous is not analogized upon.' We say: If this anomalous judgment were a principle for the anomaly, what deviated from it would not have deviated. It is not permissible for a branch to spring from other than its root. If that were so, the Root would not be a root for what is rooted in it, nor would the rooted be rooted from it. Do not think that what contradicted the form of its species gathering it is anomalous to its species and root, for you would err. Because if you knew that it does not deviate from its root at all, and that those additions are only from an increase in the matter of the element over the amount from which the complete individual stands—likewise the decrease also is a decrease from the matter of the element. Thus are the correct roots (principles). Like this is what Grammarians use in their causes ('ilal); they are all corrupt, nothing of them returns to reality at all. The truth of that is only that this was heard from the people of language to whom return is made in recording and transmitting it. What exceeds this is, along with being [76r] corrupt contradictory arbitrariness, also a lie. Because their saying 'The origin was such, then it was deemed heavy so it was transferred to such' is a thing every person of sense knows is a lie that never was, nor were the Arabs upon it for a period then transferred to what was heard from them after that. The First Creator said a saying that sufficed everyone of toil when He said Almighty: {Say, "Produce your proof, if you should be truthful."} (2 Al-Baqarah: 111). Then He added clarification saying Almighty: {And if they testify, do not testify with them} (6 Al-An'am: 150). Then He added clarification saying Almighty: {He is not questioned about what He does, but they will be questioned} (21 Al-Anbiya: 23). What we said regarding the discrimination of Reason and Senses is the action of God Almighty, so it is not asked why it was so. What is other than it is an action...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...of ours; question is inevitable in it. Yes, if a proof is valid by it, it is accepted; otherwise, rejected. Some of them named this chapter: "Applying the Cause to the Effect." By my life, if it were correct that that is a cause—like killing being a cause for death, hunger a cause for wanting food, thirst a cause for wanting fresh water—it would be obligatory to apply it to its effects. Even so, there is no way that a Cause exists ever in time except its Effect exists. But if it is not so, know that it is not a Cause. As for what an arbitrary person claimed is a Cause without proof, it is not obligatory to apply it to what is not an effect of it. In general, there is no Cause in Sharias (Laws) at all in any way, nor anything necessitating them except the Commands coming from God Almighty only. Since there is nothing in Reason necessitating prohibiting anything in the world and permitting another, nor obligating an action and leaving the obligation of another. Commands are causes necessitating what they brought. If they do not come, there is no cause necessitating anything at all nor preventing it. Since the Cause is only that which is never found except its effect is with it, this is only in Natural things. Since this is so, it is not permissible to raise the name of Cause to other than this meaning, causing confusion by applying one name to two different meanings. This is the strongest path for people of jugglery. Know and be alert to what I am presenting to you, God Almighty willing: That this thing which they named 'Inference by the Witnessed upon the Absent' and 'Applying the Cause to the Effect' is only valid for invalidating the Equal in Judgment, not affirming it. Because whenever you find things equal in certain attributes while they are different in rulings, you do not doubt their difference. Rather, our knowledge of their difference is necessary knowledge. Therefore, we are then not decisive that what is absent from our senses among those absent things equaling these present ones in the attribute in which all these present ones equaled—that it agrees with the judgment of these [76v] present ones nor that it disagrees. This is what our opponents do not disagree with us on, because it is necessary. So it is established that the benefit is great and correct by the difference of Witnessed things in invalidating the decisiveness of the equality of Absent things from senses with them. And that we do not benefit by the equality of Witnessed things—in what the nature of Reason did not necessitate for them—in knowing the judgment of Absent things. Do you not see that if we do not find a donkey ruminating, we do not decide that it does not exist; rather, if found, we would not deny it. Indeed...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...[an informant] informed me that he has the existence of a horse that ruminates. And no possessor of a horn was ever found except with a cloven hoof, except the Indian Rhinoceros (wild donkey?), for it is possessor of a horn without a cloven hoof. Such matters which Nature does not necessitate are in the limit of Possible, except that according to the scarcity or abundance of their existence, they enter the Far Possible or the Close Equal. We find luminous, red, hot things. Whoever says Light is the cause of burning, we showed him luminous things like mirrors and others which are not burning. Whoever says Redness is the cause of burning, we showed him blood, not burning. Whoever says Heat is the cause of burning, we showed him things that heat the body but do not burn. It became necessary by necessity that nothing of what we mentioned is a cause, while they are consistent attributes as you see. But every simple element, hot, dry, ascending, luminous, elevating moistures, descending by force, transforming into air, is burning without doubt, because the nature of Reason necessitates that. Whoever follows the path we forbade is not safe from confusion, contradiction, or arbitrariness without proof. What this corrupt inference also led a group to is that they said: 'Since we are living rational beings, and the Stars are higher than us and in a purer place, their influence was apparent in us, and they were more worthy of life and speech than us; so they are living rational wise beings.' It binds them by this corrupt demonstration that since they found every wise distinguishing rational living being among us is only flesh and blood possessing brain and heart—no other way is permissible, nor did they ever witness a living being except thus—they must decide that Stars and Angels are composed of flesh and blood and possessors of brains and hearts because they are living rational beings. All this is error, because it is not because of our nobility over stones and that we influence them that Speech and Life became necessary for us. Nor is it because we are rational living beings that we must be flesh and blood. But since we were distinguishing, knowing, sensing, [77r] the name of Speech and Life became necessary for us as an expression of that state of ours and a naming for it. Some of them also deceived, saying to prove the residence of the Soul in the Brain: 'The King always resides in the high citadels; the Soul is the King of the body, and the Brain is the highest of the body; so the Soul is in it.' How many kings we saw residing only in the lowlands of their province, leaving the citadels! A confused one like him opposed him, saying to prove it is in the Heart: 'The King always resides in the center of his province; the Heart is the center of the body; [so] it is necessary that the Soul be in it.' How many kings resided at the edge of their province or near their province and left the center! All this is weak arbitrariness. Like one who said: 'I found the dog long-tailed, so it is fit also for guarding sheep.'...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...and the predator has a long tail, so it is also fit for guarding livestock. This occurs very frequently, and what we mentioned is sufficient. Many people have used things like this; they forbade and permitted based on it and judged arbitrarily in God Almighty's religion. That is like their judgment that 'measuring' is the cause (Illah) of prohibition in Usury (Riba), and the arbitrariness of others that 'storing' is the cause of prohibition in Riba, and others said: 'eating' (1) is the cause of prohibition in Riba. Is this [anything] but exactly like what we mentioned before? Likewise, if we find an attribute in a described object, and that described object has a certain judgment, and if that attribute is removed, that judgment is removed—it is not necessary just because of this that whenever that attribute is found in a described object, that judgment is found for it. Rather, perhaps that attribute may be found for it, but that judgment is not found for it. An example of that: If life was never existing in a certain body, it is necessary by necessity that that body is not a human, without doubt. If a man wanted to proceed on the path I criticized, he would have to say: 'So if life is found in a body, it must be a human,' and this is a pure lie. An example of that in Sharia: If your ownership is removed from a thing, its ownership has passed to another, or it is correct that no creature has ownership over it—which is more rightful. So [they argue] if another's ownership is removed from it, does it compel that its ownership becomes valid for you, or that no creature has ownership over it? Rather, perhaps a third party other than both of you owns it. Know that looseness (tolerance) in seeking truths is not permissible at all. It is only Truth or Falsehood. It is not permissible for a thing to be 'true falsehood', nor 'false truth', nor 'false not-true'. If these two divisions are invalid by primary reason necessarily, the third division is established since no division remains other than it, which is: either Truth or Falsehood. Therefore, the First One, Mighty and Majestic, said to us in His covenants to us: {So what is [77v] there after the truth except error?} (10 Yunus: 32). Perhaps an ignorant person objects to us regarding two things, saying: 'You speak of the permissibility of things like singing and other than that; is it truth or falsehood?' The answer, and by God Almighty is success: Everything we permitted, if the doer does it to recreate himself and aid his health and energy to be strong enough to execute the commands of his Creator, Mighty and Majestic, then all of this is Truth. If he does it out of vanity and insolence, then all of that is Error. However, some error is idle talk (Laghw) not counted against us out of kindness to us, and some is counted...
foot_note: 1. (1) And others said eating... etc.: Repeated in the original text.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...against us as justice regarding us. The Chosen One sent from the First One, peace be upon him, said to us: "Actions are only by intentions, and for every man is what he intended." The second thing is that the critic says: 'You said there is nothing but Truth or Falsehood. Truth is demonstrative: either primary, or produced from primary, or nearby, or distant; and whatever is other than these two ways is Falsehood. Yet you judge by the Single Report (Khabar al-Wahid) in rulings and by the testimony of two witnesses, and you acknowledge that your judgment in that might be false.' The answer, and by God Almighty is success: Judging by the Single Report in rulings and by the testimony of two witnesses is a necessary demonstrative Truth; we decide upon its Unseen [validity as a command]. As for the particulars of that—meaning the testimony—we do not know whether it agrees with what we are certain is Truth [reality] or not; this is due to our falling short of knowing the Unseen. However, we verify without doubt that every proposition of it is either Truth or Falsehood in its essence; it must be so. We did not claim that every [judgment of ours] is Truth or Falsehood [in factual reality]; rather, the judgment in many matters is hidden from us, while they are in their essences either Truth or Falsehood. Among the strange things in which our brothers—who agree with us in friendship and creed but oppose us in Fatwa—erred is that two rulings appeared regarding Barley and Dates; they transferred one of them to Olives and Figs, and prevented transferring the other to Olives and Figs. That is: Prohibition came regarding Barley for Barley and Dates for Dates in sale except like for like, measure for measure, hand to hand; and we were commanded to give Barley or Dates in Zakat al-Fitr. They said—the saying of one who judges arbitrarily—: 'As for the prohibition in sale except like for like and hand to hand, it is transferred to Olives and Figs; as for giving in Zakat, it is not transferred to Olives and Figs.' They have thousands of propositions like this and more heinous, which we will explain in our books on the rulings of religion, God willing. Arbitrariness with the tongue is not impossible for one who accepts it for himself [78r], and Falsehood is abundant. As for that which we praise the Giver, the Benefactor, Mighty and Majestic, for its people having it, it is the Truth. That which the achiever should rejoice in is what Demonstration necessitated. Know that there is no difference between what validates Legal (Sharia) Rulings and what validates Natural Propositions in the ranks of Demonstration we presented. Rather, error in Sharia is more harmful and of more corrupting nature in the World, and of worse consequence in the Hereafter, and more deserving of being looked into and managed for correction, and worthier of abandoning looseness, and more fortunate in seeking correctness. One should not proceed in it except upon what existing premises necessitated from their likes until reaching the primaries of Reason and Sense. By God...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Almighty is success; to Him belongs praise, and from Him is the seeking of increase in His beautiful gifts. Error in that is encompassed by Falsehood, and that group is singled out for punishment in the Abode of the Hereafter for he who was stubborn and abandoned research while capable of it. Know that the predecessors named the Premises "Qiyas" (Syllogism). Our brothers, the proponents of Qiyas (Analogy), devised a weak, sophistical trick: they applied the name Qiyas to Arbitrariness and Sophistry. They named their arbitrariness via blameworthy Induction (Istiqra') "Qiyas". And they named their judgment—in what no text appeared—by the judgment of another thing in which a text appeared due to their resemblance in some of their attributes, "Qiyas", "Inference" (Istidlal), and "Applying the Cause to the Effect". They wanted to correct the Falsehood by naming it with a name others applied to the Clear Truth. Like what reached us about some ignorant Berbers who wanted to legitimize eating a piglet he hunted by naming it "Child of the Deer". It has come from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he warned of a people who legitimize wine by calling it by other than its name. This is a camouflaged trick that does not stand upon clarification. We said before that there are no two things in the world except that there is some resemblance and difference between them by necessity; it must be so. If resemblance necessitates equality of judgment, let us judge everything in the world with one judgment because of its resemblance in some attribute. Why did gathering in resemblance necessitate equality of judgment, while separation in resemblance did not necessitate difference of judgment? According to this, we must not judge two things at all with one judgment because of their difference in some attribute. All of this is error and confusion, leading to contradiction and misguidance. We seek refuge in God from all that, and there is no power or strength except in God. 15 - Chapter on Additional Discourse in Explaining Sophistry: The Ancients named what is taken from corrupt premises "Sophistry" (Safsata). We will explain sufficient modes of it by the power of God, the Giver of knowledge and His strength; there is no god but He. Know that the Rioter supporting Falsehood, his greatest weapon is Obfuscation (Talbis). That is either by affirming what is not necessary; or by dropping a division of the divisions or more than one division; or adding a corrupt division [78v]; or by bringing divisions that are all corrupt; or by clinging to a Homonymous word agreed upon in its validity which gives many things of different rulings and attributes, while agreeing also in things; so he wants to...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...specialize what they agreed upon in some of what it gives excluding all of it, and wants to generalize all that that name applies to from what specializes some of what that name applies to; or he brings it while it is a beginning. Affirming what is not necessary is like saying: 'If the Creator Almighty were other than a body, He would be an accident; since it is established that the Creator Almighty is not an accident, it is correct that He is a body.' This one suspended His Almighty being non-body on His being an accident, and this is not necessary. Had he suspended that on what necessitates his proposition, he would have been truthful; that is if he said: 'If the Creator Almighty were originated and was other than a body, He would be an accident.' This is a correct presentation, but the Creator Almighty is not originated, so He is neither a body nor an accident. We are now only in the clarification of the validity of the work of Conjunctions, not in the clarification of particulars, for that has its place. As for dropping a division, it is like the speaker saying: 'This color is not devoid of being red, green, yellow, or black,' after dropping white, azure, and others. As for adding a corrupt division, it is like the speaker saying: 'This thing is not devoid of being this thing, or being other than it, or neither it nor other than it.' This is a corrupt additional division. As for coming with divisions that are all corrupt, it is like the speaker saying: 'The Creator Almighty is not devoid of having done things to repel harm, or to attract benefit, or for a nature, or for a defect, or for His generosity and nobility.' These are all corrupt divisions. The correct view is that He did them not for a cause nor for a reason at all. Whoever claims against his opponent that he came with something of these modes, he must explain that. As for the Error occurring in the resemblance of Names (Homonymy), it is from an ignorant person and from an intentional one. As for the ignorant, he is excused. As for the intentional, he is blameworthy. The ignorant's error in that is like Adi bin Hatim when he heard the verse: {so eat and drink until the white thread becomes distinct to you from the black thread} (2 Al-Baqarah: 187), he thought it referred to familiar threads. As for the intentional, it is like those to whom it was said "Ra'ina" (observe us) from Mura'at (observance), so they said 'Ra'ina' from Ru'unah (frivolity/stupidity). And like what some of the great ones said when asked about uttering (Lafz) the Quran; he said: 'This question is impossible, and uttering the Quran is not permissible because it is not uttered (Yulfaz).' He turned away from 'Lafz' which is speech and talk, and transgressed to that which is casting out (Qadhf), like a man spitting (Lafz) a morsel from his mouth. This and its like are vanishing juggleries. Likewise, you should guard against the resemblance of Script (Writing), especially in Arabic, for...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...that is widespread in it because most of its letters are not differentiated in forms except by dots, like Zabad [79r], Zayd, Zand, Rand, and the like. One of the Caliphs wrote to his governor: 'Ahsi (Count) the effeminate men before you,' meaning counting the number. The scribe read it 'Akhsi' (Castrate), so he castrated everyone before him among them. For this reason, the seeker of truths is compelled to Grammar. Do you not see that if a reciter read: {Innama yakhsha Allaha min 'ibadihi al-'ulama'u} (It is only those who have knowledge among His slaves that fear Allah), and he put the nominative (u) on the Ha of Allah and the accusative (a) on the Hamza of Al-'Ulama, intending that while being knowledgeable, that would be an exit from the Creed? Likewise if he read: {Annnallaha bari'un min al-mushrikina wa rasulihi} (That Allah is disassociated from the disbelievers, and His Messenger), with a kasra (i) on the Lam of 'Rasulihi' (implying disassociation from His Messenger too). Guard against the likes of this with severe caution, as we will describe to you after this, God Almighty willing. From that are things occurring in the Conjunction (Ma'tuf) that are confusing, like what a group of scholars erred in regarding the saying of God Almighty: {And no one knows its interpretation except Allah. And those firm in knowledge say, "We believe in it. All [of it] is from our Lord."} (3 Aal Imran: 7). They thought that "Those firm in knowledge" is conjoined to God Almighty [meaning they also know the interpretation]. It is not so; rather, it is the beginning of speech and a proposition, and a conjunction of a sentence to a sentence, for a necessary demonstration we have mentioned in its place. Among Sophistry also is validating another thing and its invalidity by the invalidity of another thing without a proof necessitating their correlation; that is very corrupt. Like the saying of one who said: 'If it were permissible for the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, to be seen, [it would be] a seeing unlike the familiar.' And like the saying of the speaker: 'Since prohibition is valid in wheat for wheat with excess, prohibition is valid in rice for rice with excess.' All this is arbitrariness and claim. No one is incapable of linking a thing to a thing with no link between them with his tongue if he permits deciding by what he desires. And like the saying of one of the blind men who said: 'If Color were visible, Reason would be visible; since Reason is invisible, it is necessary that Color is invisible.' Contemplate this; you will find it slander, ignorance, and boldness out of place, like the boldness of children against their fathers, with no difference. Therefore, we have covered what is needed of clarifying the correct Demonstration, mentioning sentences of corrupt dialectics and fallen riotous arguments, and clarifying many of them to the extent that the student distinguishes them if he sees them. We said that whatever is other than Demonstration via other than the path we presented, it is obligatory...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...to avoid it. By my life, we have increased clarification and repeated, because the error of our companions increased in that and became very obscene, so we needed to exaggerate in clarification. Let us limit ourselves to that, and let us start increasing on the merit of what we perceive by Reason. By God Almighty we hold fast and are supported; there is no god but He. 16 - Discourse on the Merit of the Power of Reason's Perception over Sense Perception: Know that sound senses may fall short of many of their perceived objects, may be weak regarding them, and may err. Then it does not take long for the Soul [79v] to clarify its error, its shortcoming, and what was hidden from it, and it perceives it with a complete perception in its reality. The perception of Reason in all that is one perception. In general, Reason is a power God Almighty singled out the Soul with, and He did not make a share in it for anything of the Body. The perception of the Soul via senses has a share for the Body, and the Body is murky and heavy. Its perception by Reason, if it looks with it and bodily desires or other blameworthy characters do not overcome it, is a pure, complete, unmixed perception. Among the closest things we exemplify to you regarding the murkiness of the Soul by its sharing with the Body and its purity by its isolation from it, and the lightness of the Body by the sharing of the Soul and its heaviness by its isolation from it, is what you see of the state of the sleeper; for his body then is heavier in weight (1). The porters who are hired know this; they frequently forbid him (the carried) from sleeping so that if he wakes up, his weight lightens and becomes less. You see the Soul in the state of sleep may witness a part of Prophecy through true vision, which there is no way to witness in the state of wakefulness. Thus, whenever it isolates and empties itself from the Body, it perceives the obscurities of things and the correct outcomes in opinions, such that a man in that state does not hear the speech of those with him nor see much of what is present. Then we return to what we began with. We say, and by God Almighty is success: You see a human from afar as a very small body, like a child, while you do not doubt with your Reason that he is bigger than what you see. Then it does not take long for him to approach you, and you see him at the size he is, which Reason never doubted he was. Likewise occurs to you regarding Sound. Also, if a thing is very far from the sense, its perception is nullified entirely. For if a human is five miles away from you...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...or thereabouts, you looked at his silhouette and did not distinguish his eye nor hear his voice at all. Until when he approached, you distinguished all that, recognized his eye, and heard his speech. And like a rumble you saw from afar and did not hear its sound; Reason did not doubt that it has a terrifying sound if you approached it. Reason in all we mentioned does not betray. As for the sense of the body, like a mustard seed added to a human's load; he does not feel it at all. Until if the pouring of mustard increases, it does not take long for him to be incapable of carrying it, even if poured on the back of an elephant or a sea ship. Reason teaches you that that poured mustard seed has a share of weight by necessity, except that Sense fell short of perceiving it due to the delay of Sense perception from Reason's perception, and that it only perceives what appears with a strong appearance; and many truths may be hidden from it as you see. Reason perceives, as I explained to you, the share of the mustard seed of weight, a perception with no difference between it and the perception of what appeared to the Sense of the weight of gathered quintals. Likewise Smell; an amount of a fals (small coin) of Asafoetida (Haltit) may be with you in the house and you do not smell it at all [80r]. Until if the parts of Asafoetida increase, it does not take long for the Smell to find it and be annoyed by it. Reason is certain that that fals has a part of the stench. The same is said regarding Musk. Reason teaches you that the power of scent in the little and the much is one, but the much, if it increases, what dissolves from it separates in the air and occupies a wide place. Likewise the Heaven; you do not see it moving, but Reason is certain it is moving due to what you see of the difference of the two motions of the bodies in it from East to West by the motion of the Heaven for them from West to East, and by their transfer in degrees and their motion by themselves. Likewise, the eye does not distinguish the movement of the Sun at all, until if a period passes, its movement appears to it with certainty by seeing it in the middle of the sky after seeing it in the horizon of the East. And like the growth of bodies of animals and plants; you do not distinguish its growth even though it is before you and in front of your eyes, until if a period passes, you see the growth with your eyes apparently and know the ratio of its increase over what it was. Reason witnesses that for every hour there is a share of growth of that tree which you did not distinguish with your sight. This, if you ponder it, is very much. We have explained in the Chapter of Discourse on Quality in this register the sharing of Reason with Senses in all their perceived objects and its being unique without them in many things. Were it not for Reason, we would not have known what is absent from Senses, nor known God Almighty. Whoever denies his Reason has denied the testimony...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...without which he would not know his Lord, and he has landed in the state of the madman, and has not obtained a truth. By Thought (Fikr) and Memory (Dhikr), premises are taken a correct taking by the Soul looking into joining the natures of things to one another until its desire is established regarding what it wants to know. This Memory is established in animals. Animals may differ in degree in it: Among animals are those that distinguish their master and remember him even if he is absent from them, and rejoice in him if he comes to them; the strongest in that are the elephant, dog, monkey, and bear, then the cat. Among animals are those that remember a lesser remembrance, like the horse and camel. Among animals are the rest of what we mentioned that do not remember anything of that, like the rooster and others. Know that Sense, Reason, Opinion (Zann), and Imagination (Takhayyul) are powers among the powers of the Soul. As for Thought (Fikr), it is the judgment of the Soul regarding what these powers delivered to it. You find the Soul, if it loses something it stored due to forgetfulness, seeks it and inspects its memories by Thought, just as the owner of goods inspects his goods if he lost them and they mixed for him among various things; so he searches for them in one mode and place after place until he finds them and returns to them, or does not find them at all. Thus exactly same to same; glory be to the Disposer of that and its Inventor, there is no god but He. There is nothing in the powers we mentioned [80v] that is trusted always in every case except Reason. In it is the discrimination of the perceptions of sound Senses and those forsaken by illness and the like, such as the sick finding honey bitter like colocynth, while Reason testifies with correct, truthful testimony that it is sweet. And as a thing is seen in water contrary to its shape which Reason testifies is its shape in reality. As for Opinion (Zann), it is the most lying guide, because it pictures for you the huge armed man as brave while he might be the utmost coward, and pictures for you the disparate in appearance as dull while he might be extreme in intelligence. God Almighty alerted to this, saying: {Indeed, it is not the eyes that are blinded, but blinded are the hearts which are within the breasts} (22 Al-Hajj: 46). So He, Mighty and Majestic, informed that Senses follow Reason, and that the possessor of Reason whose desire overcomes him does not benefit from what his senses perceived. And Almighty said: {Indeed, some assumption is sin} (49 Al-Hujurat: 12). It is narrated from the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, that he said: "Assumption (Zann) is the falsest of speech." As for Imagination, it may make you hear a sound where there is no sound, and show you a person where there is no person. Almighty said: {It seemed to him from their magic that they were moving} (20 Taha: 66). So He, Almighty, informed of the falsehood of Imagination. Reason is truthful always. Almighty said, confirming the confession of those who rejected...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the witnesses of their reason as error: {And they said, "If we had been listening or reasoning, we would not be among the companions of the Blaze." And they will admit their sin, so alienation is for the companions of the Blaze.} (67 Al-Mulk: 10-11). And Almighty said, blaming one who turned away from using his reason: {And how many a sign within the heavens and earth do they pass over while they, therefrom, are turning away} (12 Yusuf: 105). And Almighty said regarding everything for which no demonstration is established: {Say, "Produce your proof, if you should be truthful."} (2 Al-Baqarah: 111). And He said blaming one who spoke without knowledge: {Here you are - those who have argued about that of which you have [some] knowledge, but why do you argue about that of which you have no knowledge?} (3 Aal Imran: 66). And Almighty said in the like of that: {But they have denied that which they encompass not in knowledge and whose interpretation has not yet come to them} (10 Yunus: 39). These are the commandments of the First One which His Messenger, peace be upon him, brought to us, and these are the requirements of intellects. So where is the escape from the Creator Almighty and from the Reason leading to knowing Him, except to the accursed Satan, destructive madness, and clear error? We ask the Granter of blessing to increase us in virtuous knowledge, and not to strip us of what He granted us of Reason and the love of using it and believing its testimonies. To Reason we return in the validity of Religion and the validity of Action leading to the success of the Hereafter and eternal safety. By it we know the reality of Knowledge, exit the darkness of Ignorance, and reform the management of Livelihood, the World, and the Body. Among people are those who cite Reason to validate something which Reason only invalidates; like one seeking in Reason causes necessitating the particulars of Sharias. For there is nothing in Reason except the obligation of obeying the First Creator only in whatever [81r] He commanded, even if by types of killing ourselves—less than which is Tuberculosis (consumption) (1); or a cause necessitating the prohibition of pork and permission of goat meat; or obligating prayer after the sun's decline and preventing it at its rising; or why a prayer is four rak'ahs and another three; or fasting Ramadan excluding Dhu al-Hijjah; or Hajj to Mecca in Dhu al-Hijjah excluding other months; and killing one who commits adultery while chaste (Muhsan) whether the husband of the woman or her father pardons or does not (2) pardon; or forbidding the killing of one who killed a forbidden soul if the guardian pardons him. Nor the prohibition of the [animal] with ripped belly or the insane [animal?] and the permission of the slaughtered or sacrificed. The beginning of all this...
foot_note:
1. (1) Al-Sull: Thus it is, and I did not clarify it. Or: Wa amma (As for). 
2. Aw lam: Aw la.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...is not in Reason at all. Thus are the Sharias, and thus are all actions of the Creator Almighty. He created the donkey a lowly creation for labor, created the horse for riding, endowed the form of man with Reason, empowered the dog over the gazelle, permitted the slaughter of some animals for eating excluding others, created some animals flying, some aquatic, some food for others, some rational, some ignorant, some with two legs, some with four (1) legs, some with six legs, some with more than that, and some without legs also. He created the lion brave and bold, and the monkey cowardly and anxious. He created things with sharp vision and created the mole blind. He created venomous creatures harmful to animals. Thus the Generous Creator arranged all things. It binds one who flees from this to [saying] that the Soul did that [...] in necessitating incapacity or indulgence in futility regarding the Creator, according to his principle; Exalted is He above that. We clarified that in "Al-Fisal" with a healing explanation. Reason is only a power by which the Soul distinguishes all existents on their ranks, or witnesses by it what passed upon it of their true attributes only, and negates by it from them what is not in them. This is the reality of the definition of Reason. Senses follow it in that exactly. This discrimination is the perception of Reason; there is no perception other than it. As for the definition of the benefit of Reason in using acts of obedience and virtues, this definition implies avoiding sins and vices. Discussion on this and other things connected [to it] is exhaustive, God Almighty willing, in our book "On the Ethics of the Soul." Know that for the vast majority of people, stupidity and weakness of minds prevail over them. The virtuous rational person is rare and few indeed. This is taken by sense. The text has come with that from the First Creator and from His Chosen One sent to us, peace be upon him. Almighty said: {And if you obey most of those upon the earth, they will mislead you from the way of God} (6 Al-An'am: 116). And the Messenger of God [81v], peace be upon him, said: "People are like a hundred camels; you can hardly find a riding mount among them." As for [what] the people of weak minds think is Reason while it is not Reason and Reason has no entry in it, they have erred in that greatly. They think Reason is only what safety in the world is encompassed by, and by which status and money are reached. This, if it is by praiseworthy ways containing no sin...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...nor excess, then he is rational. But if it is by whatever is possible of lying, hypocrisy, wasting a duty, wronging a human, and assisting in falsehood, it is the opposite of Reason—after the prohibition of God Almighty coming to us blaming this state a correct blame. So how can what Reason blames, invalidates, and forbids be Reason? Reason was never found blaming these vices, nor did the Command from God Almighty ever come except blaming them. Likewise, what others thought—that praiseworthy Reason which should not be opposed is adhering to familiar fashions—has no meaning. If you acquired it, is it anything but silliness and ignorance? This is not of Reason in anything. The explanation of this is mentioned in our book on "Ethics of the Soul and Virtuous Conduct" and in our book on "Politics," God Almighty willing. God Almighty is the Granter of success to every virtue. Know that things are not perceived in their realities except by one who strips himself of all desires, looks into all opinions with a single equal look not leaning to any of them, and inspects the character of his own self with his reason an inspection that leaves nothing of desire and imitation in it at all. Then he walks with his reason the path we described in this register and avoids what is other than it among what we have shown the signs of all of. Whoever does what we said, perceiving truths in their modes in every quest is guaranteed for him. God Mighty and Majestic alerted to that in His covenants to us, saying: {They follow not except assumption and what [their] souls desire, and there has already come to them from their Lord guidance} (53 An-Najm: 23). And Almighty said: {They follow not except assumption, and indeed, assumption avails not against the truth at all} (53 An-Najm: 28). And Almighty said: {So give good tidings to My servants - Who listen to speech and follow the best of it. Those are the ones Allah has guided, and those are people of understanding} (39 Az-Zumar: 17-18). Know that people, except whom God Almighty protected—and how few they are—denounce the action of one who judges by desire, mislead one who imitates, and invalidate imitation. Yet they do not speak a word after this except it returns to one of these two malicious ways whose ugliness and the error of whose follower they have testified to. Contemplate this, you will find it often. Suffice is God Almighty's blame of these when He says: {Why do you say what you do not do? Great is hatred in the sight of God that [82r] you say what you do not do} (61 As-Saff: 2-3). We seek refuge in God from His hatred. However, we say: One who does good from one aspect and evil from another is better than one who does evil from every aspect. These are hated for doing contrary to...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...their saying. If they, along with their evil doing, condemned truths, their hatred would be doubled due to the doubling of their evil doing. We seek refuge in God from abandonment. Since we have brought a sufficient sentence of this purpose—although speech on that is very long and broad—let us cut short, according to our doctrine in this register of brevity and clarification, God Almighty willing. Let us take, by the power of our Creator, to the quality of Debate, its praiseworthy and blameworthy modes, and its ranks, for it is connected to what preceded, God Almighty willing. 17 - Chapter on the Divisions of Questioning about what you want to know the reality of, among what is ascended to by proofs returning to the Primaries we presented: Know that knowledge of a truth is not reached by inference except by Search (Bahth). Search is via the thought of one, or via reminder from two: either from a teacher to a learner, or from two differing debaters researching. This mode is the utmost by which we reach the clarification of truths due to the abundance of investigation in it, such that fulfilling its right leaves no remainder at all. We say, and by God Almighty is success and we are supported: Know that necessarily, at the beginning of questioning about every questioned object among what is ascended to by proofs returning to the Primaries we presented, there are four questions, and for each there is an answer. The first is the Question with "Hal" (Is it?). We say: Is this thing existing or not? Is such matter true or not? The questioned must then answer by necessity with No or Yes. If he says No or says I do not know, the question about it drops in every case. Because the questioned thing is not devoid of being what is perceived by Reason and Senses, or what is perceived by Consequences (Tawali) of the premises we described. If it is what is perceived by Senses or Reason, speech with one denying that is futile, likewise with one doubting it. If it is what is perceived by Consequences, the question about it also drops, not because he is defeated, but [because] he did not establish a thing so one can proceed (1) with him in searching for it, and because he told the truth about himself when he said I do not know. There is no way to say to anyone regarding what is not...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...perceived by primary reason and senses: "Why do you not know this?" But until it is established for him by proofs, then acknowledging its requirement becomes obligatory on him. Whoever wants to bind him to acknowledge a matter must clarify it to him and establish it for him. The obligation is that no one believes a thing for which no proof has been established [82v], and that he believes it if proof is established for it. As for a person invalidating by demonstrations what an affirmer affirmed without demonstration, it is a volunteer act from him and a strength, but that is not obligatory on him, since the affirmer of a thing without demonstration is a claimant, and a claim falls if no proof supports (1) it. The origin in the structure is that man is born knowing nothing, then he hears sayings. Everyone considers his own opinion good. So there is no way to bind him to acknowledge any of them at all unless a demonstration necessitates the validity of one of them, so it binds him then. Otherwise, some are not more worthy of belief than others. There is no way for all of them to be true so that one believes all of them. Negating all of them and doubting them is possible until Demonstration stands on the validity of the correct one among them. If he answers with Yes and validates what was asked about, he is asked then by the second rank, which is the Question with "Ma" (What is it?). It follows the Question with "Hal". It is said to him: Since you verified it, what is it? Meaning: Inform us of its substance, definition, description, or what you can inform us about regarding the attributes of its essence adhering to it. If he informs with what he informs, he is asked by the third rank, which is the Question with "Kayfa" (How is it?). Meaning: This which you verified, what is its state? How is its configuration? How is the existence of what you affirmed for it in it? If he informs us with what he informs, he is asked by the fourth rank, which is "Lima" (Why?). It is said to him: Why was what you brought as you described? What is your demonstration for the validity of what you claimed of what you mentioned? There is no question against him regarding what he did not mention—whether he omitted or [did not] omit—except by claiming contradiction or refutation against him. Whoever affirms that against him must establish the demonstration on the validity of the contradiction or refutation he attributed to him. In this fourth rank, objection and seeking proofs or their clarification (2) occurs. An example of that is you say: Does a lunar eclipse exist or not? The answerer says: Yes, it exists. If he said No, it is said to him: Then what is this blackness appearing on the middle night of the month? If he denies the visual evidence, he becomes (3) in the category of those not spoken to. If he acknowledges it, it is said to him: It is what we intend by our saying "Eclipse".
foot_note:
1. (1) Yu'ayyiduha: Yuriduha (Presents it). 
2. Ibanataha: Inafataha (Exceeding/Adding). 
3. Sara: Wa sara.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: If you verified the meaning, we would not dispute with you on the name, and we would ask you with an expression you are pleased with, saying to you: Does blackness exist in the moon on the middle night of the month or not? If he verifies, it is said to him: What is it? He says: It is the departure of light from the moon due to the entry of the earth between it and the sun from which it accepts light. The questioner says: How does the earth enter between the sun and the moon? The answerer says: By the sun being in a degree opposite to the degree the moon is in, with the intersection of their two orbits. The questioner says: Why was that? The answerer says then: The configuration of the sphere, the transfer of the sun and its traversing [83r], the transfer of the moon and the duration of its traversing (1), and what completes this meaning. This saying applies to every questioned object in every science. Know that it is not permissible to advance a delayed one of these four (2) ranks over what we arranged before it, because it is speech contrary to the familiar. Know that the one questioned with Ma, Kayfa, and Lima answers in the response with what is possible for him, not exiting the requirement of the questioner. Except that what is necessary in the Question [with Ma] is that he informs the questioner of the Definition (Hadd) of the questioned thing or its Description (Rasm). And if with Kayfa: it is that he answers with the general states of the thing and [those of] others, or the common specific ones, or what distinguishes it from others if the questioned thing is an individual. If he is asked with Lima, [he is] to answer with the Cause necessitating the existence of what he reported exists, and describe the Cause with its description that others do not share. The Cause should be adhering to what is inferred by it, like killing; for it is the cause of killing-death, since it is not permissible that there be killing and no death. Death is an effect of killing, but not every death is an effect of killing, since there is death without killing. Likewise, death is not a cause for killing. The Definition is taken from the attribute of the thing which is the attribute of its element (genus), and taken from its completion (differentia) also. Like your saying if asked about the definition of Medicine: 'A craft'—this is the element of Medicine—then you say: 'curing for the bodies of people'. By this the [definition] of Medicine is completed and it becomes Medicine. If asked about Disease: 'Weakness occurring in the body by the enmity of its humors and their exit from moderation'. Weakness is the element of Disease, and the enmity of humors is its completion, and by it it is named Disease. Likewise your saying in the definition of the Breather: It is...
foot_note:
1. (1) 'And the transfer of the moon and the duration of its traversing': Repeated in the original. 
2. Al-Arba': Al-Arba'ah.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...an animal that draws air and water with a natural instrument and expels it with it. The Definition and Description in everything we mentioned and in everything asked about should be such that you answer with what indicates its defined and described object. Like your saying: 'Every line is either straight or curved, and everything that is either straight or curved is a line.' 'Every body is long, wide, deep, and every long, wide, deep thing is a body.' This is necessary for everything you described in every time, every place, and every state. If you want to verify, let that be with the wording of Affirmation and its meaning. For if you said 'Hot' or 'Cold', you affirmed a necessary meaning. If you want to negate, let that be with the wording of Negation and its meaning. For if you said 'Not hot', you did not affirm a meaning at all in any way. Likewise if you said 'Not a body', 'Not an accident'. The non-hot may be cold, may be moderate, and may be a celestial nature into which none of these attributes enter. If you want to divide, you should [83v] be cautious of the likes of this by not leaving a part except you verified it—either by a particle of negation so the burden is sufficed, or by inspecting all parts one by one and looking: is there a corrupt or added (1) one, or a possible negation? And from what we mentioned regarding the conditions of placing the negation particle in its place. Care (2) for Names for Named things, Universality and Particularity, Described and Attribute, Quality, Quantity, Time, and other conditions. If you look a correct look, truths will not be hidden from you, nor will tricks pass upon you. The bond of that is God Almighty's aid to you and His success for you. Perfection of knowledge belongs only to the Creator of knowledge and sciences; there is no god but He. 18b - Chapter on Discourse on the Rank of Dialectic and the Quality of Debate Leading to Knowledge of Truths: From the rule of Dialectic is that the two (3) are not [both] seekers of truth and desirers of clarification. Either one of them is on certainty of his affair by a decisive demonstration—not by deluding himself nor by a matter he persuaded it with—while the other is imagining he is right, affirming for himself what he has not obtained, like the blind in...
foot_note:
1. (1) Fasid aw za'id: Fasidan aw za'idan. 
2. Wa ihtamm: Unclear in text. 
3. Al-Ithnan: Al-Ithnayn.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...darkness deceiving himself, misleading his reason, or deceived like the dreamer who does not know he is sleeping until he wakes up. This one, being on certainty of his affair by a decisive demonstration, wants to deliver to his debater a part of the truth like what he has, and tries to solve the doubt of this erring opponent or the sophist, exposing his secret in sophistry and repelling his evil. Or one of them is certain as we presented, and the second has not stood upon the clarification of truth, so he seeks truth and standing upon it. If it happens that the two debaters are like this, that is a virtuous debate of praiseworthy consequence; it is about to resolve into a guaranteed good or an abundant reward. It is what God Almighty commanded saying: {And argue with them in a way that is best} (16 An-Nahl: 125). And Almighty saying: {Invite to the way of your Lord with wisdom and good instruction} (16 An-Nahl: 125). And Almighty saying: {Say, "Produce your proof, if you should be truthful."} (2 Al-Baqarah: 111). No one ever dispraised this debate except a silly, ignorant person of blameworthy nature, spoiling things for people, having made this aversion a curtain before his ignorance; he was not content to deprive himself of good until he strove to deprive others of it. But if both debaters are erring, or one is an ignorant [84r] seeker and the second is erring or a sophist, that is a debate where rioting abounds, fatigue becomes great, shouting increases, anger intensifies, and its harm is about to intensify. As for benefit, there is no benefit. Perhaps the ignorant therein rushes to accept what strikes his hearing without correct demonstration, so he perishes by believing falsehood and accepting it. As for if he were a rational certain person, guaranteed for him is the shattering of the structure by regret and rage, except that he is praised in supporting the truth, rewarded for that, and perhaps he benefits a listener. The bond of that is that a third party does not speak a word between them unless he sees apparent injustice, so he testifies to it. And that one does not cut off the speech of his companion until he completes it. And that speech from them does not prolong where there is no benefit. And that they proceed to brevity that does not fall short of exhaustive clarification. If one of them errs and wants retraction, that is his right, and it is obligatory on the other to accept his retraction, because a man's saying is not a part of him, but it is obligatory on him to leave error if he knows it is error. The preventer of retraction is unjust, riotous, ignorant. Likewise, if he sees his argument is corrupt and wants to leave it and take another, that is his right and he does well in that. There is no interruption (defeat) (1) in the saying debated about in that...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...The preventer of that is ignorant, of narrow capacity in knowledge, heedless of his opponent; that is very ugly. If they dispute over speech or dispute over speaking—like each saying: 'I will ask,' or each saying to the other: 'You be the questioner'—this is incapacity from both and lack of confidence: either in the power to support the saying he wants to clarify, or in the validity of the saying itself. If it is due to lack of confidence in the strength of his support, let him expand in knowledge and not expose himself to debate until he is strong; he is like the coward who does not attend the fight, weakening his sect. If it is due to lack of confidence in the validity of the saying, this one is very blameworthy for staying on a saying he does not trust its validity. It is obligatory on them in general to agree on a matter to open the speech with. As for us, our way in that is giving the opponent the choice to be questioner or questioned. Whichever he chooses, we answer him. If he returns the choice to us, we choose that he be the questioner, because this action is the most intended by the weak and the mainstay of their desire, as they weaken if questioned. So we choose cutting off their excuses and fulfilling their utmost demands in which they think they are stronger, so that it is stronger in cutting their attachments. Then if he changes his mind in that and chooses to ask [be asked?], we answer him to that also. However, we do not judge that for others because it is not obligatory. Whoever chooses to be a questioner and his opponent permits him that, he has the right to ask. He does not have the right to be arbitrary and leave that [84v] and move to be questioned. If he does, this is incapacity and a breach in the rule of debate. We choose for the virtuous not to be strict in that, out of our desire to show the truth and lack of joy in overcoming. Thus it is obligatory for everyone who follows our path. Whoever permits his opponent to be the questioner, it is obligatory on him in the rule of debate to answer. If he does not, it is out of injustice or ignorance, unless there is a fearsome ruler preventing declaring the answer; we do not speak with fears. Debate is only with safety—except for one who sacrificed himself for God Almighty and knew what he seeks and what he sacrifices of that; for him is success if he intended supporting Islam or the Truth in what Muslims differed in only. I do not see that the rational Muslim descends from himself [degrades himself]; nothing existing in his time from the Creator is dearer to him than it, nor more obligatory in sanctity except what contains its eternal success only. The rational sees no price for himself except Paradise. Whoever asked and his opponent answered him, then he fell silent from objecting, this is a place where the debate they started has ended (been cut off), unless another is resumed—unless there is fear as we presented. Unless...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the answerer brings what is irrational, or with impudence (1), or slander, or with what is other than what was asked about, out of ignorance or stubbornness. Whoever has this description, the opponent's silence from opposing him is an answer—except by informing that what he brought is not what they are in, and clarifying the proof for that only. Except what is of that not needing proof due to its clarity and the audience's equal knowledge of it. Victory (Falj) (2) in debate is the appearance of the true Demonstration only. The interruption (silencing) of the opponent is not victory (3). He may be silenced out of ignorance, fear, or a preoccupation of mind that befell him. All that is not a cutting of the truth if it is in his hand. The testimony of those present to the victory of one of them is nothing, since they might be agreeing in their opinion with his opinion for whom they testified; so their path and his path are one. Fairness among people is rare. They might not be realizing what they say nor understanding what they hear; this is very frequent. Whoever is cut off from opposing his opponent due to incapacity to answer, not due to a preventing fear, he is the defeated one, not his saying. If that was due to a reality of demonstration, he and his saying are both defeated. The incapacity of the believer to support what is valid by demonstration does not harm it; nor does what is not valid by demonstration become strong by the deception of a deceiver supporting it with sophistry. Demonstration never contradicts itself. What is valid by demonstration, another demonstration never invalidates it, unless it is of what transforms—like a demonstration valid by Zayd's life yesterday, then another valid by his death today. Thus is everything whose transfer is possible; it does not transfer by anything we mentioned of what is valid [85r] by demonstration except by another demonstration. Otherwise, the judgment of the first demonstration remains (4). A thing does not transfer from Possibility to Necessity except by a demonstration, nor transfer after Necessity to Possibility except by a demonstration. Stubbornness and denial are shame, sin, and silliness. Know that if the questioner says to his opponent: 'What is your say in such?', the answer is delegated to the questioned to answer as he wishes. But if he says to him: 'Is matter such-and-such true?', he must answer either with Yes or No. Like a questioner asking: 'What do you say about the earth, is it spherical or not?' He must have Yes or No. 'What do you say about wine, is it lawful or not?' Likewise. Or he says to him: 'Does Void exist or not?' He must have Yes or No. Likewise if the questioner asks...
