1. (1) Bi-Qihah: Nafhah. 
2. Wa al-Falj: Wa al-Falh. 
3. Faljan: Falhan. 
4. Baq: Baqi.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...with a division, saying: 'What is your say in such and such: Is it such or such?' Like his saying: 'What do you say about the rose, is it cold, hot, or moderate?' 'What do you say about the earnings of a cupper, is it recommended, forbidden, or disliked?' If the divisions are exhaustive, the questioned must commit to one of those divisions. If he does not do so, he is cut off (silenced) in reality. If they are not exhaustive, the questioner is ignorant or stubborn. If the interruption of the opponent appears, the predecessors [say]: It is not upon the questioner to clarify the truth. As for us, we say: That is upon him. Whoever invalidates a judgment, it is upon him to clarify his saying: either to enter into the like of what he invalidated, or to clear the confusion. Clarifying truths is an obligation; God Almighty took a covenant from scholars to clarify what they knew and not hide it. If the opponent exhausts the divisions and adds a corrupt division to them, the other does not have the right to leave what they are in and take to arguing in clarifying the extra division he added. But he says to him: 'You added a corrupt division which is such-and-such. I only mentioned it to you so you do not circulate it against me, so my silence about it would be like my acknowledgment of it to one who is not fair. But I am harmed by that, and I commit to the divisions you mentioned, division such-and-such, which is the correct one.' Know that whoever leaves what he is in with his opponent of debate and exits to another issue is an ignorant, riotous persuader (1). Like what we witnessed often of one who left what they were about and started pursuing his companion's grammatical errors in his speech. We do not say this to support grammatical errors and leave being busy with other than what they started in. The opponent has no more right than to express his intent with what his opponent understands; there is no addition [required] with whatever word and whatever language it is—except that we choose brevity—but to support the Truth Gathering [85v] many meanings from few, simple, easy, eloquent words for whoever is capable of that. Otherwise, there is no blame on him except in one place: that the questioner asks him, and the questioned knows that the questioner holds a view by which he returns to binding the opponent or to contradiction. His answer here is to say to him: 'What do you say in such?' Meaning: 'I hold your view.' If the one opposed by this says to him: 'I do not say what you think, nor do I say anything, nor do I support a hopeful answer; I am only a seeker of demonstration, and my error is not upon you; so support your saying or admit error.' It is obligatory then not to oppose him with a question at all, but with a demonstration by which he clarifies the validity of his saying only.
foot_note: 1. (1) Muqni': Ibn Hazm sometimes uses "Iqna'" (Persuasion) in the sense of Rioting/Sophistry.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: The opponent may be indulgent with his opponent in showing him the admission of the corruption of his saying, then say to him: 'So leave my saying and bring your saying and clarify the face of correctness.' This action is error from two aspects: One is that he is truthful in his admission of the invalidity of his saying and his return from it and his seeking knowledge of the truth; this is a great virtue and its doer is very praiseworthy. The second is that he has known that his opponent brings the like of that, so he wants to bind him with the like of what he bound him, to restrain his rioting from himself; this is fairness. An example of that is that one of the opponents says: 'Debate (Jidal) is disliked.' The other says: 'If it is disliked, by what thing is knowledge of the truth reached according to you, regarding what those you consider satisfactory of your creed differed in? Bring [what] you have and leave debate aside now.' This returns to what we said before of modes of divisions that are all invalid except one, so that one becomes valid. The opponent then must mention Imitation (Taqlid), or Inspiration (Ilham/Delusion), or abandoning the search for truth. All these modes are invalid and corrupt. If they are invalid, Debate is valid. This which we said restricts the opponent to this mode of the modes of Demonstration, so he returns to the truth or is cut off either by silence or slander he brings. We mentioned in the Chapter of Divisions of Knowledge what the ignorant opponent is opposed with of things the ignorant (1) count as proof while they are not proof at all. It is obligatory to restrain the harm of their ignorance of them in every case. Know that it is an error to oppose Error with Error in debate. Like the questioner saying to the questioned: 'You say such and such', 'Did you not say such and such?' The answerer says: 'And you also say such and such', or 'Because you also say such and such'. He brings him the like of what he denied on him or more heinous. All this is a gross error, great shame, and following error. Except in [86r] two places: One is that the saying the answerer objected with is a correct saying producing what he says; this is a virtuous mode and a cutting of the questioner. That is like a Mu'tazili saying to another: 'Why did you say God Almighty is the Creator of Evil?' He said: 'Because you say with me that Almighty created the entire world, its substances and accidents; and evil is an accident; so God Almighty is the Creator of Evil.' This is a correct opposition, except that the appearance of its wording is not precise, because in appearance he made the cause of his saying what he says to be his opponent's saying what he says. It implies for him that were it not for his opponent saying that, he would not have said what he said. This is an error. The correct way is to say...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...to establish the demonstration that God Almighty is the Creator of Substance and Accident, then proceed with his question. The second way is if the questioner is a rioter intending defamation, incitement, and rebuke, and does not intend to seek a truth. It is obligatory to break his sharpness and deter his fault with the like of this only. He should not be debated with more than that, since the purpose is only restraint, and his harm is not restrained by a correct debate at all; so nothing is more restraining to his harm than what we mentioned. Know that it is not permissible for a thing to validate itself at all, but it is permissible for it to invalidate itself. Do not think that the Primaries from which Demonstration is taken validated themselves, thus erring; rather, those are things we mentioned that Creation validated, and no person of understanding was ever devoid of knowing their validity. Do not think either that invalidating a thing by itself is a validation of it, thus erring. It was not invalidated by itself because it validated its invalidation by it—for then it would be a validater and an invalidater, which is impossible. But when it was invalidated by itself, we became certain it is false, because the correct Truth is never invalidated at all, and because it contradicted its own judgment; and everything that is contradicted is false. The saying of one who said, invalidating speculation (Nazar): "Speculation is not valid except by speculation," is not a correct saying. Because the Speculation by which things become valid is returning them to the Primary Premises which Nature judged to be valid. Whatever returns to them and they testify for it is correct, and whatever does not return to them is corrupt. This is the Speculation by which things become valid, because Speculation is only valid by another Speculation. If the judgment is cut off (silenced), the debate is cut off. They have the right then to begin a second question. The silenced one has the right then to say: "I ask you a question connected to our issue, and I bind you to say like my saying which you denied upon me." The other has no right to refuse that; if he refuses, he is a weak evader. If the other fulfills a condition, both are blameworthy if they do not return to the truth when the questioned is unable to differentiate between the two sayings. Just as we blame one to whom a demonstration appears yet he persists in falsehood and does not return [86v] to the requirement of the demonstration, we likewise blame one who rushes to accept what he hears without a demonstration. And just as we praise one who returns to the requirement of the demonstration, we likewise praise one who remains firm on its requirement and does not return due to auditory persuasion or sophistry. If he is unable to break them, and these premises are established for the two debaters (1), praised is he who believes only what the demonstration necessitated.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Multiplying proofs is strength and not incapacity, except for an interrupted (defeated) ignoramus. Verify everything you hear from your opponent and do not neglect it. Accept his retraction if he errs. Do not leave a problem except you make him stand upon it; if it settles free of deficiency and ambiguity, then answer. Everything you demand of your opponent regarding that, commit to the like of it yourself, exactly. Clarify your question [to be] free from deficiency and ambiguity. Beware of introducing what is not part of the debate; this is the action of madmen or one who wants to prolong speech so the end makes the beginning forgotten, to forget his error and slip. Contemplate his premises and your premises, your conversion and his conversion, his results and your results. Do not be pleased for yourself from your opponent except with the clear truth. Know that it is not upon a person more than supporting the truth and clarifying it. Then it is not upon him to visualize for the senses or in souls what there is no way to visualize, nor what has no form at all. Like one who proves that the First One is neither substance, nor accident, nor body, nor in time, nor in place, nor a carrier, nor carried; and the opponent wants him to form a shape of that for him. This is not binding. This is like a blind man tasking a sighted man to visualize colors for him; this is what there is no way to. This is a corrupt tasking; incapacity regarding it is not a deficiency in the tasked. As for what remains possible, it is obligatory on the tasked to explain it to the utmost he can. My tutor Ahmed bin Muhammad bin Abdul Warith, may God have mercy on him, told me that his father modeled the letters of the alphabet for a son he had who was born blind, as bodies from tar (pitch). Then he made him touch them until he understood their forms with his reason and sense. Then he made him touch their composition and the establishment of things from them until the script was formed [in his mind] and how writing is clarified and read in himself; he lifted a great distress from him by that. As for colors, there is no way to that regarding them; there is nothing but what demonstration established, even if it is not formed in the soul at all. I was tested once by some of our friends; he tasked us to show him the Accident sifted from the Substance, standing by itself. He said to me: "If you do not show me that, I will not believe in the Accident." I cannot count how many times I squared a triangle for him, then rounded it, and [showed] the departure [87r] of the squareness and the remaining of the clay as it was; and the movements of a person from his standing and sitting; and the redness of a garment after its whiteness. He refused all that unless I showed him the Accident removed from the Substance, remaining as it is, seeing it in other than a substance. I cannot count how many times I told him: "If the Accident stood by itself and was as you want from me, it would not be an accident; it is only...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...an accident because it is contrary to what you want." He persisted (1), so I returned to say to him jokingly: "If you could take me out of the sphere of the world, perhaps it would be possible then—if the separation of the Accident from the Substance were possible—but there is no way to all that, that you see it in other than a Substance. As for the whole world, it is a solid sphere and a connected jewel (substance) with adjacent parts; there is no porosity (rarefaction) in it nor gap (2). Even if an accident separated from a substance and it was permissible for it to remain after its separation from it, it would only end up in another substance." This mockery did not deter him from what occurred in his soul, and I left him refusing. I do not know if he was guided after me to reject this agitated desire or not. Such corrupt tasking, and the fact that truths are not formed for a person [visually], is not a flaw in the demonstration nor something to pay attention to. It suffices from that, and is enough for us, the establishment of the validity of that in the soul by the indication of Reason that it is true only. If it were permissible for everyone for whom a thing is not formed in his soul to deny it, it would be permissible for the one with no sense of smell to deny scents, and the one born blind to deny colors, and for us to deny the elephant and the giraffe. All this is false. Rather, the rational person must affirm what Demonstration affirmed and invalidate what Demonstration invalidated, and pause regarding what a demonstration neither affirmed nor invalidated until the truth appears to him. Likewise, it is not upon us to force tongues to acknowledge the truth, but it is upon us to force souls to acknowledge it and to cut off tongues from correct opposition due to its non-existence, since Demonstration does not contradict itself. If we established it, we are safe from our opponent establishing it. Likewise, if a person falls short of establishing demonstration for a truth he believes, that does not harm the truth a bit. None rejoices at this from his opponent except one who rejoices in wishful thinking, which is the fool who is cited as an example. Do not be content with the negligence of your opponent regarding all that can validate his saying. If you find a truth by demonstration, return to it and do not hesitate. Do not be pleased for yourself to remain an hour refusing to accept the truth. If you find a deception, clarify it, and do not be deceived by your opponent missing it, for perhaps another of the people of his doctrine will notice what he missed. Furthermore, do not be content except with the reality of victory. Do not mind if it is said about you that you are a falsifier; you have in those attributed with that among the verifiers a most noble model, among the Prophets, peace be upon them, and those below them. Yes, such that many of them were killed in defense [87v] of their right and attributing falsehood to them. Do not feel lonely with the Truth against anyone; whoever has the Truth with him, the Creator Almighty is with him. Do not mind the multitude of your opponents, nor the antiquity of their times, nor...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...people's magnifying of them, nor their equipment. Truth is more than them, older, mightier to everyone, and worthier of magnification. If you wish to be certain of the corruption of observing what we mentioned, contemplate the people of every religion and every nation; you will find them agreed upon their ancestors, describing them with every virtue and every good, and dispraising the ancestors of those who opposed them. Contemplate every saying said; those saying it at its beginning were few. Most of that goes back to one, then his followers increased. Inspect every old saying; you find it was the son of an hour after it had not been, then days, months, years, and epochs passed over it. Know that observing these matters is from weakness of mind or lack of knowledge. Do not mind either even if they were virtuous in reality; the virtuous may err as long as he is not infallible. If that virtuous person had what appeared to you appear to him, he would have returned to you; if he did not, he would not be virtuous. I will tell you a story, were it not for the hope that fairness be facilitated by it for one who might be averse to what we mentioned: I debated a man from our companions on an issue, and I overcame him in it due to a stutter he had in his tongue. The session broke up with me being the victor. When I came to my house, something wavered in my soul about it. I sought it in some books and found a correct demonstration showing the invalidity of my saying and the correctness of my opponent's saying. One of our companions who witnessed that session was with me, so I informed him of that. Then I marked the place in the book and said to him: "What do you want?" [He said:] "Carrying this book, presenting it to So-and-so, and informing him that he is the verifier and I am the falsifier and that I am returning (1) to his saying." A perplexing matter attacked him from that, and he said to me: "And your soul permits this?!" I said to him: "Yes, and if I could do that in this time of mine, I would not delay it to tomorrow." Know that this action earns you the most beautiful mention along with adorning yourself with fairness which nothing equals. Let not your purpose be to delude yourself that you are a victor, or to delude those present who are deceived by you and trust your judgment that you are a victor while you are in reality defeated. You would be, then, mean, very low, absolutely silly, and of fallen ambition; like one who deludes himself that he is an obeyed king while he is a wretched unfortunate, or in the category of one who is told "You are white and beautiful" while he is black and deformed, becoming a mockery and laughingstock among people of intellect whose judgment is the truth.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Know that whoever is pleased with this is deceived (1); his path is the path of the owner of wishful thinking, and they are the merchandise of fools. The one tempted by them finds pleasure in them [88r] until when his reason returns to him and he looks at his state, he knows he is in delusions and has nothing in his hand. Beware of paying attention to one who boasts of his ability in debate such that ignorance reaches him to say: "I am capable of making the truth false and the falsehood true." Do not believe such liars; they are lowly riffraff, people of lies, evil, and jugglery. Know that there is no way to that for anyone, nor is it in the power of a creature at all. I have explained all deceptions to you; they vanish if obtained and inspected; they are found to be nothing but claims and stupidities. Among the obscene things occurring in this path is that the demonstration appears to a person, but familiarity with the doctrines he is accustomed to drives him to say: "There must be here a proof of demonstration opposing this demonstration, even if it is hidden from me." Know that this one is very deceived and wretched, because he made his conjecture overcome his certainty, believed what was not validated for him, denied what was validated for him, affirmed what might not be, and left a resultant that has been. This is the utmost abandonment. Like him is one who leaves a demonstration validated for him due to a camouflage he did not ponder, so recklessness carried him to believe it. In general, there is no good in ignorance. Knowledge, if its owner does not use it, he is worse than the ignorant, and his knowledge is an added argument against him. Beware of imitating fathers (ancestors); God Almighty has blamed that. Were it praiseworthy, one who found his fathers as adulterers or thieves or upon some traits more malicious than what we mentioned would be excused to imitate them. Beware of being deceived by the frequent correctness of one person, accepting a single saying of his without demonstration. We may stumble during his correctness upon what is clearer and more evident than much of what he was correct in. Be content with your opponent's seriousness in supporting his saying, and do not demand him to admit defeat; that is not of the actions of people of strength. This is a door that produces nothing but enmity and being described with the meanness of victory. Let your desire to be a rightful scholar in reality, even if called a falsifying ignorant defeated fool, be more than your desire to be called a rightful scholar rational victor while you are in reality a falsifying ignorant defeated one. Rather, do not desire this at all and hate it greatly. You have in those whom the ignorant described with that before you, among the Messengers, peace be upon them, and the virtuous...
foot_note: 1. (1) Maghrur: Ma'dhur (Excused) - but context suggests deceived.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...predecessors, the best model and noblest example. Likewise, being described with debauchery (Fisq) while you are virtuous is better than being described with virtue while you are a debauchee. Guard against exiting from one issue to another issue before the completion of the first and its clarification (1); this is of the actions of the people of ignorance. Beware of speaking to one whose doctrine is nothing but [88v] opposition and contradiction, or shouting and overcoming. Do not weary yourself with him. If you could turn him from error by preaching, that would be good. If not, then by rebuking and curbing (2). If he is unapproachable, let him be avoided as the madman is avoided; his harm is more than the harm of madmen. Guard against speaking where partisanship is used against you unjustly. Guard against answering yourself on behalf of your opponent, like saying to him: "If you say such, I bind you with such." Perhaps he does not say that, so you are disgraced, unless he is an author. You must be fair to your opponent and exhaust his arguments, otherwise you are unjust. Guard against attributing to your opponent what he did not say, so you lie. Guard against answering one who did not ask you, so you obtain disgrace; the least of that is that he turns away from you, so how about if he says to you: "I did not ask you." Do not speak on the tongue of a debater other than you until he leaves the speech and permits you to debate the one speaking to him. The least in this is that he says to you: "I am in no need of your support," and his opponent says to him: "I strengthen you with him, blessing him for you," so you are disgraced greatly. Beware of speaking in a science of the sciences until you master it, except by way of questioning and increasing [knowledge], only what you know well of it. Admit to one who is more knowledgeable than you; this is an adornment for you. Do not shortchange him his right, for your diminishing him (3) [is not a deficiency for him] but is a deficiency in you. Beware of praising yourself with what you do well; leave that, for it is better in you from another. Do not despise anyone until you know what he has; perhaps something you did not reckon surprises you from him. That is only the action of the people of foolishness who do not achieve. Beware of everyone who is not fair and everyone who does not understand. Do not speak except to one whose fairness and understanding you hope for. Spend the time that passes in waste speaking to one who does not understand nor is fair, in what is more beneficial to you; you will live gaining, safe from errors...
foot_note:
1. (1) Wa bayanaha: Wa bayanihi. 
2. Wa al-qad': Wa al-qadh'. 
3. Fa inna tanaqquska iyyahu: Fa inna tanaqqusa naqsika iyyahu.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...These are two very great fortunes. Make instead of your speech the praise of God Almighty for safety from the like of his state. Do not speak except in clarifying a truth or seeking its clarification. Know that no one is capable of these conditions except by one trait: that he trains himself to lack concern for people's praise of him or their blame of him, but makes his endeavor seeking the Truth for himself only. The Ancients mentioned regarding the description of the 'Cut-off' (Defeated/Silenced) modes which we mention: One is that he intends invalidating the truth or doubting it. From this type is referring in the answer of what he is asked about to it being impossible, not possible. The second is that he uses slander, impudence, and declaring falsehood openly, not caring about the contradiction of his saying nor the corruption of what he went to. From that is judging with a judgment then breaking it. The third is moving from a saying and question to [89r] a question by way of confusion, not by way of leaving and clarification. The fourth is using obscure speech which the rational thinks is full of wisdom while it is full of prattle. Among the closest things present to my memory while writing this affair from people's books is the book of Abu al-Faraj the Judge named "Al-Luma'"; it is full of complex, closed speech having no meaning except contradiction and building and demolishing what he built. In our time, there are those who followed this path in their speech. By my life, he deluded many people that he speaks with wisdom. By my life, most of his speech he does not understand, let alone others. The fifth is that he constrains his opponent and forces him to repetition without added benefit, because he returns to the subject from which he was driven away and seeks refuge around it, having no strength nor increase other than describing his saying without proof. The sixth is deluding by feigning laughter, shouting, mimicking, medicalizing (1) (patronizing?), deeming ignorant, harshness, and perhaps by insults, accusations of disbelief, cursing, foolishness, and slandering mothers and fathers. It is likely, if he is not a slapper and kicker. Most of these meanings, you hardly find other than them in most people of our time. God is the One sought for help. People in their speech—by which they were favored over beasts and without which they would be like donkeys and cows—are of three categories: A category does not care where he spends his speech, rushing to denial or belief or stubbornness without verification. If you ask him immediately after the expiration of his speech about...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...the saying he supported without verification, he would not know nor recognize whom he supported nor his saying. This is the most predominant among people. You find one of this description being stingy to his brother and neighbor with stinking manure at his donkey's leg, spending it [only] for one who benefits from it, yet he is the most generous of people with speech—by which he is distinct from he-goats and dogs—in other than reward or righteousness, but in falsehood, sin, and corruption. Even if he obtains nothing from that outwardly except the congestion of his chest tubes, the headache of his head, the heating of his temper, and that he acts foolishly and is acted foolishly against. Another category supports what he tied his intention to and believed without demonstration. He does not care what he supports—truth, falsehood, impossible, stubbornness, or harm. Likewise, you do not find him believing what he believed except by familiarity, imitation, or desire, without seeking truth nor avoiding falsehood. These are many, and they are below the first ones. A third category intends nothing but supporting the Truth and suppressing Falsehood. These are very few; I do not know in existents anything less [89v] than it at all. We ask God Almighty to establish us in their number and not leave us void of this noble attribute by His grace, Amen. For the rational person should hate spending his life and speech—by which his Creator distinguished him from inanimate objects and other animals—in other than what benefits him for his Hereafter, more than he hates spending his money which comes and goes. Know that what we mentioned of standing upon truths is only by intense search. Intense search is only by much reading of all opinions and sayings, looking into the natures of things, listening to the argument of every arguer, looking into it and inspecting, and supervising religions, sects, schools, choices, people's differences, and reading their books. Whoever among the ignorant dispraises what we mentioned has opposed his Lord Almighty. For He, Mighty and Majestic, informed us in His revealed Book of the sayings of the differers among the people of denial saying the world is eternal, the people of Dualism, the people of Trinity, and the atheists, in the description of all that, to show us Almighty their contradiction and the corruption of their sayings. Then we return and say: It is necessary for the seeker of truths to view the Quran, its meanings, the narration of its words, and its rulings; and the Hadith of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his biographies gathering all praiseworthy virtues in the world and leading to the Hereafter. It is necessary with that to read ancient and modern history (News), supervise the division of lands (Geography), know Astronomy (Hay'ah), and stand upon the language in which translated books are read, and investigate its usage. It is necessary for him to study Grammar; sufficient for him...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...of it is what he reaches the difference of meanings with, by what he stands upon of the difference of vowels in words and the places of declension in them. This is collected in the book "Al-Jumal" by Abu al-Qasim Abdul Rahman bin [Ishaq] al-Zajjaji al-Dimashqi. As for all that preceded, let him increase of it as much as he can. For that, there are two limits: A limit which is the maximum (Goal), and a limit less than which one should not restrict himself to. The Greater Limit is not to be empty of looking into the sciences we presented except at times of performing obligatory duties, looking into what is necessary for livelihood, and leaving everything of worldly matters that can be dispensed with. Know that your looking into sciences with the intention of perceiving truths, denying falsehood, supporting truth, teaching it to people, guiding the ignorant, and knowing what you worship your Creator Almighty with—so you do not worship Him out of ignorance and err more than you are correct regarding the religion of God Almighty, the creed of Truth, and the correct doctrine in performing what He tasked you with Almighty [90r]—and your benefiting people in their religions, bodies, management of their affairs, execution of their rulings and politics, enlightening the one in charge of any of that, adjusting his nature, advising him in that with truth, making him understand, and making the ugly ugly to him—is better with God than everything by which one draws near to God Almighty, greater in reward, and more returning [benefit] upon you than all you earn—after what your body and eye have no subsistence without—of what you perhaps leave to one whom if you witnessed his action with it after you, it would enrage you. And [better] than every status that perhaps earns you nothing but sin, fear, fatigue, and rage. Know that that is greater in reward, better in consequence, and more beneficial than your gifting people dinars and dirhams. The harm of ignorance and error is more severe and greater than the harm of poverty and obscurity. Know that you do not bequeath High Status except to one who earns you good deeds while you are dead, and good mention while you are decayed bones; he mentions you only with every beautiful thing. You do not bequeath it after you nor accompany in your life on its path except every virtuous person. You do not accompany in seeking money and status except the likes of foxes and wolves. I tell you regarding that something I hope its reader benefits from, God Almighty willing. That is: I was detained in the hands of the one nicknamed Al-Mustakfi, Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman bin Ubayd Allah bin Al-Nasir, in a dungeon (Matbaq). I was not safe from his killing because he was an unjust, tyrannical, transgressing ruler, of little religion, much ignorance, untrusted, and unverified. Our sin with him was our companionship to Al-Mustazhir, may God be pleased with him.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: The rogues (Aygarun) had leaped with this loser upon Al-Mustazhir and killed him. He seized the command and detained us where we mentioned. I was thinking about a difficult issue among the universals of sentences under which fall great meanings—regarding which rioting abounded anciently and recently in the rulings of religion, and its branches dispose in all chapters of Jurisprudence. My thought in it prolonged for days and nights until the face of clarification appeared to me in it, and it became correct and true for me with certainty in its judgment, and dawned. I was in the state I described. By God, other than Whom there is no god, the Creator, Disposer of all matters, I swear—by Whom it is not permissible to swear by other than Him—my joy that day, while I was in that state, at my victory with the truth in what my mind was busy with, and the shining of correctness for me, was more intense than my joy at my release from what I was in. We did not compose this book of ours, and much of what we composed, except while we were exiled, banished from homeland, family, and child, fearing alongside that for our lives from injustice and aggression. We do not hide this but announce it, and we do not enable the seeker to invalidate our saying in that. To God we complain, and Him we ask for judgment, no other; there is no god but He. As for the Lesser Limit which the rational person should [90v] [not] fall short of: Let him look at the time he isolates for superfluities of talk that does not suffice with his neighbors, or sitting idle without work—neither of Hereafter nor of World—or when walking in the land arrogantly (while his Creator forbade him from that). Let him make these times for learning and looking into the sciences we presented, and training his nature on Justice which is the head of every virtue. For Justice necessitates that he does not lean to a saying over a saying except by a clear demonstration. It necessitates for him also that he does not busy himself with the lower and leave the better. If he does so, he is about to succeed with what contains success in the Two Abodes. As for the times in which the people of ignorance busy themselves either with pleasures in sins, or with wronging people in their wealth, striving for corruption in their politics, attacking their honors, and being unjust to them—their busying themselves with diseases painful to their souls, harmful to their bodies, is more returning [benefit] upon them than that, and better. So how about busying with sciences leading to the good of the World and the success of the Hereafter? The First One has said: {It is only those who have knowledge among His slaves that fear Allah} (35 Fatir: 28). The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "Whomever God intends good for, He gives him understanding in religion." There is no understanding except by knowing what we mentioned...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...and supervising it. Whoever is deprived of what I mentioned, how we fear for him that God Almighty did not intend good for him. We seek refuge in God from that for ourselves, our children, our brothers, and the people of good and virtue. Our success is only by God Almighty. Know that among the virtues of knowledge and devotion to seeking it and acting according to it is that you obtain the dispelling of worry, which is the comprehensive goal of all goals of every intender from first to last. By God Almighty is success; He is sufficient for us and the best Disposer of affairs; there is no god but He. 19 - Chapter on How to Take Premises from the Apparent Sciences Among People Briefly: The sciences circulating among people today which are intended are twelve sciences, and two additional sciences result [from them]. This rank is other than the rank that was with the Ancients, but we speak on what people benefit from in every time regarding what they reach their quest of perceiving sciences with, by the power of God Almighty and His strength. The sciences we mentioned are: Science of Quran, Science of Hadith, Science of Schools (Madhahib), Science of Fatwa (Jurisprudence), Science of Logic, Science of Grammar, Science of Language, Science of Poetry, Science of History (News), Science of Medicine, Science of Number (Arithmetic), Science of Geometry, and Science of Astronomy (Stars). Resulting from these are Sciences of Expression (Rhetoric) and Science of Eloquence. As for the Science of Quran, it is divided into sections [91r]: Science of its Readings, its Parsing (I'rab), its Strange words (Gharib), its Exegesis (Tafsir), and its Rulings (Ahkam). Returning to it regarding the Science of Quran Readings is [via] accepted premises returning to satisfactory known readers, returning to the Prophet, peace be upon him, for whom demonstrations established the validity of their transmission from him and the validity of his establishment. As for its Parsing, it is a correct premise in it: if the word is taken in it upon certain vowel movements and a certain form, it is a principle returned to. As for its Language (Gharib), it is the familiar from it in the Arabic language. As for its Rulings, [return is] to the concept of its words and to the clarification of the Prophet, peace be upon him, for them. As for Hadith, it is divided into two parts: Science of its Narrators and Science of its Rulings. As for its Narrators, the reference to it regarding them is premises transmitted from trustworthy people who testified to their probity (Justice) and proof; the testimony is taken from the Quran whose validity we mentioned. As for its Rulings, [return is] to the concept of its words and to the [indication] of some of them upon others, as we explained in other than this place.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: As for the Science of Schools (Madhahib), whatever of it is outside the Islamic Creed, [return is] to premises returning to the primaries of Reason and Sense as we mentioned in the book "Al-Fisal." As for the Science of Logic, we have explained it in this register; it is the expression over every science. As for the Science of Fatwa, [return is] to premises taken from the Quran and Hadith which were validated by demonstrations, and to the Consensus of virtuous scholars which was validated by the Quran as we explained in our other books. As for the Science of Grammar, [return is] to premises preserved from the Arabs, whose knowledge increases the understanding (1) of meanings in their language. As for the Causes ('Ilal) in it, they are very corrupt. As for the Science of Language, [return is] to what was also heard from the Arabs by the transmission of accepted trustworthy people that this is their language. As for the Science of Poetry, [return is] to what was also heard of their usage in meters specifically, excluding every meter used by others, since people only name 'Poetry' what is guaranteed by the Prosody meters only which Al-Nadim mentioned in his book. As for its good and bad, [return is] to things agreed upon by those who narrate it much and devote themselves to inspecting its meanings: of sweet easy wording, meaning gathering beauty, hitting a simile, fine metonymy, and marvelous composition. As for the Science of History (News), [return is] to premises which Recurrent Transmission (Tawatur) compelled the acknowledgement of their validity, regarding the existence of famous lands, known kings, their battles, and the rest of their news about which there is no doubt. As for the Science of Medicine, [return is] to premises validated by Experience or what appeared and became clear of the powers of diseases and what generates them from the disturbance of temperament, and opposing that with the powers of medicines [91v]. All that returns to the primaries of Reason and Sense. As for the Science of Arithmetic and Geometry, its premises are all from the primaries of Reason. As for the Science of Astronomy, it is divided into two parts: One is the Structure (Hay'ah) of Spheres, the traversing of stars, sun, moon, and heavens, the divisions of the Sphere and its centers. This part's premises return to Arithmetic, Geometry, and primaries of Reason and Sense. The second part is the Propositions (Judgments) occurring by the position of the transfer of the planet, sun, and moon in the Zodiac signs and their opposition to one another. If Experience validates anything of that, it is true; otherwise, there are only sayings from ancient people only.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: As for the Science of Eloquence (Balagha), it is according to what we mention in its chapter, God Almighty willing. As for the Science of Expression (Interpretation/Ta'bir), [return is] to things narrated from the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, and from the virtuous people of this science. The mainstay of these two sciences is expansion in all sciences along with natural talent and agreement in the original constitution. We have reached what we wanted of the rules of speech on Demonstration and its followers, and what resembles it of what is not demonstration. Praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds, abundantly; He has no partner. God is sufficient for us and the best Disposer of affairs.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: - 7 - The Book of Eloquence (Balagha): Aristotle spoke in this chapter, and people spoke in it much. Qudama bin Ja'far the Scribe mastered a good book in it. It reached us at the time of this composition of ours that our friend Ahmed bin Abdul Malik bin Shahid composed a book on that; he is among those firmly established in the science of Eloquence, very strong in it. He wrote to us informing us of that, but we have not seen the book yet. We are sufficed by the books we mentioned from going deep into speech in this affair. But we speak on it with comprehensive brevity, and refer to what others whom we named and whom we will name have explained, God Almighty willing. We say, and by God Almighty we are supported: Eloquence may differ in languages according to what the people of each language deem beautiful regarding the locations of words upon meanings which agree in every language. Strange (uncommon) words may be counted in Eloquence, but if their usage becomes frequent, they are no longer counted in Eloquence nor deemed beautiful. We say: Eloquence is what the commoner understands like the understanding of the elite. It should be with a wording the commoner is alerted to because he is not used to the like of its arrangement and meaning. It exhausts the entire intent, does not add to it what is not of it, nor omits anything needed of that request. It brings the understanding close to the one addressed by it, due to its clarity and bringing close what is distant. It multiplies meanings [92r] and makes its memorization easy due to its brevity and ease of words. The mainstay of that is brevity for the one who understands, explanation for the one who does not understand, abandoning repetition for the one who is told and understands, and persisting in repetition for the one who does not accept or is heedless. This which we mentioned is divided into two parts: One leaning to words familiar to the common people...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...like the eloquence of Amr bin Bahr al-Jahiz. And a part leaning to unfamiliar words like the eloquence of Al-Hasan Al-Basri and Sahl bin Harun. Then a third part occurs between them, taking from both aspects, like the eloquence of the author of the translation of *Kalila wa Dimna*, whether it was Ibn al-Muqaffa or another. Then people's eloquence is under these ways we mentioned. As for the composition of the Quran, its Revealer Almighty prevented the capability of its like and intervened between the eloquent ones and coming with what resembles it. Ibn Darraj had invented, in our view, a type of eloquence between speeches (Khutab) and epistles (Rasa'il). As for the Moderns, we say: They are distanced from Eloquence and close to Arrogance and Excess (Zayd/Zayf?), except Al-Hatimi and Badi' al-Zaman; they lean to the method of Sahl bin Harun. This is the reality of Eloquence and its meaning; we have gathered it, and praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds. It is necessary for one who wants the science of Eloquence to take a share in all sciences we presented before this. The most of this is Quran, Hadith, History (Akhbar), and the books of Amr bin Bahr. He must be, with that, naturally gifted (Matbu') in it; otherwise, he will not be eloquent. Natural talent does not benefit without expansion in sciences. The Book of Eloquence is completed, and praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: - 8 - The Book of Poetry: This is a craft about which some wise men said: "Truth adorns everything except the Slanderer and the Poet; for Truth mars them." Suffice you with what you hear. The Ancients said: Poetry is lying. For this reason, God prevented His Prophet, peace be upon him, from it, so He said Almighty: {And We did not teach him poetry, nor is it befitting for him} (36 Ya-Sin: 69). Almighty informed that they say what they do not do. The Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade maximizing it; that is only because it is lying, except what exited the limit of [lying] poetry and came as wisdom, sermons, and praise of the Prophet, peace be upon him. As for what is other than that, if its speaker sought the truth and said: "Night is night and Day is day... And the mule is a mule and the donkey is a donkey. And the rooster is a rooster and the pigeon is like it... And both are birds possessing a beak," he would become in the category of one mocked and ridiculed, and would enter into laughingstocks. Until if he lied and exaggerated, saying: [92v] "Sickness accustomed his body, and groaning... And passion wasted him so he is not visible. Thoughts do not see him except as thoughts... And he is more hidden than for thoughts to see him. We heard his groaning from nearby... So seek the person where the groaning was. He did not live because he is sturdy, but... He melted from sickness so death did not find him." [This is] stupidity and salt (wit). But we speak on it [according to] the amount we know well. We say: Poetry is divided into three parts: Craft (Sina'ah), Nature (Tab'), and Brilliance (Bara'ah).

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Craft is the composition gathering metaphor using things, soaring (Tahliq) over meanings, and metonymy about them. The lord of this chapter among the ancients is Zuhayr bin Abi Sulma, and among the moderns is Habib bin Aws (Abu Tammam). Nature is what has no affectation in it, and its wording is common with no excess over its meaning, such that if you wanted to express that meaning in prose, you would not bring an easier nor more concise (1) one than that wording. The lord of this chapter among the ancients is Jarir, and among the moderns is Al-Hasan. Brilliance is disposing in subtle and distant meanings, increasing in what people are not used to saying, hitting the simile, and improving the subtle meaning. The lord of this chapter among the ancients is Imru' al-Qais, and among the moderns is Ali bin Abbas al-Rumi. The poetry of other people returns to the divisions we mentioned and is composed of them. As for one who wants to become skilled in the divisions of poetry, its chosen parts, and the varieties of disposing in its beauties, let him look into the book of Qudama bin Ja'far on *Criticism of Poetry* and the book of Abu Ali al-Hatimi; in them is sufficient sufficiency and exhaustiveness for this meaning. A person being a poet is not acquired, but it is a trick (talent), except that we strengthen its possessor by expanding in poems and pondering them. Since we have spoken on Poetry with speech gathering its divisions, and our purpose is fulfilled, we say: This is the definition of Logic from which we warn against conjectures and leaving certainty. We have revealed its obscurity, facilitated its demand, and sufficed its owner the defamation of the ignorant, the jugglery of the deceivers, and the confusion of the imaginers. To God belongs thanks, Creator of the first and the last. Let us conclude our book with what we began it with, so we say: Praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds, and may God bless Muhammad, the seal of His prophets and messengers, and grant much peace. The book *The Approximation of the Definition of Logic* by the unique, brilliant Imam Abu Muhammad Ali bin Ahmed bin Saeed Ibn Hazm bin Ghalib bin Salih Ibn Khalaf bin Ma'dan bin Zayd, may God's pleasure be upon him, is completed.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: Comments: Line 8 / Page 38: God's Beautiful Names: Ibn Hazm held a long chapter in *Al-Fisal* (2: 120 and following) to explain this issue and discussed applying each attribute individually. The summary of his opinion is that God is not named except by what He named Himself, following the Text, without ever deviating from that. He said: Among what the people of Islam introduced in the names of God Almighty is "Al-Qadim" (The Old/Eternal). This is not permissible at all because no text authenticated it at all, and it is not permissible to name God Almighty with what He did not name Himself. God Almighty said: {And the moon We have determined for it phases, until it returned [appearing] like the old date-stalk.} So it is correct that "Old" (Qadim) is of the attributes of creatures, so it is not permissible to name God Almighty with that. "Al-Qadim" is only known in the language from temporal priority, meaning this thing is older (aqdam) than this by a limited duration. This is negated from God Almighty. God Almighty has sufficed against this naming with the word "First" (Awwal). (2: 151 - 152). 15 - 43: Abu al-Abbas al-Nashi': He is Abdullah bin Muhammad al-Anbari known as Ibn Shirshir, died in the year 293 (906). He was a poet with interest in Logic. Ibn Taghri Bardi said: He has compositions in which he refuted poets and logicians, and he has a book "Preference of Poetry" and an Urjuza poem on sciences in four thousand verses (See his biography in *Tarikh Baghdad*: 10 - 92, *Shadharat al-Dhahab* 2: 214, and *Al-Nujum al-Zahirah*: 158). 16 - 64: And the Void is false: Ibn Hazm spoke about this subject with some detail in *Al-Fisal* 1: 25 - 27, then he said: 32 And among what invalidates the Void which they called...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...absolute place, and mentioned that it is infinite and that it is a place with no situated object in it, is a necessary demonstration from which there is no escape. The strangest thing is that it is their proof by which they deceived and rioted in presenting, wanting to prove the Void. Which is: That we see Earth, Water, and earthen bodies like rocks and mercury, and similar things whose nature is 'Down' (Descent) always and seeking the Center and Middle, and that they do not leave this nature to ascend except by a force overcoming them and entering upon them—like our lifting water and stone by force. If we lift them, they rise; if we leave them, they return to their nature by sinking. We find Fire and Air, their nature is Ascent and distance from the Center and Middle. They do not leave this nature except by a forced movement entering upon them; that is seen visually like the blown skin (bellows) and the hollow vessel turned upside down in water. If that forced movement vanishes, they return to their nature. Then we find the vessel called 'Water Thief' (Clepsydra), [water] ascends in it and does not spill. We find the syringe (Zarraqah) lifts dirt, mercury, and water? And we find the cupping glass (Mahjamah) sucks the earthen body to itself. (In Al-Taqrib: Al-Mahsajah; perhaps the word Al-Mahjamah is the correct one). 11 - 72: See his epistle in *Mudarat al-Nufus*: 145 where he speaks about virtues in a Platonic manner. 8 - 80: And the error of those who thought... that the Name is the Named became clear: This is the title of a chapter in the book *Al-Fisal* "Discourse on the Name and the Named" 5: 27. Abu Muhammad said: A group went to [the view] that the Name is the Named, and others said the Name is other than the Named. Those who said the Name is the Named argued with the saying of God Almighty: {Blessed is the name of your Lord, Owner of Majesty and Honor}, and it is also read {Owner} (Dhu) [referring to the Lord, not Name]. He said: It is not permissible to say 'Blessed is other than God'; if the Name were other than the Named, it would not be permissible to say 'Blessed is the name of your Lord'. And by His saying Almighty: {Glorify the name of your Lord, the Most High}, etc. 5 - 104: *Al-Muqtadab* by Al-Mubarrad: A book on Grammar. There is a single copy of it in Koprulu (No: 1507 - 8) in four volumes, corrected by Al-Sirafi. Among the narrators of the book is Ibn al-Rawandi the Atheist. People neglected this book until it was said that the bad omen of Ibn al-Rawandi...

text: ...entered it (The scholar Dr. Hellmut Ritter informed me of all this, and he mentioned this book in an article of his in the journal *Oriens*, Vol 6, p: 67). 21 - 141: Lying of one who claimed a known number for the duration of the world: Ibn Hazm addressed this subject in *Al-Fisal* 2: 105. He said: As for people's difference regarding Date (History), the Jews say the world is four thousand and some years old; the Christians say the world is five thousand years old. As for us, we do not decide on a known number with us. Whoever claimed regarding that seven thousand years or more or less has lied, and said what never came from the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, in a valid wording; rather, the contrary was authenticated from him, peace be upon him. 7 - 160: Ibn Hazm refers to a debate that took place between Mani and the Mobadh regarding the issue of cutting off progeny and hastening the emptying of the world. The Mobadh said: Are you the one who says marriage is forbidden to hasten the annihilation of the world and the return of every form to its form, and that is a necessary truth? Mani said to him: It is necessary to aid the Light in its liberation by cutting off progeny from the mixture it is in. Adurbadh said to him: Then of the necessary truth is to hasten this liberation for you which you call for, and to aid in invalidating this blameworthy mixture. Mani was silenced, so Bahram ordered Mani to be killed. (*Al-Fisal* 1: 36). 11 - 160: Muhammad bin Jarir al-Tabari and all Ash'aris—except Al-Simnani—went to [the view] that no one is a Muslim unless he infers (uses reasoning), otherwise he is not a Muslim. Al-Tabari said: Whoever reaches puberty (dreaming) or grows hair among men and women, or reaches menstruation among women, and does not know God Almighty with all His names and attributes by the way of Inference, is a disbeliever whose blood and wealth are lawful. He said: If the boy or girl reaches seven years, it is obligatory to teach them and train them in Inference for that (*Al-Fisal* 4: 35). 14 - 17: 180: Review *Rasail Ibn Hazm*: 144; there he spoke about the definition of Reason. He said: "As for mastering the matter of the world, courting people with what agrees with them and improves the state of the courter—of falsehood and other things, or vice or otherwise—and trickery in growing...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...money, fame, and promoting status by all possible disobedience and vice, is not Reason; rather, this character is called Cunning (Daha')." This saying agrees with what came in page 181 of this book. 8 - 81: *Kitab al-Siyasah* (Book of Politics): Perhaps it is the one mentioned in sources as "The Book of Imamate and Politics in the section of Biographies of Caliphs, their ranks, and encouraging the obligatory parts of it." (*Al-Dhakhira* 1 - 1: 143). 20 - 187: Sacrificing the self: Ibn Hazm repeated this opinion of his in his epistle "Mudawat al-Nufus" (*Rasail Ibn Hazm*: 118). He said: Do not sacrifice yourself except in what is higher than it. That is only in the Essence of God Almighty, in calling to truth, in protecting the sanctuary (women/honor), in repelling humiliation not obligated upon you by your Creator Almighty, and in helping the oppressed. The sacrificer of himself for worldly goods is like the seller of rubies for pebbles. He said: The rational person sees no price for himself except Paradise. 15 - 192: Ahmed bin Muhammad bin Abdul Warith Abu Omar, known as Ibn Akhi al-Zahid (Nephew of the Ascetic), is Ibn Hazm's tutor in Grammar (See *Al-Takmila*: 790 and *Al-Jadhwah*: 99). 13 - 197: *Al-Luma'* by Abu al-Faraj the Judge: It is the book *Al-Luma'* in Principles of Jurisprudence by Abu al-Faraj al-Maliki Omar bin Muhammad, who died in the year 331 AH (See *Al-Fihrist*: 283 Egypt Ed.). 23 - 197: Classes of people in their speech: Ibn Hazm presented this idea briefly in his epistle "Mudawat al-Nufus": 147 of *Rasail Ibn Hazm*. 2 - 199: Abu al-Qasim al-Zajjaji and the book *Al-Jumal*: Abdul Rahman bin Ishaq al-Zajjaji died in the year 340 in Tiberias. His method in Grammar was intermediate, and his compositions intend benefit (See his biography in *Inbah al-Ruwat* No: 376; in the footnote is a list of references). As for the book *Al-Jumal*, there are many copies of it today. Multiple commentaries have been written on it as well. The Andalusians cared for it; they explained it and explained its verses. Among that is the commentary on verses by Al-Shantamari. Al-Batalyawsi composed a book on it he named "The Robes in Correcting the Defect Occurring in the Book of Al-Jumal." Ibn Kharuf has a commentary on it, and Ibn Hariq has a commentary on its verses. Likewise Ibn Asfour and Ahmed bin Yusuf al-Fihri al-Labli have a commentary on its verses "Washy al-Hulal fi...

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: ...Sharh Abyat al-Jumal" (See Brockelmann's History, Supplement 1: 171). 23 - 199: Al-Mustakfi and Al-Mustazhir: Al-Mustazhir, who is Abdul Rahman bin Hisham bin Abdul Jabbar, was pledged allegiance in Ramadan of the year 414 AH. He appointed Ibn Hazm and Ibn Shahid as ministers. Then Muhammad bin Abdul Rahman al-Nasiri revolted against him in the month of Dhu al-Qi'dah of the same year and killed him. He was pledged allegiance as Caliph and nicknamed Al-Mustakfi. He was backward and weak. He imprisoned Ibn Hazm and his cousin Abu al-Mughira. He stayed in the Caliphate for sixteen months. After that, the command of Cordoba returned to Banu Hammud, and Al-Mustakfi fled to the frontier region and died in his exile. 5 - 201: Dispelling Worry: Ibn Hazm treated this idea extensively in his epistle on Ethics (See *Rasail Ibn Hazm*: 116 and following, also the Introduction to the Epistles). 7 - 201: What Ibn Hazm said about sciences here, he explained extensively in an epistle of his titled "Maratib al-Ulum" (Ranks of Sciences); see *Rasail Ibn Hazm* 59 - 90. 2 - 204: Abu Amir Ahmed bin Abdul Malik bin Shahid (382 - 426), foster child of the Amirid state. The demise of Amirid glory in Cordoba affected him, but he did not emigrate from his country as Ibn Darraj or his friend Ibn Hazm did. He participated in political life when Al-Mustazhir came with Ibn Hazm, then praised Banu Hammud who overcame Cordoba. He was afflicted in his last days with paralysis that crippled him. He was extravagant in his generosity, intense in self-pride, leaning to humor and jest, admiring his poetry, mocking the sons of his people especially the class of tutors. He became famous among the Easterners for the epistle *Al-Tawabi' wa al-Zawabi'*. As for his book on Eloquence which Ibn Hazm mentions, Ibn Bassam cited some paragraphs from it in *Al-Dhakhira*. (See his biography in *Al-Dhakhira* 1/1: 61, *Al-Jadhwah*: 124, *Al-Mughrib* 1: 78, *Al-Matmah*: 16, *Al-Kharidah* 12: 201, *Al-Yatimah* 1: 382, and *I'tab al-Kuttab*: 74; I have written a detailed study on him in my book "History of Andalusian Literature" - under print -). 4 - 204: Qudama bin Ja'far: Meaning his book "Jewels of Words" (Jawahir al-Alfaz) - most likely - for it is specific to Eloquence.

book_title: The Approximation of the Definition of Logic and Introduction to it with Common Expressions and Jurisprudential Examples
text: 5 - 205: Ibn Darraj: He is Ahmed bin Muhammad bin Darraj al-Qastalli Abu Omar (347 - 421). He was a scribe among the scribes of composition (Insha') in the days of Al-Mansur Ibn Abi Amir, and the greatest praiser of the Amirid state. When the command of that state ended in Cordoba, Ibn Darraj began moving around the cities of Andalusia praising its princes until he settled down with the ruler of Zaragoza, Mundhir bin Yahya, and lived in his care until he died. The critics of Andalusia advanced him and testified to his merit. Ibn Hazm said of him: "If I said there was no one in Andalusia more poetic than Ibn Darraj, I would not be far [from truth]." Muhammad bin Ibrahim al-Qaysi al-Washqi collected his Diwan alphabetically in the year 467, but it did not reach us. (See his biography in *Al-Dhakhira* 1/1: [page missing], *Al-Jadhwah*: 102, *Al-Silah*: 44, *Ibn Khallikan* 1: 60, *Al-Mughrib* 2: 60, *Al-Yatimah* 1: 438, and *Al-Nafh* 2: 782; I have written about him extensively and sufficiently in my book "History of Andalusian Literature" - under print -).
